texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In addition, we have also enjoyed good market acceptance and higher orders for next-generation singulation and  trim and form systems and significant order growth for solar plating systems from the largest Asian producers and  research institutes. Strength from these new products has brought more balance to Besi's portfolio in this  downturn while we await the introduction of new smartphones and other electronic devices next year and until  underlying semiconductor demands better matches production capacity levels.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As mentioned earlier, many of our recent R&D investments have yielded good results, particularly in our TCB, die  sorting, trim and form, singulation and solar plating products. In particular, our TCB business continues to  expand with an approximate U.S.$7 million order for eight systems announced this quarter from an existing  customer. High gross margins and low warranty expenses also indicate that our equipment is performing well in  the field, very important factors for our long-term success.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: Besi is also seeking additional opportunities in the solar and battery plating markets after last year's success and  to incorporate ever-greater commonality in the parts and modules used in our platforms.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, we laid the groundwork for additional cost savings in 2010 and ‘11, per means of our  December head count reduction plan announcement, targeting €8.5 million of annualized cost  savings and a realignment of our packaging systems business to improve our portfolio returns.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We now see customers more than ever focused on expanding their wafer level capabilities to  achieve higher density, miniaturization and performance levels, than presently available in array  connect assembly processes and with a greater focus on low energy consumption.

file: BESI - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 24February2011 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: These end-user applications require ever-higher levels of miniaturization, chip density, and performance at lower  energy consumption, which can only be provided through advanced assembly process equipment. One of our  best-positioned products for the growth in the smartphone and tablet market, the Esec 2100 die bonder has  enjoyed tremendous success and reached a milestone of over 400 systems sold since its introduction two years  ago, our most successful product launch ever.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: Also, our soft solar die bonding system, which was introduced in the late 2009 and has many applications in the  automotive electronic market also enjoyed great success. In addition, we saw nice revenue contributions this year  from new products we introduced, including foil-assisted molding systems, the new die sorting platform, and our  new singulation system, which shares a common platform with our trim & form systems.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: We realized cost reduction benefits from a variety of actions including the realignment of our packaging and wire  bonding units and €7 million of cost savings from our December 2009 head count reduction plan. We also  reduced costs from the final transfer of all our tooling from the Netherlands to China and Malaysia.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: Much is scheduled in 2011 to advance our Asian production transfer. We plan to ramp manufacturing of Esec  2100 die bond in Malaysia to approximately 20 systems per month by the end of the year from current five system  per month levels. We will also prepare the successful Esec solar system for Asian production in 2012. To handle  increased capacity requirements, we plan to put additional 70,000 square feet near our Malaysian operations,  expanding our footprint there about 60%. In addition, we plan to double our Chinese tooling and module capacity  from a total of 60,000 square feet. We also intend to drive further organizational efficiencies through a decrease of  our European-based cost. In light of our ongoing Asian tradition, we will take measures to further reduce our  European overhead and supply chain costs including our footprints in certain areas.

file: BESI - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: As you have seen, we have phased out older generation packaging and wire bonding systems in favor of  promoting higher growth, higher margin die attach and packaging systems for advanced packaging applications.  Thanks to such portfolio changes and our ability to more easily scale our business, our gross margins are holding  up better than in prior downturns. This year we received increased orders for advanced packaging systems from  leading smartphone and tablet supply chain vendors. Such customers demand ever higher levels of  miniaturization, chip density and performance at lower energy consumption levels.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: Towards this end, we're slightly ahead of schedule with our head count reduction plan to generate €8.5 million  cost savings per annum by the end of 2012. In addition, we have focused on inventory reduction given the  uncertain industry outlook and we're pleased that they declined by €15 million this past quarter.

file: BESI - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5March2013 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-13.pdf
BESI - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 27February2014 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, BE Semiconductor Industries NV
texts.text: Industry analysts and customers anticipate increasing spending this year from the shrinking of next-generation  device geometries and power consumption requirements and increased chip density and functionality. However,  the key variable influencing our business prospects in the next couple of years is the adoption rate by customers  of flip chip and wafer level assembly processes to address below 20-nanometer geometries.

file: BESI - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 26February2015 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-15.pdf
BESI - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 25February2016 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Other areas of product strength included next generation singulation and trim and form systems and plating  systems for solar and 3D lithium battery applications. Strong profits and margin levels were realized due to the  successful execution of ongoing Asian supply chain and production initiatives, a further reduction of European  based cost and timely restructuring actions taken during the year in response to both adverse industry and  currency movements.

texts.speaker: Cor te Hennepe
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Finance & Legal
texts.text: Thank you, Richard. Besi's Q4 2015 revenue was up by 7.9% versus Q3 2015 and was at the high-end of our  guidance range. The increase was primarily due to higher demand for epoxy die attach and die sorting systems for  smart phone and high end server applications and increased plating shipments for solar applications. Revenue  declined by 12.6% versus Q4 2014 primarily as a result of lower demand for smart phone and mainstream  electronics applications post the [ph] large (7:41) 2014 industry capacity build.

texts.speaker: Richard W. Blickman
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, we received important orders from leading solar producers and Asian Research Institutes in the second  half of the year for new developed solar plating lines, as well as an initial order in the fourth quarter for a new 3D  lithium iron battery platting line.

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: Looking at the underwriting and claims side and talk about three lines of business, our excellent  slide about trees and saplings which you’ll remember of course from the year end, three lines of  business we touched on those environmental risks, M&A transaction insurance, and opening an  Oslo office to attract energy business in Norway that doesn’t come directly to Lloyd’s all up and  running and writing business in the first half of 2010.

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: First thing to say is, please relax that’s a little wave of the tsunami. Now a lot of you cover a lot of  other insurance companies. A little bit about where it comes  from absolute performance, relative performance and then some of the opportunities which we’re  still managing to look at and invest in this year.

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: So to quickly go on what’s in the account, standard marine account in our mind, and that is made  up of hull, energy, cargo, liability and war. Energy 35% that is for us an EMP book really upstream and  that is concentrating getting the hydrocarbons out of the ground, we don’t really compete in the  onshore downstream book because we don’t believe there’s sufficient rate there to make a profit.

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: When you look at the marine casualty, I liken it to a dying zebra on the Serengeti; very quickly the  hyenas are there on the pick over the bones, be it salvors, adjusters, and lawyers. So rule one for       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: What else are we doing other than what’s happening in the market at the moment? We have two  basic mantras; one, we never feel we can walk on water, our past results are our past results, we  have to concentrate on getting this year right. Secondly, whatever the market is, there is always  opportunities. So the mantra is the market is always good. So what are the things that we are doing  at the moment?

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: We started an office in Oslo to write some Energy business, we had a lovely Norwegian lady broker  working in the market who wanted to go back to Norway. She is now set up in Norway to write  some Energy business for us, we set her a fairly ambitious budget, she has already written 80% of  it in three months. So from our point of view, that was a good decision.

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: Finally, what’s happening in the market? Obviously most of our businesses are quiet, a little bit  though, but the one area that’s interesting obviously is the Energy market and that all comes  flowing from the Deepwater loss. As you know, we have told you what our loss from that is which is  six million net. That does not change. We have exposure to two of the joint ventures of the well  itself, and of the owners of the drilling rig. Those figures won’t change. But, from that, the market  rating has started to change.

texts.speaker: Andrew Horton, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Welcome everybody to our interim results, for our six-month results through the 30th of June, 2010.
texts.text: And I think maybe Martin mentioned that we hold as you are aware our catastrophe reserves until  premiums have earned out and 2010 was a good example of why we do that. There’s sort of a  feeling in the market that catastrophes only tend to happen in the second half of the year because  they tend to be hurricane related and of course with the Chilean loss in the first half of the year, we  had a catastrophe in the first half and that is one of the reasons we hold our reserves until the  premiums have substantially earned, and we could allocate some of that reserve we are holding  end of ‘09 to the Chilean loss. Rating environment is down a bit, but we’ll see on the chart in a  second this is still a well rated business line.

file: BEZL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 22July2011 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Just touching on the losses, it's been an unusual first half. We've totaled up, we think between $75 billion and $85  billion of losses, which includes Australian floods, New Zealand earthquake, the Japanese earthquake and then  the tornado losses in the U.S. And the tornado losses themselves are greater than each of the individual hurricanes  that happened in the U.S. in 2004, so large losses.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The other bullet points picking up on fidelity and crime insurance, it's something we started a year or two ago. We  continue to grow that. The environmental risks, I think, we announced last year and we continue to add to that by  having an underwriter over in London, originally we opened up in Philadelphia in the U.S. And to the data breach  response obviously is a network security losing data or lots of data of individuals and having to manage that, that  continues to grow with this environment. There is some high profile cases in the first six months, people seeing  the value in having that product.

texts.speaker: Martin Lindsay Bride
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, in this half year, we have had significant catastrophe events affecting all three of those classes and therefore on  particularly the 2009 and 2010 underwriting years, where we would have been holding some catastrophe margins  on those classes, we've released those. So particularly on the property and political risks side, compared to the  level of reserve release, you would typically see in a half year period in the first half, reserve releases are above  average as they are being released to mitigate the catastrophes of those classes business have seen this half.

texts.speaker: Adrian Lewers
texts.profession: Head-Political Risks & Contingency, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So within Political Risk and Contingency, there are three business units, the first is the political risk and trade  credit unit. The insurance that we offer here is to traders, investors, contractors who have exposures in overseas  jurisdictions. Typical clients here might be commodity traders, trade finance banks, or foreign direct investors.  And as far as our portfolio is concerned, we focus on oil and gas, mining energy. And then from an investment  perspective, a number of our clients are in the chemicals and the oil services industry.

texts.speaker: Adrian Lewers
texts.profession: Head-Political Risks & Contingency, Beazley Plc
texts.text: And then we have a growing weather portfolio, which covers a range of different products, but principally relating  to pre-agreed level of rain, snow, sunshine, et cetera. And the underwriting of that portfolio in particular is  supported by a very extensive weather database that we have in-house.

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: The other one is losses come through whether they're from natural catastrophes, other areas, other risk losses or  under reserving losses actually come through. So losses are borne, more companies going to loss, capital is  destroyed to some extent and we see a wider growth in the rating environment. And that's why, as Martin  mentioned, we increased our letter of credit facility, so we're actually ready for that opportunity if it comes.

file: BEZL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 23July2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: The aviation business is progressing well. We acquired an excellent team of aviation underwriters towards the end  of last year. The leader joined us into the first quarter this year and that is progressing exactly as planned. Just  touching on the European floods, because there have been one or two announcements on the European floods. We  expect the European flood losses to be absorbed within our loss ratios we set up for catastrophe business. Most of  the loss is going to fall within the reinsurance team and the maximum loss to us will be a $30 million retention for  a loss of that type. And it is no surprise to you that the challenging investment markets in the second quarter, but  overall we now have a run yield on the portfolio of 2% per annum, so everything else being equal, we should earn  1% in the second half.

texts.speaker: Martin Lindsay Bride
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Reserving is a key part of Beazley's performance. We have a practice of reserving conservatively across our  portfolio of the claims and therefore, on average, you should expect to see reserve releases coming out of the  Beazley portfolio. And the first half of 2013 is very much in line with the long-term trend at Beazley. It's actually  an improvement on 2012. Those of you who were here last year will remember we signaled this time last year that  reserve releases had been below average and that was really related to those classes of business that had been  impacted by the 2010 and 2011 natural catastrophe events. So the reserve release for this half year is a return to  what we would consider normal levels of reserve releases, up on last year but very much in line with the longer- term trend.

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Mark talked about the pink line, which is property, the pale blue line, which is marine coming down because of the  energy market. Generally the energy business, our energy business has had a great run over the past few years and  we are seeing rating pressure on offshore risks in energy. The life accident health hasn't moved at all since we  acquired it in 2009. It has the flattish, the most consistent rating of any of the divisions. And the bottom line  which is political risk continues – and terrorism continues to edge down, because there's been very little claims  activity in the terrorism world. So it tends to be driven down by the terrorism rates. But overall, the portfolio is  holding up pretty well.

file: BEZL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 22July2014 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Lindsay Bride
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, overall on the KPIs, the finance KPIs, just a couple of things I really wanted to highlight. GWP growth is  slowing down a bit. But you can see a healthy NEP growth, net earned premium growth. So, that's the benefit  where you have flowing through of the activities over the last year or two to continue to grow the top line still  flowing through net earned premium. So, a slightly larger business this half than the same half last year, and that  is always very encouraging.

texts.speaker: Adrian Peter Cox
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Specialty Lines, Beazley Plc
texts.text: What that caused to happen was that a lot of people were leaving those companies and joining other insurance  companies and starting new teams, particularly in specialty lines. So we saw a lot of new capacity in D&O. We saw  a lot of new capacity in healthcare, environmental E&O and basically across our product set. So we had a marked  increase in supply of insurance in specialty lines combined with a lack of paid claims, and that caused the  downward spike you see there.

texts.speaker: Adrian Peter Cox
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Specialty Lines, Beazley Plc
texts.text: But there is growth. And where there's growth, there's opportunity. What are we going to continue to do? Exactly  what we have been doing, investing where we think the pie is growing and where we think we have expertise and a  competitive advantage. Cyber liability still has only got about 25% to 30% penetration across most brokers.  There's business to grow there. A lot of the businesses that we've invested in the last few years are beginning to  gain critical mass now, environmental, miscellaneous medical and so on and so forth, all areas we think which  play to our strengths.

texts.speaker: Adrian Peter Cox
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Specialty Lines, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, we've been really focusing our fire power. We only have 100 – by the end of 2015, we'll only have 115  underwriters in the U.S. We're not an AIG or a Chubb or Travelers. So, we really have to focus our fire power. So,  we've started this year what we call the six-by-nine initiative. The good news is, as Andrew said, we grew 14% in  the U.S. this year, but we're up 35% with those nine brokers. So that strategy really is paying benefits. And as we  move forward, we will be getting, I hope, better and better in how we organize ourselves and our brokers.

texts.speaker: Adrian Peter Cox
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Specialty Lines, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, these are the offices that we have. You can see that we have 11. By the end of 2015, we should have grown our  underwriting force by over 35% and really concentrating on the areas in green there. We'll not go into too much  detail on this, but you can see that we're focusing our underwriters, so that we really build out our presence in  those hubs where we're averaging 15 underwriters per office by the end of 2015 and a broad spectrum of products.  And [ph] I'm not sure (28:05) that's what we're trying to do onshore in the U.S.

file: BEZL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 24July2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mike Donovan
texts.profession: Global Focus Group Leader-Technology, Media and Business Services, Beazley Plc
texts.text: I'll also mention that a lot of the press and government concern has been around infrastructure risk, attacks on  the power grid, things of that nature. Our insurance does not deal with that. We're simply – we're dealing with the  risk to consumers or for financial loss essentially associated with loss of data. So, our insurance is not focused on  any of those infrastructure risk at all.

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, the outlook. One of the roles of the CEO, I feel, is to be the most repetitive person within the company. Many  of my colleagues are nodding in the audience at this point in time. And one of the things that, I think, I've been  repetitive on for several years is the returns. It should be expected to reduce. So with a low-claimed environment  and with rates under pressure across many lines, the underwriting margin should reduce.

file: BEZL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 22July2016 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: A bit of stress I think in the insurance at this point in time, which means we have the opportunities as some  companies withdraw from lines of business to pickup underwriters. One or two have gone through M&A over the  past two years or three years and again, we better pickup underwriters. We've highlighted a few here. The UK  and international Med Mal Group that joined us from Marketform earlier in this year, which was good; fine art,  specie here in London, and expanding the environmental team as one or two carriers have withdrawn from  environmental in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Clive Andrew Washbourn
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Marine, Beazley Ireland Holdings Plc
texts.text: Why do we feel positive? Well, the income is not only been hit by the fact of rate reduction, but the industries we  insure have been struggling. The shipping industry, property buyer, tankers, the freight market, the ships are  losing money. So that's always difficult with dropping values and dropping maintenance to continue to make a  good profit. And the oil and gas industry is absolutely driven by oil price, less than $50, all the construction  offshore development start, half of the drilling rigs that are out looking for a laid off, all the supply boats and all the  other offshore support vessels, all struggling. So, that all has an effect on values and on premium, and on our  ability to grow.

texts.speaker: Clive Andrew Washbourn
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Marine, Beazley Ireland Holdings Plc
texts.text: But within one year to three years, both the oil and gas business and the shipping business will begin to come  back into a growth area and hopefully profitable. Like all side, supply and demand sectors are trying to predict  exactly when they pick up is really difficult, but we know it will. So we just have to stick to what we know. We have  a very high retention rate at the moment, the [indiscernible] (15:05) we've had in five years, and that is because  as we've constructed our portfolio, we believe to be and identifies our core clients, we're holding onto the guys  that are going to see us through this difficult marketplace.

file: BEZL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 21July2017 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: What are we actually doing from the business point of view? We announced back in February that we'd acquired  Creechurch in Canada and created Beazley Canada. We had no presence in Canada up until acquiring  Creechurch who's an MGA we have been supporting for almost 20 years. We knew the business really well and it  writes a lot of specialty lines business and a bit of property, sort of writes business lines we like, and we can now  build on that group of people and add to it. And we've announced we're going to add an environmental  underwriter to our Canadian operation who arrives shortly.

texts.speaker: Andrew Pryde
texts.profession: Chief Risk Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, on to the design of the risk management framework, it is an intuitive cycle, which starts with identifying and  assessing risk. We then set risk appetite for each risk category, which we express as the amount of risk that the  board is willing to take at a 1 in 10 likelihood. Of course, we do monitor risk at other durations such as setting the  natural catastrophe risk budget, the 1 in 250 points of the distribution to monitor tail risk.

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: And I'd just like to touch on Martin's point again on the special dividend front because that always seems to come  up at this point in time. Our view of special dividends is we are going to be consistent with capital management.  We assess it when we get through the windstorm season and have our defined plan set for 2018 with the  absolute capital. Martin gave an indication of where we think the capital will be at the end of this year for next  year's underwriting, but we don't know that until we've gone through the formal business plan process.

texts.text: And on the back of that, not surprisingly, we've seen property rates rise and you can see the rate increase in our  property division is 10% but within our open market property, which has been impacted more by the catastrophes  and, to some extent, the attritional claims, the rate increase in open market property is 20% year-on-year. And  those rate increases have driven the 3% rate increase across the total portfolio, which is probably slightly higher  than we thought it was going to be for 2018.

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director (Chair), Beazley Plc
texts.text: Good growth in specialty lines, obviously, seeing the rate increases in terms of property. Within specialty lines,  cyber, of course, is a key line of business for us with environmental, miscellaneous, medical and management  liability all growing in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Martin Lindsay Bride
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, on to reserve release picture. So, Beazley reserves prudently; continues to be the case, and so on average,  you should expect reserve releases to come because we believe the reserves we set up are greater than the  amounts we will pay out. So, compared to the very smooth picture that you've become used to over the last five  years, we do have in one of our divisions, reserves strengthening this half year. This will happen occasionally, but  when you reserve prudently, more often than not, you do get releases. So, $34 million of strengthening in the  property group. About two-thirds of that relates to increasing reserves for the cost of the natural catastrophe  claims last year. And then about a third of it from strengthening reserves for other claims on – for 2017 in  particular [ph] underwriting year (00:10:56) in property group was the most notable area.

texts.speaker: Ian Fantozzi
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: And finally, as I talk about staff productivity, we need to have the working environment to make the best of this  technology. So we've been turning our environment or we plan to turn our environment into something called  activity-based working solutions, which is where we map all the activities that go on in each office and then tailor  the physical environment to those.

texts.speaker: Martin Lindsay Bride
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Turning now to reserve releases, a very strong year of reserve releases for Beazley. It's certainly the highest as a  percentage of net earned premiums that we've seen for five years or six years. And the principal driver of that is  the level of release from the short tail classes of business that have catastrophe exposure. We have, in very recent  times, had relatively good catastrophe experience following a period, obviously, where there were significant  catastrophes. And you're seeing that come out in particularly the blue and the pink at the top of the stack and, to  some extent, the white block which is the marine block, including the energy account below t hat, so that's very  encouraging.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: We also benefited in 2013 from favorable claims experience. That was driven significantly by lower than average  natural disasters. The largest natural catastrophe of 2013 that the market experienced was the European floods.  And although those were significant by local market standards, they were by no means at the same order of  magnitude as the losses that occurred in 2011 or even Superstorm Sandy in 2012.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: The claims ratio improved from 53% to 45%, with that lower than average instance of natural disasters. And you  can see at the bottom of the page there, rating moderated from plus 3% in 2012 to plus 1% in 2013.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Marine, which is the lighter blue line in the middle of the chart, reduced rates overall by 5%, with most of that  pricing pressure coming from the marine-energy account, and also the marine-war accounts. It's worth pointing  out though that within the marine business, there were areas of positive pricing, in particular, the liabilities  business where rates continued to strengthen, following the losses in 2012, including the Costa Concordia cruise  ship disaster. And against that picture of increased rating strength, we have more than doubled our writings,  operating liability business to $25 million.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer
texts.text: So in 2015, we plan to write less property catastrophe reinsurance, less energy insurance, and overall we will  deploy a smaller natural catastrophe risk budget.

texts.text: The third area of opportunity is what I would describe as the green shoots in our business. These are  products such as environmental pollution liability and transaction liability, which is the insurance of reps and  warranties in M&A.

texts.speaker: David Andrew Horton

texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Now, we've also benefited from a relatively benign claims environment, once again, and in particular, the natural  catastrophes that we saw in 2016 were below the level, for which we budget. The largest event of the year was  Hurricane Matthew, which I think is a market loss in the $5 billion range, which for an industry that's preparing  itself one day for a hurricane affecting Miami, that's going to cost $250 billion, is relatively slight, and they were  relatively insignificant events as well for Beazley. And as Martin has just covered, the reserves for prior liabilities  continue to develop positively, and our consistent approach to the reserving process has maintained that surplus  over our actuarial in the target range of 5% to 10%.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: And at the bottom of this chart, we can see pricing, as I've mentioned, minus 2%. That was led by the large risk  short tail catastrophe exposed lines of business. And if I was going to pull one out, I guess I would identify energy,  where weak oil price below $60 leads to weak demand for insurance, and we saw prices fall by further 13% in the  energy insurance market in 2016.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So, in the 2017 plan, we plan to continue to reduce the volume of large risk short tail exposed lines business,  such as energy and large risk property, and we will be focused on protecting our margin in those businesses.  Alongside that, we will continue the trend of recent years and reduce our catastrophe risk appetite in 2017.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Secondary opportunity is onshore in the U.S. We continue to benefit from this more focused distribution strategy  that we've talked about previously, and also putting more underwriters, more product throughout our footprint,  getting decision makers closer to the customer. In addition to that, in 2016, we've benefited somewhat from some  market desiccation, for example, in the environmental sector, where the leading competitor actually withdrew from  the market. We expect those opportunities also to continue to drive some growth in 2017.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So in the next slide, we talk about what is going to happen next. This reserve margin, the margin in our reserves  on the balance sheet is a lead indicator of the future. There's one or two mechanical technical things related to the catastrophes that contribute to that position, but it is  at the lower end of our range. So as far as reserve releases going forward are concerned, there may be a slight  reduction in 2018, but our forward-looking guidance as to what you should expect reserve release wise from  Beazley is the same picture that you've seen in the past.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Martin, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. And so, in the next part of the presentation, I'm just  going to look at our underwriting performance and that remains the key to the results that we're announcing today.  So if I start with the highlights from 2017, it was a year dominated by a high incidence of natural disasters. We're  pleased therefore to be able to report an underwriting profit combined ratio of 99% that compares to prior of 89%  and our average combined ratio, which is 90%. So in achieving this positive outcome, I think there are two things  to point out. One is our balanced business model, specialty lines, which is 50% of our business with the exception  of one or two notifications in our environmental team with those exceptions specialty lines is largely unaffected by  these catastrophe events.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Second thing to point out is our active cycle management, so in 2013 our catastrophe risk budget was $575  million in 2017 that have reduced to $370 million. And one area of our business in particular benefited from that  active cycle management was our reinsurance division which despite the fact, it was one-off if not, the most costly  year on record for natural disasters achieved a breakeven outcome.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: So if I turn to claims, the year as I say was dominated by the cats, the hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria. In total  those are expected to cost the industry $100 billion as well as the California brushfires. And we continue to  anticipate that our losses net of reinsurance will fall within a range of $200 million to $300 million as we reported  in November. So no change in our overall loss estimates or generally on the claims side as Martin has just said,  we were pleased that the reserves for prior liabilities continue to develop positively and our consistent approach to  reserving means that we have finished the year with the reserve over actuarial within our target range of 5% to  10%, albeit right on the low boundary of that range despite the effects of catastrophes.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Claims ratio up 10 points to 58%, all of that increase was driven by the catastrophes. Pricing there at the bottom,  you can see that minus 1% continued to fall although it moderated from the minus 2% we gave our the year  before.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Balancing all of that, our two largest divisions, specialty lines and property actually had flat trading conditions  through 2017 and the latter experienced some [ph] post (00:18:13) event rate increases in the fourth quarter  following the natural disasters.

texts.speaker: Neil Patrick Maidment
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: Against the background of low-single digit growth in the real economies of the developed world in recent years,  we've been targeting growth of 5% to 10%. The 2018 business plan is targeting growth right at the top end of that  range. Quarter the plan is continuation of what we've been working on in 2017. So it's further growth in specialty  lines, driven by three things. We see continued opportunity for growth onshore in the U.S. The combination of a  more focused distribution strategy and the initiative to put more of our product through our office footprint  continues to drive opportunity across the product range and specialty lines. But if I was going to point to two  things, we see particularly strong opportunities in healthcare and environmental.

texts.text: This is a slide familiar to most of us. I think my predecessor believed and I certainly concur with him that this does  show nicely the benefits of a well-diversified portfolio. A  couple of things worth noting, I think property, the green – not the green, the pink line at the top there, is as high  as it's been in the last decade, which is interesting and also interesting is the bottom blue line there, even marine  has turned positive, which doesn't happen very often.

texts.speaker: Adrian Peter Cox
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Underwriting Officer, Beazley Plc
texts.text: As I said, we'll be reporting both divisions separately from H1 this year. You can see from those stats that CyEx or  cyber & executive risk is between 35% and 40% of the old total. We should also expect it to have a slightly different reserve release strategy in specialty lines  [indiscernible] (00:21:41) did because it's shorter tail. It also has aggregation risk or catastrophe risk. So its  reserve releases, if there are any, are more [indiscernible] (00:21:51) shorter tail business with those sorts of  exposure. We have plans to grow both of those in 2019. If anything the plans for specialty lines new are slightly  more growth than CyEx new because some of the real engines of U.S. growth are environmental and  miscellaneous medical, for example, they've been growing quite strongly and the bulk of our international  business is within specialty lines.

texts.text: As far as the International Business, €34 million of pre-tax profit. This is actually down 38%. The story here is  twofold. texts.speaker: Gian Maria Mossa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, General Manager & Director, Banca Generali SpA
texts.text: The next page is about closing remarks, so page 24. And of course, we met last year to explain our ambition for  the next three years and the key pillars of the strategy. We went through all the dealers except for the first one.  There's sustainability, and at that time I said that we would present these topics during the first conference call.  So here we are.

texts.speaker: Gian Maria Mossa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, General Manager & Director, Banca Generali SpA
texts.text: So pages 25 and 26, you see what we mean by sustainability. First of all, this is a very, very important topic for  us, and as three main drivers. The first is that for us, sustainability is a cultural shift. So we change the vision of  the bank; so including the word sustainability, so our vision is to be number one in the private banking by value of  service, innovation and sustainability. And we set an important project, defining implementing and monitoring  sustainability KPIs within all the business functions of the bank. So first of all a commitment to be sustainable to  create long-term value for our stakeholders.

texts.speaker: Gian Maria Mossa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, General Manager & Director, Banca Generali SpA
texts.text: Second, from a governance perspective, we instituted the nomination, governance and sustainability committee  within the board, and made up by the independent board members, because both are responsible for setting  sustainability and governance guidance.

texts.speaker: Gian Maria Mossa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, General Manager & Director, Banca Generali SpA
texts.text: And third, probably even more important, we introduced a new commercial approach dedicated to sustainability  and we are the first player to provide this kind of service, is everything is digitalized. And if you look at page 26,  you see the three main steps. The first one is that we provide almost 160 funds with the buyers in the ESG trend.  And thanks to the partnership with different companies, we have introduced the concept of the sustainable  development goal representation.

texts.speaker: Gian Maria Mossa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, General Manager & Director, Banca Generali SpA
texts.text: So, for each fund, we give the contribution in terms of these goals. You can build a portfolio made up by only ESG  funds, giving a preference of one, two or more of the sustainable development goals. And then you can report to  the client probably the performance risk analysis as usual. You can provide a full reporting of the positive  contribution of each fund to the social development goal targets, and let's say, that is a way to see how clients can  provide a contribution to have a better word like this continue investing and performing because you know also  that [indiscernible] (00:30:46) that these kind of products in the long-term present also a sharp ratio better  [indiscernible] (00:30:55).

texts.speaker: Gian Maria Mossa
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, General Manager & Director, Banca Generali SpA
texts.text: So just to cut the long story short, we have a platform, a proprietary platform, fully digitalized for the trend and  given these preferences and May preferences in terms of social and sustainable development goals, we can build  up a solution, a portfolio with this fund and we can report the positive impact in terms of having a better word, and  these open the door to new clients more sensitive to these kind of topics.

texts.text: Our land and development portfolio is €3.6 billion. 90% of this portfolio is impaired and the coverage ratio was  60%.

file: BIRG - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 3March2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Richie Boucher
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bank of Ireland
texts.text: We achieved a net interest margin of more than 2% in the second half of 2013. Defaulted loans are now reducing;  they've have fallen by €1.2 billion since June, 2013, which is the first significant reduction in recent years. I regard  this as being very significant. The reduction is across all our major loan categories, and is a function of our actions  in support for customers who are in financial difficulty. It also reflects the improved economic climate in our main  markets and the recovery in the property markets.

texts.speaker: Andrew Keating
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bank of Ireland
texts.text: Our provisioning assumptions continue to accommodate a 55% peak-to-trough reduction in the house prices,  compared with 46% at December. On forbearance and restructuring, we are rolling out effective solutions, which  are working for our customers and the Group. Our customers are meeting the terms of those new arrangements,  and we are achieving all of our targets in this regard.

file: BIRG - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 27February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Richie Boucher
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In parallel, we've maintained tight control of our cost base while also continuing to invest in our people, our  businesses and our infrastructure. Our customer loan impairment charges are €1.1 billion lower than last year.  The reduction reflects the effectiveness of the actions we are taking, the improving ec onomic environment, and  rising collateral values. The reduction also reflects a €280 million provision reversal on our Republic of Ireland  mortgage book. Like I said earlier, in total, our underlying PBT was €920 million. I would note that this includes  additional gains of circa €500 million, and Andrew's going to give you more detail on those later.

texts.speaker: Richie Boucher
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our SME customers employed thousands of people all across Ireland. We have a strong position in the growing  agri sector and provided over 50% of agri lending, including approved funding for the purchase of over 24,000  acres of land by our farming customers.

texts.speaker: Andrew G. Keating
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to capital. During 2014, we increased our CET 1 transitional ratio by 250 basis points. At December, it  was 14.8%. It reflects our strong operating performance, reductions in risk-weighted assets consistent with the  balance sheet, together with dividends received from our life assurance subsidiary. Looking forward, we continue  to expect to maintain a buffer above a CET1 ratio of 10%, taking account of the transition rules and our intention  to de-recognize the preferred shares in 2016.

file: BIRG - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 22February2016 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew G. Keating
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I referred earlier to the additional gains of €237 million. These gains arise in the normal course of our business,  but they may not reoccur at the same level in future reporting periods. Excluding those gains, our sustainable  earnings have more than doubled in 2015 as compared with the previous year.

texts.profession: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As usually, we have structured the presentation in four different chapters. texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The positive development shows on all levels EBITDA, EBIT, and net profit. One of the driving factors behind this  was the increased generation from hydro power plants and we also do have a reinforced position as one of the  Swiss leaders for new renewable energy both in Switzerland, but mainly abroad we now have a stronger position,

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Mühleberg power plant which was again into focus and still is of course of the debate did show that it is compliant  with the latest earthquake risk assumptions and BKW did hand in the application for the extension of the  operation. The group-wide productivity enhancement and cost reduction program is on track. We do see first  positive results.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The key figures on page 6, again, on all these items, we did have positive development and I will come now into  detail to all the elements. The higher production from hydroelectric plants and new renewable energy is shown on  page 7. Hydroelectric plants it's 17%. This is compared to a very dry season in 2011.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Nuclear power plants had a stable first half. We will see of course then when we compare to second half. 2012 of  the second half of 2011 that there, if we can operate the plant as expected until the end of the year, an increase  because as you may remember last year, we did have a longer revision. The revision period is always in the  second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Thermal power plants refers to mainly Livorno mainly Livorno Ferraris and you'll see here a drop, a heavy drop in  production, 132-gigawatt hours only. And that is not due to any technical problems. This is market forces. The  prices and the spreads are very low. This means Livorno Ferraris did not operate very many hours. And as I  already pointed out new renewable energy did have an increase of more than 90% which means it almost  doubled.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: When you look at page 8, our sales position. Electricity sales in Switzerland did have a negative impact of 7%  mainly because of our position outside our mainland. They're distributors outside our supply area. International  sales did go up. This is due to some positive developments in Italy with regard to customers which we were able  to win. In trading, the volumes went down. This is in combination with lower prices.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now to the financials in more detail here. The financial highlights on page 10, as I will come to all the elements, I  would not like to go through the page in detail but go directly to page 11. There we see the overall numbers for  revenue down to EBIT. Operating revenue went up 2% and the energy procurement cost on the other hand went  down and other expenses also went down. In other expenses there is one special effect if we do a comparison  with the first half 2011. In 2011, we did have a write-down for the project cost for the replacement of the  Mühleberg power plant.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Depreciation went up 25%. This is on the one hand due to our higher park off of our plants we did invest. And this  means that then we also have higher depreciation amount, but it also is based on the updated cost estimation for  the nuclear waste disposal which leads to a higher depreciation. The higher cost estimate is booked to the  investment side, and then depreciated over to the remaining life.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now, what is interesting to see and what I would like to explain is that if we look into the segments, page 12, we  have Energy Switzerland with a very positive development while then in Energy International and Trading went  down and posted a loss. Networks is showing a stable result. So why is Energy Switzerland so positive and  Energy International and Trading had to post a loss?

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 13, first to Energy Switzerland. Energy Switzerland operating revenue was lower because of the lower  sales volume. But on the other hand, the cost side, there, we did have a better situation. We did have a higher  hydro production which shows here then in the result. And also here shows this CHF 14 million impairment impact  which I already explained in the half year to half year comparison.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If we look now at Energy International and Trading, the main reason for the loss is that Energy International and  Trading does take the production from Energy Switzerland at prices which are fixed three years ahead of  production. And that price includes also then currency impact which means that three years ago we did have high  energy prices and a high euro. Now Energy International and Trading has to sell at of course lower prices and  that leads to this loss here.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The line Energy hedging shows certain hedge transactions which have to be shown under a mark-to-market  regime. There is – some of this business has now had – because we were short in that position, prices went  down, did have a positive mark-to-market effect. International sales, as already mentioned, went up due to  additional customers.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The net sales to other segments, CHF 210 million and minus 7%. This is the revenue under the grid section which  is then shown under the Energy Switzerland segment as external revenue. And as I already mentioned because  we had to reduce prices, we do have here a negative impact. And the other element here is the cost reduction  program which is run in the Network division. And also with that, we were able to compensate some of the loss on  the price side.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If we now go back to the group, to the overall group, then we start again with this EBIT of CHF 156 million to go  down to net profit financial results. Financial result was better, 56% better than last year mainly because of the  performance of the state funds. The state funds for decommissioning of the nuclear power plant. There we did  have positive results of around CHF 30 million, in the previous year period it was minus CHF 7 million. Overall,  that's CHF 37 million difference, positive difference. So we did have, at the middle of the year, a return of around  5% in these state funds.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We also do have a higher interest on provisions because the provisions are higher for the nuclear waste disposal  and also we have provisions for the onerous energy procurement contracts, which we booked the end of 2011.  That was the sort of the negative impact on the financial result side.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Result from equity valued companies down 34%. The main impact there is that we went from a minority position  in the Fortore wind farms to a full consolidation in – at the end of the first half of 2011. So in the first half 2011,  that was still a positive equity result under equity valued companies result. And now, this is of course missing. So  this is not a performance problem here, but it is that we went from a minority position to majority position in the  majority position in Fortore wind farms.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So, if you look at the details in the published report, you will see what other lines we have there. I think what is  important here is to note that both CapEx and investment into equity value companies and group companies went  down quite significantly. And that has to do that we are rather cautious on the investment side. Investment in the  equity value companies' main part there is a [indiscernible] 00:15:07 the investment in coal fired power plant in  Germany where we have a minority stake. Overall, the net change in cash and cash equivalents is CHF 30  million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now from page 23 on some statements about strategy. We did announce in the first half the revised strategy the  Strategy 2030 and that was based on certain trends and development. And I think this is still the same picture we  have here that we expect growing demand for electricity. This political will to promote renewable energy  production the Swiss energy strategy which is still under discussion with more local energy production, the  conversion to the smart grid, and energy efficiency. Feed-in tariffs for renewables which distort the market, it's a  fact – I think it's important to understand mainly the effect on the pump storage power plants in Switzerland. We  do have there some negative effects these days, but it's of course open for debate what will be the future  development.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Page 25, the market position in Switzerland is stable with about 320,000 private customers, more than 20,000  business customers, and more than 100 distributors, which account for about half of our energy sales.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The grid, on page 26, stable situation there as well with still this open question of how exactly the transaction for  the ultrahigh voltage grid will happen. As I already mentioned, we do see the amount which will be in question, but  it is still open. What exactly will be the form of compensation, what parties, shares, what party is that, but we will  be compensated in one of these forms or a combination at the end of the day Page 27, regulatory update. We did  have two main elements in this first half year. And one was the approval of our energy tariffs by ElCom, the  regulator. And based on that ruling, we can factor in up to around CHF 23 million for cost overrun in past periods  into future tariffs. It is not yet – it has not yet been decided when and how exactly we will have to do that.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Then there was a ruling, actually it was in August, but I think it's important to take note of this ruling on the  transmission grid cost for 2009. And this is a federal court ruling, which means this is the final, final ruling. Based  on that, we will receive one digit million Swiss franc amount because one of the elements, which ElCom imposed  on us was not approved by the federal court.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: What is still open a bit is what will happen now with the decisions with regards to the following years, because  these are still open. You see that the transmission grid costs for 2010 and 2011, there we have pending decisions  and now asked if this leading decision for 2009, we will have to see what ElCom does take into account of that  decision and how exactly. But I'd say at least we do see there a potential also for some additional amount to be  paid to us.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: It may also have an impact, but again, there, not yet clear how exactly that plays out, but it may also have an  impact on the lower grid levels, and it might even have an impact on the value of the transmission grid sale  transaction.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Also, page 29, production strategy is the same slide. We have not taken any changes there. So we do see our  focus still on hydro and wind. And if we look at the countries, then Switzerland together with Germany and Italy  are our main focus also here that's a confirmation.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Renewable energy production in Switzerland, page 30. Here, you see that new renewable energy has had a  positive increase in volume. And renewable, hydroelectric plant, we already mentioned as well that we did have  there a positive development.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Page 31, here, we can give an update on two of our important projects which we do together with partners,  [indiscernible] (23:27). That's actually the picture you have in front of the half year report. That is now under  construction. [indiscernible] (23:38) these three projects which we are now discussing also for quite some time  there has been I would say also one very positive development is that the parliament of Canton of Berne has  approved to raise the dam. The Project 3 would be to raise the dam for this power plant.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Page 32 gives you an overview of our position in the renewable energy production international. You see that the  main part here is wind with now volume in gigawatt hours of 250-gigawatt hours for the first half. Hydro and  biomass also is a contributor to that. Biomass, very small. But the hydro plants in Italy, they are very – are in very  good shape.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now to Mühleberg nuclear power plant. The update here is divided up into legal regulatory – and a regulatory  update, page 33, the legal update. We do have a decision from the Federal Department of Environment,  Transport, Energy and Communications which granted the unlimited operating permit in 2009. And as most of you  will know, there has then been in the first half 2012 the ruling by the Federal Administrative Court that this existing  operating limited is listed. So they're concerned in that sense what DETEC had decided but they also imposed a  new operating limit until end of June 2013.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Regulatory update there with regards to the requirements from supervising body, ENSI, Federal Nuclear Safety  Inspectorate. All these elements, there are several elements which are under consideration. We did hand in  certain concepts for long-term operation. We did also hand in certain tests with regard to earthquake stability. We  also handed in now just recently this ultrasonic test under reactor pressure vessel after what came up in Doel 3 in  Belgium. And we're able to show that in the reactor. There is no such type of manufacturing fault as suspected at  Doel 3.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Overall, we currently think that the costs of all – for all these measures are in the order of magnitude of CHF 170  million. And you do see here the various elements on page 35 and also what the timeframe is. I think this is  important. The timeframe for this investment amount is some years. So, it's not something which happens within a  year or so. It couldn't be realized within such a short period of time. And whether it's also important is that it is  BKW's assumption that the power plant will be in operation during the whole time when these measures are being  taken.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: With regards to the fossil fuel [indiscernible] (29:02) power plants, we have abroad, coal-fired power plant in  Wilhelmshaven. This is still under construction. And in Italy, we have Livorno Ferraris. I already mentioned that  the production volume in the first half was very low. What you see here the production value of 1 terawatt hour,  this is what should be expected in a normal year. Let's put it that way. Tamarete which is [ph] a peaker (29:22) is  now in the test phase. So, it should go on stream in end of this year.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Page 37 takes together where we have our installed production capacity. And on page 38, if you look at our  investment program until 2015, we have investment plans for about CHF 1.3 billion new renewable energy in  Switzerland and abroad are, of course, dependent on whether we will get permissions to build, mainly in  Switzerland. That's most of the times an open question or whether we do find attractive projects internationally.  No clear – that consists of the – a part of the CHF 170 million and the ongoing maintenance and replacement  CapEx.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Page 39, our cost reduction and efficiency program is on track in 2012. We expect – we already do see positive  impacts and we expect further positive impact. Of course we also have some costs for redundancies, but the net  effect should be positive in 2012 already.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: To the outlook and summary page 41. One element is the hydro production, which had the positive development  in the first half. We should expect, if we look at this picture here on page 41 and also the second half of the year,  should have a further positive development. The levels in the water reservoirs are slightly above norm.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If you look at the wholesale price for electricity, is one other important element here to calendar year 2013 in – for  the German market, we did see further declining of the price levels and also the spread between peak and off - peak is quite narrow, has narrowed slightly, but is narrowed this important to see.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So overall, for page 44, the final page. We think that the strong business model has shown in the first half 2012  that this may – is capable of delivering strong results and also strong cash flows. We have shown that we are a  market leader for renewable energy and we're able to push up our production from that source, and the financials  are strong, the balance sheet is strong, no refinancing required in the near future, and it is a cash-generating  business.

file: BKW - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 12September2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Sep-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Then -- our company is in a sense a unique company within the Swiss energy supply system because we are fully  vertically integrated company with a strong network, a great network or distribution system network, a distribution  network, we have production, we have trading, we have sales, and of course, [indiscernible] (00:02:06) we also  have a lot of customers -- end customers, about 360,000, not everybody can claim that. And on top of that, you  see it in this graph, we are now developing options for capital-light growth. You see this in this energy solution  and new business model. This is the corner stone of what we are doing as a company. We are fully integrated  and we are now investing into innovation and into new business models.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So what is happening in our environment? We are faced with some really major challenges. Number one, the  weak economic environment in which we find ourselves, which is putting pressure on the electricity prices. The  electricity prices is and remain for probably quite a number of years, still one of the main determining factors of  our profitability. Not forever, but right now we are strongly dependent on the electricity prices. And we do see  decreasing price levels, as you know, strongly decreasing price levels. In the last few days we had – not even  days, months, even we have certain stabilization. But nevertheless, there are many good reasons for the  possibility that the prices remain at this very low level. There are also some good reasons why it could regain  some ground again, but this is not – is not sure.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: You know about the international overcapacity, also due to the regulated production of new release – of new  energy sources, low peak-base spreads which is kind of contradiction what is happening right now with the more  and more fluctuating energy sources coming into the energy supply system. You should in principle see a figure  value for peak – off-peak systems, for example, our pump storage capacities. But right now in this transition in  which the market finds itself, these capacities or these facilities are not valued on the market. We have, that is on  the positive side, at least stabilize Swiss francs as you know very well, but, of course, it is still – is much stronger  than it was a while ago.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So what happened in 2013? The first half year we had solid good operating results. I would even say we had  quite promising operating results, however, partly influenced by positive special effects there, of course, and  Bacher will speak about them a bit more in detail. We had a large acquisition of a wind farm in Italy, Castellaneta,  selling toward this year. We continue to increase our investments into small hydropower production that is  regulated hydropower production and we continued with a lot of discipline our cost reduction programs that we  have started about 18 months ago.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If we look into these numbers a little bit more in detail, then let me start with the operating revenue which was up,  but now that includes the special effects under other operating revenue of CHF 31 million. In the energy  procurement which was lower, there is this great usage compensation effect. But other than that, we were also  able to cut some of the cost. In the expenses excluding energy procurement included there is the personnel  expense. Personnel expense went up around CHF 10 million. And now you could ask why if you have a cost  cutting exercise to personnel expenses go up, two reasons. One is in the services business, we do increase our  workforce. So we do go down with our workforce in the infrastructure business. But in services business, we are  willing to go up with the workforce since this is a profitable business. So, therefore, personnel expenses did go up  in the first half year compared to the first half of 2012.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 11, the cost reduction program, we're on track. We were able already 2012 to get at about 50% of what  we have as a target and now in financial year 2013, we are also according to plan underway. The workforce  reduction, 250 jobs in total is the target, at the end of June we were at about 200 jobs of those 250 jobs.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 12, I would now like to start to talk about the segments. You can see here in the overview that Energy  Switzerland went down from CHF 103 million to CHF 73 million, while Energy International and Trading was able  to come back to positive results and Networks was able to increase its result further.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Let's look at all these segments, page 13, Energy Switzerland. It does have stable net sales to external  customers, but on the other hand now due to the internal price, Energy Switzerland does get the three year  forward price for electricity and those prices did come down somewhat and therefore overall, Energy Switzerland  now has a lower EBIT at CHF 73 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Energy International and Trading came back to a profit, main reasons for that are that the internal prices now are  lower, that they have to pay for the electricity and on the other hand, under the line energy hedging which went  from CHF 1 million to CHF 18 million, you do see that some of these hedges which we will -- which we have to  report mark-to-market did have a positive value in this first half year. Networks, stable in its operating profit, and  that is also due to its cost reduction or its share of the cost reduction program. And then now here you see this  gain of the sale of the high voltage grid and that led to a high EBIT of CHF 96 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 16, if we now take all the segments together again and start from EBIT and go down to net profit, you  see that the financial result was minus CHF 31 million, it was more negative than in the previous year. There is a  weaker performance of the financial markets in the state funds. It's not a weak performance, it's just a weaker  performance. In 2012 the profitability of these funds was at 9%, now this year we were at 3% which for a half year  is still ahead of expectations. And then we have a higher interest cost by – because of the provisions for the  onerous energy procurement contracts.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 18, you have a better overview of where did we invest our money. You can see again, wind was very  high with this Castellaneta transaction call that refers to the Wilhelmshaven power plant which is going to be in  operation as of next year and then you have networks which is lower than the previous year because we now no  longer invest into the very high voltage grid because that is now transferred to Swissgrid. So you will see lower  levels in the networks division, but you will see some considerable investment in that area. The balance sheet out  of these developments has increased the balance sheet, some has increased again and we're now at close to a  [ph] CHF 1 billion (00:19:08) – equity, as already explained, was up compared to the previous year if we look at  the restated number for the previous year.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The state funds for nuclear waste, disposal and decommissioning, on page 20, we show on the upper half that  we're under way according to plan. You see that also in the graph. We are now at exactly where we should be  with our investment. So there is no underfunding, it's just funded where it should be, but that's on the lower part of  this page there is a planned revision of the regulation, the so-called [indiscernible] (00:19:54), it's in ordinance.  And this ordinance if it is going to be changed as proposed by the government, we will have other parameters to  calculate the contributions.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Well, I would like to give you a short summary on the future issues and trends as we see it. Number one, was it  always to be – was we always have to remind ourselves is that we have completely integrated into this global  trend that's happened in the energy supply market. This global trend, most important one I spoke about before is  the pressure on the electricity prices. On the other hand, we still have a growing consumption of electricity. I just  read this morning that according to the car show, probably not in Geneva because that is extreme usually. One  believes really much more in electric cars, that will not have a big impact on electricity consumption but it shows  that the transfer from use of oil and gas to electricity for mobility may increase.
