It's just a sign that electricity will  become more and more important as the energy source. Still electricity price is under pressure probably for the  next few years to come.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The political will to promote renewable energy remains very strong, although, of course, political authorities start  to realize that besides the normal effect [ph] and the warranted (00:24:33) effects are also considerable side  effects by the regulation. Nevertheless, the overall will to transfer -- to transform the energy supply systems in  Germany and in Switzerland is strong and the political authorities will try to find ways to keep on with this  transformation but probably try to reduce the cost on the economies for it.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The Swiss energy strategy was just again disclosed or communicated with [indiscernible] (00:25:08), it's clear  focus on local, renewable energy production, focused on grid -- technologically advanced grid often called Smart  Grid and energy efficiency in the hope of reducing the consumption or not reducing it but limiting the increase of  electricity consumption.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: There are still more or less anticipating market with full market liberalization in Switzerland, probably, it's the  speculation around 2017. This is what is our planning phase right now and we are anticipating the conclusion of a  bilateral electricity, of course, between Switzerland and the European Union. All in all, as a company, we are of  course analyzing what is happening in our environment, but we are not that much engaged in the political  discussions anymore. Our strategy is to align ourselves to the environment and to find opportunities in this  changed environment to develop the company in a profitable way.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We are probably or certainly going to also increase the speed of our cost saving programs in the context of the  new organizational structure that we have given ourselves. [ph] What -- Where are we strong? (00:27:29) What is  one of our key competitive edges? We do have access, direct personal access to our end customers, about CHF  350,000 that is through our sales, but also through the grid which is important. We are vertically integrated  company in a system that will become more and more vertically integrated. The modern technologically advanced  energy supply system is an integrated system and it is also a system that is composed of many micro grids, small  grids which are build up then to a bigger grid to the whole grid system let's say in Switzerland. And our company  can follow this trend from one level to another because we do have the end customers. We do have the lowest  level of the distribution grid. But we can follow the grid and our customer all the way up.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So we are an integrated company in an integrated electricity supply system and that is a strategic advantage that  allows us to create value along the entire value chain for our customers. And, yes, we are still local to a certain  extent. We are very much oriented towards partnerships with our network of more than 140 smaller supply  companies. This network is called utility. We are strong partner in this partnership or in this network and that  allows us very direct access to over 100 smaller supply companies [indiscernible] (00:29:19) and that is a good  advantage also in order to sell new products and new services.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have two pillars in our business development strategy, an old, strong, capital intensive one which is and which  will remain very important for our company, but also a second pillar or maybe future pillar, still relatively small is  the energy services business which is in its nature quite different to the infrastructure business but which goes  very well together in this new integrated supply system that I just spoke about. So what does that mean  infrastructure strategy or infrastructure system? It's generation, production of electricity and there we focus on  hydroelectricity and on wind. Why? We have hydroelectricity which is mainly on the free markets, mainly. So  where we position ourselves in a market situation and we have on the other side wind which is mainly regulated  business. So this is another element of our strategy within the production is to have a portfolio or a balanced  approached in this market between production which is regulated and which is non-regulated.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So we have -- all our investments, particularly investments on production against into the market, into the free  market are under scrutiny and continue to be under scrutiny due to the fact that it is extremely difficult to know  where the electricity price will be going after the year 2020. Everybody can have an opinion, nobody really knows  it.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Although one of the elements of stability in our company increasingly important is our grid infrastructure business.  This grid infrastructure business is a solid base for our income and it is also a base for innovation. Base for  innovation both for the regulated markets, in the context of Smart Grid and it is also a base for innovation in the  context of [ph] free markets (00:32:17) special energy services.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: You see here more or less, our new organizational structure without showing an organic [ph] growth (00:32:44).  These are the four divisions, the four divisions of our company, division Generation focuses on large scale energy  production with our large hydroelectricity plants and also for example, Mühleberg, we have no borders anymore.  So this division is responsible for production in Germany, Switzerland and in Italy focuses on large volume  production.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now, I would like to talk just very quickly about what we are doing with our growth elements will production for  regulated markets, you have this in your documentation and it was mentioned already the acquisition of our wind  farm, Castellaneta, very interesting nice projects and also through our [indiscernible] (00:35:34) wind collaboration  with wind farms in Germany and then little repowering in Switzerland, you see our investments into wind are  mostly in Italy and in Germany, it's increasingly difficult to do anything in Switzerland, even this repowering –  repowering, so the installations were already there was very [indiscernible] (00:35:58) to get the permission to do  it but this is just in brackets.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So wind strategy is in Italy and Germany strategy is more – more than a Swiss strategy unfortunately from my  point of view. And I would like to mention our projects, in the hydropower production, we have received recently a  number of construction permits for small regulated hydropower plants in Switzerland. They are always quite  complex. So it's not at all to be taken for granted that you do receive this compression. And we are still continuing  to invest into these areas. And we have acquired in Italy just very recently five small hydropower plants also  mainly for the regulated market, 10 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now I would like to speak for a moment about the nuclear situation, situation around about Mühleberg, I've  mentioned before we have an unlimited permit. We have delivered at the end of last year a basic concept to the  nuclear authority to NP, which has already accepted them as good in principle and we have now delivered since  the middle of this year a detailed planning for investments into Mühleberg in order to allow a further operation of  the plan and they have not yet answered or have not yet commented on the detailed plan. But from a technical  point of view, we are not really expecting any major difficulties. Now, this does not really make our life much  easier because now we have to take a fundamental decision whether we want to invest these funds or not. And in  the current situation where the electricity price is depressed where it is likely to stay at least low in the next few  years, this decision is not an easy one to take and this has not been taken yet but it will be taken in the course of  this year.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have mainly three elements. It's the investments from the developments of the electricity price and the  probability of a politically induced decommissioning of the plant somewhere between now and, let's say, 2026.  Because what is clear and that has been also already well communicated is an investment that only allows us to  run until 2022, will definitely not be viable. So, it's either 2017, 2018, 2019 for decommissioning or then we go to  2026 at least. So, these are the, are the point that we are trying to make a good and wise decision in the months  to come.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Hydro, we still have – we have committed some, we also have room for to maneuver in the hydro plant. We also  have the possibility to postpone some investments until the situation is a bit clear in the market. Wind, [ph] you  can almost view (00:41:19) turbines by turbines ,so we can decide as we go and with new renewable energies,  we feel in general also very confidence that -- and we also have committed already [ph] comfortable forms  (00:41:33) to do this. All in all, we still have an ambitious investment program and everything that goes into  regulated markets is not only to a certain extent challenged. Everything that goes into the market is under  constant review if we should do it or not, this is the main message to you.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Sales, I don't want to go into the details. I'd like to remind you of the very good market position that we have  through utilities, through our direct access to the customers, so we have collaborations which are quite similar to  other utility collaborations, collaborations outside of Berne and its adjacent Canton, for example, in eastern  Switzerland with [indiscernible] (00:42:23) and also with our partner in the west, Group A and we were able to  increase energy prices to our regulated customers effective 1st of January of next year by 3%.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Yeah, the other element, important element of access to the end customer is our distribution network, but we'll  also in the future have captive customers which doesn't mean that we can do what we want there. We have to be  quite cautious regarding increases in the cost for the grid, nevertheless, we were one of the companies which  decided to increase the prices also for the grid customers due to the increase that was granted by the authorities  [indiscernible] (00:43:24) increase. We were not the only one but one of the few which said, okay, we're going to  push that so we were also a little bit criticized, but that is okay.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Transmission grid was transferred to Swissgrid as mentioned by Beat Grossenbacher, there, again, I would like to  remind you that, while it is an important installation, it only represents about 15% of the invested capital in the  total Group. So, it is maybe technological, very fascinating, but regarding business, and possibility to develop new  business and invested funds, the distribution grid is much more important than the transmission grid. The  distribution grid is 85% and the transmission grid is 15%. But we also sometimes have to remind politicians  [indiscernible] (00:44:19) because all the discussion goes about the transmission grid, which is an error plus the  new energy supply system at least in Switzerland, in Germany the situation is a bit different but at least in  Switzerland we'll be mainly determined by the capability of the distribution grid, so the grid that is directly near,  which is near to the end customer.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The grid fees have been increased by 4%, this is the increase in WACC that I have mentioned already a few  times. So we have spoken quite a bit about our infrastructure business, production and grids. This is where we  come from, this is -- we discussed this in the call, this is a little bit in our DNA. How -- how to do this? But we also  like to invest and develop new technology and now we are in the process of modifying our DNA a little bit, new  biochemistry knows that this is possible, and it's also possible in real business life. And this is to transform BKW  into a company that is really also able from a cultural point of view, from an organizational point of view to develop  services and to promote services and to promote them in the combination with what we do in the infrastructure, to  leverage the fact that we are a vertically integrated company. We do this, thanks to our direct access to clients  and we do it through our development of new technologies and of course we don't do all the technology  development ourselves. We are also in the process of establishing good partnerships with large global technology  provider in order to combine their knowhow with ours.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Our knowhow is on the side of the distribution network and declined. One example here that we are quite proud of  because it is really new for BKW, we are not investing any funds, here is our photovoltaic initiative where we bring  together the order of roofs which are – which can be used for photovoltaic energy production. We bring in all the  knowhow that you need from instant planning of course and installation of photovoltaic installation running for 20  years guaranteeing the production, purchasing of the panels in China mainly bringing all this together in an  integrated package and [ph] signing (00:47:10) at the same time also financial investor's pension cost and  investment cost, bringing this together and creating a packaged business. This is very new for us because we are  doing everything except investing. But it has already --  we have found a partner for the investment. We have  found a partner for the roof that is the Canton of Berne, but still it is a good thing. It's 23 photovoltaic installations  and we are discussing with two other large owners of buildings in Switzerland.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: While I'm coming to the outlook for this year. In summary, we can confirm what we said in March. And we believe  that we will have results which are similar to the ones in 2012. BKW has an investment case. Summer, we have a  strong and very robust business model with our portfolio approach and what we are doing and our vertically  integrated business model. So, what we can offer is a certain degree of stability in a very fast-changing  environment. This stability comes from the fact that we are quickly developing new services as we are vertically  integrated and we have direct access to a large number of end customers both through the grid but also through  our sales network and that we do have a diversified production portfolio, diversified in technology, diversified in  regulation and also in geography with our investments in Germany and in Italy. We are a market leader in  renewable energy, and we continue to push this investment. We are at the same time of course following also the  development of regulations. There are also some challenges in this area, but we believe that in those countries  we are invested right now, the regulatory risk can still be very well managed among others by investing into  technologies which are at the – not too far away from the production costs – in their production costs, not too far  away from the market price. This is one way in which we hedge also the regulatory risk which does also exist.

file: BKW - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 20March2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: A few points on the business in the year 2011, the year we report, I'll not go through every point, just I like to point  out that one of the most important or most influencing factor was, of course, Fukushima, but not as much as the  factors which dominate the business, not only of BKW but the whole sector is dominated by market development,  low market prices and quite low demand. Overall Europe, and of course, also influenced quite strongly by  subsidies given for new renewable energies, which has become the size and the measure, which influences the  market quite in a not in an exact double way.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: As to generation, the two effects are, of course, also seen in the biggest of last year. So in nuclear power, we  have 9% less production and as we had also bad hydrologic situation, also a decrease of 9% in last year, reached  it with over has influenced in a negative way our result as well. Those are our key figures. I think some more  detailed information, especially of different effects, we can follow from last year would be given by Beat  Grossenbacher in continuation of presentation.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The updated estimate of the decommissioning and disposal cost for all Swiss nuclear power plants that was  released in last year when these numbers became known, but I will also show you there more details of what that  means for our company.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now, first I would like to explain the adjustments. We now report the numbers on one hand as reported and on the  other hand as adjusted and some or most of these adjustments are now under provision for onerous energy  procurement contract. Wilhelmshaven, Livorno Ferraris and Tamarete are power plants where we have minority  interests and we have to take the energy at costs and since we assume that these prices will be lower than  market prices, we had to book provisions for onerous contract that for CHF 280 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 13, [indiscernible] (00:10:55), which power plant is concerned in which way. It's that new fossil-fuelled  thermal power plants, which are concerned and these do not profit from any subsidies and that is the main reason  since, these have to be measured against market prices, why these – for these companies we had to book  impairments and provisions.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: In the future, these provisions will be released over the next few years to compensate the high energy  procurement costs we expect, but since Wilhelmshaven and Tamarete are not yet in operation, we'll first have a  negative impact because there will be an accrued interest on the provisions.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Energy procurement costs were down as well because of lower electricity prices. And here in this energy  procurement cost, there is also the impact of this longer service period for Mühleberg nuclear power plant, which  accounted for about CHF 28 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: In the expenses, excluding energy procurement included are CHF 14 million impairment of the project cost for the  replacement of Mühleberg nuclear power plant, as we disclosed in the half-year figures already. Depreciation was  up because we have now more power plants, especially wind farm Fortore, which now is accounted 100%.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If we go on page 15 to the business segments, you can see that there were quite some changes now in the  segments. The Swiss supply business on the one hand in Energy Switzerland and on the other hand in the  Networks division together, they are a very stable contributor to group operating income. I will come to the details  now with the next slides.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: For Energy Switzerland on page 16, you see that operating revenue was up 5%. This is based on slightly higher  prices at stable sales volumes.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Depreciation was up also because often less in new power plants and together there was than the EBIT 31%  lower than last year.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Energy International and Trading [indiscernible] (00:14:57) an operating revenue which was 7% down reflecting  the lower price levels, but also the reduction in the spread for base and peak load energy.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Electricity trading CHF 865 million, down 19%, proprietary trading was CHF 20 million, about CHF 21 million  higher than last year. Last year we had minus CHF 1 million, now we have a positive result and this is based on a  difficult market situation, a very good result.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We showed this line Energy hedging and this is a new line this year. We showed it already in the half-year result,  but it is a new line for this year, it is minus CHF 41 million. I will come to an explanation in more detail in the next  slide, but we have to say here that this reflects opportunity costs and not full picture of the whole situation.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The net sales to other segments, CHF 919 million, this is the sale of electricity to our Swiss distribution and that  was up 7% due to higher internal transfer prices. Depreciation was higher as well because of acquisition of power  plants. All-in-all, it delivers then an EBIT for this segment of minus CHF 40 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On page 18, I can give you more details about this line Energy hedging, and you can see that we have, if you look  at the years, we look at we had 2011 or so-called own-use, we do have the reflection in the P&L, but for the open  positions 2012, 2013 and 2014, own-use is not booked. These are open positions. But if we do hedging which has  to be accounted for on a mark-to-market basis, we already see the effect of that in this line Energy hedging.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Page 19, to the Networks division, operating revenue was up 4%. Although the volumes were a little bit lower, this  was up because of slightly higher prices for grid access fees and also because we were able to increase sales to  external customers with the engineering business and the electrical installation business.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Cash outflow from investing activities was lower because we had a reduction in the current and non-current  financial assets. If you look at the CapEx property, plant and equipment and the investments in equity-valued  companies and group companies, together we invested about CHF 500 million. About CHF 170 million of that into  networks, about CHF 170 million in wind assets, and about CHF 60 million in hydro assets.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The balance sheet total due to these investments was higher about 8% if you compare it to the prior year. We  now are at balance sheet total of around CHF 7 billion. Equity stands at CHF 2.7 billion, was impacted negatively  because of these impairments. On the other hand, the financial liabilities increased from CHF 1.050 billion to CHF  1.200 billion. This is due to the financial liabilities we now have to account for since we have 100% of the Fortore  wind farms.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The new cost estimation for nuclear waste disposal and decommissioning, which was done in 2011 as already  mentioned lead to an increase in the provision. Let me explain these numbers again cost calculation price level  2006, cost calculation price level 2011, these cost calculations are so-called overnight costs, which means that  we estimate a cost what would it cost today to take all these measures which are necessary. And you can see  that there was an increase from CHF 2.4 billion to almost CHF 3 billion for that cost estimate. A part of that cost  has already been spent, this is also important to note.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The most important driver of the increase is that there are new requirements when building such facilities, which  will be necessary for the nuclear waste disposal.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The provision – gross provision as per the end of 2011 stands at CHF 2.1 billion and as some of these costs have  already been paid, these has to be deducted to come to the provision, which has to be included in the balance  sheet as of end of 2011 and the number is CHF 1.4 billion. Now, this is the liability side. On the other hand, for  some of these costs we have to pay money into state funds for decommissioning and nuclear wastes also, that's  on the right-hand side of the slide 23, where you can see that the value of the funds for our nuclear power plants  stands at CHF 600 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And you can see also here on this graph, the green line shows you where we start with the CHF 600 million and  where we will have to be at the end of the useful lifetime of the plant, expected useful lifetime of the plant. This is  around CHF 1.5 billion. Now the around CHF 30 million we pay each year together with the expected return on  the assets should lead to the CHF 1.5 billion at the end of the foreseen useful life of the plant.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: You also see other financial liabilities. This is the financial liability, which we together with the wind farms  acquired, there were some lease financings embedded in these plants and we acquired them and these are still  running.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Thank you very much. We'll come back to strategy part, and let's begin with some trends and the impacts we  assume or some which we, of course, kind of influenced. So, we believe in increasing demands for electricity,  even there is a number of measures taken against this increasing demand, we do not sign it for energy, in  general, but I think all the possibilities that are offered by electricity are still quite attractive, so that in the next  years, or even decades, it will be very difficult to find a way to decrease demand for electricity. Of course, on the  estimation or around the assumption that the economy will recover more or less in Europe in a [indiscernible]  (00:29:27) ways.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Of course, I'm not going to comment on all those statements. Of course, it's a strong political will to promote  renewable [indiscernible] (00:29:38) in Switzerland, especially is not enough. There must be permits and the  possibilities to build up and so on. But if you look at Europe, I think there will be still quite a lot of opportunities to  invest in [indiscernible] (00:29:51).

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If I go to slide 29, you can see the figures for the market position in Switzerland. The actual figure showing last  year's development. Of course by its customers and then distributors they've shown a decrease of last year of  energy consumption. We do not have the official figures but looking at the temperature, looking at the economy,  there will certainly be a decrease after a strong increase the year before. So that's reflected by private customers  and the distributors. On the other hand, we have an increase on business customers that's not because of a  natural development, it's just because we could get some more customers on the contract.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: From the figures on the grid, you know that the transmission, high voltage – ultra-high voltage grid will be taken  over by Swissgrid this year. At least, that's the plan and that's also was low – respective low prescribes, so we are  on the way to sell it out to take over from – depending from which point of year you look at it the high-voltage grid.  Beat has mentioned these line assets for sale that's the corresponding line and the corresponding slide here. But  this slide also shows us the possibility for the future – for the long-term future to play a different part in all the  system BKW has positioned to play this part with, it's quite wide distribution grid.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So BKW is prepared and, of course, has the necessary competences to answer to all these needs and new rows  that are given by the new energy strategy. This we are – summarized more in detail on our production site, that's  the elements we revise to follow. So in hydro in all countries, Switzerland, all surrounding countries, we are active  and we are searching for opportunities to purchase energy installation plants that are [indiscernible] (00:34:41)  that could be interesting to integrate in our portfolio. More or less the same in wind, five strong activities in  Germany [indiscernible] (00:34:52) in wind Switzerland is quite limited by the possibilities we had planned in  Switzerland to increase our production. It's not depending from our role it's depending from the possibilities. And  we concentrate on Switzerland as to other renewables, based on other renewables in Italy but they will not follow  an extension strategy which we will just hold them.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And on nuclear, of course, we – as reported, I will comment detail. We stay in nuclear in Switzerland and of  course as long as possible in France. And the same with coal in Germany where – that's the plant of  Wilhelmshaven, gas in Italy, and of course as a possibility and the condition that it's necessary in Switzerland that  we find necessary – the necessary legal framework to build up gas in Switzerland we would be ready to bring our  contribution as well.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: In Switzerland as to renewable energy on page 33, we are the leading company in different sectors but still  compared to the quantities we find we are able to build up and we are able to purchase abroad. Of course, these  figures for Switzerland are quite not in a same order.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: As to not new but ordinary or old renewable in Switzerland, we have reported already and we have followed  maybe that Bielersee Kraftwerke in Hagneck, that's where BKW was founded, we are investing, we are building  up and have started the renovations of new plant to replacing of the old plants with increasing capacity and with  an increasing quantity for production. And we are also ready to invest in [indiscernible] (00:37:30) actually first  element which is called, the so-called, [indiscernible] (00:37:37) will be under construction soon. And second  element is up now to be in the Parliament of the Canton of Berne this year. So, we hope we are looking forward  that having the decision, so that after rotations in the cities of Basel and Zurich, we'll be able to start to build up  City of Berne has already voted in a quite clear positive way for Grimsel. Third part, the rising of the dam, of  course, will take a little longer, but I'm still optimistic that we'll be able to raise this dam in future as well.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Some indication on what we've done in renewables internationally. You can see the situation and location of the  different investments. I'll not go to every one of them, but up to now we have some 275 megawatts under  operation in wind. We have two overall midsized hydro systems in Italy under operation, which brings us quite an  interesting contribution to our result.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Coming back to Switzerland and especially to nuclear power plant of Mühleberg. We reported last three week  already that we will go on the Federal Court and for the existing time limit for operating Mühleberg which has been  given by the respective state department and then changed by the Federal Administrative Court, so that request  will go on. We did not pose or we didn't contest all the safety measurements that we did contest the uncertainty  which has been given by the decision of the Federal Administrative Court and realized to have some order in the  delays in the questions who is responsible and the questions to whom ask for the permits and so on, so it will be  much more clear. So that's what we hope in the future.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We agree with the responsible Federal Institution that we have three questions to answer. One is the core mantle,  where we think that with a few measures, safety can be raised quite a lot. Then earthquake safety where we have  to prove – actually we had to prove up to end of this month that Mühleberg will be stable at an earthquake at the  10,000 yearly earthquake which we think we could do, but now still we decided just to have sufficient margin for  this to reinforce the dam of Mühleberg water power where we'll start works within a few weeks depending on the  permits we get. But we think that we could have terminated this additional safety measures up to end of this year.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And finally to the question of the [indiscernible] (00:42:11) we think we have three possibilities to go on. One is  this combined cooler, other one is taking the water from the summit which is a river quite close there passing by  at Mühleberg, more or less 1 kilometer, and then with a subterranean line or an additional reservoir past situation  of the existing plant which could be three possibilities to do this [indiscernible] (00:42:48). I think actually when the  responsible authorities will have a look at the plant and made up their mind or have more security concerning the  possible investment and the necessary investment there to go on planning Mühleberg further years from now.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Actually to – coming to the thermal power plants, you know about Wilhelmshaven where we've faced some  difficulties and which have caused this correction this – in the balance sheet. Actually we scheduled – we  rescheduled to be on-stream by end of 2013, and hope that all the problems will be solved up to then. The  measures have been started and are under work today. So as – in Italy, Livorno Ferraris, of course, is in  operation, and we are with Tamarete. We have actually a situation where we will be a little late on schedule but  more or less on schedule in taking into operations, though that we are looking forward to have Tamarete next  year, definitely under operation, go under operation all end of this year but the contribution in producing energy  will not be high in the year 2012.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Our plans are always under estimation that we will have not to shut down little bit earlier than planned. Our  projects go to renewable in Switzerland by some CHF 400 million as you can read all the different figures here on  page 39. We'll invest some CHF 100 million in hydropower in Switzerland. Coal-fired is not a new plant. It's just  the rest we have to invest and some indication on the cost of refitting Mühleberg because that the measure is not  to be defined more precisely in the next few months. Though, of course, remaining is as always the maintenance  investments which goes up to approximately CHF 150 million per year.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So coming finally to outlook and overview. So just indication where we stand in our reservoirs by beginning of this  month, so we have started with more or less average filling degree and in the very cold period it in February, of  course, we have used this energy remaining the basins for our customers but also of course for the international  market, so that we are now going quite slightly into spring and hoping that the snow will melt as quickly as  possible to refill our basins, and showing development of the future prices you can still see a trend in the last  month actually being a little bit corrected, but I don't know if that's already a reliable sign of spring or just a short- term effect that we can slightly see that the prices rising again.

texts.speaker: Kurt Rohrbach
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Switzerland, we are the leading producer for renewal energy but are just diversified into our portfolio and go on  building up our peak load capacity, also in the future especially with [ph] Grimsel (00:52:10) and even if suffered  last year, we still have strong balance and we'll be able to be financed until 2018.

file: BKW - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 21March2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: As BKW Group today presents itself with a strong competitive position and a successful and particularly solid  business model in a much changing environment. As most of you know, we are a leading provider of  comprehensive energy services at all stages of the energy supply chain. We're one of the most important  electricity distributors in Switzerland, supplying around about 1 million customers, in-line also with our extensive  distribution network that spans about 20,000 kilometers and where we have by the way about CHF 1.6 billion  invested. We have a diversified production portfolio with substantial peak load capacity, and we are the Swiss  leader in power from new renewable energies in particularly from wind.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now the interesting thing that is really new maybe for most of you is that we are in the process of adding to our  vertically integrated value chain, a new dimension or maybe reinforcing this dimension and that is the dimension  of services in an ever more complex energy system services, which will also require new business models to be  marketed. The idea is to combine our knowhow, our experience, what we have been doing over the decades in a  stable environment and combine it into a value proposition for our customers in a changing and much more  complex, much more diversified energy supply system.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We are in a challenging business environment, and if we look into the next few years, we see already that this  business environment will remain challenging. We have the fact that the wholesale prices for electricity have  continued or have for the last two to three years gone down and if we look into the next few years, we see a  continued downturn may be flattening out somewhere in the next three to five years, but we are rather cautious in  our prediction of what is going to happen.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: On the positive side, I can say, there is a certain awareness growing in the political environment that investments  into the energy infrastructure have to be viable and have to be attractive for the investors that have been shown  for example in the decision of the Federal Council to increase the WACC on the investments integrate. We see  that as a very positive sign, not only directly from a money point of view, but also because we see that there is a  certain change in our political regulatory environment that points a little bit in the direction that people realize that  investments will be made when and if the investment conditions are favorable for the companies that have to  make the investments.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Our strategy, strategy BKW 2030, 2030 is, of course, a very long range. We are not going to wait for the next 10  years to start to implement a strategy. We are well on the wealth way already now with very, very concrete steps.  The first one I mentioned already, this approach of the comprehensive Energy Services, which are based on the  vertical integration and the knowledge and the competencies that have been acquired over the years in the  management of this vertically-integrated system that goes very well along with what is happening in our  environment, where the energy supply system is becoming more complex, more comprehensive and will require a  knowledge of systems operator for the entire energy supply system.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have a very good infrastructure in which we will continue to invest and where we have also the opportunity to  test new technologies, which are normally summarized under the word of smart grid. And this knowledge that we  are developing there will also be sold in the years to come to other maybe smaller energy supply companies who  don't have the opportunity to develop this knowhow and these technologies.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have our sustainability goals, which are important for us which are in line with the company orientation, but  which are also a source for higher quality and less mistakes. And in that sense, in a broader sense, also a source  for further productivity improvements.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Last but not least, we do large investments into renewable energies, particularly in the wind domain. As you may  be aware, we are by far the largest investor, Swiss investor in the wind technology. We have invested almost CHF  1 billion in the last four to five years into that technology. However, mostly abroad, not in Switzerland. In  Switzerland, it's much more difficult to make this type of investment.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have a reinforced position through our investments in renewable energy. For example, we have acquired the  wind farm Castellenata in Italy that was a highlight. We have productivity enhancement and cost reduction  program, which is on track. We are looking there to reduce our cost by short of CHF 100 million, we have  achieved half of that, which is I think very good achievement of the management considering that we are in a  company that maybe go for the first time through such an clearly focused cost reduction effort. Not everybody  believed we could do it, that's really what I would like to say.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And then we have Mühleberg produce more than 3 terawatt-hours of energy, last year the highest ever production  that was delivered from this plant.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: These adjustments for exception impairment charges, those of you who follow us know that last year, we already  had impairment charges, there we had it on several lines. This year the impairment charge is only on the energy  procurement line. We have to build provisions which are above the EBITDA line. It's not additional depreciations,  it's provisions and therefore it impact EBITDA. CHF 112 million is the number on that line, then you see further  down on the income tax line, the effect that has on income taxes. And with that, we come to that adjusted net  profit of CHF 205 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Where and why did we have to build additional provisions, let me start with the fossil thermal power plants in Italy,  the new power plants Livorno Ferraris and Tamarete. Our assessment of the future is that it will be more difficult  than we assessed it the previous year to achieve positive results. And therefore we increased the provision for  Livorno Ferraris by around CHF 40 million. We increased the provision for Tamarete by around CHF 20 million.  And then we also built a new provision for a hydro power plant in Switzerland. We there assessed that again, we  will not achieve the full result as expected when we started building the new plant.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If we look at the numbers for the group from operating revenue to EBIT, on page 13, I can start again with that  increased operating revenue of close to CHF 2.9 billion, which was driven by higher revenue in energy trading  based on also the higher production. This higher production also is reflected in higher energy procurement cost.  Other expenses were stable, although as already mentioned, our cost reduction program did deliver first results,  we on the other hand grow some other businesses and for these reasons, the other expenses are at about the  same level as in the previous year. With that, we achieved this high EBITDA of CHF 523 million, depreciation was  about stable, and therefore, EBIT also increased considerably.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now if we go into the segment results, we see the picture that Energy Switzerland and Networks built the  backbone of our strong result. Both Energy Switzerland and Networks were able to increase their result at the  EBIT level. And the international and trading is still on EBIT level and at a loss-making level. However, this is  based on the internal transfer prices and the key international and trading as the trading hub does buy the energy  from Energy Switzerland at prices three years ago. And therefore you also have the negative impact from  declining prices and also from the euro effect in that area Energy International & trading for 2012 for the currency  impact had to bear about CHF 40 million. Without that effect, Energy International and Trading would also have  had a positive EBIT result.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If you go into a little bit more detail in our segment, per segment on page 16, I'll start with Energy Switzerland,  where the high production is the driver of the increased operating profit. As you can see, operating revenue was a  little bit lower. That is due to the negative price effect and also a little bit lower sales volume. On the other hand,  we had there also positive impact from cost reduction on the other side. The depreciation here increased quite  considerably that is based on the updated estimation for the cost for nuclear waste disposal.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Energy International and Trading, as already explained, why do we have there these low results, I would also like  to point out that we had positive results from proprietary trading, stood at around CHF 15 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Here is also included the service business from installation, and this was again able to be increased strongly. In  revenue, we achieved now a level of about CHF 150 million. What we also have here is a one-off effect from the  transaction in the – from the transmission grid to Swissgrid, around CHF 17 million we were able to book in 2012.  This is a timing difference which otherwise would have had a positive effect only in 2013. But this will be not  achieved again of course in the next year.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The result from equity-valued company is negative. This is based on a non-capitalization of cost for  Wilhelmshaven, the power plant which is under construction. There are also costs for testing, which cannot be  capitalized, and therefore that leads here to a negative result under equity-valued companies.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: In which technologies did we invest in 2012? This you see on page 21. There was, as you first of all see, a lower  level for all categories in 2012 compared to 2011. The highest investments were into networks. These are  maintenance CapEx mainly. Then you have the investments in coal, which is deferred to license into the power  plant in Wilhelmshaven, and then you see for hydro, wind, new renewable energies, nuclear and other, those are  all at about CHF 20 million each.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: I would also like to mention on page 24 where we stand with the provisions for nuclear waste disposal and  decommissioning and with the moneys in the financial, in the state funds. Our next provision stands at around  CHF 1.5 billion for that topic and our financial assets are at around CHF 700 million. The state funds in 2012 had  a return of around 9%, and you see here the green line, that's the actual value and the estimated development  and it's almost where the reference value is, as you can see 2012 there are about 5% short of the reference  value. But we expect now and we hope, of course, that the financial results in the future will result in exactly the  reference value together with the payments of around CHF 30 million each year.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: I would now like to give you a short overview again about the important future issues and trends in how BKW  wants to position itself in these very fast-changing environments. In principle, we have a situation in which there  would be growing demand for our product, our main products still being electricity with the conversation from  other power sources, for example, also fossil fuels, to electricity. However, we have a market situation in which  subsidized and not subsidized power sources compete with each other for the same market, and that means that  the market in which we are operating right now is rather distorted.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We see a strong will to promote renewable energy. We see also that the strong will works in Germany, which is  the leading country for us in that respect. We have an ever increasing production of subsidized renewable energy.  It works but it does have side effects which are not yet accounted for in the whole energy supply systems. With  that, I mean, for example, that the also increasing need for backup capacities right now at least are not solid  investment case for a company like BKW.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The Swiss energy environment's probably going to look a little bit different than that in Germany. Why? Because  in Switzerland we will have more local, more decentralized energy production by many, many very small  producers because of the number one that the lack of the possibility to have big centralized renewable power  plants, we cannot build large wind farms in Switzerland at least not now, and we certainly can't build any offshore  wind farms in Switzerland. So we will have a much more localized decentralized system which also leads the  system to being more complex and more diverse as I have mentioned in the beginning.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Ever more important, as you know, will be a reliable grid and the grid that is capable of absorbing the volatile, the  ever increasing volatile energy production, and at the same time produce the energy or rather deliver the energy,  then when it is necessary. So, probably in the future, we will have the situation that on a dark winter day  everybody including the small local producers will want to draw electricity from the net, and on a nice summer  day, when nobody needs the energy, everybody will want to push the electricity into the grid. That is one of the  big questions that will have to be answered. Also politically, who pays for what in that arrangement, let's call it like  that, who pays for the system cost, for example, of a more sophisticated intelligent smart grid.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And then also almost a never-ending story, the bilateral electricity accord between Switzerland and the European  Union, unfortunately I can also not give you a clear picture of what is exactly going to happen there. I would like to  simply say we are very interested to have well-designed relationships with the European Union also in the  electricity sector, of course, on the other hand, it should be an accord and an agreement, and it will take some  time, we think, until it will finally be agreed on.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Our strategy BKW 2030 for the strategy which is reality for us today 2030 for the strategy which is reality for us  today and which we are working in implementing can be may be categorized in four key elements that is  continuity and stability. Our environment is not stable and not very continuous so that is already a big task,  continuity and stability.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Then, of course, financial stability as Beat Grossenbacher presented, we are in a quite good position there. Then  the infrastructure strategy that is to continue to invest in the energy production infrastructure and into the grid  infrastructure, these are all-in-all still larger attractive investment opportunity, by the way not the least in the  regulated area. It's maybe not great returns, but it's relatively solid returns. And then coming from our  infrastructure and from our vertical integration, the development of new energy services, new business models  that will grow with the transition from today's energy supply systems into the new energy supply system.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have implemented or we have decided or announced on a new company structure. In January, we are now in  the face of implementation and this is, I think pretty good example for the slogan, structure follows strategy, this is  represented with two new areas divisions, number one, renewables and efficiency, this is a more technological  organizational unit that shall bundle all the technological knowhow, the solutions that we have throughout the  company, and use the conversion of technology that is happening also between communications and energy into  new solutions in an ever more complex energy system.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: This is an effort that we are making at the end of the day with the assignment to not only grow that this maybe  even relatively easy, but to really produce acceptable and good returns with renewable energy not only with wins  and with new business model in this segment. It is still a small division and it has to earn its right to grow, but it is  now starting with many hopes and also many expectations from our company.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: At the same time, we are now bundling the whole company order interface with our customer in the Markets  division. It has a similar assignment as renewable and efficiency, that is to bundle what we are doing our vertically  integrated company, make it an offer for our customer and develop the market. The Networks division stays more  or less unchanged with a strong infrastructure business and with ever growing services business.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Let me repeat generation. It's improvement in business and investment efficiency, make the most of our invested  capital, renewable and efficiency, technological solutions for a new energy system, market bundling the  competences towards our customers, and promoting and selling our new services, and then the Networks division  is one of the stable elements of our company, that has both the infrastructure business and the service business.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We are in the process of finalizing the project of Wilhelmshaven, our coal-fired power plant which will add to our  baseload capacity. We expect it to be on stream by the end of this year. And we have other basin-flexible  production capacity in Italy, gas-fired capacity that has been and will be coming on stream, of course, there the  financial outlook as you have heard is not that positive.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We are very proud to be the main Swiss operator of wind farms in Switzerland and also abroad. We have our  wind farms at very advantageous positions in Southern Italy and in the middle and towards the North of Germany.  We have a significant increase in the installed capacity since last year, plus 50% installed capacity. And of course  more important we have also an increase in the production volume of 70% with on – within one year, so you see  BKW, yes, is Mühleberg but much more although I normally say that to this media journalist, not to the analyst. So  we have the project, we will continue with the investment program, I will mention it to you in a moment.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Here we are. I would like to speak about these investment plans that we have until 2016. We are right now  planning to invest CHF 1.2 billion in the different technologies, about CHF 200 million in hydro electrical plants,  again about CHF 200 million in our wind technology. Then, we will continue to invest in Mühleberg is the figure  that you see here which is something below CHF 100 million, of course does not yet include the major project that  is right now under evaluation for the long-term operation of BKW. As you may remember, we are now going  through the several legal procedures, and then in the course of this year, BKW will then decide on fully  entrepreneurial grounds and whether or not to invest more than CHF 200 million additionally into Milwaukee that  would then be for a long-term operation.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Please note that we are continuing to invest heavily into the networks more than CHF 400 million in a regulated  area and also more than CHF 100 million in the what we call new renewable energies. These are the  technologies that have feed-in tariffs. So in total we are investing more than CHF 500 million in the regulated  area, which keeps our company in the entire portfolio of what we are doing a certain solidity that we do  appreciate.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: One of the key elements of BKW, in addition to our investment plans and our investment strengths, is the access  that we have to direct customers. This is of ever more important strategic assets that we are having because we  have direct access not only to today's energy consumers, but also to future energy producers, these small not  independent but partly independent energy producers, who will however still depend on this complex and  technologically advanced grid that links everybody, and that has to assure that supply, also in a situation where  the independent self-producers cannot supply their needs by themself.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We would like to highlight also the utility platform, where we work together with the [ph] one-to-one (45:25) energy  brand. This utility platform gathers about 130 regional energy providers mostly in the further neighborhood of  Berne and it was for example possible for us in spite of the low prices on the wholesale market to retain these  customers with us. They are free, they can buy their electricity where they want and we were able to conclude  with them also many year contracts at I would say reasonably advantageous condition for both sides. So this is  definitely an asset for BKW. We do have a strong, loyal customer base that we have to take care off very well, of  course.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: One of our solid and good elements in our portfolio as I mentioned is our extensive distribution network. We have  around about 20,000 kilometers of grid. Of course, as Beat Grossenbacher said, we have that – this highest  voltage network that has been transferred to Swissgrid. However, one has to remember that in terms of value and  of capital investment it's the distribution grid that is of importance, 85% of the capital is invested in the distribution  gird and remains also with our company. And as I explained in my beginning remarks, the redesign of the energy  system particularly in Switzerland will be very local, very decentralized, and so it affects mostly the distribution  network at its lower level. We see this as a business opportunity both in terms of a reasonably good investment  case, and also in terms of new business models that can be developed in the interface between the Grid and the  customer.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So and coming also to this new business models, I mentioned it just in the previous slide. This is this combination  of the client that is in the middle of everything, the technology that is party available that has to be developed.  This is technology that brings together what we know in the standard energy supply technology and is combined  with modern communication technology through a package, which enables the new system as it is now slowly  emerging.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: BKW sees itself there as a provider of comprehensive energy services, not only for the operation of the grid but  also selling services as we do already today with our two daughter companies, Arnold AG and ISP AG for third  parties. By the way, both of these companies have only a minority of their turn over with BKW and they are very  well positioned through profit from the expansion of the infrastructure as it will be needed in one way or the other  in Switzerland in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now, so we come to the outlook for the year 2013. I mentioned the challenging market environment, the energy  prices that remain low and have only certain possible upward trend that we have regulatory requirements, which  are signals, which are partly positive, but regarding regulation of trade also, of course, difficulty, we have a  persistently strong Swiss franc. So taking all of this into consideration we expect an EBITDA and net profit for the  financial year of 2013 to be in-line with the reported figures of 2012.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: BKW, the investment case, it's a great company. Has a strong business model, it focuses on comprehensive  energy services, which will be more and more needed in this complex energy systems that we are going into. It is  the vertical integration. This vertical integration is the base to develop new solutions and new services for our  customers. We do have direct access to end customers, this means we can also test some things, pilot some  things before we go into a broader market and we do have a diversified production portfolio. We have a diversified  investment portfolio with investment into regulated and non-regulated areas, which gives us a certain solidity in  our investment portfolio.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We are a market leader for renewable energy. Also there we have a well-diversified portfolio and we focus on  hydroelectricity and wind. And we do have substantial peak load capacity at our disposal.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Apart the fact that we are cash generating, we also have growth opportunities in the development of new  business models which are in the beginning, but where we see the way to go quite concretely and we have  focused investments in profitable areas, hydro, wind, networks, and new business opportunities.

file: BLNDL - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 4August2010 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-10.pdf
BLNDL - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 4August2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-11.pdf
BLNDL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 16November2010 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Nov-10.pdf
BLNDL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 15November2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Our third financing was the £560 million British Land non-secured revolving bank facility in May. Having no  access to the unsecured banking market during 2008 and 2009 and with no immediate requirement that's seeing  improving sentiment, we launched a £350 million and closed at £560 million. The margin on the five-year facility  is 125 basis points. Together, these well-timed financings reflect the benefits of maintaining liquidity and have put  us in a strong position in the current climate.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: The announcement we've made today about Aon is important too. It's good for the UK, it's better for the city and  it's great news for Leadenhall. We will also continue to exploit new opportunities to create longer-term value  through recycling capital, through further acquisitions and through development. This mix of near-term resilience  and our ability to capture future upside puts British Land in a very strong place.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 20November2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Charles Sheridan Alexander Maudsley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Retail, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: A number of retailers, including those shown here, have acclimatized to the tougher environment and are doing  relatively well. But we're also seeing continued distress with results into administrations, most notably JJB and  Comet and further administrations do remain at risk.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 13November2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: We're already letting up vacant space with around a third now let. And that's ahead of ERV. The area will benefit  from further regeneration and the opening of the new Crossrail station. In terms of development, there are  350,000 square feet of consented schemes. Our current plan is to put these schemes back into planning because  we feel strongly that we can do better. That after all is one of our key competitive advantages.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 18November2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Plans for our medium-term program are also taking shape. The largest project, as I said, is at Canada Water,  covering our sites at Surrey Quays and Harmsworth Quays. Here, we've got nearly 40 acres in an area which we  think will improve a lot. As you can see, it's well connected to the City, Canary Wharf and the West End . Our cost  of acquisition has been modest, and although it's early days, this is a project that can add material value.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Overall, we've been busy enhancing facilities and improving environments. Importantly, we've also been selling  parks if they don't make the grade. We sold nine parks over the last 18 months. Of course, many of these actions  are not exclusive to our parks. We've been doing these things across our portfolio. This has contributed materially  to our consistent out-performance.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 17November2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've made good progress, we're creating great environment, and investing in London and the South East and net  £170 million in the period is now around two-thirds of our business. We're investing around transport  infrastructure as well as in assets we know and like. Our focuses on getting closer to our customers is paying off.  We're investing in the Retail portfolio to ensure it's compatible with the way customers shop on and offline.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: At Paddington, there's a real sense of momentum. By next year, the campus will start to look and feel very  different. We're due to complete the first phase of public realm improvements at the end of the year and we  submitted planning for the next phase. These pictures give you a sense of how we'll transform the campus to make  it greener, more pedestrian-friendly environment with landscaped areas to relax and spend time.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: At our Investor Day in July, we talked about we're evolving our portfolio by delivering spaces in tune with our  customers' needs. The average lot sizes of our multi-let assets is up from £80 million to £150 million since 2010,  reflecting our focus on larger multi-let schemes where we can influence both offer and environment. These now  account for around 70% of our Retail portfolio.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've also got a substantial near- and medium-term pipeline, which will in turn have a big impact on our  business. Much of this development will be around our three London campuses and we'll create the fourth for  Canada Water. Taken together, that's over 7 million square feet of development in areas with strong and  improving transport infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We also have £200 million of CapEx projects planned. That's everything from public realm improvements to small  extensions and refurbishments. We've got some exciting medium-term prospects. We submitted planning on a  substantial mixed-use scheme at Eden Walk in Kingston, and next year we expect to submit planning for a leisure  scheme at Meadowhall. That's around 330,000 square feet. That's in addition to the retail we're planning at  Broadgate and Canada Water.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Of course, the biggest project in our pipeline is Canada Water. It benefits from strong transport links and  proximity to Central London. What sets it apart is a mix of water and green spaces which will be integral to the  scheme.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 16November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Just a short comment on Canada Water. We've now assembled a very strong team. We're having encouraging  discussions with a wide range of potential occupiers. We're working on our master plan with the views of  submitting planning in 2017.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: In the meantime, we're generating income at a yield of almost 3%. Canada Water represents a really exciting  opportunity for British Land.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: You'll see the development valuations are only down by 3%. Here, we've seen developments under construction  benefit from profit releases as we approach completion. As you can see, Canada Water has decreased by 2%.  This represents a value of £6 million an acre, and as Chris mentioned, it yields nearly 3% while we progress our  plans.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 16November2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: We're also delivering from more than just a financial perspective. As you know, sustainability is integral to our  strategy and our leading position is now recognized by a number of international indices, as you can see here.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Retail, here too, we've made good progress. Clearly, there are headwinds in the market in terms  of the economic climate and continued structural change. So retailers are firmly focused on quality. As you can  see, our leasing performance has been very strong. There's healthy demand for our space and we're signing  deals on average 12% ahead of ERV, showing that we are on the right side of polarization.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: So despite more than doubling the ERV of our committed pipeline since March, speculative development  exposure remains at just 4% of the portfolio. We have costs to go on this committed pipeline of £446 million. 85%  of this is covered by residential receipts to come on Clarges, two-thirds of which are already contracted.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: For a moment, let's look at these developments in the context of our LTV of 27%. If you strip out the book value of  these committed and near-term developments, then the rest of the portfolio carries an LTV of just 22%. Chris will  talk more about future developments, including Canada Water.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: And the second thing, which really stands and will stand the company in great shape over and above the  financials has been her focus on sustainability, which is really, as you know, built into the way the company thinks  about it, and that's in no small part down to Lucinda's focus and attention. So thank you very much for all the hard  work. We look forward to working with you over the next period, but also wishing all the well for the future.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Canada Water is a large scale, ground up, and mixed-use opportunity. That is very unusual. But Canada Water is  by no means our only opportunity. As Lucinda said, we've doubled our commitment with development pipeline in  the last six months. It now stands at 1.5 million square feet and, yet, as she said, speculative exposure remains  low at 4%. And we've already pre-let or under offer over 20% of our near-term pipeline. Our medium-term  pipeline, and that covers 3.2 million square feet, and that excludes Canada Water. So we're successfully  positioning the business for growth.

file: BLNDL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 14November2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: In Offices, we continue to rollout Storey as we further enhance our campus offer. At Canada Water, we've  submitted our planning application and signed our Master Development Agreement.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
