texts.text: In May, we signed a Master Development Agreement with the Council. We submitted our planning application for  the overall master plan, including 3,000 new homes. And we submitted a detailed application for three buildings in  the first phase, delivering nearly 600,000 square feet of mixed use space. As I said before, we hope to obtain  planning permission by the end of our financial year. That would enable us to start on site during 2019, but these  processes are inherently complicated. So, there's always a degree of risk in terms of timing. It's a great example  though of our overall strategic direction to become a specialist in mixed use spaces and something that we'll  deliver over the next 5 to 10 years.

BLNDL - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 15February2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-11.pdf

Green Lanes is mostly dominant with a sizable annual footfall of  around 5.5 million people with Zone A’s of between £50 and £80 per square foot, rents are highly       corrected transcript

file: BLNDL - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 9February2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: And we also expect to grow our retail development pipeline in the months and years ahead. As we said at the half  year, capital recycling will be a more important part of our investment strategy as we look both to cover some of  the costs of our development program and to take advantage of further investment opportunities as they arise.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 18May2010 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Chris Grigg, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody, welcome and thanks for coming.
texts.text: Moving to Offices, the changes have been equally significant, and one of the biggest factors has  been new technology. Buildings have to be capable of housing the technology for modern  communications, and they have to be flexible so you can change the configuration of the office  whenever you need to. They also have to take the heating and lighting load you’d expect in highly  specified air-conditioned offices. Most offices are now open plan and more densely occupied in  order to improve efficiency.

texts.speaker: Chris Grigg, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, everybody, welcome and thanks for coming.
texts.text: The estate enjoys an attractive self-contained environment and more recent buildings have been  completed to BREEAM excellent standard, which guarantees high quality and sustainability. It’s  also close to a number of major public transport interchanges. As you can see, the estate has  attracted a broad mix of tenants, including oil companies, ad agencies, financial services and  government.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 23May2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Chris Grigg, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, and thanks for coming. I’m pleased to report a strong set of results this morning.
texts.text: In offices, we’ve carried out new lettings, lease renewals and rent reviews on almost 900,000  square feet, which represents 13% of the portfolio, and occupancy rates increased from 93% to  98%, as we let out most of our remaining space in recently completed developments. We took a  13% share of last year’s high quality lettings in Central London as a result. These lettings were  more than 11% ahead of ERV, demonstrating the quality and appeal of our developments to  tenants. Our ability to deliver energy efficient buildings is also a competitive advantage in attracting  occupiers.

texts.speaker: Chris Grigg, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, and thanks for coming. I’m pleased to report a strong set of results this morning.
texts.text: Annualized gross rental income is 4.2% ahead of the prior year at £546 million. This slide is  designed to help you understand the effect of market rental growth on annualized gross rental  income. The top three lines show the accounting rental income growth in the like-for-like portfolio,  which increased by 1.4%. Retail improved by 2.3% benefiting from lettings and rent reviews across  the portfolio; a considerable number, given the economic climate facing retailers and this reflects  our relative negotiating strength.

texts.speaker: Chris Grigg, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, and thanks for coming. I’m pleased to report a strong set of results this morning.
texts.text: Barnstaple Shopping Centre should be seen in the same light. The property is dominant in its  location with limited competition. The environment inside of the shopping centre is attractive and  the rents are around £55 Zone A, highly affordable. The initial yield of more than 8% per annum is  sustainable and should grow steadily over time.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 21May2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Charles Sheridan Alexander Maudsley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Retail, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: With shoppers, we continue to improve what we offer, which we view as essential future-proofing if we are to  attract and retain the best retailers. Though we're upgrading the physical environment, and this improves footfall  in dwell time, we successfully obtained 62 planning consents. We've completed five superstore extensions totaling  95,000 square feet, and we have 142 capital projects underway.

texts.speaker: Charles Sheridan Alexander Maudsley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Retail, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: As a result, we're committed to developing the next generation of assets both by enhancing our existing portfolio  through continued improvement in the environment such as building out our planning consent at Surrey Quays  and through new development such as Whiteley, where we started on-site in September and we're already 68%  pre-let or under offer. We have a total of 1 million square foot of planning consents, which represents real  opportunity to create the sort of incremental value Chris talked about.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 14May2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Charles Sheridan Alexander Maudsley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Retail, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: During the year, we've also been busy upgrading the physical environment. We've gained 40 planning consents  and we've initiated five cinema and restaurant schemes. And over the year, on asset management, we've spent or  committed CapEx of almost £80 million, further enhancing the quality of our assets.

texts.speaker: Charles Sheridan Alexander Maudsley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head-Retail, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: We've got planning consent to add 100,000-square-foot extension to the existing 300,000-square-foot scheme.  And we'd hope to be on site next year. We've also started master planning the 15 acres site at Harmsworth Quay,  which medium-term has potential for a major mixed use redevelopment.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 14May2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: In recent years, we've positioned our business around several key trends. We identified these trends early. We   talked to you about them and bought and sold accordingly. Our first trend, occupiers are much more focused on  the environments in which they operate. It's a theme right across our business. It's why we talk about places  people prefer, but also why we're investing more in Paddington, at Broadgate, and at Regent's Place as well as at  Whiteley and at Glasgow Fort. These are campuses and estates where we can have a real impact on the overall  environment as well as on individual buildings.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 14May2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Canada Water is a great example of an exciting project, which touches all of these things. One of London's largest  single regeneration projects, we intend to create a truly mixed-use scheme that will really be something quite  special. I'll come back to the project in a bit. We'll follow our usual format today. I'll kick off. Lucinda will follow  up with the financials, and I'll wrap up with our usual look-forward.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Broader retail market fundamentals have improved. Consumers are now benefiting from lower oil prices as well as  economic recovery. And many retailers are doing better. Our leasing volumes have dropped a bit, reflecting the  fact that we're nearly full. And the quality and terms are better. We're attracting a broader range o f brands.  There's been strong demand from fashion and footwear and continued growth in F&B and Leisure. Overall,  lettings and renewals were signed nearly 9% above ERV over the course of the year, and our pipeline looks  healthy, too.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've been building large-scale extensions, adding leisure as well as food and beverage. These are income  producing from day one. We're also investing in relatively simple improvements like better car parkin g, landscape  – landscaping and Wi-Fi coverage. We're seeing tangible benefits in terms of footfall, dwell time and consumer  spend, and we expect this to flow through into rents over time.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The to-sell amount is significantly lower than 18 months ago as we successfully presold over half at Clarges during  the year. We fix construction costs at an early stage, and we've already fixed costs on over 85% of the current  program. It's worth mentioning that we're seeing construction costs increase as contractors re -establish profit  margins. Going forward, we're factoring cost growth of 6% per annum in our appraisals. Our near-term pipeline  consist of over 1 million square feet of London office space, all of which is adjacent to existing campuses and  benefits from wash over or optionality. Looking to the medium term, Chris will talk you t hrough Canada Water  shortly.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: It's a unique opportunity to regenerate a part of London that's been overlooked. We will use our development  skills and what we've learned from Broadgate, Paddington and Regent's Place to create a truly mixed used scheme  that's modern and technology-enabled. We'll create a new town center for the area, which is integrated with the  local community. And we'll take advantage of the existing water and green spaces to create a place which is in tune  with modern lifestyle. We acquired the last piece of the Jigsaw in February and we're currently in the master  planning phase. We'll submit planning in 2016.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 16May2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, we turn now to my third point, creating a high-quality portfolio for the future. We've shown you these long- term trends before. We're evolving our strategy in the light of them to ensure that our portfolio remains just as  relevant tomorrow as it is today. We want to own places where we can control the broader environment, exploiting  our mixed-use expertise to drive long-term performance. That means campuses or campus-light in London and  principally multi-let assets in retail.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Consumers expect much more. It's not just about F&B and leisure, authenticity and connection with local  communities are increasingly important. Natural light and open air also make a big difference so it's not just  about indoor environments. Hope you guys can still hear.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, why is British Land well-positioned in this environment? In short because we can deliver these stores to  retailers. Our multi-let portfolio enables retailers to reach over 60% of the UK's population through a network of  regional and local centers accounting for footfall of around 330 million people. Our places are not only highly  accessible they're also easy to adapt.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Glasgow Fort, as you know, is a large open-air regional center. We've expanded it and improved it, focusing a lot  on higher quality and better design. Believe it or not, that's what the new car park will look like.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Let me turn now to offices. Our three campuses account for over 70% of the business. We have a clear view how  we can grow and improve all three, helped by better infrastructure, particularly Crossrail, as well as more occupier  focus on clustering. We have significant opportunities for development to widen occupier appeal and introduce a  broader range of uses, more retail and F&B in particular. All of these will improve the environment and customer  experience, not just for our office occupiers, but the people who live, shop and relax there. In this context, we will  monetize places people prefer through improved rental growth, sustained high occupancy, alongside a more  diverse and resilient occupier base.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, a few words on Canada Water. Our long-term aim is to make it a great London campus, as you know, set  by Roger Madelin. We're still very much in the planning process, and we expect to submit planning in early 2017.  In the meantime, though, we are nearly £8 million of rent per annum, which helps cover near-term costs. Given  its scale and because it will be truly mixed use, we'll now report it separately, which we hope you'll find useful.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 17May2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: It's more than just creating great buildings though. At our campuses, we are creating great environments too,  driven by our understanding of what our customers want. Our research has emphasized the importance of great  transport links. Space to work collaboratively is increasingly a requirement. F&B and high-quality outdoor space  are also important.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Take Tollgate, our local center in Colchester. We invested £6 million enhancing the environment. We reconfigured  the car park and improved the public rail, including a new playground. We're now doing deals which crystallize  rental growth. The result this year, ERV was up 14%. There are similar stories across the portfolio. We completed  1.3 million square feet of retail lettings in the year, 11% ahead of ERV. That's more space on better terms to a  broader range of occupiers than a year ago.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: If you look at the more traditional classification, you'll see the shopping centers and shopping parts are also  closely aligned; more details in the appendix. These results again prove it's not just the biggest centers delivering  performance, it's about the quality of the environment and meeting customer needs.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Before I hand over to Lucinda, I'd like to say a few words on sustainability. We're recognized as industry leaders  in this area. It's also a fundamental part of how we deliver strategy. Our view of sustainability is broad. We focus  on four areas aligned to our strategic priorities. As you can see, well-being, community, future-proofing, as well as  skills and opportunity are what we look at.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Let me give you one example. Our research shows that people who feel a strong community association with the  retail center visit over 30% more often, and over 50% more likely to recommend. We've got a range in initiatives  to strengthen link with those communities. One of the most significant is our partnership with the National Literacy  Trust. Over 5,000 children took part in their Young Readers Program this year across 22 centers, bringing more  families and positive connection to our property. There are further great examples on this slide and across our  business. We've also set ourselves challenging targets such as our aim to reduce carbon, energy intensity by  55% over 10 years, reducing carbon emissions, and saving costs for us and our occupiers.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Chris, and good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with the results I'm presenting to you this morning,  especially in the context of the environment. As usual, I'll take you through the numbers and our performance and  the drivers of our valuation. I'll also talk you through developments. This year's performance reflects the continued  execution of our strategy, delivering assets which are appealing to occupiers and customers alike. We've sold  well, demonstrating capital discipline. We've increased our financial capacity so we have even more resilience,  and we can create value through our developments.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: All together, this means that from where we see things today, we're guiding to a small decline in next year's profits  and I note that that is captured in current consensus. This, together with the environment and our target payout  range, influenced the board's thinking in looking at the dividend for the forthcoming year, and we're proposing a  further 3% increase this year. This reflects confidence in our ability to grow income over the medium term.

texts.speaker: Lucinda M. Bell
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Over half of this is income-producing with a yield of 3%, principally Canada Water and Eden Walk. We've made  good progress in securing planning consents, and Chris talked about leasing appetite. Our approach will be  driven by pre-let interest and we will be disciplined with capital and risk.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Let me update you also on Canada Water. We're making good progress and our fourth public consultation period  is now underway. This image is from the consultation materials and shows just how close Canada Water is to  Central London. There's also a link in your book.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: So, whilst the environment is uncertain, we look forward with cautious optimism for our business. A high-quality  portfolio should continue to outperform. Our strong balance sheet provides flexibility. And over time, we can  enhance returns by allocating capital to the opportunities that we have created.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 17May2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: We know that to maintain our performance, we need quality assets in the right places. Let me remind you, in the  last four years, we've made £2.3 billion of retail asset sales that includes a £1 billion worth of superstores and  £0.5 billion of multi-let assets that don't fit our strategy. But we're also investing in assets that do. So let me give  you an example. At Fort Kinnaird, we opened a new leisure extension in 2015 with a seven-screen Odeon and a  range of restaurants. We've improved the environment and extended the trading hours. In 2016, we opened a  purpose-built store for Primark. All this represented an investment around £30 million of which our share was just  £12 million. This year we've made 86,000 square feet of lettings, 17% ahead of ERV. And we welcomed new  occupiers like PureGym and Wagamama. ERV growth is nearly 6% this year, and is also a head of IPD on a  three- and five-year base basis

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Looking further forward, we have a very significant opportunity at Canada Water. I'm pleased with our progress  here. We signed the master development agreement with Southwark Council last week and submitted our  planning application for the overall master plan and for three buildings in the first phase. That phase covers 1.8  million square feet with around 650 new homes. That's really complementary to our mixed use model. We're  continuing to engage with the local community. 10,000 people have visited our exhibition so far. And their views  remain critical to our approach going forward.

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: This engagement is part of our broader approach to sustainability. We are very mindful of our wider  responsibilities, which include delivering places which are energy efficient and low carbon. So we're pleased  today, our portfolio is nearly twice as efficient as it was in 2009. And we've maintained our leading sustainability  performance across a range of industries.

file: BLNDL - Q4 2019 Earnings Call 15May2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Christopher Grigg
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Today, you'll hear how our business and our strategy are delivering. I'll also make some specific comments about  how sustainability and community engagement are integral to our approach. This year, our financial performance  has been robust, to use a phrase. And we've made further good progress on our strategy. That's in the context of  an uneven market, where London offices were healthy but retail was challenging. We sold £1.5 billion of dry or  off-strategy assets, overall ahead of book. And our leasing performance was, again, excellent with 2.7 million  square feet let across the business, 1.6 million of that was in retail. Strikingly, that's the most in the last five years.

texts.speaker: Simon Carter
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Secondly, it's about providing the right mix of uses. We think of mix as a series of, if you like, building blocks. Our  skill is in combining them in the most effective way. So, Canada Water will look and feel very different to  Paddington. Equally, Broadgate is different to Regent's Place. But the underlying approach is both codified and  similar.

texts.speaker: Simon Carter
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Finally, a sustainability mindset has been integral to this process. The building will be BREEAM Excellent rated.  We're retaining over half of the original structure. And with efficient design and the use of low carbon materials,  we're saving 11,000 tonnes of embodied carbon, equivalent to [ph] heating empowering (00:25:20) almost 3,000  homes per year.

texts.speaker: Simon Carter
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Sustainability and community focus have been high on our agenda for more than a decade. For example, [ph]  we've more (00:25:34) than half our carbon intensity over that period and our portfolio is 44% more energy  efficient. We'll be similarly ambitious going forward. We're looking at the use of lower carbon materials. For  example, at our Storey building in Haggerston, we're using cross-laminated timber and we'll use that again.  Clearly, sustainability and corporate responsibility in its broadest sense have moved up the national agenda. And  I know it's a growing priority for many of our shareholders, our occupiers and frankly our own people.

texts.speaker: Simon Carter
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: So, let me assure you. It will continue to be a key area of focus for us because being considerate about the  environment and the local communities is part of how we run every aspect of our business from our developments  to the way we manage our properties. We set out some examples on the slide. To be clear, we've been publishing  detailed sustainability accounts since 2002. And our reporting has been commended by EPRA for seven  consecutive years.

texts.speaker: Simon Carter
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, The British Land Co. Plc
texts.text: Of course, looking forward, we will focus more on build to rent. Back in November, we said we were in exclusive  negotiations to acquire an operator. That didn't result in a deal. But Residential remains an important part of our  strategy. As you know, we've got a number of opportunities in our portfolio. Canada Water, where we have plans  for 3,000 homes, is the largest single part of that.

file: BMEL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 17November2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, these heat maps or this store density map gives you a picture of where we are today. The one on the right is the  position as of the period end just being reported on, as of the end of the first half. And as you see, we now have 472  stores. So what is hopefully evident from that map is that large part of the country are deeply underrepresented or  underpenetrated by B&M, and indeed even within what you might consider are heartland of the Midlands,  Yorkshire, South Wales, there's still plenty more penetration to be had, which brings me, of course, to what have  we been doing over the last six months in terms of the 47-store openings that you saw on the earlier slide.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The market's competitive. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to work out, for the first half of this current quarter, the  unusually mild temperatures have been challenging. Being blunt, if you have on your shelves de-icer, hats, gloves,  scarves, electric heaters, 13.5 tog duvets, blankets, if the weather outside is 15 degree Celsius, 16 degree Celsius, it's  going to be a hard sell. So yes, it's been a challenging start to the current quarter, but I think that is the case for  most retailers out there with seasonal products.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to our German business, all going to plan. Opening more stores and just increased distribution capacity,  all going on track. Ironically, the mild weather which is also taking place in Germany right now is actually good for  all the construction site where the warehouse expansion is taking place. So, the construction manager is actually  happy with the current weather. To put into the chase, we're confident of meeting your full-year expectations of  our earnings.

file: BMEL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 15November2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Simon Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: Mr. and Mrs. Smith in Birmingham are behaving exactly today as they were a year ago, notwithstanding the  outcome of that June referendum results. And what we are saying to is that when you look at weekly trading over  the half, actually the patterns are just the usual patterns of when the public holidays or what's the weather, when  are the school holidays, as opposed to any shifting consumer sentiment.

texts.speaker: Simon Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: You'll all know that our peer group quite often are delighted with the two- to three-year payback on the CapEx cost  of opening our new stores. Ours is eight months and if we include the positive working capital that our business  model requires, it's still a very attractive 15-month. Just to put that into context, at the time of the IPO, since then  we've opened, I don't know 150 stores or something, that number was 14 months, it's now 15 months. Part of that  is a rounding error. But actually, the other part of it, I'm happy to share, is that, within the cost of fitting out our new  stores, it's just inched up a fraction deliberately because of two or three things that we wanted to do at a higher  level. For example, we now use LED lighting rather than old fashioned fluorescent tubes, that has a higher upfront  CapEx cost, but of course, I'm sure you're aware, over a five year, ten year period, it reduces your energy bill.  Similarly, point of sale signage. We've just upped our game slightly, modest £40,000, £50,000 per store, just as  we open those larger stores, thinking about, we absolutely looked the part.

file: BMEL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 14November2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: But what's changed in the intervening period is that of our current pipeline, well over half in fact are new builds are  very extensively modeling as where the place is being practically rebuilt. And the case study we give you here  from last summer, August 2016, is a store that was developed as a brownfield site. There were just land there  previously. The developers built a store to our specification for us and when you'd get to do that, you get very  predictable returns. It's the ideal size, it's got car parking, it might have a garden center.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: Turning now to Germany, where as you heard, the business grew by 11% in euros. And I know analysts and  investors hate to hear about the weather. And I feel deeply uncomfortable talking about the weather but the  unfortunate reality is, is that in our German business that peak period is the spring/summer garden season. They  sell a lot of fresh plants and flowers, and a lot of products for the gardening enthusiasts. And the harsh reality is  that this particular year in Germany for the first time in the four years we've owned this business, it was a  washout/freeze-out. And as a consequence, you sell less gardening and plants, but also your footfall goes down  because the reason for visiting the [ph] above (26:29) store doesn't exist on the basis that the shopper doesn't  want to do a bit of [indiscernible] (26:34) around the garden that weekend.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: And whatever the economic climate, the British consumer wants Heinz, they want Kellogg's, they want Cadburys,  and they want Coca-Cola. Not all of them wants a German me-too copy or indeed a Big Four own-label  proposition. The British consumer watches TV, consumes a lot of advertising and marketing from very bright  brand-leading – leading-brand FMCG and food companies. And Heron, like B&M, gives them what they want.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: So, just to wrap up, in terms of outlook for the full year, the remainder six months of this financial year, I would  remind you that value is where the consumer wants you to be. Now, whether that's ALDI, [indiscernible] (35:36)  Primark or ourselves, we just think it's a good place to position yourself in the current economic climate. And as a  point of detail, we can share with you that food and FMCG is really performing strongly because of its very clear  price proposition.

file: BMEL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 13November2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Paul Andrew McDonald
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: A little bit of noise around – the other factors that we see in terms of transport and distribution costs, I'll talk a bit  more on the cost slide, since there's a little bit of pressure around – particularly around wages and fuel cost  increases that we've seen.

texts.speaker: Paul Andrew McDonald
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: So, effectively, once you kind of sell through that stuff, we brought through – we brought forward some of our  Autumn Winter products which clearly sells less well at that particular time of the year given the temperature was  still 80 degrees. But equally, we're [indiscernible] (00:07:55) gross margin, equally it's been hugely beneficial for  the cash gross margin.

texts.speaker: Paul Andrew McDonald
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: In terms of the gross margin performance, overall group margins, flat with last year. Although actually, broken  down into the individual components of that is that – in terms of the core B&M business, actually, we've seen  gross margin growth of 53 basis points. And that is predominately almost entirely as a result of that very strong  sell-through on kind of Gardening. But even on other areas, be it kind of things like paddling pools, water pistols,  all those, anything which is outdoor-related sold through very, very quickly. And therefore, we were able to  achieve a lot more sales at kind of full price compared to the prior year.

texts.speaker: Paul Andrew McDonald
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: Although equally, I refer to kind of transport and distribution area, and probably the one area that we are seeing a  headwind is really – is on transport and distribution. Fuel prices are increasing significantly higher than last year.  And also in terms of kind of colleague wages, again, when we were starting to see some inflationary pressures  particularly in transport and distribution.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: And what these products on the right-hand side are trying to get across is that there are three messages. First of  all, we had a great record season on outdoor living, barbecues, paddling pools, patio sets. Like it or not, our  homewares and indoor adornment isn't particularly attractive to consumers when you've got a record summer.  There won't be outdoor stuff. They're spending their money on outdoor living. And so, that has been sluggish.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: In a nutshell, for a sum of money that represents something like four months' worth of our EBITDA, we were able  to acquire 2.5 million square feet of retail space and established working distribution center along with these IT  and head office processes that allow us to enter the French market in a really interesting way at relatively low cost  and certainly a lot more quickly than we could have done on a greenfield basis where you're opening up one first  store at a time.

file: BMEL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 28May2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Notwithstanding the relatively flat marketplace, there are also things that we can do inside our business to sell  health. A nice example of that would be our own label program you see on the top right hand side of this page  whether its seasons harvest or ocean fresh. We can do on label as well as the rest of them.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So in terms of the building blocks, what we mean by that is in terms of the stores estate, as we receive the keys to  these new stores, we are spending more money on them to make sure that they're consistent in how they appear,  that they're very strongly branded as B&M. Remember, we don't do any advertising. So our advertising is our  stores. And, of course, we're making sure that they are light right, easy to shop, and whether that's LED lighting or  increasing the looks levels, we're doing what's right to make sure that this business is built to last.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have a policy of constantly investing in our existing store estate, and over the last 12 months invested just shy  of £7 million to make sure the stores are fit for trade. One of the positives of our stores, of course, is that they're  not particularly complicated places. They don't have complex or sophisticated air conditioning, they're pretty  straightforward to maintain. And as a consequence, the recurring maintenance CapEx for our store estate is  relatively modest, but it's something that we make sure happens.

file: BMEL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 25May2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Roberts
texts.profession: UK-Operations Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: So with the weather being very bright for this weekend, if they want to bring in a certain product whether it'd be  gardening or soft drinks, they can. And so that really gives us, I think, a real advantage against our competitors.  But it's also important to motivate that team and to recognize them. And we've pushed on with reward and  recognition during this period. We've improved our induction into our business. We've also identified that we have  top 50 managers within our organization that make a huge contribution to our weekly revenue. And so we're  working with them very closely allowing them to help to shape and make decisions in terms of the way that we go  forward this year. And if you were to add up their knowledge, it would run into hundreds of years. So, we're really  trying to tap into that group.

texts.speaker: Martin Roberts
texts.profession: UK-Operations Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: So the weather is bright out there as Simon said, I love it when it's bright. It makes me happy in terms of the  sunshine and this year's no different. We have over 500 gardening lines within our seasonal offering this year.  Again, almost some of the processes we've improved, we've rolled gardening out in 10 phases and you might ask  why? Well phase 1 is all about what the customer wants. So, at the beginning of the season, the customer wants  grass seeds, they want chemicals, they want propagation.

texts.speaker: Martin Roberts
texts.profession: UK-Operations Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: It's not rocket science, that's how we do it. We run it logically right into the final phase, which is phase 10, which is  all about outside furniture. And so, it allows the stores to receive it, merchandize it out and do it in a really great  way. We've also focused on that extra value packaging, particularly around solar, which has helped us manage  the currency effect. And, I think equally, we've done a great job, Simon talked about the 130 buyers running  around the world. But they really have done an amazing job on backing winners and keeping on trend.

texts.speaker: Martin Roberts
texts.profession: UK-Operations Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: And, if you're not aware, solar is still huge, huge for the customer, is on the top of their shopping list and if you go  to friends or family, solar seems to be everywhere and it continues to be a really important part of the seasonal  offering along with faux rattan and though some of you might not be familiar with it, but I'd encourage you to  embrace it.

file: BMEL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 30May2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Jun-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Paul Andrew McDonald
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: In terms of just a little bit more color around the kind of core B&M sales, yet again, obviously just under 5% LFL  sales growth. If you just look at Q4, actually in Q4, the LFL was flat, and very much the case is if you look at the  first two months of Q4 January and February combined, it's kind of close to 3.3% and certainly [indiscernible]  (00:08:12) very cold weather and snow in March impacted sales, ahead of that all important kind of [indiscernible]  (00:08:19) the guiding range and et cetera, the sales in March were certainly more challenging.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: But I'd actually put that in perspective because what that slight positive number equates to for the average UK  household is only £2.63 a week more than a year previously, so, less than the price of a cup of coffee in a café.  And so, in that concept, that slightly more benign environment isn't exactly going to drive those shoppers rushing  to Harvey Nichols or Selfridges, we say that they're going to be just as drawn to a discount proposition like B&M  as indeed they would be to Aldi.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: And, actually, I'm happy to share with you that the minus 6%, the underperformer is gardening and plant. It was a  wet summer. We can't control that side of our business. But the great thing about the B&M model is that you could  have a wet summer, but you still got plenty of other things to sell. And one final tidbit for you, one of the best  performers there, one of the best categories was stationery. So, we have the versatility in our business model to  roll with the punches the weather might send us.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: And, actually, what that tells us is that we should just carry on rolling out but actually owing to do is patiently wait  until we've got the chilled and frozen distribution capacity of our own rather than relying purely on the Heron  facilities in Hull. So, what we're updating is that we're going to carry on doing another 10 stores or so, but until  Bedford is operational we're then going to pause until that facility can service the B&M stores and that facility can  do about 300 B&M's. And once that's live, the ambient volume is going to that facility will allow us to repurpose  one of the existing northwest of the UK buildings into chilled and frozen which will then allow us to deploy  nationally.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: But crucially, as you heard earlier, this facility will be the first B&M facility that will have frozen and chilled  compartments within the warehouse.

texts.speaker: Sundeep Arora
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, B&M European Value Retail SA
texts.text: So, the underperformance last year is very identifiable as being largely the gardening and plants department. And  for those who've watched the weather in Germany, they've had a good start to the year. The sun has been  shining and those departments have traded extremely strongly compared to the washout last year. And so, whilst  there's still a lot more to do, a lot more change over this coming financial year, we remain as committed as ever to  the ultimate success of our German business. And indeed, this year, this financial year, we will be opening  another 10 new stores.

file: BMW - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 5May2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: For this, we are breaking new ground and building some necessary foundation. Here are just three  examples of our efforts. First, tapping into new sales channels; second, zero emission e-mobility;  and third, a sustainable production of future mobility concept.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: On to first point, this aspect deals with new growth potential and includes the business opportunity  of selling engines through third parties. We entered into an exclusive partnership with Carbon  Motors Corporation in the United States. This deal includes our commitment to deliver over 240,000  high-efficiency diesel engines with BMW Advanced Diesel technology, to be used in U.S. law  enforcement cars from 2013 to 2019.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: Regarding the second point, our ideas about future mobility primarily focus on electric power. Our  global field test with the MINI E has been a great success; I have really to say has been a great  success. In fact, a passionate international MINI E community has already developed.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: The BMW ActiveE will take the idea of practical everyday use even further. The test fleet will be  launched in several countries, among them China. Just a week ago we signed a cooperation  agreement with the Chinese government and local energy suppliers. Another project in the pipeline  for China is the launch of a so-called New Energy Vehicle. This is to be developed and produced  locally together with our joint venture partner, Brilliance. Because mobility of this kind exists without  borders, we need global standards.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: In Europe, we need to define the rules for a single e-mobility market. This is the crucial first step  before we can responsibly allocate the resources needed to manufacture these technologies on a  production scale. Key regulatory issues in this field are, technological requirement on vehicle and  infrastructure, the responsibility in the value chain regarding the environmental impact, and the  classification of different drive concepts. All these points have been raised in our meeting with the  German Chancellor on Monday.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: The fact is the BMW Group is determined to continue to drive the development of e-mobility with its  breakthrough innovations. The development of new drive systems is part of efficient dynamics and  consists of the full range of cars, from fuel-efficient combustion engines to hybrid drives and plug-in  hybrids, as well as our Megacity Vehicle. The Megacity Vehicle will be our first series-produced e- car. It will be launched in 2013 as a BMW sub-brand.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: And finally my third point. In April, we announced in Seattle that we would build a joint venture  carbon fiber plant with an investment volume of €100 million for the first stage. Carbon fiber  reinforced materials will play an important role in the serious production of our Megacity Vehicle  and other vehicle concepts.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schöberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: We are convinced that future mobility concepts also need to be sustainable produced, the BMW  Group is creating a whole new meaning of sustainable production. Now, others are following our  lead in this area.

file: BMW - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 4May2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schoberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schoberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: In the past decade, we laid a solid foundation for today’s competitive advantage with  EfficientDynamics. And back in 2007 we charted the roadmap for our development up to the year  2020 by launching our Strategy Number ONE. We intend to shape future mobility by using our  strong financial footing and continuing to innovate. As we see it, this includes the following aspects:  to maintain our technological lead in the field of sustainable drive systems with both combustion  and electric motors, to pool the most promising expertise within the company, and to provide  customers with attractive mobility services.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schoberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schoberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: Here are four examples. First, we are a major driving force in the field of e-mobility. Beginning in  the fall, customers in the U.S. will be able to lease the electric BMW ActiveE. In Shanghai, we  presented our BMW e-car from China for China. It is a plug-in hybrid based on the BMW 5 Series  long version. In all-electric mode, this car has a range of 50 kilometers.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schoberl, Corporate and Intergovernmental Affairs
texts.profession: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. This is Maximilian Schoberl, Director of Corporate Affairs. I
texts.text: Right now, we are cautiously optimistic about the U.S. market. But there are still a number of  factors, such as rising oil prices that point to possible volatility. A downturn in the economy would  also have a negative impact on the used-car market. We remain cautious about European markets.  In particular, the debt crisis among southern European members of the Eurozone implies a certain  risk of volatility for the coming months.

file: BMW - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 3May2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The BMW Group continues to benefit from the decisions we made as part of our Strategy Number ONE back in  2007. And today, we are clearly looking far ahead again. In 2016, we aim to sell over 2 million cars. We also aim to  generate sustainable profits. This means a goal to achieve an EBIT margin in the Automotive segment in the range  of 8% to 10% over the long-term. So far, almost no car company has managed to achieve this performance for a  longer period of time.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Political regulations around the world affecting the automotive industry remain on the agenda. Specifics vary from  country to country. In China, the government is strongly pushing for electrification. In the U.S., the government  has established CO2 emission targets for 2025. E-cars will be receiving credits. They will be factored in several  times when calculating a brand's fleet average.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: In Europe, the EU Commission will decide this summer about the European fleet average of 95 grams of CO2 per  kilometer as the target for 2020. At present, e-cars in the EU also receive a so-called supercredit. However, this  bonus is supposed to expire in 2015, which would prove challenging.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: In order to meet the diverse CO2 emission targets, we are consistently pursuing the development of future  technologies. Our goal for 2020 is to reduce our fleet's CO2 emissions by 50% compared with the mid-1990s. So,  what steps are we taking? We continue to invest in efficient dynamics, as well as in plug-in hybrids and e-cars. We  have signed a cooperation agreement with Toyota Motor Corporation. Together, we want to take the lithium-ion  battery technology to the next level.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The carbon fiber for the BMW i family is produced in our new hydroelectric-powered plant in Washington State.  We are producing car body parts from this carbon fiber, as well as components for the eDrive in Bavaria. We will  then build our e-cars in Leipzig. That way, we strengthen Germany's position in the fields of industrialization, e- mobility and light-weight construction.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are taking advantage of our earning power to make targeted investments. Our development spending on  lightweight construction and alternative price technologies will secure us a stronger market position in the future.  Our vehicles will need to become even more efficient to meet stricter CO2 standards worldwide. Over the full year,  this will result in additional expenditure between €800 million and €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: However, we are well aware of the uncertainties in the market. We are responding to competitive pressure in  Europe with an attractive product lineup. Nevertheless, increased competition could have an adverse impact on  pricing in specific markets. A number of growth markets are characterized by market regulation measures such as  import duties and special taxes. At the same time, we are taking the necessary steps in preparation for stricter  CO2 taxation.

file: BMW - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 2May2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: All of these developments pose risks to the economy and consumer spending and will affect our business  performance. As always, companies need the most reliable framework possible in order to plan for the future. But  this can only be achieved with parameters that are based on sound analysis. One example where this is clearly not  the case is the recent proposal by the European Parliament to tighten CO2 limits in Europe from 2025 on.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: This proposal was politically motivated and published without conducting any kinds of technical feasibility study.  The EU's 95-gram CO2 target for 2020 is already impossible to meet without the use of alternative drive  technology. The European Union must decide, as other countries have, whether or not it wants to combine  reductions in emissions and fuel consumption with boosting incentives for technologically advancements.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We will once again be making strategic recruitments this year. We are increasing staff numbers to capitalize on  the group's planned growth. We are also strengthening our expertise so that we have the know-how we need in key  future areas primarily e-mobility and carbon fiber. Accordingly, our workforce grew by about 5% as of the end of  the first quarter. We are firmly convinced that our investments today will benefit us tomorrow and beyond.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Looking ahead briefly to 2014, we have already shared a glimpse of what to expect with two totally new vehicle  concepts, the BMW Concept X4 and the BMW Concept Active Tourer. Returning to this year, 2013 will be  dominated by the start of series production of our ultra-sustainable BMW i family. Already this autumn, you will  all be able to experience a fully electric BMW i3 on the road, and it will be available to customers at the end of the  year.

file: BMW - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 6May2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Let me give you three examples. First, the BMW i3. The demand for our innovative electric vehicle is high. In  March alone, we sold 1,000 BMW i3 cars worldwide. Just a few days ago, the BMW i3 was launched in the U.S.  American customers are particularly open to new types of drivetrain. We expect the majority of BMW i cars to be  sold in the U.S. We especially focus on California as a relevant market for electric cars, as it is considered by  experts to be a trendsetter for the whole United States.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Just like the i3, the U.S. could become the key market for the BMW i8 as well. It is currently being tested by  international media at our press event in Los Angeles. With BMW i, lightweight technology plays a central role.  Carbon fiber is a material with a significant future in our industry, and we will also use it in other series models.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: It goes without saying, we monitor closely all the relevant trends in our environment and beyond, as well as  assessing the external challenges that have an effect on our business. Some of the questions we ask ourselves are:  what do customers expect of a leading mobility company today and beyond tomorrow? How do we remain at the  forefront of technological trends and create attractive services? How do we want to develop our brands further in  a timely manner so that we can win new customer groups without compromising on our brand identity? How can  we master the complexity arising from the many requirements and the growth targets we have set for ourselves?  And last but not least, what kind of company do we want to be in the future?

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The development of new low-emission and lightweight technologies and other measures to enhance fuel economy  remains our main focus. This R&D spending is designed to strengthen our future market position.

file: BMW - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 6May2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Overall, the BMW Group continues to offer our customers worldwide a very young product portfolio. In total, we  are launching 15 new models and model updates for BMW and MINI customers this year. Let me give you a few  examples. The new BMW 2 Series Convertible has been available since February. March saw the market launch of  the updated BMW 1 Series. The model range includes BMW's new CO2 Champion, the 116d EfficientDynamics.  Fitted with a 3-cylinder engine, it needs 3.4 liters of diesel per 100 kilometer and emits 89 grams of CO2 per  kilometer.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The BMW Group is addressing the challenges ahead for the whole automotive industry. In particular, intense  competition in mature markets, normalization of the Chinese market, the enormous investments needed to lower  CO2 emissions. We consider these aspects in our strategic alignment. We adjust our course to take advantage of  opportunities for the company. Our target remains sustainable, profitable growth.

file: BMW - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 3May2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: An M vehicle for the luxury class was something many of our customers wanted, and the BMW 7 40e iPerformance  will show how we transfer BMW i 'born electric' technology into our Series vehicles within the BMW brand.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Our plug-in hybrid BMWs will be under the label of BMW iPerformance. This summer, customers will already  have five iPerformance models to choose from. This means we will offer a plug-in hybrid for every class, from  compact to luxury.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Electrification of our vehicle fleet is a key element of Strategy NUMBER ONE > NEXT. A greater proportion of all- electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles within our fleet is essential in order to meet Europe's ambitious CO2 emission  targets for 2020.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: In the first quarter of this year, we sold over 5,000 BMW i3 cars. I am also delighted that the German government  is taking concrete steps to support electric mobility. I'm optimistic that this will increase the demand for electric  cars. In the long term, and we're convinced of this, alternative drive trains will be an integral part of individual  mobility. And we want to be clearly the leader in the electric mobility.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: In terms of technology, we are working parallel on optimizing our combustion engines with EfficientDynamics  NEXT and also on electrification, with battery packs and fuel cell. At the beginning of 2020, our BMW iNEXT will  unite the full range of future features: autonomous driving, digital connectivity, intelligent lightweight  construction and next-generation electric mobility.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Mobility service and digital services are already a part of our business model today. DriveNow, ParkNow and  ChargeNow are just three examples. Especially in major cities, customers need seamless and individual mobility  solutions. For sustainable urban mobility, the USA is our pilot market. In early April, we launch ed our car-sharing  service, ReachNow, in Seattle. The number of people who have registered has far exceeded our expectations.  ReachNow is modeled on DriveNow in Europe. Our partner for this service in the USA is a technology start-up  called RideCell.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The U.S. auto market has reached a high level overall. The trend towards SUVs continues in the North America.  Partly due to low oil prices. The BMW Group set the right course early on and is now in the process of expanding  the production capacity for X models. We have taken into account the changes in demand for Sedans and adjusted  our planning. The measures we have implemented will have a positive impact on the sales situation in the second  half of the year.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Further electrification of our vehicle fleet is another priority: The 3 Series and the 2 Series Active Tourer were  released onto the market as plug-in hybrid models in the first quarter. This will be followed by the plug-in hybrid  variant of the new 7  Series in the summer, which will strengthen our company's competitive position and  underline its focus on sustainable mobility.

file: BMW - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 4May2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: I would like to say a few words about all three of these areas. Let's start with the first topic. You know our targets  for the financial year 2017: A new all-time high for deliveries at group level and a new record for group profit  before tax. We expect the EBIT margin in the Automotive segment to remain within the range of 8% to 10%. And  we have also set ourselves the goal of selling 100,000 electrified vehicles. After the first quarter, we are well on  track.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Electrification of our portfolio is a clear priority. We know from experience that customers prefer to have more  choices. In the first quarter, we delivered twice as many BMW plug-in hybrids, BMW i3s and i8s than in the same  period of last year. Almost 20,000 customers opted for alternative drive train. This means that electrified vehicles  already account for more than 3% of BMW Group total sales. When the new MINI Countryman plug-in hybrid  arrives in summer, we will have a total of nine electrified models in showrooms.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Our electric BMW i3 was designed for urban mobility from the ground-up. Unlike series-produced models with a  combustion engine, the sales curve for the BMW i3 is continuing its upward course. In the first quarter alone,  sales figures were up 50% over the same period of last year. Of course, the extended range also contributed to  this. As I have said before, electro-mobility is a marathon. New models will provide us with further momentum; in  2018, the BMW i8 Roadster; in 2019, a pure electric MINI; in 2020, a pure electric BMW X3. Our efforts will  continue to require extensive investment.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: When it comes to drive technologies, we prefer a broad and flexible approach. It is still too early for accurate  predictions about which drivetrain will prevail in which marketplace and when. That's why it's even more important  for us to stay quick and ready to react. Strategy NUMBER ONE > NEXT will take EfficientDynamics to the next  level, EfficientDynamics 2.0. We will continue to make our combustion engines even more efficient.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: An important factor remains the aerodynamic optimization of all our models. By 2025, all our vehicles with  combustion engines will be fitted with electric ELV recuperation systems. This will bring a further CO2 reduction of  around 5% to 7%. We are working on fuel cells for longer distances with our partner, Toyota. The modern diesel  drivetrain is also a component of EfficientDynamics 2.0. There is much being said about diesel. However, we  prefer a more fact-based and rational discussion. I would now like to say something based on the facts.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: One thing is certain: Diesel plays a key role in Europe's ambitious climate policy. Clean diesel vehicles of the Euro  6 generation use at least 25% less fuel than comparable petrol models. Therefore, they emit at least 15% less  CO2. One thing is clear. It will not be possible to meet the EU's strict CO2 targets for 2020 without diesel. We will  continue to need clean diesel drivetrains in the future. That's why we equip our new models with the most modern  technologies for exhaust gas treatment. As the number of Euro 6 vehicles in the market grows, diesels will  account for less and less of overall particulate matter and NOx emissions.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Particulate matter is anyway only an issue for diesel cars over 10 years old without a particle filter. Particulate  emissions from engines only account for a very small percentage of the total volume. However, in public  discussions, air quality alert and banning diesels vehicles are often mentioned in the same breath. Without the  fact, the debate about diesel creates uncertainty, especially for the owners of older diesel models.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Additionally, incentives could be used to motivate car owners to switch to new technologies, like electro-mobility  or to newer, more efficient combustion engines. Big cities benefit from an intelligent mix of solutions. For example,  improved traffic flow; support for e-mobility and charging infrastructure; promotion of car sharing with modern,  low-emission vehicles; less congestion and easier parking through digitalization; as well as environmentally  friendly buses and taxis.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: As a global company, we need planning reliability for our investment decisions. The same applies to customers  and their purchasing decisions. But how is anyone supposed to make a decision when every country has different  regulations and every big city has its own concept for low-emission zones? Planning reliability comes from joint  solutions. Individual mobility and diesel needs a coherent framework both at a national level here in Germany and  across the European Union.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Second, electro-mobility. We are strengthening this important future technology at our home base in Germany.  We have the highest level of in-house development in electric engines, power electronics, and high voltage  batteries, of any of our competitors. We are now electrifying all our brands and model series. We are creating  flexible architectures for both conventional and electrified drivetrains. This enables us to meet the varying needs  and demand in the markets. Already today nine locations worldwide product nine electrified models, eight of  which are plug-in hybrids.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Peter
texts.profession: Member of the Board of Management, Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: I would like to emphasize, profitable growth remains our focus. This strategy has paid off over the years. The  BMW Group has been one of the world's most profitable car companies for years. At the same time, we strive to  remain a leader in new technologies and innovations, with a clear focus on electro-mobility. We remain firmly  committed to pursuing these goals in the future.

file: BMW - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 4May2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are tackling several key areas at the same time. First, we will continue to expand the electrification of our  portfolio. Second, we will be launching various new models. And third, we are accelerating our autonomous  driving activities.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: First, a few words about electrification. I have often said that the e-mobility growth curve is exponential. This is  confirmed by our sales figures for the first quarter of 2018 compared with the first three months of last year.  Between January and March, we sold over a third more electrified vehicles. Sales of our BMW iPerformance plug- in hybrids are up more than 40%. Our MINI Countryman with plug-in hybrid drivetrain is also in strong demand.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: I have stated our goal for the full year very clearly. We aim to sell at least 140,000 electrified vehicles this year.  Our new models will help us achieve this. I am talking, of course, about the BMW i8 Roadster and the revised  BMW i8 Coupé, which will be launched in May. Both come with the fourth generation of the BMW eDrive  technology for plug-in hybrids. This enhances significantly their electric range. You already know that we plan to  offer 25 electrified models by 2025, 12 of them pure electric.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: You can already see what lies ahead this year. We will be presenting three all-electric concept vehicles, our new  technology flagship, the BMW iNext; the BMW i4 as a four-door coupé; and the first fully-electric vehicle of our  core brand will be the BMW iX3, which I presented in China this April.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Through this, we are sending a strong signal for sustainable mobility in China. From 2020, we will be producing  our first fully-electric BMW, the iX3, in Shenyang, which will be the start of using pure electric drivetrains within  our core brand. The iX3 will be the first to use our fifth-generation electric drivetrains. Our customers in China  already have six electrified models to choose from. And they also have access to the world's largest network of  public charging points. By the end of this year alone, there will be 80,000 ChargeNow charging points in more  than 100 cities.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Our iNext, which we will launch in 2021, will be fully electric and completely connected. It will not only be partially  autonomous, but also completely safe. The iNext will be followed by a whole range of additional highly automated  models. For this reason, we are combining all our expertise in vehicle connectivity and automated driving at the  new campus. We will also be introducing new forms of collaboration in a highly flexible working environment,  designed for quick decision-making.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Peter
texts.profession: Member of the Board of Management, Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Overall, used car prices are trending downward slightly in international markets, as expected. We place a strong  emphasis on proactive risk management. We evaluate our portfolio on a regular basis, so that we can make  adequate provisions for our business risks at all times.

file: BMW - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 7May2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl
texts.profession: Director-Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: In the luxury segment, we are gradually realizing our strategic goal of significantly increasing sales and revenues.  The 8 Series Convertible and Gran Coupé are ready for market launch. Many customers are eagerly ordering the  new X7. The incoming orders both for markets overseas as well as Europe are exceeding all of our expectations.  As part of our model offensive, we will continue to introduce sustainable drive technologies across the fleet, as set  out in our Strategy NUMBER ONE > NEXT. In the first quarter alone we sold more than 27,000 electrified  vehicles.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl
texts.profession: Director-Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: And, by the end of this year, we will have a 0.5 million electrified vehicles on the roads. In Europe, our percentage  of electrified vehicles delivered is 3 times the industry average. In 2018, we were the market leader for  electrification in both Europe and Germany, not just in the premium segment, but in the market as a whole. We  plan to maintain a leading position going forward, both in Europe and worldwide. To do so, we will continue to  introduce more electrified models across all brands and model series. This also includes Rolls-Royce and BMW  M. Plug-in hybrid technology will be a focus for us in 2019; the 3 Series, X3, X5 and the 7 Series all come with a  fourth generation of our electric drive train technology. This gives these vehicles an increased electric range of up  to 80 kilometers. Our fully-electric BMW i3 has been on the market for about six years now. During this time, its  range has doubled. This is one of the reasons it continues to post such strong growth.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl
texts.profession: Director-Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: MINI fans will also be soon able to go fully electric. Production will begin this year for the MINI Electric. Pre- production test drives have been very well received by the media. As you know, the MINI Electric will be built in  Oxford; this also underlines our continued commitment to the UK. On the BMW side, we are expanding our fully- electric range with the addition of the iX3 from 2020 and the BMW i4 and iNEXT from 2021. By 2025, we will have  at least 25 electrified vehicles in our lineup, 12 of them pure electric.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl
texts.profession: Director-Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: As you can see, we are clearly not betting on any single technology. From my perspective that would be the  wrong approach. We are relying on a broad portfolio of technologies with flexible platforms for combustion  engines, plug-in hybrids, and electric drive trains. We're also conducting further research into fuel cells with our  partner Toyota. Over the long-term, drive trains with hydrogen fuel cells will offer greater local emission-free  range, with very short refueling times. These will complement our battery-electric vehicles. Every customer has  different needs and every market different business conditions. We can only achieve the flexibility needed for fully  sustainable mobility around the world by staying open to different technologies.

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schöberl
texts.profession: Director-Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
