What did we achieve between 2007 and 2012? We  have become more profitable. We have consistently moved forward with our EfficientDynamics Technology  program. By year-end 2012, our fleet was made up of 73 models with maximum CO2 emissions of 140 grams per  kilometer. In 2007, it was 27 models. We have invested €1.2 billion in training and professional development  programs for our employees in the last five years.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: There will be also a BMW 4 Series model for the first time. We have shown the BMW 4 Series Concept Coupé in  Detroit and the media response has been very positive. Having a clear strategy to 2020 leads us to look to the  future with confidence. We will break new ground in 2013 by putting electric cars into series production.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Already, the first pre-production BMW i3s rolled off the assembly line in Leipzig in January. This is a clear signal  to anyone who may still have had any doubts. The BMW i3 is definitely coming onto the market. It will be a reality  by late 2013. We will then be able to offer our customers a new dimension in driving pleasure. We've always  emphasized the need for emission-free cars in our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: This enables us to achieve the long-term regulatory requirements for CO2 emissions that apply to new cars in EU,  U.S., China and other countries. And true, megacities have no choice but to promote alternative methods of  mobility in the medium term.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are approaching the topic of electro-mobility holistically. In the manufacture of BMW i family, we are also  setting new standards. In the use of innovative material, in the careful use of resources and in industrialization of  electric mobility, we are revolutionizing how cars are made. It takes only half as long to make a BMW i3 compared  to a car of a similar size in our portfolio. Many customers have already expressed interest in buying a BMW i3.  Our car, they do not know these technologies they are not familiar with. What this tells me is that our customers  have phased in our knowhow and power of innovation.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Head-Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Within our core BMW brand, we offer a range of possibilities from emission-free cars in the BMW i family to  highly-efficient innovative BMW models and efficient high-performance cars in the BMW M range. All of this is  BMW. We will continue to chart a new course for our company and for our industry. That is how we define  premium. That's what makes us stand out. That's BMW. Thank you.

file: BMW - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20March2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: What you see next to me is the BMW i8. It embodies our company's strength. The BMW i8 is not only an  attractive plug-in hybrid sports car. It is also the world's first series vehicle featuring laser light. In the future, a  driver will be able to see not 300 meters, but 600 meters ahead in the dark. And the energy efficiency has  increased by 30%. This innovation will definitely benefit customer needs. The first BMW i8 cars will be delivered  starting in June, in Germany, the U.S., China, Japan, and other countries. Our dealers all over the world tell us,  they will easily be able to sell every single BMW i8 we produce.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Today, the BMW Group's fleet includes 39 models with CO2 emissions of less than 120 grams per kilometer. In  1995, our European fleet average still stood at 210 grams of CO2 per kilometer. In 2013, it was 133 grams of CO2  per kilometer, a reduction of 37%. By 2020, we want to reduce our fleet's CO2 emissions by half from their 1995  level.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The continuous investment in innovations ensures our long-term success. BMW i is an example of our innovative  strength in several areas: the vehicle concept consisting of a Life module and a Drive module; the industrialization  of carbon fiber in large-series production; and the application of especially sustainable production procedures.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The BMW i is currently being launched in various markets. Customer demand is exceeding our expectations. By  the summer, it will be introduced in the U.S., currently it's the most important market for electric cars.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: To date, we have invested about €600 million in our e-mobility network, thus creating 1,500 jobs. The  comprehensive use of carbon fiber underscores our leading position in the field of lightweight construction. We  are planning to apply this expertise also in other series models in the future.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We believe the electric motor is a future technology for zero-emission driving in urban areas. Battery technology  will continue to progress.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Our eDrive technology brings together the following technologies today: electric drive trains and low -emission  plug-in hybrids such as the BMW i8. When it comes to emission-free long-distance driving, however, electric cars  featuring hydrogen fuel cell technology offer great potential. Alternative drive technologies are key towards  meeting the global CO2 targets in 2020.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: As a leader of our industry, we believe we need to act as a role model in terms of sustainability. It is a crucial factor  in achieving long-term success. By 2020, we plan to reduce the resources needed to produce each vehicle by 45%  compared with 2006.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are working hard in preparation for stricter CO2 requirements after 2015, which represent a major challenge  for us. We are responding early and will continue to be a pioneer in this field. We maintained  our dual-track  approach in 2013. On the one hand, refining our combustion engines to make them even more efficient and  competitive; on the other, forging ahead with our development of new and alternative drive technologies.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The most important aspect here is e-mobility. In this area, we are refining both battery and fuel cell technology.  This will allow us to offer emission-free driving for different ranges over the medium term. Our goal is to maintain  the BMW Group's leading position in technology and efficiency in the future. This is a central aspect of our  premium concept. Lightweight construction and intelligent in-car connectivity were further focal points. We  expect our R&D ratio to be lower in 2014, closer in line with our target of 5% to 5.5% of rev enue, which we are able  to confirm for the period up to 2016.

file: BMW - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19March2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: The car next to me is just one ex ample of our innovative strength. The new BMW plug-in hybrid, it's an X5 as you  can see. The specs are impressive: 3.3 liters of fuel per 100 km; energy consumption of 15.3 kilowatt per hour; and  emissions of 77 grams CO2 per kilometre. This model benefits from the technology transfer from the BMW i  family. Our early commitment to sustainable mobility is paying off. Now, we are electrifying all our model series,  step by step. Nonetheless, our entire industry continues to face great challenges ahead. There a re, however,  opportunities as well for new business areas, new customer groups and further growth.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the German car manufacturers have delivered their part of the bargain. The ball is now in  the court of policy-makers, especially here in Germany. A new Electric Mobility Act is a step in the right direction.  But beyond that, we need a serious debate about the right tools to ensure Germany picks up the pace when it  comes to electric mobility. Other countries are already way ahead. Really, I would like to say way ahead. In China,  the BMW i3 is not subject to the restrictive procedure limiting licence plates in Shanghai, which reduces the cost  by over €10,000.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: In California, electric cars can use the Carpool Lanes on highways and they also get attractive financial incentives.  And Norway has a well-established charging infrastructure. Electric cars charge and park for free. There's also no  VAT or registration tax for such vehicles. The BMW Group strongly supports the building of a charging  infrastructure in China, the EU and the U.S. for private customers as well in the public domain. We are fostering  synergies between e-mobility and car sharing. The BMW i3 is about to join our DriveNow fleet, in London in  spring, in San Francisco from May, where it will replace the successful BMW ActiveE, in Hamburg, Berlin and  Munich from July. This is one way to improve the acceptance of electric cars and gain access to younger  generations.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Intelligent mobility services have been a central part of our strategy from the very beginning. In Germany,  DriveNow is already profitable and the number of users continued to grow. At the end of 2014, DriveNow had  about 390,000 registered customers and in early March, there were 420,000 members. New cities are joining the  program. Last year, we added London and Vienna and we are expanding now DriveNow further, adding ten cities  in North America and up to 15 cities in Europe. We hold strong in our belief that the future of mobility has to be  sustainable. The increasing political regulations on climate protection as well as continuing urbanization and all  its consequences are proof of this.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: The following key technologies are part of our roadmap to meet the increasing challenges of regulation: Efficient  Dynamics, hybridisation and electric mobility. At present, our European fleet average for emissions stand at 130- gram of CO2 per kilometre. You know where we come from. We come from 210 gram, we moved from 210 grams  to 130 grams since 1995. We are now applying our expertise and the experiences gained with BMW i to our  conventional models. The new BMW 7  Series, for example, will set new standards when it comes to intelligent  lightweight construction. And besides our technological advancement, our strategic market position is another  success factor.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: The new BMW 2 Series Convertible has been available since the end of February. And on the occasion of its tenth  anniversary, we completely revised the BMW 1 Series. Part of this model range is also BMW's new CO2 -champion.  The 116d needs just 3.4 liters of fuel per 100 kilometre and emits only 89 grams of CO2 per kilometre. Its three- cylinder engine was previously introduced in the BMW 2 Series Active Tourer. The new BMW 1 Series will arrive  at dealerships in late March.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: As a world first, the new BMW M4 Safety Car utilizes our innovative water injection technology. It provides a  significant increase in performance, while reducing fuel consumption and emissions. The benefit of our water  injection technology will soon be available for our M customers as well. This year our MINI brand will have an  exceptionally young portfolio. Last year, we launched the new MINI three-door model and 55 years after the first  MINI ever, we put the first MINI five doors on the road. In 2015, we will present the new MINI Clubman. The  concept car shows pretty much where MINI is headed. Since then, the management board has decided that MINI  will be concentrating in the future on five models, each with its own strong character. And MINI will offer  electrified solutions as well.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: My second point, as I see it, being a good corporate citizen means that how you produce is just as important as  what you produce. Since 2006, we have reduced resource consumption and emissions per unit produced by 45%  on average. And in 2014, we reached an important milestone. As a first, we procured more than half of the energy  we needed for production from renewable sources. Onto my third point, digitalization and connected services for  our customers. Digitalization is a major differentiator and growth driver, particularly for premium manufacturers.  For the BMW Group, connectivity is a given in our customers' everyday life. They expect our vehicles to provide  them with full access to the digital world around them. With ConnectedDrive, we have been offering connectivity  services for almost two decades now.

texts.speaker: Norbert Reithofer
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: With our Vision Zero, we are gradually implementing entirely collision-free driving. We recently presented our  new 360-degree collision prevention system in a BMW i3 at CES in Las Vegas. The system can reliably identify  obstacles and apply the brake in order to prevent accidents. Even today, we offer many driver assistance systems,  such as traffic jam assistant and active speed control. Our future models will be able to drive themselves in certain  situations, such as in parking garages. If desired, the car finds its own parking spot without the driver being  involved. We have shown this system with the BMW i3. And upon returning to the garage, drivers can summon  their car using a Smartwatch.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In 2014, the BMW Group rolled out the new Efficient Dynamics engine generation, further reducing new vehicle  fleet emissions. The modular engine system comprises highly-efficient three-cylinder, four-cylinder and six- cylinder drive trains with lower weight and turbo technology to ensure driving pleasure and dynamic driving  performance. Commonalities within the ultra-efficient engine family enable economies of scale and a high level of  flexibility. Plug-in hybrid technology, combining both combustion engine and electric motor, was implemented in  a series-produced vehicle for the first time in 2014 in the BMW i8. Additional models will be fitted with the  innovative eDrive system this year.

file: BMW - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 17March2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Our BMW Vision Next 100 offers a vision how we believe mobility in the next 30 years and beyond will develop.  The BMW i Vision Future Interaction here on stage shows you the first steps to realizing this. Both these vehicles  embody a new area of mobility at a time that will be characterized by sustainability, connectivity and automated  driving.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: The past year was marked by the new BMW 7  Series. The sixth generation of our flagship model is being well  received by both customers and the media. From its market launch in October 2015 to the end of February, 2016,  we sold more than 9,000 BMW 7  Series vehicles. The 7 Series is our beacon of innovation. Its Carbon Core  received the EuroCarBody Award 2015, the world's most prestigious recognition for innovations and car body  construction.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: We are now integrating the hybrid technology in additional model series, such as the BMW 2 and BMW 3 Series.  Hybrid drive also makes sense in the large vehicle classes. The new BMW 7 40e iPerformance is a dear example of  this. This car's figures are truly impressive. Fully electric range: 40 kilometers. Fuel consumption in the current  EU test cycle: 2.1 liters per 100 kilometers. And carbon emissions per kilometer: 49 grams.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Let us move on from our four wheels to two wheels. At present, BMW is the world's most successful premium  manufacturer of motorcycles and maxi scooters. Today's product range is more varied and more individual than  ever. By 2020, BMW Motorrad is planned to grow to 200,000 units. To achieve this, we are tapping into new  markets, launching motorcycles below 500 cubic centimeter, which are ideal for urban environment. With the G  310 R roadster, BMW Motorrad will launch its first product below 500 cubic centimeter in the second half of this  year. Spring, we will see the launch of the R nineT Scrambler, a lifestyle motorcycle based on the very successful R  nineT.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: R&D spending was concentrated on ramp-ups and new vehicle projects, hybridization and lightweight design.  With these investments, we are preparing our product portfolio for growing regulatory requirements. Our focus is  on even more efficient combustion engines and drive train electrification. Additional points included driver  assistance systems and connectivity.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Within a complex competitive environment, the cost competition will only intensify. Operational excellence is  imperative to being able to increase efficiency further and to invest into the future. When it comes to drive train  technology, for instance, we will continue to follow a multi-track approach that allows us to comply with the  increasingly strict legal regulations on emissions reductions all around the globe.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: The transformation of traditional mobility is a process. One of that will extend over a longer period of time, even  though the pace will increase exponentially over the course of this development. We are leading the BMW Group  into a new era. To this end, we leverage innovation technologies, comprehensive connectivity and zero -emission  mobility. All of these need to be industrialized, bearing in mind our business responsibilities, and in a sustainable  manner, which itself is another great challenge.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Let's move on to the third point, the expansion of BMW i. With BMW i, we have managed to very quickly create a  globally known brand that embodies sustainability. Since its introduction in 2013, we have delivered  more than  50,000 BMW i vehicles to customers. Today, the BMW i lineup has a larger market presence than any other  electric vehicle. BMW i assumes a key role as an enabler for our BMW core brand. BMW i attracts new customers  to BMW. BMW i gives easy access to electro-mobility as part of DriveNow. 20% of our car-sharing fleet is already  fitted with an electric drive. BMW i is also instrumental in tapping new sales strategies via new channels or  Internet orders.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Our viewpoint on e-mobility is clear. E-mobility delivers a solution to the demands of urban mobility today and  tomorrow. We are charting a clear course, and we will continue to do so. An additional i3 model will be offered  from the second half of this year on. Its battery capacity has increased by 50%, and we have also revised the  design.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: In the future, we will offer all BMW models with a plug-in hybrid drive under this label. From July onwards,  customers will be able to choose from a total of seven BMW models that are either fully electric or fitted with a  plug-in hybrid drive.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Additional electrified models are due out in the following years. One of them will be a MINI with a plug -in hybrid  drive and, of course, iPerformance customers will also benefit from the BMW 360° ELECTRIC offering, including  a wall-mounted rapid-charge box and ChargeNow. The world's largest network of public charging station.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: And a completely new i model is scheduled to follow early in the next decade. We call it BMW iNEXT. This highly  innovative model will be BMW i's new spearhead of innovation and technology. It will enable us to take BMW i to  the next level. In doing so, we rely on our experience in electro-mobility. The iNEXT will cover all aspects relevant  in the future. Autonomous driving, digital connectivity, intelligent lightweight construction, a trendsetting interior  and the next generation of e-mobility.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Over the last few years, we have consistently enhanced our efficient dynamics technology package and still see a  number of areas with significant potential for us. With EfficientDynamics NEXT, we are making the benefits of  this technology package even easier for customers to experience in our combustion-engined vehicles.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: Over the next 20 years, we will still have more than just the one type of the drivetrain system. The i3 and i8 have  made us a trendsetter in e-mobility. Over the next few years, we will be adding to our i family, with iPerformance  ensuring technology transfer into our Series model. To do this, we will offer electric models in nearly every BMW  Series. Our latest plug-in hybrids incorporate our third generation of modular electrification systems. And  development work is already underway on our fifth generation for 2020-plus, enhancing and electrifying our  conventional engines will allow us to continue meeting our CO2 targets even in the future.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board
texts.text: However, our customers also expect us to offer larger vehicles with alternative drivetrains and far more range. To  meet their demands, we are enhancing, not only our battery technologies, but also hydrogen fuel cell technologies.  At the moment, we are testing a small fleet of hydrogen-powered BMW 5 Series GT. Customer focus means two  things to us. On the one hand, it means continuing to offer customized drivetrain solutions. On the other hand, it  means viable implementation of those solutions with maximum synergies and minimum complexity between  technology paths. That's why we have taken deliberate steps to broaden our core expertise in the field of  powertrain development.

texts.speaker: Friedrich Eichiner
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: At Group level, the company will target an EBT margin of at least 10%. The Motorcycle segment will adopt an  EBIT margin target range of 8% to 10%. In the Financial Services segment, we will maintain our target o f a return  on capital employed of at least 18%. Our target ratio for R&D activities remains within the 5% to 5.5% range of  revenue as before.

file: BMW - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 22March2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: First, a few general remarks. Right now, everyone is talking about plug-in hybrids. Here, the BMW brand is clearly  number one in the premium segment. And our BMW i3 is one of the top three best selling pure electric cars  worldwide. This shows we are in a strong position. And we continue to drive ahead. In 2017, we aim to sell  100,000 electrified vehicles, and by 2025, we want electric models and plug-in hybrids to account for around 15%  to 25% of our sales. That's why we are electrifying all our BMW Group brands and model series.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Our goal is sustainable mobility. We are absolutely clear on this. Everything we do is for our customers. We want  them to experience premium mobility in both an individual and emotional way. With our services, we are available  whenever and where ever the customer needs us. For this, we will embrace the opportunities offered by  digitalization. With Strategy NUMBER ONE > NEXT, we have taken clear decisions; cooperation with Intel and  Mobileye, our campus for autonomous driving; and our automated test fleet for urban environments.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Peter
texts.profession: Member of the Board of Management, Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We will continue to renew our product lineup over the next few years. As we continue to enhance our  conventional engines, we will also be driving development of a new generation of electric motors and conducting  intensive research into hydrogen fuel cell technology. We are refining our rear and front-wheel drive architectures  to make them equally suitable for both conventional drivetrains and electrification. This will increase our flexibility.  With the additional driver assistance systems in the new 5 Series, we are also taking another important step  towards autonomous driving. We are bringing technological innovations into series production, but only once they  achieve the right level of maturity and safety.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: All other sites worldwide provide us with additional flexibility depending on demand. In total, our network  comprises 31 locations in 14 countries on 5 continents. We have an even balance of production between  Germany and the rest of the world. All locations are preparing for electrifications of the models and series. This  capability is part of our Strategy NUMBER ONE > NEXT. NUMBER ONE > NEXT has been designed for  adaptability, serving as both a vision and a dynamic roadmap that evolves as we progress.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: What does our priority list look like? Top priority is currently electrification. Next is connectivity on autonomous  driving. As part of this digital shift, we're expanding our services. We are expanding our know-how in selected  areas through strategic cooperation with partners from our own industry and technology leaders from other  sectors.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: I would like to say a few words about this. First, sustainable mobility. Since 1995, we have reduced the average  CO2 emissions of our European fleet by more than 40%. For us, the plug-in hybrid has been a success story. The  X5 was the top-selling plug-in hybrid in 2016. By the end of 2016, we had six plug-in hybrid models on the global  market, plus one model for China. The new BMW 5 Series here on the stage has also been available as a plug-in  hybrid version since March. This summer, it will be followed by the first MINI plug-in hybrid, the Countryman.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: In 2018, we will welcome a new member of the BMW i family, the BMW i8 Roadster. Demand for pure battery  electric cars is also growing. We see this in the BMW i3 with its new battery providing 95 ampere hours. BMW  Motorrad has already an all-electric model, the C-evolution. Its range has also been increased significantly. In  2016, electrified vehicles accounted for around 2.6% of our group sales. But in certain EU countries, electrified  cars already make up over 20% of our sales. In 2017, we aim to sell 100,000 electrified cars. Already in January  and February, we sold more than twice as many e-cars worldwide as in the same period last year. February sales  of the i3 were 55% higher than last year.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: With our strategy, we have decided that the fully electric drivetrain will be integrated into our core brands, an all- electric MINI in 2019 and an all-electric BMW X3 in 2020. Soon, range will no longer be a differentiating factor.  We are already concentrating on achieving an optimum balance between all relevant features – safety, range,  and duration of life of the battery. We believe that our customers would benefit the most from this approach. We  are keeping expertise in electric drivetrains, power electronics, and battery cells within the company. We have  more an in-house value creation in electro-mobility than any of other competitors. This also brings cost benefits.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: At the same time, we are also working on fuel cells. These are particularly well suited to larger model series and  long distances. We plan to produce a low volume series in 2021, and we will be able to offer vehicles with fuel  cells from 2025.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Also, by 2025, all our vehicles with combustion engines will be fitted with 12 and 48-volt energy recovery systems.  The drivetrain mix will ultimately be decided by the customers. We are starting out on the basis of two trends.  Demand for e-mobility will increase significantly over the coming decade. In some markets, in particular,  development will be strongly driven by regulations. That is why we are stating a range of 15% to 25% in our  estimates of the share of electrified cars in 2025.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: In this context, we are refining our vehicle architectures. There are already designs so that we can build cars with  a combustion engine and plug-in hybrids on the same architecture for every model series. That is the result of our  project i. From 2020, project i 2.0 will enable us to introduce a pure battery electric model for all our model series.  To achieve this, we are now gearing our architectures towards combustion engines and pure battery electric  drivetrains.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are not only able to assemble and paint cars with both drivetrains on the same line. We also only need one  car body construction to produce model with a combustion engine or electric drivetrain. The benefits of this are  obvious – maximum flexibility for planning and production regardless of how immobility develops in a segment or  a market.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: That brings me to the second of our priorities, digitalization and connectivity. The iNEXT is the next innovation  spearhead for our company. As with project i, BMW i will once again be a key element within our strategy. The  iNEXT project will develop modular kits for our electrification offensive across all brands and segments.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: On electrification, we have the in-house expertise to develop drivetrains. We support projects to create public  charging infrastructure worldwide. In Europe, we are involved with other companies in setting up a network of  rapid charging stations. On fuel cells, we continue to work with our partner Toyota.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: On the field of services, we are expanding our offering through the Now Family. This represents a holistic  approach for the big issues of urban mobility: parking, charging, air quality. DriveNow is our car sharing program  with more than 800,000 customers in 11 European cities. The all-electric BMW i3 makes up one-fifth of the fleet.  ReachNow has been on our demand mobility services in the U.S. since 2016. This is a completely new service  offering. Also, in Beijing, we are testing ReachNow. ChargeNow already comprises 65,000 charging points in 29  countries. The plan is to open it up to other OEMs. ParkNow is already integrated into the new BMW 5 Series  and  BMW Connected app. This service is also available to any driver via Internet and app.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Alongside key performance indicators, our reputation as a company also includes sustainability as well as our  attractiveness as a global employer. We are here clearly number one. This helps us to attract young talents we  need for digitalization across all our business segments. We already hire more IT specialists than mechanical  engineers. In 2016, we hired 6,900 people.

file: BMW - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 22March2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schoeberl
texts.profession: Director Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Today's speech will be a bit shorter than yesterday at the Annual Press Conference. Therefore, we will have more  time afterwards for our Q&A. The full speech from yesterday can be found in the press kits along with the Annual  Report, our Year Book, and the Sustainability Textbook. As always, the Annual Report is also on line.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: It provides a road map for our transformation towards sustainable and digital mobility. We are making good  progress with our strategy. You can see this in the decisions we have made on the market side, in our product,  and in our services. Let's take a look at the first point. The BMW Group has a decisive advantage in an ever more  connected world. We are a global company through and through and extremely flexible. We have 30 production  sites in 14 countries. We are already producing electrified models at 10 locations worldwide. Next year, we will  also begin producing the all-electric MINI at Oxford.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Our model offensive is also a drivetrain offensive. We are using scalable modular kits for electrification. From  2020, we will be able to fit all model series with any type of drivetrain. This shows our future is electric and  sustainable. With our electric cars and plug-in hybrids models, we are already number one in Europe.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: As you know, I have set some clear targets for sustainable mobility. More than 140,000 electrified vehicles sold  this year, a total of 0.5 million electrified vehicles and plug-in hybrids on the roads by the end of 2019. 25  electrified models, 12 of them pure electric by 2025.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Over the course of this year, we will present a number of pure electric concept vehicles that will all go into serious  production. Like our new technology flagship, the BMW iNEXT and the captivating BMW i Vision Dynamics, which  I announced as the BMW i4, the car here on my left side. We will produce both in Germany. In 2020, we will  launch the first all-electric BMW.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: With the fifth generation of eDrive, our vehicles will be able to drive 550 to 700 kilometers on electric power,  depending on the model. We will all achieve this with the BMW i4 and the iNEXT. But the BMW iNEXT is far more  than just a car, it will enable the entire company and all our brands in terms of technology, design and new  approaches.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The iNEXT combines autonomous driving, connectivity, electrification and services. Sustainable mobility and  autonomous driving go hand-in-hand for us. Soon, we will be opening our campus for autonomous driving outside  Munich. We will be launching autonomous driving in the iNEXT in 2021. This means we will technically master  Level 3 to 5. The system will be fully integrated and safe. Our test fleet for Level 4 and Level 5 will take to the  roads at the same time as the iNEXT. When it comes to autonomous driving, safety is our top priority. This year,  we will double the size of our autonomous test fleet to around 80 vehicles.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Peter
texts.profession: Member of the Board of Management, Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Flexible architectures and the integration of electrified vehicles into our existing production network will enable us  to respond quickly to changes in customer demand. The CapEx ratio for 2017 increased to 4.8%, reflecting the  high upfront investments. In 2018, we will continue to make major investments to secure our future  competitiveness. We are, therefore, assuming a CapEx ratio of up to 5% for this year.

file: BMW - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 21March2019 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Maximilian Schoeberl
texts.profession: Director Corporate Affairs, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Today, we will focus on 2018 as well as on our progress with Strategy NUMBER ONE > NEXT. Today's speeches  will be a bit shorter than yesterday at the Annual Press Conference. Therefore, we will have more time afterwards  for the Q&A. As always, you can get a hard copy of the Annual Report, our Yearbook and the Sustainability  Factbook at the entrance. Please also take a look at our online version of the Annual Report.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are strengthening our core business and our global presence, for example, in China and the U.S. We deliver.  We turn words into action. Our successful transition to the new emissions standard, WLTP, is a good example for  this.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: What is our approach to master these challenges? We are investing in our range of electrified vehicles for all  customer needs. We also will create additional flexible platforms for all type of drivetrains. From 2020, the popular  BMW X3 will be our first model that we will offer with all three drivetrains.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We will keep our foot on the throttle with the new model releases. This year alone, we will launch more than 20  new or updated models. And we are electrifying all our brands and model series. By the end of this year, we will  have 500,000 electrified vehicles on the road.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: As anyone who's ever driven electric car will tell you, e-mobility is sheer driving pleasure in its purest form, thanks  to the electric engine and battery. Together, they form the heart of every electric vehicle. We produce the electric  drive and high-voltage systems ourselves. This keeps essential e-mobility expertise firmly in our own hands.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Regarding battery cells, we will continue to build on our existing expertise. This summer, we will open the new  Battery Cell Competence Centre in Munich. This also includes infrastructure. Our ChargeNow customers have  already today access to more than 100,000 charging points in 25 countries. ChargeNow also demonstrates that  cooperation between companies is increasingly important.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: We are targeting total savings potential of more than €12 billion by the end of 2022. Performance > NEXT will  have an impact well into the next decade.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The iNEXT combines several future technologies: full connectivity and a futuristic interior; an electric range of up  to 600 kilometers for every day driving for both short and long distances. It also signals the launch of Level 3  highly automated driving. And at the same time, we will also be testing Level 4 and Level 5 autonomous driving in  urban areas with a fleet of iNEXT vehicles. This opens up a whole new chapter for the BMW Group.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Technologies from the iNEXT will be integrated into our entire model line-up. The BMW iNEXT will be released  onto the market in 2021.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Peter
texts.profession: Member of the Board of Management, Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we responded early to the challenges in our environment and launched a company  program to boost performance back in 2017. Through Performance > NEXT, we are systematically addressing  structural issues across the BMW Group, optimizing processes, and improving efficiency. We have already made  several important decisions.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Peter
texts.profession: Member of the Board of Management, Finance, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: The European Union's extremely ambitious CO2 legislations also require high additional expenses and will lead to  higher manufacturing costs, which will impact earnings. At the same time, we again expect to face significant  currency and commodity headwinds in the mid- to high-three-digit-million euro range. Further development in  tariffs is another major uncertainty. Our guidance assumes there will be no increase in tariffs between the U.S.  and the European Union.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: All these models come with the fourth generation of our battery and electric drivetrain technology. This enables an  electric range of up to 80 kilometers. The BMW 2 Series and BMW 5 Series models will also get a battery update  in the summer.

texts.speaker: Harald Krüger
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Management, Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
texts.text: By the end of 2020, we will have launched more than 10 new or updated models with electrified drivetrains. For  me, this is a clear statement. We will not only boost sales of electrified vehicles; we also aim to increase sales  and revenues significantly in the upper segments in particular.

file: BN - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 27July2010 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse, Chief Financial Officer
texts.profession: Hi to everyone. This is Pierre-Andre Terisse speaking. I’m the group CFO. I’m here together with
texts.text: So a word about productivity; you know that we’ve been engaging into very strong focus and  initiatives on these fields because we see that as essential for two reasons, number one, to be put  in front of the the evolution of the cost of raw material; and number two, because that’s a way for us  to fuel the investments we are doing. We have an ambition to generate €500 million of reduction of  cost at the beginning of the year. Programs are in place. It goes through very simple but many  initiatives across the different labels. You are – hear some examples which by the way can be  sometime triple wins. Triple wins in Fresh Dairy for instance, when we decided to take away the  overlapping, so the pickup on the yoghurt, which is delivering money because you save packaging  which is delivering a reduction of our carbon footprint emission and which last has been boosting  the sales on the – of the SKUs on which we have done that.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse, Chief Financial Officer
texts.profession: Hi to everyone. This is Pierre-Andre Terisse speaking. I’m the group CFO. I’m here together with
texts.text: Same thing in Waters, with a thought of reduction on the weight of the bottle of the PET and a  systematic benchmark exercise we’re doing in this division. And in Baby Nutrition, an example  about the purchasing method, which basically means that we are together with suppliers analyzing  the value of the goods we are buying and trying to allocate it better in order to reduce the cost.  Altogether, this has reverted into €230 million cost savings in the first half, which means that we are  very much on track to achieve our target for the full year.

file: BN - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Another element of, or example of, how we are growing our own categories is in the Aqua Drink segment. We are  leveraging the equity and the functionality of our water brands and our key brands, introducing flavored and  functional waters on that base. We believe by the way that part of the way we navigate, we have been able and we  will continue to be able to navigate our business successfully in the current pretty lukewarm consumption patterns  in the OECD countries is to introduce or to improve the Indulgence product range. And one way of doing that for  water is definitely flavored and the Aqua Drink segment.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The result of that, as you can see on the left top part of this chart, is that the growth of our Aqua Drink has been  stepping up regularly and spectacularly over the last three years. The first half of this year is way beyond the 18%  forward the pie chart on the right that will make even more space for Aqua Drink as a total part of our Water  portfolio.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Talking about Activia, I'd like to tell you that we have introduced a significant innovation for Activia in the first  half of this year with a launch of a new cup; a new cup which needs a revolutionary process for us, a complete  change of the process in terms of form, fill and seal of the pack, which brings a new consumer experience. It has  brought tremendously better visibility and uniqueness on the shelf. This cup is actually is tinted. As you can see  for Activia, it comes with green, but for Danonino, it would come in blue, for example. So it brings additional  differentiation for the brand itself.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And here are the few examples of what we have been doing on the first half of this year on the productivity side.  For example, the packaging of the new Evian bottle. We have been able to make it even lighter, reducing the level  of plastic we use by about 12%. Using more recycled PET than before. We have been able to increase to 50%  instead of 25% recycled PET. And we made that bottle even easier to compact for our consumers, and therefore  being more consumer-friendly. The result is both the top and the bottom green lines of this chart, which is 52%  reduction of the carbon footprint for that bottle, and a significant cost reduction in the same time.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Another example of a breakthrough model for us is the milk-cracking technology that we have been talking – or  discussing with you for a while already. That's an example in Saudi Arabia with Danette, our Indulgence dessert  product, where basically by using the technology of milk-cracking, we've been able to improve the recipe in terms  of consumer preference. We have a cheaper recipe, as we are making a better usage of the milk protein. We bring  less CO2. That's – we are talking about 17% decrease in CO2. And 20% water saving in the process overall. And we  are bringing better nutrition, because overall, we are lowering the level of fat and energy of the product itself. So  this is a very good example of how productivity can actually drive a 360-degree improvement of our business  value to our consumer and our environment.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Finally, I started with the environment. I think this set of numbers is a good illustration of how relevant those  transformations, both strategic and operational that were brought to our portfolio between 2007 and 2010, in  terms of choice of categories in which we play, countries in which we decide to allocate our capital, the way we  create value for our consumers and we manage the value price equation for our consumers, is relevant to allow us  in this environment to navigate our business model in a way where we are well in line our guidance for a top line  this year of 6% to 8%.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: I move to Water. So it's been two or three years, I think, that I've been telling you that Q2 and Q3 are always very  difficult to read, and that Q1 is a better indicator. There is no exception this time. The weather conditions have  played a role. To help you understand that, I think there are three elements to keep in mind. The first, and that's  obviously the most important, is that Water is really – has really stepped up versus last year in terms of  underlying base performance for two reasons. Number one, because the improvement in Western Europe have  confirmed, and they have confirmed in the second quarter as well. The second reason is that Aqua Drinks are  adding some element of performance in emerging geographies, and this is particularly the case in Asia and Latin  America.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So when we were running at about five points of growth a year ago on Water, we are clearly today running as  underlying trends two points above that. So 7% to 8% is the underlying performance of water. To this, you have to  add pricing, because the sharp increase of PET has led us to pass a price increase, essentially in emerging  countries. Pricing is two to three points, and therefore in 2011, the underlying performance is even higher than the  one we mentioned before.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: This means that you have around nine points of one-offs or exceptional items, which are basically relating to two  topics. The first is the weather condition. May and April have been just exceptional in Europe. It's been the case in  Latin America as well. The weather condition has been good. And this has obviously contributed to higher sales.  Fukushima has led to an increase of – an immediate increase of buying water, which has therefore emptied the  stock, and the stock has [indiscernible] (43:56).

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: We are quite careful about whether or not this is going to translate into real sustainable medium-term consumer –  increased consumption, sorry. We don't believe we have enough evidence to think this is going to be the case. So  for the moment, in our analysis, we consider that this has been as well a one-off and there will be no long-lasting  effects of that. So eight to nine points, which add, and you get to 19%.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Obviously, when you think about Q3 and Q4, you have to eliminate these nine points. And not only when you look  at the weather condition outside as well as inside, it's a bit freezing, to be frank. It's not – it's clear that we'll have  Q3 probably, if it continues like this, probably below the normal trends of – the normalized trends of Waters.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So I hope I've been clear enough and given you sufficient elements. When you look at the price mix, you can find  some of the reflection of the elements I have been describing. Volume growth has been higher 10%, higher than  the normal trends for the second quarter in a row. This is due to Western Europe and Aqua Drinks. And of course,  the pricing mix elements has being significantly higher because of pricing, but also because of the weather  condition in Western Europe, and therefore, the real performance of Western Europe.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Innovation, just to remind you, that we have a 360-degree strategy in this division now. We keep focusing on  Water. That's obviously the core of the division. And focusing on Water, ranging from the jugs, this is the case in  Mexico with the launch of a new six-liters, which is providing accessible luxury to the consumer; and at the same  time trying to work the on-premise market with new bottles, one in Indonesia and another one in Spain. And  obviously, the Aqua Drinks is a second priority with some pretty good new innovations in Mexico.

file: BN - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 27July2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, this word of introduction being made, I'd like to say that I'm very glad to report a solid set of results for the  first half, which are in line with our objective for H1 and Q2 despite a combination of factors, more or less  predictable, from high comps in Water to the carryover effects of the inflation of the first half of last year from the  poor weather conditions in Europe in the second quarter to the worsening consumption trends in Southern  Europe in April. Over the first half, there's been a number of takeaways for us, the management of the group, and  I would like to share two or three of them with you.  First, I think we should not forget that we have a very good set of brands and business all over the world which  account for two-thirds of the group and grow more than 10% in average. These are: Mizone, Dumex, Aqua,  [indiscernible] (2:32), Danone-Unimilk, Oikos, Danone Japan, South Africa, Brazil, Al Safi Danone in Saudi  Arabia, Bonafont [indiscernible] (2:44) and actually all of our operations outside Western Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If I look at our environment, and you know this slide which we've been using now for the past few quarters., we've  seen basically three things throughout the first half. A, an inflation which has been a little bit higher than what we  expected, notably on some specific raw material which has been the whey and the milk proteins, and we have tried  in front of that to generate more productivity to increase our level of productivity.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I would just like to say a word, before moving into the figures more in detail, about sustainability. It remains a  very, very important axis of development for Danone because it guarantees that we'll be able to deliver growth, not  only in the short term but also in the medium term. Two examples, we've been entering the Top 10 of the Best  environmental protection are being perceived and recognized by the consumer. And, secondly, we are  progressively rolling out the SAP platform for carbon footprint measurement. And, for that, we've received a  reward here in the UK, which is [audio gap] (13:04-13:08) given by Finance for the Future. So that's one.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On the left hand side of the presentation you will see sourcing. As part of our management in Russia and the effort  for making the business sustainable for Danone and its environment, we've set up a Milk Business Academy  around a farm which is going to receive in the next five years, 700 farmers, train them, with a very concrete goal  which aims at increasing in the yield of the farm and the yield of the milk of cows 10%, and ensuring high-quality  and long-term supply of milk for them. So, this is the group and this is what I wanted to say about the various  events which have been taking place throughout the first half. I'll now go into more figures on this.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: About the sales, two things to mention here. 7.7% reported, that comes from the fact that we had a currency affect  of 2 points over the first half, no scope effects. And the 5.9% is broken down into 2.2% and 3.7%. Interestingly,  this breakdown gives the same result in terms of volume for the second quarter, 2.1%, but that is obviously down  at different things. In particular, Water is obviously down given the weather condition in the second quarter, while  Baby is up by about the same amount or even more. Value is decreasing as we move into the anniversary of price  increase which we passed for the majority of them in the first half of last year. And the currency effect, as you can  see, is slightly higher in the second quarter than it is for the half.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If you look at the dynamics of that again, 7% in Q1 was very much at the top of the guidance of the 5% to 7%  guidance. 5% is at the bottom. I would just like to remind you that we had a second quarter last year which was  exceptional in Water for two reasons. Number one, because of Japan and the loading of inventory in these  countries following the catastrophe of tsunami and Fukushima, and, secondly, because we had tremendously good  weather conditions in April and May in Europe. In front of that, we've obviously had very bad weather conditions  and, therefore, we are where we thought we would be some time ago – sorry, a month ago or two months ago,  which is at 5% for Q2. And, again, that reflects the dual feature of Western Europe sales which are declining and  the rest of the world, which is growing double digits.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So about – I'm moving to Water. Sorry. I'm actually moving back. And I was – yeah, just a comment that 4.6% in  Q2 is a real good and solid performance, given the weather conditions and the high comps. This is confirming that  we are in a category with very strong dynamics. Solid in Western Europe, very strong outside, and we are  benefiting as well from Aquadrinks, which are always very strong.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Looking at the margins by business and by geography, no surprise, this reflects pretty much what I've shown you  in terms of evolution of sales and what I've said so far about the reason or the drivers of the margin change. Dairy,  that's minus 85 bps, impacted by Southern Europe and the carryover of inflation of milk, in particular. Waters is  as well impacted by the carryover inflation, while weather conditions in Europe have not helped the solid  performance of the first half.

file: BN - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 29July2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: We have done so in Europe as well by stabilizing our market share in dairy Europe, and improving our sales  performance outside Europe by accelerating in the CIS and North America by investing behind our brands, as well  as strengthening our presence across our energy markets, through small, well-targeted transactions which I'm  going to come back on in a minute.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: But most of the efforts though of water during this half have been focusing at aquadrinks, at unlocking the  potential of the category as you can see at the top of this slide. I will mention two examples, one is the launch of  Blue – B'lue, which is the aquadrink version launched in India in the region of Delhi and it's going to complement  our positions in Indonesia and in China. B'lue is on the right part – the bottom right part of the screen.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: I will mention as well Brazil, which started from zero about four years ago and start being something not only  meaningful but more and more exciting. We have completed the portfolio. We are not only in HOD and water any  more, but we are as well in aquadrinks and we are aggressively getting penetration in regions away from São  Paulo, so that's definitely an area of growth, which is extremely important for us.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Waters continued strong performance, and the weather has not been precisely very nice, but I think what you see  here is demonstrating that the reliance of water to the Western European business is far less important than it was  in the past. Asia and aquadrinks have kept outperforming. Europe has remained soft obviously on the back of poor  weather condition, but with market share gain. And that's important to emphasize. And the market shares, that's  written below, have been growing noticeable most of all markets.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: In front of that, we've had higher than expected input costs but a significant portion of that has been erased by  productivity. And an important factor has been the deleverage which you see under the column of other COGS, the  deleverage of Europe which continues to hurt the European, the Western European margins.

file: BN - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 25July2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: If I take all the streams, all the priorities we have for 2014 one by one and we go through it, I'll start with Europe  dairy maybe. We continue working with the team, which is strong and increasingly focused. Some of you – most of  you have met with Gustavo Valle, he has very clear mind about what he wants to create for Europe, and this is  expressed by the green spiral you see on the top right of the chart. It simply means that he wants to go and get  cost-saving, optimize the cost base in order to reinvest and to generate a stream of growth in value-added  products.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Waters, a very good performance: 13.1% top line in the second quarter, 11.2% in the first half altogether. So that  remains a very strong trend in line with the trend of the previous quarters and years. Still very much the same  dynamics. We see Water and Europe being growing low single digits. The big addition is coming from the  aquadrinks and in particular from the aquadrinks in Asia, which are driving the mix up, which are driving as well  the value up altogether, but on a volume base, which aren't growing.

file: BN - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 24July2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer
texts.text: ALMA has continued to deliver nearly double-digit growth this quarter, which is a big achievement for us despite  what we see as a sort of general slowdown of macro-environment in various emerging countries.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer
texts.text: I can't say I'm fully satisfied with it yet. As you know, there is the question of how far, how much, how fast the free  trade zone or any other really sustainable solution can be found through the booming e-commerce market and we  will not – or I will not be satisfied until we are at this stage and we are not yet. So this is still work-in-progress on  the free trade zone.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving to the Water division on page 16. The Water division continues to display a solid broad-based growth,  which continue to be well-balanced between volume and value. Europe and plain water continue to deliver solid  progression on the back of positive market dynamics and aquadrinks continued to perform above average in all  regions. All countries are growing and all regions are contributing to improve market share.

file: BN - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 28July2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As we discussed earlier in June, the environment remains very volatile. And we have to navigate through fast  evolving dynamics, especially in some emerging markets that you can see on the right. And in this context we  make sure that we stick to our plan and that we remain focused on our core agenda, making sure we properly  manage our risk and opportunity and driving safely on our journey towards 2020, delivering consistently quarter  after quarter.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: If we go into the Water division for Europe, it's a solid Q2 driven by volume. And solid despite the high base of  comparison and not very favorable weather conditions starting this summer.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And in that sense, we are building for the long term. This is the reason of our partnership with Healthier America.  And more recently, as you have seen, our pledge on sustainable agriculture, naturality, and transparency. End of  April, Danone U.S. announced indeed a pledge to its farmers, retail customers, and consumers to further improve  sustainable agriculture practices for its milk supply, to increase transparency for its portfolio of product, and  evolve to more natural and fewer ingredients, especially for the factory brands. Also, to provide more choices to  consumer.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Two weeks ago what we did is that, in line with this pledge, Danone announced implementation of the first of  those many major changes by bringing non-GMO ingredient option and clear label commitment. This is the  beginning of the transformation. Danimals, Oikos, and Dannon brands we label to contain non-GMO ingredient.  And additionally and starting now, all Dannon product in the U.S. that have GMO ingredients will be clearly  labeled as such.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: I think this kind of engagement is fully in line with our mission and our view on alimentation for the future. It's a key  distinctive approach. and this is what will guarantee that we are building for sustainability, rather than for short  term.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let's switch now to Water and Mizone in China on page 12. So basically, while we are moving into the Mizone  transition, I think it's important to look at Waters in two separate parts. First, outside China, where we continue to  expand the portfolio across the different markets. We are leveraging both plain waters and aquadrinks. And we  keep delivering strong results globally, above 8% again this quarter, supported by volume growth and supported  also by a market share gain on the global Danone universe.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Innovation remain a key driver to deliver the ambition on providing healthy hydration to people. You have some  example on the chart. And all these initiatives are getting positive traction.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Basically, if we look at the outlook of Q3. You have to remember that we have a base of comparison for Waters,  which is quite high, especially due to a hot season last year in Europe, as well as the fact that the transition of  Mizone started only within the Q3 last year. And on top of that in the recent weeks there had been impact on  flooding in China that might also have some impact on the Q3 performance for the division. So we will monitor this  impact.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Third, just I would like to stop on the box Other, which is reflecting mainly a positive base of comparison. You will  remember that last year, we had a negative box, which included both the cost associated with Dumex deleverage  and adaptation plan. And to a lesser extent, cost linked to our – the fire incurred in our Cuijk factory. And on  Dumex, remember that you have to look at it with these [ph] works, (25:21) but also in the scope effect, where you  have also 14 bps to have it comparable to last year base. So it's really about the reverse of the effects of 2015.  There's nothing specifically new of change in the box.

It's been the line  extensions of Alpro, a very successful strawberry, high protein, Go On product that's already one of the top-selling  of the brand, after only a couple of months on the market.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber

texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA

texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Strategy and Information Systems, Danone SA

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Strategy and Information Systems, Danone SA

texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Strategy and Information Systems, Danone SA

texts.text: Page 8, on the efficiency side, the Protein efficiency program that we started to implement last year is now under  way and fully on track. The first savings are in line with our plans, so about €75 million of gross savings year-to- date, and we are continuing to be disciplined to allocate resources in the areas of the business that will generate  sustainable value over the long term.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis

We consider the solid H1 performance to be confirmed in the second part of the year in line with  the outlook given for Waters at the beginning of the year.

texts.text: Protein unlocked also sustainable savings in selling and overhead expenses, and together with the synergy from  WhiteWave integration and our continuous discipline in resource allocation, contributing also for 75 basis points of  margin expansion, which is the total of the two last green box that you have on the bridge.
