texts.text: I think I will conclude on this one, which is just to remind you the commitment of Danone to all the  stakeholders. I know that is very fashionable, but I really want to express that in Danone it’s not a  question of fashion. We work for the shareholder, we work for the environment, for the ecosystem,  for the consumer and for the shareholder, obviously. So that’s the reason why we are very proud  about our result.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: Pierre-André Terisse, Chief Financial Officer  Okay. Good morning to all of you. I’ll try to go pretty fast on the financial part, which is quite dense  and detailed. We thought it was very important for you to have all the elements to assess not only  the reported numbers, which are see – are shown on the screen in yellow, but also to well  understand the breakdown between what is our performance and what is – what has been the  impact of Unimilk due to first – the first consolidation in December. It was important for you. It is  important for you to have the elements to access the performance of Danone, which we call stand- alone and that’s going to be the green part. And it is important as well for you to understand what is  going to be the pro forma for next year and, therefore, what is the base on which we are going to  build 2011 and this is in a very nice tableau.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: 7 stable. We are back to positive pricing and mix contribution. This is on the back of the price  increase we had mentioned to you at the time of H1 and Q3, which had been taken in high inflation  market, but also in Russia on the back of very sharp increase in the cost of raw material, as Franck  already said, due to the exceptional weather conditions, and we have now in Q4 a much more  balanced growth than in the rest of the year.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: And on this division, too, we keep launching new products, two examples here. One is the full  recyclability of our bottles, our PET bottle in Mexico, so we’ve reached another gap, another level,  which is to have fully recycled bottles. This is a case for Bonafont in Mexico and Qua in India, which  is one of the acquisitions, small acquisition of the year. We have acquired a platform of water  coming from the EMEA and we’ll of course be working on that as a base for the whole of India and  the European platform.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: 9 in the input costs which is net of negative 300 growth impact and therefore productivity which has  offset more than half of it, through the other COGS and also productivity in the services, and in  particular, in the A&P. I will come back on that, but this has contributing €80 million, the productivity  on the A&P line.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: So on the COGS line, I won’t go further. 10% input cost inflation, €560 million of productivity. This is  a record. This is a new level of Danone. This is an ambition , we will have to reproduce in 2011 in a  context which, of course, we’ll come back on. This is made of strong productivity, again, across the  board in all sectors. This is true in industrial. This is true in purchasing. This is true everywhere and  this is true, as well, in services.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: The first is a surge in milk price, which has been of about 30% in Russia on the back of the forest  fires and the heat wave, which has impacted Russia during summer. And the second is dynamics  of top line and the focus on market share in top line by the management of Unimilk in 2010 which  has been extremely strong.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: And I think I explained that last year. We are not going to give air – fresh air to our competitor like  pushing at our price too much; first of all, productivity; secondly, the mix; and third price increase to  the consumer. And if I hear what I hear by the time being it seem that the most impacted brand by  the raw material effect are not the brand like Danone – are the private label because, obviously, the  weight of the raw material is far more important for them than add value product like Activia. But I  will comment on that.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: If you think about Medical, if you think about Baby food, even Dairy and now even Waters,  whatever the feeling about the water in the past, and it’s definitely easier to deliver result in a  difficult context when your categories are naturally growing, which is exactly the same for the  geographies. And as I said, we have the right geographies and the right balance within the right  geographies. It’s clear that it’s for us easier to be – to deliver the result to expect in countries which  are naturally growing, especially when you are number one, especially when you have the full  range of innovation in Western Europe, you can spread all over the world.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: The last is, as I said, we have natural hedging. More and more our raw materials are close to our  factory, we produce locally, we sell locally, the consumer is local. So the price of milk, for example,  is not the same in every country all over the world. There is very small speculation perhaps more  on the milk powder, but on this, we can cover at least six months or seven months.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: So on more than 50% of the group, we have less impact by the raw material increase, because it’s  a liquid milk. We are using liquid milk, so it’s a local production. And as I told you, we start to  organize the way we can be involved in the production for our needs.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, so we start. I speak in English or I try to speak in English, because we have some of your
texts.text: 14 for Danone communities, or the products we are – we will plan to launch with first on a little bit in  Algeria, which is 70% vegetable milk. That kind of product, Ambient, will arrive as soon as possible.

file: BN - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 15February2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Water, we are talking about the fact that you have to drink for health and you will see we have two new surveys,  medical survey, about the impact of having the right hydration for your body we are going to disclose. So we build  the category. And Medical Nutrition and healthy aging is exactly the same. Everybody want to live as long as  possible, except that everybody wants to live in independency, not having somebody taking care of you, which is  exactly the way we build the category.  If I take the example of the Fresh Dairy, on the left, you have the per capita consumption. And you see different  clusters, countries where the consumption per capita is very high, like France or Spain, 32, 33 kilos, country which  are growing where we are, like Saudi Arabia, Argentina and so on, country where we just start and country like  Russia and U.S., where we are recovering or building the platform for the future. It's going to be the main fuel. Not  right now, that will take time.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: But the main thing you have to understand within the Water division, I call it Water, is a mix. We continue to  improve the quality of the businesses because of the Aquadrinks, and you know the Aquadrinks are Mizone in  China growing – I'm not sure we disclosed the growth of Mizone in China, but one day we know this business will  do, will deliver €1 billion. Don't ask me when, but the growth is double-digit and the first figure is not a two. So it's  really booming, really, really booming. And Aquadrinks is very important because our margin are better on  Aquadrinks than on the Water.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Mexico, we launched the Baby Nutrition, we have two additional water plants. Brazil, we launched HOD, means  we have just replicate our rollout the success model we have in Mexico with Bonafont in Brazil. We are already  number one in São Paulo, now we add the HOD and I'm sure one day or another we will conquer these [ph] in our  list (16:45). We launched also this – the same model in Poland with Bonafont. Egypt, we – it's another subject how  to protect the milk resource for us, so we just opened a farm in Egypt to really control milk quality because now we  have the right size to build that kind of platform.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So the environment, I will take an example because it's difficult not to take five minutes about the crisis. For us,  the most difficult thing to deal with is not the economic crisis, except if Europe disappear or whatever, but we will  have another meeting to explain the consequences of that. But personally, we think that the 2012 context will be  the same than the second part of the 2011 context.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So it's not very positive, but it's not very pessimistic. And if we find a way to deliver plus 7%, 8% full year, but also  on Q4, that the reason why, except Fukushima and the impact on the water business, that's the reason why you  saw in the – because you already saw the guidance, we say 5% to 7%. So because we put this a little bit lower  because of the impact of the Water business due to the seasonality last year and especially Japan and Fukushima.  So, the most important thing we have to deal with is this raw material. We expect a slowdown. We expect not the  – the beginning of the year is continue to grow. Less than in the past, but continue to grow. But we think that –  and especially if the crisis is very strong, we will see the commodities going down in term of price. So, we plan  that.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Danone, we want to be the lowest cost producer. We want to have the lowest cost structure we can imagine.  And as you can see, we planned last year to achieve €500 million in productivity. We achieved €528 million and  we plan the same kind of figure for next year, which is definitively more adapt to the Danone model, that's the first  priority. The second one is the mix, because if you have the right mix, you are less impact by the raw material  increase. When I'm talking about the Aquadrinks and if the PET is growing up, which is the case, obviously you  control a little bit better.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, it's really fine-tuning marketing. Is it new for us? No, we started in 2008 to do that when we deicide to do the  reset. And by the way, we are very happy having done the reset in 2008 because it give us fresh air and more  elasticity. If you are always hot, you are totally blocked by the consumer or by the retailers.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Another thing which is important for us, not because we are going to save the planet. It's not our job to save the  planet, but we have to give sense to the people. And it's funny to see that people are thinking about, let's say, social  issues or environmental issues outside of the company. But we think that the first thing we have to do is to ask all  our people to take care of this, because they are working in Danone, but they are also consumers, they are also  stakeholder, they are also speaking about the company.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So we really decide to focus on this minus 30% CO2 target in 2012. And most, most of the things we are doing to  achieve the target help us to save money because when you put out a [ph] pickup on a Par 4 (32:55), you save  money. So productivity is behind also the program. It's always dual, social and economic, and we create with SAP  a wonderful tool to really measure the efficiency of the program.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Danone SA
texts.text: So a word about Dairy. You know the format again. The green bands at the top, shows that we are showing  numbers ex-Unimilk, this is the last time. We'll start the year next year with the full integration of Unimilk and,  therefore, no analysis ex-Unimilk. But to continue what we have started at the beginning of the year, Dairy  performance ex-Unimilk is basically in line with Q3. Q3 was showing a slowdown versus the previous, the first  part of the year, reflecting the slowdown of the American and the CIS market. Q4 is very much in line with that.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Danone SA
texts.text: Unimilk, as Franck reminded you, the priority of 2011 was really to build the foundation. And build the foundation  means make the company profitable and make the integration. So from that standpoint, this has been successful  year definitely. Profitability, in particular, in the second half has come back to a level pre-heat wave and milk crisis  in Russia. This is due to pricing we have taken to some slowdown in the cost of milk, but also two very good initial  results of productivity programs and synergies which we are putting in place when making the integration.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Danone SA
texts.text: I'll just drink water before talking Water. So that's been an outstanding year I think. Full-year top-line growth  16%. The third quarter had been weak on really poor weather conditions, yet 8%. Q4 is basically benefiting from  all the positive you can imagine. It's benefiting from very positive underlying, i.e., Western Europe, which is  growing slowly but growing, emerging markets which are very strong and, at the same time, it's benefiting from  additional factors.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Danone SA
texts.text: The mild weather in Europe in Q4, it's a long time ago. I know it's been cold since then but the first part of the  winter has been mild. Secondly, the Aquadrinks performance, which has not only been very good for the year, but  has even accelerated in the last quarter of this year. And the last is the pricing. We have been on the back of a very  strong increase of the cost of PET, we have been passing price increase and all together that's been helping the  performance as well.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Danone SA
texts.text: The mix is clearly showing the acceleration of the Aquadrinks, which are doing very, very well. I'm talking of  Mizone in Asia, I 'm talking of Levité de Bonafont in Latin America, and this is what you see on the next slide on  the right, i.e., a new version of Levité Pomelo Rosado in Argentina for Villa del Sur. And at the same time, in  Europe we keep reinventing the packaging, in particular, food use of bio-materials after Volvic, which was first  bottle last year with 20% of bio-meg. We have been using that material for Aguas Lanjarón in Spain this year.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & EVP-Finance, Danone SA
texts.text: So, this is it for 2011. I'll drink again. Thank you. For 2012, a few words. One word of context, when we look at the  environment, you know that in the past three years, we've not been very optimistic and, unfortunately, reality has  rather matched our fears. When we look at 2012, we see no reason to become suddenly more optimistic. And,  therefore, when building the course of action and projections for next year, we basically assume that the  environment in 2010 is going to remain, as Franck said, in line with what we have seen during the second half of  2011, neither worse nor better. We assume that European consumption will remain under pressure and will  neither improve nor collapse, but rather is going to remain soft as we have seen it.

file: BN - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 19February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And another very important items for us, or KPI for us, is CO2 impact, minus 35%. We achieved the target we  fixed with the company. And you will see that doing this, we also improved the quality of the business and the  efficiency of our businesses.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The CO2, just to show you that even if you are taking care of environmental issue or even social issue, it's not  because it's nice, it's because we are convinced it's impacted positively the results, even the financial results of the  company, when we decide to achieve the minus 30% CO2 impact. For example, we have to reduce the weight of  the PET of our plastic bottle. Doing this, we save money.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: When you look at what happened with the [ph] meat (8:25) in France and everybody talking about proximity,  when the main, the center of the strategy of our basic plain yoghurt in France is the milk of our farmer, it's  because on the environmental issue, also social, because we want to pay the right price to the farmer. But you can  milk of our farmer. So that's the reason why we present to you also the results, even if you can't consider it's  something apart for us. It's totally part, in the center of our strategy.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: It's not the end game. For me it's the beginning of the new story. And on the other side, yes, 40%, and you see also  the result, like-for-like minus 3% top line and 190 basis points like-for-like margin less. But we deal with this, and  the wrong thing will be to focus on the left, on the green, and just milking the blue. And we are going to restate the  blue, and I will explain that to you. Obviously, the idea is not to have them to switch from minus 3 to plus 10.  Forget this. But you will see an example in the water business. When you fix Europe, you grow 10%. That's the  leverage we are running after and it's exactly what we are going to explain.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The result of this equation, sales plus 5.4%, so we can say we are in trouble in Spain. At the end of the day, the  Danone model still deliver 5.4%. Is it good? Is it as we said in our jargon, our language, is it an empty glass or full  glass? It's a full glass for us. It's a full glass. We still have a huge opportunity on the green side, but we are going to  fix the blue one. How long? We'll see. Not tomorrow. But anyway, the snowball of the green one is running much  more faster so we are protect and you have the result plus 5.4% whatever the difficult of Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Margin, yes, we missed. We make the profit warning and I remember you that we did it just to protect the green  side. We don't want to push up the price in China just to deliver margin in Europe. No, no, no. Otherwise, we will  kill China and one day we will be in trouble. So we have to fix Europe with Europe solution and continue to deliver  and to push as fast as we can the emerging country.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The free cash flow, as I said, we achieved the target. For me, the result of 2012, a positive, definitively positive. So  the green part, the one you like. Me, too. I will not comment again this because I did it. But just to explain to you  with some example. The fresh dairy U.S. On the left, you have the full range of Danone including Stonyfield  because when you are talking to the U.S. you have to look at the fresh dairy division, not only brands or certain  brand.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Waters. Not only waters because waters is doing quite well, the waters, H2O, thanks to Evian, thanks to Badoit,  thanks to Salvetat, thanks to Bonafont in Brazil. But the best score is delivered by the Aquadrinks strategy where  we grew, as you can see, at CAGR 20%. And obviously the margin are better in this product than in the plain  water. And if you look at in the room beside, we are going to launch the Pure Aquadrinks in France, in the UK, and  it's really a winning story. So we are going to roll out this.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: And you have the reserve of the new steps for us. For example, Aqualene water, they're both 10 billion liter of  water Indonesia. In front of big competitor but more – it's just a question of water. If we have more water, we can  sell more. So more than 10 billion,

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So now we have to decide what will be the best road to market, how to roll out country – not by the full country  but city by city to make the same success in India, we have here for example in China. This is our ambition.  Europe, not yet. Just the example, just to help you to dream a little bit that situation of the water division, the only  difference with Danone equation, we fix Europe because Europe is, depend the country, between minus 3 plus 3.  And Evian is doing well, and you can see the results of the division, which is growing double digit because the  main subject we have in Europe are linked to the dairy, not because the dairy is not good, because historically the  fixed since now two or three years in the water division. On top of that, we launched in Europe the Aquadrinks. So  we will see an improvement and so on.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So now I go back to the global equation and I go to the European part. Again, same figures you saw a few minutes  ago. First of all and the idea for us is to explain quickly, how do we want to tackle this European situation because  we will tackle it. We are not going to sleep waiting better days or better environment as everybody explained to us  every day. No, we are going to take care of our situation.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: If we are talking about brand activation and consumer activation, we will keep the management and the people we  need to stay specific for category, because we don't have link between baby food and water and dairy in terms of  brand activation and consumer connection. We have some but not a lot. We want to keep this specificity.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: And the performance in the CIS and Noram which has been as related as Marc mentioned. We'll see that. But we  are close to 10%% for the combination of CIS plus Noram this quarter. Volume value, the good thing is that  volumes are growing, regrowing, reaccelerating versus the previous quarters at 3.2%. And the second good news is  that this is true for all categories, all businesses, i.e., water [indiscernible] (37:16) but also dairy.

file: BN - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20February2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: In addition to that, we have confirmed this year extremely interesting successes like the one we have in Brazil  where we started greenfields operation four years ago, and now that become sizable and profitable, and it's going  to be our new geographies for Water.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: An innovation again, very much in the field of either the mix side on Water, the value side [indiscernible] (17 :57 )  with Evian and Badoit Limited Edition for Christmas, all the aquadrinks and you see an on-the-go version of Villa  del Sur Levité for Argentina on the screen.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Even for Activia, we have more than 100 white mass all over the world, which is not very efficient. So we are going  to save money by – like in the car business, we are going to use platform to really reduce the cost of our recipe.  That's what we call simplification.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: In terms of simplification, adaptation, new way of purchase, we are not only thinking about milk, our main raw   material, which are milk, food preparation or PET. Last year, we decide to – all of us, to drive Renault car all over  the world. And we had Nissan and Infiniti in some countries. We saved a lot money by negotiating a worldwide  agreement on this.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: In term of product, in term of packaging, I already explained and obviously by stretching also our categories like  we did with an incredible success in the Water division with the aquadrinks, like Danio in the Dairy one.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Best service. We are also looking how could we do business leveraging the strength of our brand by selling product  differently. The best, it's a small example but it's a good example, the one for Evian in Paris when you note that  one of the main reason for the consumer not to buy packaged water is because you have to carry the pack. So we  organized something to deliver at home, Evian.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Fresh Dairy Product again, we have only one target, develop the category. Develop the category with this strategy  called 1 Y oghurt A Day. Why 1 Y oghurt A Day? Because if I take the U.S., for example, it's one yoghurt per year as  an average. I'm exaggerating a little bit, but let's say one per week which is more than one per year if you calculate  well.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Water. I'm smiling because I remembered a question few years ago about Waters and stupid division, we have to  sell. Y es, why not, except that if you can look at the this chart, it's the successful [ph] pull (01:00:55) of the Danone  Group. And it's very easy to understand.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: The thing very easy to understand. We have 7 0% in the emerging market, 30% in Europe. The business itself is  growing in Europe. The plain water itself in Europe is growing. Small product like Salv etat is growing double- digit. Evian is growing. We are going to relaunch this year Volvic is growing also. So plain water in this beautiful  part of the world called Europe is growing. So we are not damaging the incredible double -digit growth we have  with water in the rest of the world.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Having said that, on top of that, we have another engine, the aquadrinks. And the aquadrinks are growing  incredibly strong. Y ou have the figures. And I can tell you that I think nobody really understand why we have  success in the aquadrinks. Aquadrinks, it's a brand very often mineral water or spring water brand, with less  sugar, natural flavor and the right answer to the consumer, very often the right answer to the mother of the  consumer, for obesity issue and so on and so on. But to do it, the kitchen to build that is not so easy to understand.  I'm sure we will have some illustration of that in the future from our competitor.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: We are going to launch Chinese positioning in Indonesia. Why in Indonesia? Because with the volume we have  with water, we can leverage the organization. And now just imagine, we didn't launch already aquadrinks but  juice, because we grew with the aquadrinks, for example, in the UK, Volvic Juiced is growing double-digit, same in  France with this – my favorite product, the strawberry one. So we didn't launch that in Indonesia. We didn't  launch that in China. We didn't launch that yet in Brazil. We have in Mexico, but we still have a lot of country we  can roll out this best practice.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Perhaps another one, the green, China with Mengniu, because I read in some newspaper, they don't learn, they  continue to join with forces in China. Y es, because we are convinced that Mengniu with COFCO behind is going to  be the head of the milk product in China, and I don't know why but I think it's a good idea to join forces with the  strongest Chinese company. And on top, I don't think we will have the time, the money and the strength to build  and to fight in China alone to build the dairy category. I think it's a real good idea to join forces with these people  in their country.

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: But even having said that, I think we have to build a strategy how to fix the milk supply, how to fix the PET supply,  how to deal with all this issue we can really have in different country, especially in the emerging country. So that's  the reason why we are going to work very strongly on all our organization.

file: BN - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 20February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Franck Riboud
texts.profession: Chairman of the Board of Directors
texts.text: The question for me is, is it going to be solved for the next year or not? No, I don't think so that the assumption we  are taking in the group, that will continue to be difficult. Perhaps not the same difficulties, perhaps not in the  same place, but there we will have difficulties in the environment. And I remember in 2008 with Emmanuel and I  think some of you were there, when everybody was saying, Europe, it's not an issue because we have the emerging  country and Emmanuel and myself comment and say, no, no, you will see also some difficulties in the emerging  country. So it's not because we are afraid, it's just because we are realistic and we think that the context will  continue to be difficult.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Waters, continued sustained strong growth. The story continues with the same drivers, a very balanced growth,  double-digit for the year. 7.5% volume contribution, 4.1% price and mix and that is mainly mix. The Water  performance is overall very solid. Water performance in Europe is very solid and, obviously, there is an  acceleration effect which is coming both from emerging markets and in particular Asia, China, and Indonesia, and  coming from the Aquadrinks performance. So that's a division which has continued de livering very strong  dynamics.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: I will end up, and I think that's a nice symbol, my presentation with non-financial KPIs. It's because it is very  important for us to continue building the model, not only from a pure financial standpoint, but also to look at  physical metrics which measure the improved sustainability of our model. We have, over the past few years,  delivered a significant reduction of our carbon intensity. This has not only made our business more sustainable  together, but it has been building productivity as well.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André Terisse
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We've extended our efforts to the reduction of the Water intensity, i.e., the Water we use for business; and,  therefore, the output we have. And we have as well reduced the frequency rate of our lost time accidents. All that is  very much intertwined with the improvement of the performance and is contributing to the improvements –  sorry, the performance of the group.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: CEO and Vice-Chairman of the Board of Directors
texts.text: Our Water business has grown significantly last year despite some challenges in the regulatory and competitive  environment in Mexico, which we're gradually addressing. But Brazil, Argentina have been growing fast. Our  aquadrinks has been growing on this region more than double-digit or basically double-digit too. So it's also one of  the big engines for our Water business in total. And you can see a collection of innovations, not even mentioning,  Oikos in Brazil which is not even in this picture. That's today already our fourth biggest brand in Brazil in Dairy.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: CEO and Vice-Chairman of the Board of Directors
texts.text: I'd like to turn to our guidance, to my guidance basically, sharing with my colleagues a chart which is no news, I  think, for you who attend full-year conferences. That's not particularly creative, but it's not to say that I don't  think it is important. That's the environment in which we are. But I would like to say that this is a year where we  really believe Danone has its own destiny in our hands despite all of this.

file: BN - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 23February2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The third important battleground for us has been water. Water, as I said, is one of our three businesses of four  businesses delivering more than 7% organic growth this year. This is on the back of a stellar year of growth in the  plain water area, our core fortress business, 8% organic growth. All geographies contributing to this growth,  including Europe, including France, and that's very good news for the future.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: A word before I finish to share briefly with you that you've heard me many times say that Danone's growth and  model is about a balanced economic, social, societal model. We think that being a leader in the alimentation, the  food and beverage world, in the current world means also working very hard on our social and societal impact, in  particular, on environment. So, I flagged here a few things that we've already shared with you.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our 2015 CSR achievements are what they should be. We've never satisfied with what they are, but I think they are  creating a future that makes most sense for everyone, in particular, through the COP21 of the UN in Paris on  climate change. We've announced a completely new and breakthrough climate policy that's completely consistent  with our strategic cycles, plastics, water and milk organization looking at the cycle of those, as we explained  during the Investor Day.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And they will translate into very breakthrough objectives, reaching a zero net carbon perspective, emba rking the  whole agricultural sector and not only our direct scope of responsibility over time. And one thing which is not here  but I can repeat is the commitment that the Evian brand will be the first zero net carbon brand in its category  worldwide and, of course, at Danone by 2020. So it's only four years from now.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving to Waters, Water division continued to deliver a very solid model of growth. We are full year at 7 %. And  we have 7% despite the impact of the transition that we have actively managed on Mizone starting the second half  on which I will come back in a minute.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: On the overall model and out of China, we have a growth that is double-digit which is a reflection of all of the work  that has been done around healthier hydration behind both plain waters and aquadrinks. There is still positive  traction on aquadrinks. It's a division where innovation is key to our agenda in order to activate, animate and  recruit consumer and kids to the category. And, on that, we have been successful as well. So, we will continue to  drive this solid platform for growth in the future.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, in 2016, as I said, the division will be driven around two axis: continue to develop healthier hydration option  in all regions focusing on the development of both plain waters and aquadrinks; and complete the transition of  Mizone, which should be done by the end of this year, within H1, which will be still impacted by the adjustment of  stock and a progressive return to growth in H2. As a consequence, 2016 will have an unbalanced profile of growth  which will be the reverse of the one that we had in 2015 because it will be impacted with the basis of comparison  of China on the H1 until it returns to a more normalized profile of growth in H2.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: This is page 34. This is a rich slide but I think it's an important one. It's an important one because it is importa nt  in order to read our 2016 agenda. I will start on the top of the chart with the environment and I will give you  absolutely no news on it. Meaning that we know we are in a VUCA world. We know it will continue. It's volatile.  It's unstable. And it's complex. I think, therefore, the priority that we have set ourselves in rebalancing our model  is really a key one because having a stronger and more resilient model will be what will help us to absorb this  volatility.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As you know and as I mention, we will have a start of the year that will be impacted by high basis of comparison in  water given the Mizone transition and in ELN. However, the underlying trends of all our categories remain very  solid and set for growth. So, when I take into account the comment I made on the environment, when I take into  account the high comps of the beginning of the year and especially when I take into account the way we want to  drive our agenda, so that growth is solid and profitable, we have defined our objective as being for sales growth  within a range of 3% to 5%.

file: BN - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 15February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: In term of outlook for Waters for 2017, we forecast solid growth, a growth that will be unbalanced between the first  part and the second part of the year still impacted by the Chinese transition. So, just to conclude on Water, we will  continue our agenda around developing healthier hydration opportunities for people in this great category,  continuing to rely on a strong innovation agenda and strong activation of our great brands.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: In terms of margin, you see a very significant improvement in the margin like-for-like of 167 basis points. This is  made of both structural and contextual elements. On the structural part, the growth and the favorable mix impact  have of course been drivers of improvement. And on the contextual part, it's basically mainly two things, which we  discussed at the end of 2015, which are the reverse effect of the cost in 2015 that we had related to adaptation  plan in Dumex, and also a cost that we incurred as a result of a fire in our plant Cuijk in the Netherlands.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: What it is about is traveling towards through the revolution that will lead people to eat and drink differently better  in the future, and we started this revolution by writing a manifesto that was a couple of years ago, a bunch of us  and then crowds of people in Danone and outside of Danone, basically described what they believed was a  foreseeable sustainable future for an industry like food and water in the incredibly complex world in which we are  entering.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: To start this journey and guide this journey, we planted a tree. This is our tree. This is the alimentation tree of  Danone. It has roots that are about ingredients, trusted origin, stewardships of water resources, zero-net CO2, a  number of very important components for the trust and the choice of consumers tomorrow but also for the ability  to operate with government NGOs in the again complex environment in which we are.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: What comes next is soon WhiteWave. WhiteWave is our next phase of transformation in the journey towards our  revolution. With two very clear matching corporate missions for the company, as you know, and this is a chart  you've seen already in July. It hasn't changed. Another chart you've seen in July hasn't changed either is that  WhiteWave will help us strengthen. At that time, I said fast forward the writing of our transformation. This is still  absolutely the case, by on the left side, bringing the entire sustainability and sustained growth of both dairy and  dairy alternative protein-based fermented products. This is where Danone has a fundamental expertise and where  WhiteWave has a fundamental expertise. And this will, on the right side of this chart, double the size of our  business in the U.S. We'll be entering the top 15 league of the largest companies in the food and beverage space,  but by far, the fastest growing in the environment that I just described. So, you can expect a superior growth by  this combined business in the coming few years in the U.S. compared to any other portfolio of food and beverage  companies there.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: And finally, as you know, we are creating a very significant partner for our trade for customers, being the largest  retail refrigerated dairy company.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: We're not about globalization here. We are about making sure that people can make the relevant decisions, given  the relevant political context, the relevant religious context, environmental context, NGO, civil society context that  we would not be able to do if we had a big shared service of 5,000 people in Geneva. So, this is the Danone  model of the future, and this is the backbone on which we are building now the next layer.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Back to this tree. There is one role on the bottom called EVP, resources efficiency, which will drive transversal  spend efficiency, balancing the short-, the mid-, the long-term efficiency agenda, integrating operations into our  cycles visions, so all our manufacturing into this vision, and most importantly providing the resources, the  ingredients, the sourcing, the roots for our Manifesto Brands. This is the bottom part of the tree guarding that.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Let me take you briefly through the two curves. To start with, the blue curve of long-term growth. We are already  paving the way of the alimentation journey I described. Three examples on this chart. The Dannon Pledge in the  U.S. for more naturality and non-GMO. Again, it's not about 10 years' time. It's about at the end of this year,  already at the end of this year, after one year and a half of hard work, three of our brands, top brands, by the way,  Dannon, Oikos and Danimals, our kids brand in the U.S., will be entirely out of the GMO system, entirely natural.  That's what consumers want, and we will deliver that.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Evian, you've heard us say by 2020, Evian will be fully carbon neutral. So wherever you enjoy Evian, in the U.S.,  in Japan, in China, you enjoy a brand that has paid and that has replanted trees to ensure that it's carbon neutral  beyond everything we do about reducing our direct impact on CO2.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: I think Danone is uniquely positioned to get there. You have all the values of our trees that I've already described.  But there is more. Two things. One is consumers are requesting – you are requesting, your kids will request, more  transparency, more traceability, more fairness for brands, more ethos in many ways. And to address this in a very  strategic way, we have decided to create a partnership – actually a unique partnership with the B Corp, B Lab  movement that we signed a year and a half ago now. So, Lorna Davis, our Chief Manifesto Catalyst sitting on the  board on one side. And we're testing with them what does that mean for a multinational company to work in a B  Corp environment. Only a few significant companies are part of the B Corp movement today. Most of them are  very small start-ups. But you have very inspiring brands like Ben & Jerry's, like Patagonia, like Happy Family for  Danone, and we want more.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: The other curve is the green curve, the accelerated efficiency. We have decided that it was time for us to  maximize our efficiency on the back of the very powerful backbone of One Danone now. 30 different clusters  geographically. The grid, unified and aligned grid of our regions, we believe we now can ambitiously roll out a  program which will allow us to buy better, to spend better, to work better, which is entirely focused on the scope of  professional services, sales and marketing spending, and operation spendings.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So, efficiency is not just about the short term. Sustainability is nothing else than the efficiency of the future. And  that's what we are creating with this very important function. So, the mix of both will allow us to deliver what is on  this chart again, which is decoupling the short-term efficiency and the mid-long-term growth by ensuring two very  important things: consistent EPS growth and fueling our growth model with the savings that we will generate  through the efficiency programs.

file: BN - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 16February2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: So, if you turn with me on page 4, this is basically the landscape in which we are working on developing our  business. Our ambition is to be leading the way to create and to share sustainable value. You've heard us plant  the One Planet. One Health vision in June last year, which really embraces the food revolution that's sweeping  the category in many ways and that we see as an opportunity, and we don't want to be the incumbents on that  side of things.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: The result on this page is that we are developing what I think is today's the healthiest of all food portfolio of large  companies around the world, which we manage in one of the most responsible manners to our consumers,  employees, suppliers, customers, and to yourselves, and creating, therefore, a sustainable circle of value creation  over time.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Page 7 is another important set of metrics of the of the year as well because as I earlier said, I think sustainability  means we need to deliver on many more metrics. The close to 90% number that you see here of our portfolio of  products deemed nutritionally to be consumed on a daily basis as an important metric for us in terms of the  sustainability of what we do every day in this world. The 10% reduction of carbon intensity for Danone on a two- year basis with our starting point of 2015 is very promising for us, too.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: You all know how much carbon footprint reduction is also linked to value creation, efficiency in resources, cost  management, et cetera. But most importantly, for us, we are the only company that measures that against the full  scope, so not only our direct scope, but that includes agriculture which is roughly 60% of the total emissions of the  Danone system.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: By the way, on this, starting this year, 20% of our LTI as management will be related to the ability of Danone to  stay at the leadership level, the A- that you see here, which is measured by the Carbon Disclosure Project of the  UN as such. And this is to ensure consistency over time.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: And finally, we've this year delivered the accreditation of five of our companies as B-Corp, as you can see on  page 8. Turning to page 8, we are walking the path towards our certification roadmap. We see DanoneWave in  the U.S. already a public benefit corporation, well on track to get certified in 2018 as a B-Corp. And Cécile and the  team have restructured our syndicated credit loan in a very innovative way, including ESG and actually B-Corp  agenda as drivers of lowering the cost of that debt for us, if we achieve certain ESG and B-Corp criteria. So, this  is really embedding sustainability into the financial performance of Danone.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Turning to page 12 and in the same vein, you remember this bet that we made in the U.S. of going for non-GMO  pledge for half of our total volumes in a number of our biggest brands. So, the first one on which we've actually  reached the non-GMO total certification is Danimals, which is the leading kids brand in the U.S. in dairy. You can  see how the market share in 2017 has evolved, a very strong increase in the market share as a result of the non- GMO certification of Danimals. And in a category that has continued to decline, we have enjoyed close to a  double-digit growth of that brand with the two largest other competitors strongly declining in market share. So, this  is the first reward of that pledge and there will be more coming, also an element of consistency between business  sustainability and financial performance.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: More on page 14 about an important topic on another division which is water, where I'm pleased with a number of  initiatives that were taken by our brands, evian, Lanjaron, Villavicencio, but I could name Bonafont and others  about tackling the big topic of recycled – recycling and plastics. We see this not only as a license to operate, but  also growingly a consumer choice. And we announced in Davos that evian would be beyond being zero carbon in  2020; by 2025, would be fully positive in plastic, meaning using entirely recycled plastics for its business system.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: The other very important efficiency agenda for Danone is, of course, our Protein program that we announced  exactly one year ago at the full year of 2016. So, 2017 has been a year where we've put the foundations in place.  10 of our 30 local clusters are activated on Protein. We've on-boarded the rest of the clusters already. All the  playbooks in the 15 sub-categories of SG&As – services and goods spending are in place now. And we are  confirming, obviously, our 2020 objective to be delivering €1 billion of savings, €300 million of them being into the  margin, and €100 million of that already to be booked in the 2018 margin of Danone.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice-President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement, Danone SA
texts.text: Moving to the next page. All the performance that you've seen has been made in a still volatile environment,  which included strong headwinds. So, if you look at the chart from left to right, first and as anticipated, milk prices  have increased overall by around 10%. We suffered the same pattern on crude oil prices, which increased in the  second half more than 10%, negatively impacting the bill for plastic packaging.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice-President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement, Danone SA
texts.text: Moving finally to Water on page 41. Water generated a very strong performance with growth at 10.3% in Q4 from  a 3% growth in the previous nine months, with both plain waters and Aquadrinks in all region contributing to  growth, and including the confirmed end of transition period for Mizone in China.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice-President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement, Danone SA
texts.text: On the margin side, Waters delivered a profitable growth equation with a full-year margin improvement. This  includes strong negative impact in H2 related to the PET price that has increased, as I said earlier, and the  negative impact of the sharp devaluation of the sterling. These negatives were offset by portfolio valorization, mix  of growth and overall operational efficiencies as well as very good buying practices to mitigate PET impact.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice-President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement, Danone SA
texts.text: On page 42, regarding the drivers of performance for Q4, plain waters grew double-digit in Q4, driven by very  strong brand activation and successful innovations for new design on the Volvic brand, new format,  personalization in Bonafont. This performance is supported by positive trends across all region; Asia, LatAm and  Europe. We have also progressed in our initiatives to have evian becoming a circular brand where we committed  to have our bottles 100% plastics recycled by 2025. Europe in Q4 was particularly strong, driven by growing  market, especially Spain, that was backed by a very good plan.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice-President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement, Danone SA
texts.text: Turning to the underlying drivers of our like-for-like margin improvement, the 70 basis points improvement is a  result of, first, a slight negative evolution of our margin from operation, which includes a positive contribution from  growth through mix and portfolio valorization, a strong negative impact from the increase of raw materials and  packaging bill with an increase, as I said, in both worldwide [indiscernible] (47:37) milk and PET price around 9%,  and lastly, mitigated by continued strong productivities, over €600 million, that enables to mitigate most of the cost  base inflation.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice-President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement, Danone SA
texts.text: If we go to 2018 and what we expect, overall, milk price inflation will continue but to a lower extent than last year,  so around low- to mid-single digit. There will continue to be a strong increase of the crude oil price driving up the  PET pricing leading to an overall inflation of our plastic bill to high-single digit. We will also continue to be  impacted by the sterling devaluation due to our import model, notably for Waters and EDP in the UK.

file: BN - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 19February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: On the brand side, huge transformation going on, and I think in the next couple of days, weeks, we will discuss  about one of the big changes, which has been Activia and I'll come back to that. 20% of our brands are now in  their Manifesto journey and they grow faster than others. But also happy to report that for the first time, we've  been best-in-class in carbon reduction on the CDP climate ranking last year, and we expect to continue that.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Faber
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Danone SA
texts.text: Plant-based, 15% of our total EDP sales and as you know, we have a plan that is going to treble that Plant-based  business by 2025 for us to €5 billion. So it's a big investment, we continue to focus a lot on that after the Alpro and  the WhiteWave acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement & Director, Danone SA
texts.text: If we go now through our different entities, first, if you look at the overall performance, it's important to note that  both quarters in Specialized Nutrition have grown more than 5%, which makes 50% of our portfolio that is growing  over 5%. If I start with Waters on page 28, the Water business accounted, as you know, for around 20% of  Danone sales in 2018, delivered a consistent mid-single-digit growth all along the year, landing at 5.3% growth on  a full-year basis and posting its sixth consecutive quarter at mid- to high-single-digit growth.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement & Director, Danone SA
texts.text: Then let's go to 2019 starting with the context. Overall, in term of raw material, the indicator shows that milk price  will be up single digit this year, and it's already the case. It was already the case for S&P in January. The oil price  has been quite volatile. All in all, we expect frozen packs material to be up mid- to high-single digit this year.

texts.speaker: Cécile Cabanis
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, IS/IT, Cycles & Procurement & Director, Danone SA
texts.text: For 2019 and in order to help you understand better our path towards 2020 commitments, we have decided to  guide more precisely on growth and margin. So, for 2019, our guidance will be the following: around 3% like-for- like sales growth, which will be accelerating versus the base of 2.6% in full-year 2018 excluding Argentina; and at  least 15% of recurring operating margin. 2019 will be another key step towards both our 2020 commitments and  our 2030 goals. We are confident that we are taking the right step to strengthen our operating model.

file: BNP - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 6May2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On Slide 53, you see that BancWest’s asset quality is truly stabilizing and the need for further  impairment of its investment portfolio is declining. As for Europe-Mediterranean, it’s benefited from  a decrease of the cost of risk in Ukraine where the environment is improving, in particular after the  presidential election and also due to the favorable evolution of the steel price.

file: BNP - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 4May2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-11.pdf
BNP - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 4May2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: And on that object of the own debt revaluation, which impacted negatively of course, I wish to remind you that  BNP Paribas will calculate this on market replacement value and so this impact basically reflects the improvement  in the market conditions at which BNP funds itself.  So if I now take you through a couple of slides and particularly if I can ask you to cast your eyes on slide four,  where you basically see the key elements, you see that by the end of March, we have completed 80% of our  adaptation plan. I remind you the adaptation plan has objective to improve with 100 basis points the core Tier I  ratio, so we have done 80% and of course this has ramifications on Basel 2.5 as well. And we have a handsome  10.4% core Tier I ratio.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: Before switching into the evolution of the businesses, allow me to give you a quick update on the solvency, the  liquidity and other elements around it. So if I can ask you to flip or slide depending on the device you are to slide  seven. And on slide seven, we look at the solvency or the adaptation plan as it impacts the solvency. And as I just  said, we have achieved 80% of the overall plan where under other activities you find back the sale basically of  Klépierre and retail you find the progress with respect to leading and Personal Finance. You know these are the  elements for which there are also adaptation plans in being rolled out.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: And then in CIB, we have the reserve-based lending deal that we talked about in the US that we have sold to Wells  Fargo, and in addition to that of course, we have further reduced the risk-weighted assets by €6 billion in the  quarter. And of course all these elements had some impact on the P&L so we will see that as €84 million in terms  of adaptation costs. The costs are impacted in this quarter by €84 million due to all these adaptation plans and of  which roughly two-thirds are at CIB and then there is also €74 million impact related to the sale of €2 billion  worth of assets. So that is part of the €6 billion that I talked about. There is €2 billion that came from sales and  which had a little discount and so led to a loss, a one-off loss of €74 million. So that is the status of the overall  implementation plan, adaptation plan.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: Operating cost for investment solutions for operating merchant changed and as we reap benefits or some of the  first benefits from the adaptation plan in asset management, but at the same time as I said we also keep investing.  We don't go stop-and-go we continue to invest especially in Asia.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: But allow me to first finalize the CIB as a whole, by reflecting on the costs, which were actually marginally higher.  If we look in terms of constant scope and exchange rate instead of facially the amount that you see. So if we  exclude the €54 million resulting from the adaptation costs and the one that the two thirds of the total that I  mentioned earlier and we correct for the dollar which basically appreciated over the periods, the adaptation costs  and dollars though, the delta is actually negative at 1.7%. So the costs in that scope reduced by 1.7%. And in any  case, BNP Paribas can fund one of the best cost income ratios in the business. I mean even without correcting for  the elements, we stand at 60.6%, so 60.6%, which further improves to 57.5% if we exclude the impact of the  adaption plan. So all things considered, CIB delivered a good performance despite the impact of the deleveraging,  which is underway.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: So that is basically an illustration of that we stress the advisory and structuring. We also of course stressed  $1.3 billion project bond out for Dolphin Energy or a deal in Germany, which basically – a good combination  example of how financing – so the corporate banking and fixed income can successfully work together.

texts.text: And particularly noteworthy is the contraction in personal finance thanks to its adaptation plan to which I  referred earlier. Investment solutions costs were marginally higher as good cost control, especially in asset  management, was countered by an increase or increased costs to cope with higher levels of activity in insurance.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: So bear with me for a couple of more slides starting at 27 which is our global cash balance sheet. You can see that  in the first quarter, we have further increased the surplus of stable funding which is the dark and the pale green  parts, so the surplus of stable funding over the funding needs of our client activity. This increased by another €10  billion in the quarter and now stands at a high €79 billion, equivalent to 111% of the financing needs of our  customer activity. This holds true also in U.S. dollars where the surplus has increased to €57 billion by the end of  March.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: Now, if you can again proceed to slide seven, I would like to say a word about the Adaptation Plan. As you can see,  it's basically now totally done and ahead of announced schedule. In particular and as a reminder, the U.S. dollar  funding needs we reduced by $65 billion, but we already did that or achieve that back in April. The CIB RWA  reduction of €45 billion we've basically done, and here I would like to stress that we accomplished this with less  than a third of the sale cost originally envisaged, that is to say for those who follow us for a while that it is not the  €800 million that we announced that it cost us, but it was limited to €250 million.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: Operating expenses increased at a lower rate than revenues. As you know, that is basically what we aim for. This  was essentially due to two contrasting factors. The first is the benefits kicking in from the Adaptation Plan in Asset  Management, where costs showed a 6.8% reduction to that, but secondly and on the other hand, the fact that we  continued to develop our businesses in Insurance and Security Services, especially in Asia. And so, all in all to  conclude, and net of the one-off impact from Greece in 2011, pre-tax income showed a healthy double-digit  improvement compared to previous year.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: So, with this, I would like to conclude my focus on the different business lines. Before I hand over to you, I would  like to illustrate a few significant evolutions in our balance sheet as well as in our liquidity and solvency. If we start  in the third quarter, we have further increased the surplus of stable funding over the funding needs of our client  activity. This is the greenish part of this slide. This increased, as I said, this accident increased by €19 billion and  now stands at a high €71 billion. Or expressed if I look at those green liabilities over those green assets, it leads to  an equivalent of 110% of the financing needs of our customer activity.

texts.speaker: Lars Machenil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: I'm almost there, I'll always give it – almost give it back to you for questions. There's basically slide 32, that I want  a talk about on the solvency. I already told you that we exceeded 9% Tier 1 target fully-loaded Basel 3 and actually  we're at 9.5%, which basically means we indeed exceeded it. This corresponds to 11.4% under Basel 2.5. If I look at  the evolution of the quarter, this means that the Basel 3 fully-loaded ratio improved by again, for lack of a better  word, a mighty 60 basis points with half of the benefits accruing from the combination of the net income, which  we showed you are solid and the RWA reduction stemming from our Adaptation Plan. However, the other half of  the benefit came from the revaluation in the available for sale portfolio. So, it's on the upside. This clearly  illustrates the volatility introduced by Basel 3, so those who would have forgotten about it, this is what the  removal of the prudential filters do to you and it basically confirms in our mind that it was wise for us to reduce  our sovereign debt portfolio.

texts.speaker: Philippe Bordenave
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: How did we achieve that? Basically, in two-half, the first half was the sharp decline of dollar funding needs of CIB  minus $57 billion due to the adaptation plan. And so this – the half was a reduction of the structural needs of the  – basically, so you can, you can look at those $57 billion as being broadly the same as the $53 billion of funding  needs of our customer activity reduction that you see at the bottom of the column, $22 billion reduction in  consumer loans and $31 billion reduction in trading assets. And so this is really structural below the black line in  the middle.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: We naturally work to deliver an adaptation plan reducing costs, I will come back just in a second. We intend to  reduced cost of roughly 10% in Asset Management 2012 compared to 2011. And naturally, we continue to develop  in emerging countries because the Asset Management is very good in emerging countries. In all the businesses, as  I mentioned, the revenues are up. We naturally continue – you know very well BNP Paribas, we continue to have  always cost optimization. And so, our pre-tax income excluding Greece is minus 6% compared to 2010. So  globally, we continue to show that our business in Investment Solution is resilient despite the very challenging  environment for 2011.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: So our action plan is very simple, to continue to invest and to adapt in-source businesses. We think those  mentioned, we are going to reduce the cost in Asset Management of 10% but we continue to develop naturally in  alternative investment and in energy market debts and equity as we develop Asset Management.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: So now, I come to CIB. As you can imagine, it is really a revolution into CIB business model all over the world for  all the banks. And so, as Philippe mentioned, first of all, we have to deliver the adaptation plan we explained last  November. So in U.S. dollar, we have reduced sharply our funding needs. Our objective was to – our target was to  reduce by $60 billion, end of 2012. We have achieved $57 billion, end of 2011, and so we have increased the target  from $60 billion to $65 billion by the end of 2012. Naturally, we have also to reduce our risk-weighted assets.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: It is interesting to see that in Basel 2, end of 2012 – end of 2010, we were at €187 billion in terms of risk-weighted  asset. After Basel 2.5, we remained let's say at €197 billion due to, first of all, the increase of Basel 2.5, let's say  only €37 billion, it's a huge amount but not so huge compared to some competitors. And our adaptation plan, €22  billion in capital market and in financial activities plus €5 billion in also adaptation measures. So globally, at the  end, we have delivered a pre-tax income of €3.6 billion for the whole year. And for the first quarter, we were just  at a breakeven which was not so bad compared to – due to a very, very difficult environment. So globally, we have  delivered what we have said and as always, at the level of BNP Paribas.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: For 2012, the program is €20 billion. It's significantly reduced due to the adaptation plan because that will need  our reducing as well, and we have already completed €5 billion of new issues. As of the end of January in two  months because we are taking into account what we did in December as well because we closed the program last  year at the end of November. So we keep issuing roughly €2 billion to €3 billion per month.  On a pure private placement basis – mostly private placement, retail by our own – the placement in our own retail  networks as well and a few other ways with a private nature I would say like long-term repos, placement through  the CRH.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: And again, the switchover to Basel 2.5 generated an inflation of €32 billion. You remember we had said that it  would be in the region of €40 billion, so at the end it's 40 – €32 billion essentially in Capital Markets because,  well – and at the same time, the de-leveraging plan and the adaptation plan has generated a reduction of €25  billion in terms of risk-weighted assets of which precisely €8 billion related to the lower inflation resulting from  the application of the Basel 2.5 rules. So we have almost – well, plus €32 billion, minus €25 billion, if you want we  have almost, I would say, balanced one with the other.

texts.speaker: Georges Chodron de Courcel
texts.profession: Co-Chief Operating Officer, BNP Paribas SA
texts.text: We have the adaptation plan that is bringing back 68 basis points, 100 minus the 32 we have already achieved.  And then, we have the assumption of a strip dividend for both years that is adding 20 basis points and the organic  generation for – during 2012, we have taken as – we have taken the consensus – the Bloomberg consensus as  usual in that kind of situation with the assumption of a payout ratio of 25% again in 2012. And this gives 72 basis  points. Total, 9%. So, it's an ambitious target, but it's a target that is achievable.

texts.speaker: Yann Gérardin
texts.profession: Head - Corporate and Institutional Banking
texts.text: All region have enjoyed growth of our Corporate Banking businesses. If we excluded the impact of our voluntary  downsizing of the E&C [Energy & Commodities] business, [ph] it means that (23:22) all the CIB business line  achieved a double-digit underlying growth in 2015.

texts.text: The downsizing of the Energy & Commodity Financing line is largely completed and the activity is now well  positioned.

texts.speaker: Yann Gérardin
texts.profession: Head - Corporate and Institutional Banking
texts.text: In addition, CIB has been very disciplined and agile as proved by many rece nt actions such as our early adaptation  to Basel 3. As I said, we're also finalizing the downsizing of our Energy & Commodity finance business line. file: BNR - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 6May2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Just let me begin with some words on the macroeconomic environment. Overall, the global economy continued to  grow moderately. We saw Europe in a path of positive growth. The North American economy grew in terms of  industrial production but at a slower rate due the pressure on some export-orientated business sectors and a  repeat of the poor weather conditions we also saw last year. And Latin America and Asia Pacific, they presented a  mixed picture with different dynamics, country by country.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In North America, Brenntag's North American development in the first quarter was clearly positive. Gross profit  increased by 3.9% on an FX adjusted basis. Our business with the oil and gas industry made that higher level, as I  said last year. With the lower price of oil affecting our business in the upstream segments, the highly diversified  [ph] niche (09:20) of our business allowed us to maintain positive performance as a whole. As a result, EBITDA  strongly grew by 10.8% on a FX adjusted basis.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In North America, we also expect a positive earnings development. Due to the highly diversified nature of our oil  and gas business, we expect earnings stability and the long-term potential of the business remains very strong.
