texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: Acquisitions made last year contributed operating EBITDA amounting to about €13 million. The demand in the oil  and gas sector was clearly lower than in Q1 2015. Previous year's Q1 was the strongest quarter of the year. Based  on the gross profit that was lower by €15 million, we estimate that this resulted in an EBITDA decline for oil and  gas of about €9 million or 35% -- 34% apologies, of the oil and gas EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: Come to North America, gross profit in North America increased by 5.9%. This is clearly driven by contributions  of the acquisitions for 2015 set against the weaker than expected performance in oil and gas and some challenges  in the industrial production. The operating EBITDA in North America decreased by 5.3%, [ph] which (11:17) is  almost attributable to path of the reduction of the oil and gas gross profit could not be fully compensated by cost  reductions.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: We have taken measures to replace – to reduce capacity in the oil and gas business to reflect the low level of  demand. We reduced head count by more than 13% or more than 150 FTEs in these businesses beginning of 2015.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: Now, looking to the macroeconomic picture, the start of the year was clearly challenging but not significantly  outside expectations. There was a sustainable weakness in the overall economic demand in North America.  Demand for the oil and gas sector shows further sequential declines. The weaker performance in Q1 in this sector  is expected to be compensated in subsequent quarters by reasonable business from planned, [ph] unplanned  maintenance (14:02) in the midstream sector. We might expect GPs to be in the region of €55 million to €60  million for subsequent quarters.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member-Management Board
texts.text: We will see solid EBITDA growth from our business in Europe, Asia Pacific and Latin America, excluding  Venezuela. In North America, industrial production inside and outside of oil and gas is sequentially weaker and  we expect it to remain a challenge for the rest of the year. We expect our EBITDA in oil and gas will be around €15  million lower for the full-year basis. For North America, we might expect to see a positive contribution from  acquisitions. In Latin America, the 2015 EBITDA generation in Venezuela of around €12 million will not repeat  this year.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Upstream is affected by the fall in prices and some drilling rigs are now idle as a result of unfavorable economics. In addition, we see upside for  North American and European manufacturing sector particularly compared to a year ago where energy and  transportation costs were higher.

texts.speaker: Steven E. Holland
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: Our customers are B2B and are often multi-site organizations. The best way to further describe these customers  is to explain their typical requirements. They are looking for innovative customized solutions from a specialist in  our categories. They require a one-stop shop of competitively priced, low-value bulky essential items, without  which their business cannot operate, and as a result, they demand consistently high service levels. They need  both manufacturer branded and our own brand, as well as innovative and environmentally-friendly products.  These requirements are met through our deep product knowledge and expertise.

file: BNZLL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 25February2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: I've also talked to you before about our salespeople and customer service specialists based around the world,  who I'm very proud of and who offer exceptional levels of service to our customers. Today, I would like to illustrate  how their expertise makes us uniquely well-placed to help customers in the area of sustainable product solutions  and also share some insights into the benefits of global sourcing center in Asia.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: As we are all aware, the environmental impact of single-use plastics is an increasing priority to our society. As a  leading distributor to the grocery and foodservice sectors, the majority of the single-use plastic products we sell  are food and beverage related packaging, which is essential to the transit of products from our customer's site to  the point of consumption in a practical, safe, and hygienic way. As such, there will always be a need for these  types of products, although increasingly with more sustainable characteristics, which we are actively promoting.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: Given our size and expertise, we have a unique position in the supply chain, which enables us to advise our  customers on their sustainability strategies and at the same time, benefit from our relationships with our extensive  supplier base in order to bring a broad range of sustainable products to market.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: Since we are not a manufacturer with heavy investments in capital equipment and a distributor that turns  inventory extremely fast, we are very agile when it comes to adapting our product range. As the global leader and  expert in our industry, we are proactively working with customers, suppliers, and other stakeholders to promote  and support the sustainable approach to single-use plastics. We see the increasing demand for sustainable  products as an opportunity for growth.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: To provide some insight into our capabilities in the area of sustainability, I would like to share two examples with  you. Plastic straws became a much talked about issue in the UK in early 2018. Almost overnight, customers  wanted to switch from plastic to paper straws. We already had paper straws in our product range, and we were,  therefore, able to adapt quickly to this changing demand. As a result, last year in the UK, the volume of plastic  straws we sold fell significantly, but was more than made up in value terms by increased sales of paper straws,  resulting in a 25% increase in the total sales value of straws. This demonstrates our sourcing capabilities and  expertise in sustainable products, as well as the agility of our supply chain.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: A further competitive advantage lies in acting as a trusted partner with our customers, supporting them on their  sustainability journey. A good example of this is our partnership with one of our contract catering customers in the  UK. This caterer services a large client at their main facility, which has two restaurants and eight other food  outlets serving over 2,500 meals and 3,600 hot beverages daily, using some 500 Bunzl products. Their client has  been focused on sustainability for a number of years.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: Initially, we helped them to review their entire range and introduce more sustainable products, using both our  Sustain items, which are fully compostable, and the Revive range, which is both recyclable and made from  recycled materials. Using Bunzl's expert advice, our customer was able to consolidate all disposable products into  as few material groups as possible to enhance their ability to compost and recycle these products after use.

texts.speaker: Frank Andre van Zanten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Bunzl Plc
texts.text: More recently, the specialist knowledge of our sales and sourcing teams has enabled to us to introduce further  alternatives to plastic products, including reusable items. These alternatives include takeout food containers,  which are made from sugarcane fibers. In addition, we have partnered with a manufacturer to design and produce  an entirely new range of compostable products for yogurt and fruit, which will be introduced next month. With the  changing landscape for the future of single-use plastics, we are especially well-placed to support our customers  going forward.

texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.

texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.

texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: On slide 10, we have the copper price, different from zinc, there we have a quite substantial price  increase compared to Q4. texts.text: And we can turn to the Smelters production on slide 19, and there we see there the weaker spot on  the quarterly result, which is obviously the low production in the copper smelters on the left side of  the slide. And here we are probably less affected than some of  our competitors because we have this ability in particularly in Rönnskär to combine the traditional  copper flow with recycling of electronics, exactly what we are now expanding as I’m coming back to  later.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: 3 output from the copper smelters had its impact and we turned the positive curve trend line turned a  little bit down in Q1, as you can see on that slide.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: And now if we turn to slide 22 and talk about today’s big news, I will say is that we decided on  today’s Board Meeting to spend SEK1.3 billion on increasing the capacity for recycling electronic  scrap from the present 45,000 tonnes per year to 120,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: We will increase the metal production from electronic scrap by 2 tonnes of gold, 32 tonnes of silver  and 14,000 tonnes of copper. This is not going to increase the output for copper in Rönnskär, its  going to replace the equivalent feed of lower margin copper conc.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: So I think it is important that these additional volumes is additional from electronics scrap, but is not  giving a net increase for the smelters. The payback is good and the profitability is good. We plan on  a four year payback. And that is a surprisingly short time in this capital heavy industry is, of course,  because we build on using open capacity and the copper process in Rönnskär. So we can build on  past, already existing investments or fixed assets.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: On the market, electronics scrap is driven very much by the fact that we are using in the world more  electronics, and the life cycle of electronics products are reduced year after year. And that means  that more and more is wasted. And this waste is both something that the world would like to take  care of, and it’s also a very good source of material.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: On slide 23, we see the breakdown of where the electronic scrap or scrap is coming from and we  have the European Directives WEEE, which calls for an increased recycling rate in the different  countries in Europe. It’s presently at four kilos, and is planned to be increased as a directive to 13  kilos per person and here in Europe by 2016. So we think the availability of electronics material will  be very good.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: On slide 24 we can see that Europe is well developed when it comes to recycling electronics, and  there is a huge potential in the market for the technology leader we are to develop and continue to  expand in this area. We have on 25 a value chain or a material flow in Rönnskär. As you can see  today recycled materials account for 24% of Rönnskär’s feed. But only part of that is electronic  scrap, which today accounts for 6% of the total feed in Rönnskär, which will increase with the ratio  new spoke about.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: The material flow once it’s coming into us, as seen on slide 27, and as you can see we have  basically two starting points of the flow in Rönnskär. One is for the copper conc from mines, for  example, from Aitik but also from external mines. And we have another one with KALDO  technology, which is pre-processing the electronics, and that is going into the refining process. And  we extract copper gold, silver and the other metals. And also waste energy is used for, and sold –  re-sold on the market.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: So there should be a slight potential for a reduction in tonnage on ready products. We’ve had a  CapEx of almost 600 million in the first quarter, which is clearly down from the CapEx of 1 billion in  year-over-year ‘09. And it’s slightly impacted by the fact that we are in the commissioning phase of  the Aitik project, and of course we are not finalizing payments until things are working and then we  are in agreement with that.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: Below that you can see a positive effect of over 100 million from lower costs in the first quarter  compared to the first quarter – in the last quarter of last year. And there are some comparison  issues where we – compared to a high fourth quarter where we had slightly one-offs. So I would  say that costs are roughly on par with the same level as in the fourth quarter. When it comes to  prices and terms, we’ve had a positive development of 200 million and then that’s entirely explained  by the improved hedge levels as Lennart noted on our copper hedging program. And as you can  see at the bottom of this graph where we specify the hedge effects in each quarter, we had a  negative effect in Q4 of 72 million, and we have a positive effect of 196 and that’s where the  change come into play of the copper hedges.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon, everybody and welcome to this presentation of the first quarter results of Boliden.
texts.text: The concentrate market for copper is very tight and continues to be a struggle to us. We have today  been deciding on the large electronic scrap recycling expansion program. And I think this is a very  positive move and we are very excited about that one.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good afternoon, everybody, to this webcast of Boliden’s First Quarter Result 2011. Together

And we are on the expansion program of the Garpenberg zinc silver mine, and  also that project is on plan.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good afternoon, everybody, to this webcast of Boliden’s First Quarter Result 2011. Together
texts.text: If we go into the market in the first quarter, it has continued to develop well, both when it comes to  the zinc and the copper. We think the fundamentals in China  are good, but fact is the published demand was down.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good afternoon, everybody, to this webcast of Boliden’s First Quarter Result 2011. Together
texts.text: We have a good industrial demand in Europe. And if we turn to the supply side, we have lower  growth in metals production in the world. We see lower activities in the  Chinese smelters, and there are speculations if that is an attempt to push up the treatment charges  for the negotiations or for other reasons.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell, President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay. Good afternoon, everybody, to this webcast of Boliden’s First Quarter Result 2011. Together

texts.profession: Okay. Good afternoon, everybody, to this webcast of Boliden’s First Quarter Result 2011. Together

Europe and North America – or  high growth in U.S.A., Germany, somewhat slower, and the rest you can see on the graph.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have in the press release this morning announced two things. First of all, that we have found a new copper  discovery, which is between the Laver and Boliden. It's 10 or 100 kilometers north of the Boliden Area. And we are  looking at the continuation of Aitik after 36 million tonnes and beyond. And then we are saying that we have  sufficient resources in reserves in Aitik to carry an even higher production rate. And therefore, we have started to  evaluate the further expansions.  The background for both of these projects are the exploration results that we have had in the previous years. We  have seen a very good development of our mineral reserves and resources. We have updated those basically in the  February of each year. And now we are coming with some exciting things in between of the normal reporting  times.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We started the drilling in 2009. It's a porphyry copper deposit. It's an Aitik-type mineralization, large scale and  low grades. You can see on the picture, the blue lines or the blue holes are evaluated. And we have a number of  new holes, which are not yet analyzed. The cross section is looking like this. And as you can see from this, it's  shallow. It's not deep down, but it's immediately coming up to the surface. So it's a very accessible ore body.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: A total of 57 drill holes and 21,700 meters have been completed through April. We have the copper, gold moly  bearing mineralization and identified, but it's not yet classified as mineral resource. And we hope and plan to have  it classified as mineral resource at the turn of, or at the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: As you can see on the table, it's a very large deposit. It's – we think ore deposit, but exploration results indicates  500 million tonnes to 700 million tonnes with an average grade of 0.15 to 0.25 and the gold between 0.10 and 0.15  grams per tonne.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We will continue to drill in the area. We will prepare for mining concessions, and we are going to start. This is a  very big – this is a potentially a very big thing and therefore it's going to take a long time and therefore, we will  start with some of the environmental work already in the fall of 2012. We'll continue the drill program and the  impact study will be in the mid of 2012.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We are looking at, basically, a growth possibility from 36 million tonnes per year to 45 million tonnes. We have  decided to start a pre-feasibility, which will include a lot of different things. And for certain, a tailings expansion  and more mining equipment.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We are going to look at even higher production numbers. We are talking about a possibility at a later stage to look  at 65 million tonnes per year. But this is basically for permitting and for planning. It's nothing I suggest anyone  should think of at this point. But we are going to talk about it in the permitting. And therefore, the numbers will  be around. But 45 million tonnes seems to be an interesting study that we have started. The summary of the two

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In Aitik, it's debottlenecking almost activity where most of the infrastructure is already in place. And we think we  can go to 45 million tonnes without too big difficulties or major too big investments. In Laver, it's at a very early  stage. It's a discovery. We don't even have it as a mineral resource. And I'm sure you will ask a lot of questions  about all the details. And we are shy of being precise on much things. We are showing what we know, and that is  that we have a discovery here. And the indications are a low grade and high volume potential.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have, in the Boliden Area, also the Maurliden East and Maurliden, the two small open pit mines. Maurliden  East is combined copper, zinc. And we will see a gradual decline in copper. And we will see gradual increase in  zinc.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The guidance on CapEx is about SEK5 billion in the year. And, again, the new copper opportunities are exciting.  With the disclaimer, and certainly around Laver, it's a lot of – it's a very early stage and I would like to underline  that.

file: BOL - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 3May2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Copper is more dramatic. The most dramatic is, of course, the inventory, the bottom part of the chart here where  you see the gray areas peaking very dramatically in a short period of time. And I would say that this is very  difficult to understand, the transparency is not good. There are beliefs that this is moving of inventories. And  despite the high levels or much higher and much – or very fast increase in inventory levels, there is still not a huge  sort of oversupply in the market. It's not easy to buy copper concentrates. For example, when we close Rönnskär  for maintenance shutdown. So the whole picture is not very transparent for the market or from us as both a seller  and a buyer of concentrates in the market.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The price is a reflection of that short spike in inventories and copper prices are far below the bottom in Q4 if you  compare with the zinc situation, so quite negative copper price development in the quarter and also after the  quarter end.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: This is a picture which is showing in somewhat more details. It's from CRU, and you can look at on the top here,  we have copper and zinc metal demand, 4.5% and 4.1%, plus were zinc and copper demand increase year-on-year.  It's a similar situation when it comes to the demand.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have lower precious metals prices. We have lower hedge result, and we have a negative TC impact adding up to  minus SEK59 million. And we compare here Q1 with Q4 of 2012. The dollar-Swedish krona exchange rate  difference is well known. We have cost which is minus SEK39 million. So we have a cost increase but comparing  with historic increases, this is a low, and we have maintained the costs well here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you look at the production, as we can see here, the ore tonnage, if you look at the light yellow bars, it's on the  level of last year. Winter conditions are – basically every winter, sort of playing in here, and we can see it on all the  Q1 bars in light yellow, that it's lower than the average for other quarters. We see that the metal content, the line  diagram is going down, grade again, as I said.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: On zinc, we had not a fantastic quarter in ore production, but it was better than Q4, it's a little less than a couple of  quarters earlier. We had warned for lower grades in Garpenberg and Tara, and we had a little better grades here,  but still we are on lower than reserve grades in Garpen.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the smelters, basically good news, SEK298 million in result or profit before interest and tax and before –  without revaluation of the process inventory, compared to SEK360 million, so a little down. SEK202 million in  Q4, so it's a very big improvement from Q4. CapEx SEK213 million. It's down from a year before when we had the  final payments of some of the electronic scrap recycling payments to do.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The production, as you can see here, not very dramatic, slightly lower metal production than before but a good  level of feed. And in the zinc we have high level of feed in Q4. We had the Odda leaching reactor breakdown and  we're moving on in a good way, so not too much to say here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have the push-backs, we have a lot of waste rock, we have a lot of things to cope with. We demonstrated high  capacity, but we informed everybody that we're going in the direction of the plan. Q1 was 33 million tonnes, I  think we are spot on basically the expansion plans. We could have been a little bit better without some of the  freezing conditions and whatever, but basically, we are following the plan on Aitik.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Electronics recycling is going as planned, nothing new on that. It started well last year. It has been continuing  through and we see good results in the smelters. And it's part of it, it's coming from there.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The Kankberg mine started well and actually ahead of plan. We have had some issues in the leaching. We have  long lead times because all the ore is going through leaching instead of some of the gold coming with the [ph]  copper con (20:48) and whatever.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The zinc smelter in Kokkola with the silver projects, it's going on plan. It's a big building. I was there looking at it  on site. It's an impressive one and it's well underway. And the big one is, of course, Garpenberg where we have  been going through some very significant milestones recently. We are done with the raise-boring of the ore hoist.  And that is the part of the Garpenberg problem that we have several times been sort of saying, hmm, if we have an  issue on this project, this is probably where it could end up.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The future projects on further expansions of Aitik, we are working on the feasibility studies. We do not have  anything new to say about that, else than that we're working on it. And Laver, it's the same there. We are  continuing to drill and we are continuing to plan and we are continuing -now we're not drilling for new ore but we  are sterilizing different parts. We want to know that we're not putting a plant right on top of a very rich ore or  things like that.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And of course, permitting and environmental or permitting issues are basically taking most of the time. It's a long- term project and we are still in early days here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Boliden area mix change is a complicated one for you to – you probably think it is a very difficult and poor  visibility. And I think it is, because we have fine mines with distinct different kind of ores. And on top of that, we  have the processing of slags from Rönnskär. So you can say that we have six very different materials going into  three different lines in ones concentrator. It is going up and down depending on what we do. We have been – had  pushed or we have pushed Kristineberg, the zinc mine more than we have planned, and therefore, we are in lower  grade areas than we have planned. So also in our own planning, we are slightly low because of that.

file: BOL - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 6May2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The reason for the decline is essentially lower prices and terms, and we have this final pricing clause in most of  our deliveries, which means that the decline in metal prices we saw in March, affected not only the March results,  but also had to adjust the sales for the previous month, February. So we had a double month of the lower price,  and might be that some miss that. Of course, that clause is going double positive, when metal prices are going the  other way round, another time.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Mine supply growth is limited in zinc, and which has, over a long period of time, stabilized the zinc price at around  2,000, and we have seen new capacity coming in on the copper side, which has led to the decline in copper prices.  For a time, the latest development is however, positive. Benchmark terms have been cleared on both zinc and  copper and they are going in a positive direction. Have not had any major impact in the beginning of the year, but  will follow later.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the zinc price, first, as you can see here, we see month-by-month. In the second – in the first quarter,  we saw the dive in March. And then a good recovery in April again and we are over 2,000 wh ich is given the  general base metals picture, quite okay.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The copper price, and you saw also the – official inventories going down in zinc, which is very important to note.  Copper also see a decline in inventory, but the concern that more capacity is coming in, is putting pressure on the  copper prices.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we go into the mines result, earnings of SEK 147  million, which is a big decline from the previous year, metal  prices and terms and this final price or definite pricing has significant impact on this. If we compare with Q4, we  saw the copper coming down, but I think that was expected by everybody following us a bit in detail.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We had an extraordinary good copper production in Aitik in the fourth quarter of last year. Winter conditions, we  have always talked about as lower. We cannot produce at full speed when temperatures are going down. So that  has a little bit of impact. And we had some planned maintenance. Nothing special, but we were very free of  maintenance in the fourth quarter. In addition, we had better grades in Q4 and the normal grades as have been  guided in Q1. But the quarter-over-quarter, there is a significant decline.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The other one, which – and I think this was expected. What was not expected, and not by ourselves either is rock  conditions in Tara are at time to time, difficult. We have the rock conditions in Tara gives us some problems time  to time. It is not unique, it happens and it happened in the end of the first quarter. We cannot a ccess the mining  areas as we would wish, so we have disturbances.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Startup is a process. Y ou start with water in the system, if you take the concentrator plant, then you cont inue with  rock, and you continue later, when everything functions, you go in with ore and you start to flotate and get the first  concentrate out of the plant.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: No production in the old concentrator plant now, we have it, of course, idle so we can start it up when we need  now to do new adjustments, which can very well happen. But basically, we are in production now since the  beginning of May, which is extremely good news. The production plan is to do the guiding, we do in order to  understand this. We have a plan to do 2 million tonnes this year.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we move onto the smelters, basically a result in line with our expectations; we did 199 millions, it's a little bit or  it's below last year, but as a consequence of metal prices and conditions. The production went stable or was stable,  nothing much to talk about there. The cost was good. We had the first effect of the Rönnskär plan, which is to cut  cost, which gives effect sooner than the more long-term job we do on process stabilization or process – or recovery  of the process stability.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have a long way to go before we are where we want to be with Rönnskär, but I think the first steps of these  action plans have been going approximately as planned and that's good. In Kokkola, we have the other project. In  the zinc smelter, we have the other big investment program going parallel to Garpenberg; it's silver recovery from  silver-rich zinc concentrates. The project is on plan and on CapEx and we expect production to start in the  beginning of Q3.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Rönnskär, what we did for process stability is to do a number of things here. First of all, we need to feed slightly  less challenging materials. Rönnskär is one of the leading smelters in the world to process complicated materials,  but we have the combined effect of difficult electronics feed and copper concentrate, and the combined effect gave  us a problem.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: So we are working on the feed mix to improve the material planning and how we mix what we feed, in order to not  have this combined effect, which are very, very difficult when they happen. We are also learning and going deep  into the process control. We have a very good new manager with a very good technical process industry or  metallurgical background.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And he is really going after fact-based recipes and how we feed and how we manage the process with the crew in  Rönnskär. This is a more long-term job. We also have some new test areas of some drying of some wet material,  which is difficult to process in larger quantities. We have some other process changes that we are doing in  prototype format, which will probably take us to a better level in the future than we ever were before this problem  started. But that's still a long time and early to say.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The impact on the first quarter was stabilized production. We had high copper feed. We have  slightly lower  electronics material with the impurities, we don't like at this point and we have seen the stabilization of the  inventories or the intermediate stocks. We think that if you annualize and see the cost impact of what we have  done so far, we estimate that we are somewhere on a run rate of 50 million improvement compared to before the  project.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The production is good in zinc and – so the feed is good, the rates are slightly lower, but basically okay. And on the  copper side, not much to say.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance, Boliden AB
texts.text: And then to that comes Tara that was not guided for before in advance and as Lennart has mentioned, that is due  to rock problems and that plays into these numbers as well.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The first line here is the project update, which we have looked at many times before. But I think it is exciting times  now. We are through basically or almost through the big investment period with Aitik36, now up well on that level  or above, within 37  million tonnes to 2013, which is one year ahead of the original plan.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: But the news of today is, of course, the Aitik45 and let's have a look what have we done here. We have decided on a  Board meeting yesterday to start the project we call Aitik45. This project will include the 6 00 millions we have  decided to spend 2014 and 2015, which is basically a new crusher and some environmental equipment and some  electric supply we need for the bigger capacity, but also some smaller debottlenecking.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have an underground conveyer system from the existing in-pit crusher, which was very expensive to build.  And we don't know how – when we move the in-pit crusher, how we shall – where we shall put it and  consequently, how much we will invest. We can take lower investments and get higher operational cost or we can  take a longer-term approach to it with slightly bigger investment. It's a couple hundred million, so it's a fairly  significant piece and that is open at this point.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The whole package number two is open and not decided yet, so before we are there, we cannot draw the very clear  details. So we have not done the feasibilities of everything yet. The first step is to enable 45 million tonnes, but this  second step is needed in order to keep 45 million tonnes and enjoy the improvements we have seen in the reserve.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Maintenance CapEx, as Mikael already said, we are going to continue outside of the project. It 's the same we did  with Aitik36. Truck fleets will have to be renewed, shovels will have to be renewed, whatever else and normal  regular maintenance. And we are not going to increase the truck fleet. We are going to continue to have very short  drive distances. Over time slightly better or a better strip ratio, so we can use the truck fleet to drive ore to a large  extent than waste.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: All in all, the maintenance CapEx will continue in a similar way as before, but the pushback itself, which is a bit of  a maintenance CapEx, that of course, will increase with speed. If you produce 45 million on a one to one ratio, you  have to produce 45 million waste too. If you do 36 million one to one, you produce 36 million. So, of course,  stripping will go up in proportion there. But I think it is very encouraging.

file: BOL - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 5May2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The expansion of Garpenberg continues on plan and we are very proud and we have the Annual Shareholder  Meeting here today and it's a great project we are going to show. The lo wer volume in the first quarter is compared  to the previous quarter, but strong year-on-year development. Cost is under control. The working capital is higher  as we know. We have an appeal regarding the diesel tax that has been in Aitik, which has been an ongoing process.  It has been rejected and the process continues.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Good development in Aitik when it comes to grades, but lower production. So the grade improvements has come,  as forecasted, and the production has been lower, also as forecasted. There was winter this year as every winter, of  course, but this time it was probably less affected by extreme low temperatures, but more of very heavy snowfalls.   We are driving the trucks in steep hills and it's dangerous to drive them without clearing the snow and also the  snow is coming with the ore into the conveyor belts and ore storages and creates ice and other issues there.  Normal seasonality, in other words.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The Garpenberg success is there, but we see, compared to Q4, slightly lower production. That is perfect in line  with our guidance before. We had built up an ore storage over several years which was depleted by the end of the  year, and now we are continuing the ramp up of the mine, which will be in full production at the yearend. And  therefore, when we go into the new year without the stockpile we go to slightly lower level. Actions in Tara  continue.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The P200 project in Odda is to increase the production to 200,000 tons per year of zinc from the 160,000 tons  where we are. And finally, Laver, we have the application for exploitation concession has been appealed or we  have a hiccup at quite early stage of the Laver permit process. And this is so mewhat a concern to us but quite  normal.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we then look at what have we done and what have we communicated which have an impact  going forward, well  first of all, Aitik is going into the high-range. We had 0.21% grade in Q1 and that will continue 2015 and 2016. We  are going to continue to ramp up to 45 million tons as part of the Aitik45 project and the guiding for 2015 is 40  million ton, slightly up from the previous year.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The Garpenberg again is continuing with a full-year effect next or this year but also the quarter-by-quarter will  come up from the level we're at. And we will be at 2.5 million ton pace by the end of the year.

file: BOL - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 3May2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The free cash flow was SEK 210 million and then the first quarter is seasonal, a bit weak. We are building normally  inventories and working capital and we have somewhat lower production for weather reasons.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The global market is sliding or going sideways, I would say. I don't think we have major bad news , but we don't  have major good news. The global construction industry, the most important segment for base metals, have been  developing recently well whereas the automotive sector or automotive or transportation sector has been slightly  negative.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we look at the zinc prices, first of all, the long-term curve is very, very stable. Some years back we were  forecasting very high zinc prices. Instead, we have got a flat dev elopment where [ph] there's more or less or  (04:03) more or less all the commodities have been going down. And with a bit of good news in the quarter, [ph]  we'd see on the blow up (04:11) to the right that the zinc price has responded positively.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Copper, however, the long-term curve is continuing to slide downwards. We are down on the cash cost curves or  cash cost support levels. And short-term, we have also in copper seen a positive price development.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Nickel is similar to copper. Even though we have some more volatile metal and the swings from peak to troughs  are more dramatic, but basically the long-term slide can also be seen here. And we see on the blow up to the right  that also nickel has responded positively.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I mentioned that metal prices are down on the cash cost curves. To the left, we see zinc, and to the right, copper.  The three horizontal lines are representing the cash cost of the industry, the average or the 90th percentile on the  upper curve and the 50th on the lower curve. And we can see the volatility of prices.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On production, we see the milled ore production, the throughput on the bars, and the metal content on the line.  As we can see, we are up on a quite good level on copper, even though it's a seasonal low there. In zinc, we have  seen good production in all the zinc mines. Tara has had strong development with new developments and a good  sort of – the organization well in balance after the reductions we have done and other adjustments, other action  plans. Also worth to note is that Boliden Area has delivered a lot of zinc in the quarter, and has had a very good  result.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In copper and zinc production, we can see it in similar way. Good throughput in the copper smelters and in the  zinc smelters and good metal content. Basically a flat development, but with more complex materials and some  more better margin processing.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: When it comes to volume, we have a negative impact of roughly SEK 40 million. There are few different things in  there. Aitik has often a seasonally lower production in the winter months, and this was the case also this year,  especially January, so cold weather and production was slightly hampered. We have also guided for slightly lower  grade in Garpenberg in the first quarter due to some rock stability issues that we had towards the later part of  2015, that is also in this numbers. And then finally, there's a slightly lower volume of free metals in the smelter  side.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Thank you, Håkan. And to conclude and see what's in the information we have given and going forward. First of  all, Aitik will have a copper grade of 0.21% in 2016, which we have informed about. The Garp enberg will have  grades of around 4% zinc and 120 gram per tonne of silver. I think the cost action plans are going well, so I think  that's within the guidance we have given before.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Productivity, we have developed with our organic strategy which has been more focused on developing our  existing units rather than buying new things and justifying with a lot of tonnes of metals or something else. We are  less tonne focused and more profit and cash flow focused.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The Kevitsa acquisition was announced on the March 10th. Not much more to say about it. We've had some initial  contacts and discussions. We are looking at basically two things for Kevitsa to be a very good deal for us. We  would mean to have better nickel prices. We think we are somewhere low. We don't know when it will happen, but  we think it will happen eventually. And the other side of the coin is, of course, what we can do ourselves and we  think there are improvements on the synergies and are very good. We know all the equipment, all the processes;  we know how to mine an open pit in the Arctic climate and so on.

file: BOL - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 25April2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: I think the result, we did another quarter of over SEK 2 billion and that is obviously a good level. It's almost three  times the level of the same time a year ago, slightly down for the reasons I said and we had many good news on  the copper smelters and most of the mines, in particular Tara, Kevitsa and many more actually. We have some  somewhat low production in the zinc smelters, Tara – Kokkola and Odda. Those issues, smaller issues we had  will be corrected in the maintenance we have later this year.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Metals demand were good 2%, 3% in the base metals, copper, zinc, and higher in nickel. And we have seen  some short-term issues in some of the large copper mines in the world, which is holding back the mine supply a  little bit, but I think it is shorter term. The zinc concentrate supply has been more structurally weak for a long time.  And we now see the impact on closures of smelters in China, Japan, Korea.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The zinc price or the prices are following on the slides here and we can see the very strong development for zinc  and the quite flat situation in the first quarter – in the quarter itself. And we have seen a tailing off and a weaker  price environment in the beginning of the second quarter.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Compared to copper, we see a very different long-term trend where too many copper mines came out and put  pressure on the copper price, which is still quite low. But the shorter-term reaction in the second half of last year  and the first quarter is similar to zinc.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Treatment charges, a lot of questions we get about zinc TCs and where are the benchmarks going to be. We're  quite reasonably happy with where it ended. The price escalators are gone, but the TC levels are now not going  down with a lower zinc price, unfortunately not going up with a higher zinc price. But I think the combined gross  profits for the zinc smelters are, together with the free metals and as we can see it, are still on a quite good level.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the prices compared to the cost of the industry, you are familiar with the graphs, the lines are  showing the cost level of the 90th, the 75th and the 50th percentile and you see the spreads on the metal price.  And as we can see, we are having a high zinc price and we are far off the cash cost curve. So it's a very profitable  business to be in right now. In copper, it's good but not great.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Smelters, SEK 835 million. That's clearly up from last year, not anywhere near as much as the mines. And it's  actually down from the previous quarter. Now, we are seeing the lower TCs filtering through in the end of the  quarter and we have had some disturbances, as I mentioned, in the beginning. But basically, the copper mine – or  copper smelters are doing very good, lead smelters, Bergsöe is doing exceptionally well. So I think that we are  very happy with the smelter results as well.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: And you've all seen the metal prices increase and that explains half of this SEK 260 million. In addition, we had  some imbalances in the zinc flow where mine production was very good towards the end of the quarter, and at the  same time, there were some disturbances in both our zinc smelters. And that has caused higher-than-average  inventories of zinc concentrates, which explains roughly a quarter of this SEK 260 million. Again, the timing effect  that we will – at least the volume component, we will expect to see it coming back in the near future.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the smelters, we have not seen the full effect of the TCs, but as I said, it's not a dramatic sort of deterioration. I  think that the combined gross profit for zinc smelters are looking good.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: To summarize the quarter, we are seeing the benefits of being a mining and smelting company. We have seen  that when the mines are now going much stronger, we are seeing part of that offsetting that the smelters are  going opposite direction. And last year we saw very much the other way around.

file: BOL - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 27April2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: High grades in Aitik again, and this time, you should understand what's happening in Aitik and I'm coming back to  that. But basically, the lower volume and high grades are effects of the same event and basically driven by the  new crusher installations. And the project is going on plan. The crusher is running with ore today. We're doing the  start, stop and testing and taking over criterias with the suppliers, so, plenty of work there. So far so good and I  think we are over the risks involved in start-up period. So, it looks good.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: So, in the general context of a very strong global economy, it is slightly less strong for the segments for the base  metals. Strong but not quite as strong as a general picture may look like. Base metals, high copper prices or high  copper and nickel demand growth. [ph] Much is (04:14) more than normal is driven by the developed economies  with new energy systems. There is a hype for battery metals and a lot of other things.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the concentrate markets, we saw a tight market in the zinc concentrate and a quiet balanced market in copper  concentrates. Looking at the prices, we have this picture we always follow. Of course, we see a good metal price  development that's well-known to you all. If we compare with the long-term prices or the cost of the industry, I  would say that zinc is very high priced. Nickel is, in spite of the positive development, still a low priced commodity.  And copper is good, not without being extreme high.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And that can be seen on this picture where we have the cost of the industry. The low line is showing the 90th  percentile where 90% of the mine supply or the different metals are running at positive cash flows. And as we can  see here, certainly, it's very profitable to be a zinc miner. It's not so profitable to be a nickel miner.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Low milled volume is an effect of the same thing as the grades are high. The new crusher is on the top of the pit,  and we stood still one week to reconnect from the old crusher into the new system. And we have had an on-off  situation on a daily basis. Therefore, we have focused our mining in the lower part of the pit where the grades are  high, but the volume of ore is low because of this sort of planned and not very surprised pricing disturbances. So,  all in all, copper production is good, but it's a very high grade and lower volume kind of situation.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Also in Tara, we have been in very good areas. We have had very good grades, and Tara is developing well with  very high returns given also, apart from the grades, the favorable zinc prices. Winter conditions and as an  interesting detail, winter is harsh in the north of Sweden, but this year, we can also say winter impacted our  underground mining which we have never said before, and I'm referring to Tara where the whole of Ireland was  on a standstill because people couldn't go to work during the heavy snowfall situations there. So, funny, but true.  Also, underground mines were affected by weather conditions this year. And the winter conditions, as I will  mention later on, also continued into the second quarter which is not very typical.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In smelters, this is a picture from one of the – or the other, the second very large investment going on right now; a  new acid plant in Harjavalta. And earnings were SEK 640 million compared to SEK 835 million. The decline is due  to lower market terms, this is in zinc being the most important. CapEx were SEK 231 million down from last year.  We see a market where the good conditions in general, but market terms are going negative to us. Stable  production and high free metals in the copper smelters. We had a production record in Harjavalta and the zinc  smelters are doing fine.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the quarter, we took a one-off write-off of our fire which I think we mentioned last time in the lead smelter base.  So, we had a new project and right before commissioning everything was built, everything was there, it's an SEM  80 million project and it was a fire, so most of the equipment was destroyed and we took the hit in the operating  cost this quarter.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Smelters, production quite flat but better than it looks because we've got more of the byproducts and continue to  deliver on the strategy of complex materials. Copper production was 92 ktonnes up from 89 ktonnes a year ago,  record production in Harjavalta. And interesting to note with – after the acquisition of Kevitsa and very high  grades, we have an exceptional or historic high internal feed rate so, almost half of all the feed to the smelters is  from internal mines.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The continuous – or the winter, I mentioned in the beginning, continued into the second quarter. If you are a skier  and you're in Scandinavia, it's an amazing skiing season also now. So, there's a lot of snow. It has also been a lot  of snowfall. So, we have had some disturbances also in the second quarter, which is unusual, nothing to be  nervous about too much but still some disturbance.

file: BOL - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 3May2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look into the markets, this is, of course, something that's been prepared. And looking over what happened in  Q1, it's, of course, interesting day today as we've seen the copper price and other metal prices go down  significantly over the last two or three days. But even without that, we can say looking at Q1 that we did have a  slowdown in industrial production. We didn't see it in prices during the quarter. We actually saw that copper and  nickel demand was quite stable, and zinc also stable even if it was not growing during the quarter. And the metal  prices were up compared to Q4. So far, we didn't see any kind of signs of any slowdown.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the concentrate market, what has really been the news is the change that we've seen in the zinc market, where  zinc concentrates have become readily available. For us, who are net smelter, this is very good. We've seen the  new benchmark coming out with significantly higher TCs than historically. What happens in a quarter like this –  and Håkan will take you through the numbers – is that for us, the higher TC is immediate negative impact on our  minds, but the positive impact on the smelters is a little bit slower because the way that we work through the  inventories and the smelters, and that we're still during Q1, we treated quite a lot of concentrates that would have  the terms and conditions as of Q4. The concentrate market for copper has been quite stable, you can say. The  TCs are slightly down but it's a relatively good situation anyway.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: When we look at what we are, and I'm coming back a little bit to how we look at our price levels in general, you  can see here that both zinc and copper for the quarter were pretty significantly above the cost curves, which is  always, of course, indicate there's a downside risk in case something were to happen, whereas nickel is right  down in the cost curve, we see a very low downside potential in nickel price rather an upside potential.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you go to the smelters, which is probably the very nice thing to talk about these quarters as our smelters had  quite a good run, the prices and terms have been helping and this is despite the fact that the full TC effect of zinc  has not come through yet. We've had stable production. We didn't have any big maintenance stops in the quarter.  And thus, we've been having good results going through altogether. And thus, also seen a good result.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Prices and terms is a fairly limited impact. We can see the negative correlation here with the stronger dollar  compensating for the lower metal prices. And as Mikael indicated, the impact of new zinc TCs, new stronger zinc  TCs is very limited in this quarter as smelting division has mainly been producing out of inventories that was  sourced to last year's levels.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We do have something new which is a negative information for those of you who've not followed the Swedish  internal domestic [ph] qualities (00:13:42). There is now a proposal to change the diesel tax for mining. That's in  the new budget. It is, of course, not a done deal in terms of done deal, but it's very likely to go through. That will  have an annual impact on us of around SEK 120 million per year, out of which SEK 100 million is in Aitik and the  SEK 20 million is for the rest of the business. That would come into effect as of August 1, so, of course, we  wouldn't have the full effect for this year but it will be a full annualized effect coming right away.
