file: BOL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 19July2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: The Aitik ramp-up continues and we are on plan now. We were off plan in the first quarter, but I would say that  we are on the way to reach the 36 million tons by 2014 as the original plan suggested, and so that's of course the  big news of the quarter. Parallel to that, we are going into lower grade areas. We have communicated this very  clearly, and I think you have already – all got that message clear.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In an open pit, you are – when you go to the bottom of the pit, you are basically in the middle of the ore and the  highest grades, and then you have the pushback which is waste rock in the beginning and then it's going in on the  lower grades early on. And we are going to be on lower grades for the next couple of years.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: I'm sorry. Now something happens here. Okay. The zinc price, as a consequence, has been flat which is – if the  inventories officially are going up, basically the metal prices should go down and it doesn't. And that is, I suppose,  because of the anticipated lack of new mines when several of the zinc mines will deplete in the next couple of years  and very few projects will take their places.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: The zinc TCs have been going down. This is the realized zinc, including the escalator, so it is including the metal  price effect, and here we have the spot terms. And clearly, the zinc TCs are going down and the spot levels are  below the benchmark levels. And the zinc premiums are going up and have a little bit unclear situation here. It's a  little bit different in the different parts of the world, but positive development on the zinc premiums, which  indicates a good demand, and negative on TC, which indicates a shortage of mine supply.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we go over to copper, you see that the inventory levels followed – went with zinc in the beginning but has been  up and down since then basically on a healthy and good level, and the copper prices have been going up. We see  here that the first – second quarter is clearly below the first and you can also see the beginning of Q3 which is on a  high level. And actually today I saw the metal prices came strong.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Copper TCs have gone up a little bit; the benchmark on 56 versus here – versus 46 a year ago, and stimulated also  on the spot terms, which are higher than the benchmark terms. So it's really the opposite from zinc. And if we see  the copper, the premiums, the benchmark levels are up, and the spot, basically it's around the benchmark levels.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Now, we're back up again and this is on a yearly rate of 32 million tons and we are basically on the expansion plan  towards the 36 million tons as the final result of the project. The contained metal or metal content here was not  improving. It was flat and that is of course because of the open pit where we were in the bottom and we're now  going into the lower grade areas. So even if the metal production is not very dramatic, it's a big change; ore  production up, ore volume up, grades down. So it's a big change within that seemingly little or flat and stable  development.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In zinc, we have seen basically a lower grade in Garpenberg, which has an impact here, and that is due to – we  have been on a higher than ore reserve average for several quarters now, and in Q2, we were on the average rates  which of course is what long-term should be, the expected level.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the Aitik expansion, we showed in the previous quarter this table and we said there is, you can divide  one thing as peak performance, how much can the different parts for the mine deliver and the other one is  reliability, and I think this – it's very significant difference when you are particularly in a ramp-up period. We  have filled in all the peak capacities here. We have no concerns about 36 million ton capacity for Aitik, the system  up there.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Basically it's the trucks and the blasting, the shovels and the whole logistic in the mine; can these mines support  both ore production and waste rock production to the levels we have in the plans. Until you have done it and done  it for a longer period of time, you cannot tick that in. And with the problems we had with the trucks, we were not  really there in the previous quarter, but today, I think we're feeling much more comfortable on that one.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: So ramp-up period is continuing. We are on the way to 36 million tons. And the actions implemented; more  robust ore supply; the truck engine exchange program is basically finalized, almost finalized; the old crusher is  connected; and the new crushers, we can start to work with them again. I mean when we were having nothing else  than them, we couldn't work on them. We could just sit there and be kind to them and hope and work as good as  possible, but reworking them, rebuilding them in anyway was absolutely a no-no. So the situation has improved a  lot.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In Smelters, results are down and it's basically driven by the maintenance stop, the shutdown and the lower zinc  TCs. We did SEK 143 million in Q2, which is up from last year despite the fact that we had bigger rebuild – or  maintenance shutdowns. Compared to the first quarter, of course, the difference is essentially the maintenance or  it is more than explaining the difference.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have increased the secondary feed. We are working now to get more and more feed into the system, also the  old system as a preparation to the new [ph] Boliden (19:53) system. So we're running really full speed on  electronic scrap as much as we can do in the existing system. So we don't just triple, 45,000 tons to 120,000 tons.  We cannot do that overnight. We have to ramp it and part of that ramp up is to maximize, to really run blast full  speed on the existing ones.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we then start looking into the basics, you have a little bit negative – a small number, SEK 50 million negative on  the metal prices, that's zinc and copper being down but the precious metals are positive. So this is a very small  negative. Then you have also small negative or a negative of about SEK 100 million on the Swedish krona  exchange rate.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Sensitivities, you've seen these numbers before. There's nothing really new about them. You can say that there is a  10% effect on metal prices. It's about half a – a little bit less than SEK 0.5 billion on copper and a little bit more  than SEK 0.5 billion on zinc. That's the sensitivity that we have. And lead, gold and silver are individually less  important, but of course combined they're also important for the total sensitivities.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: The new crusher availability is still low, but we have the old one. And as you know with three crushers, we can live  with a lot of difficulties and the negative we are going to live with, with these variations is essentially longer  distances for the trucks. So it means more fuel and it's going to be in the long run that we will not have capacity,  truck capacity to go to the – drive to the wrong place. But essentially, we should be safer, much, much more safe in  the ore supply now with the three in production, even if the two new ones are not very reliable.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we are then summarizing with what we have said here which has an impact on going forward, well, the ramp up  continues with Aitik, 36 million tons, 2014. I see that we are going to do that. The smelter maintenance stops were  in the second quarter heavy and we will have a little also in Q3 at a profit effect of about SEK 45 million. The lower  grades in Aitik from Q3 will continue and we are substantially below the reserve grade average of 0.25%, closer to  0.20%, and the grades in Garpenberg are on average reserve grade 5.3%. It will go a little bit up and a little bit

file: BOL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 19July2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Zinc has been going down 8% from the previous quarter and copper on the next page has a similar. We have, of  course, a continued concern that the inventories, the official inventories in zinc is continuing up and I think you  see the rest, a slight negative price pressure there. In copper, we had not 8% but 10% lower copper price in the  quarter, but here it is combined with lower inventory levels.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: On CapEx, we invested SEK753 million compared to SEK600 million a year earlier. And the projects are on plan.  And of course the strong thing of this report is of course Aitik, 38 million tonnes annualized production rate. And  one of your question is – will, of course, be can you keep this trend? And the answer is of course not because we  have our plans and we have to take away waste rock and we have a capacity. It doesn't work that way that you, for  a long period, suddenly can go away in the different directions on your mine plans. You simply don't have the  capacity for it. But what it does, it is to reconfirm very, very strongly that we are on plan for our expansion of Aitik  and the probability of continuing if we have the permitting and the pre-feasibilities and feasibilities on further  expansions. The concentrator is prepared for it, that's pretty evident or that is evident. The other projects are also  on plan.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The production, while we see how the Q2 corporate – oil production went high but the contain metal is not  following because we are on – now on the low side on 0.20 copper grade which is very low. We are on the zinc side  seeing another good quarter. Tara is doing very well. Garpenberg is doing very well. And then, we have the  Boliden area which is doing less in zinc now and more in copper. It will reverse when we come into next year I will  say a few words about that later.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the bar chart and the metal chart, we see a similar development here that we had good processing  capacity or processing volumes. The bar and we see that the metal supplied is slightly lower. So we are seeing the  tendency here that copper concentrates are a little less rich and this is what you can see and read from a lot of  other companies too in the world.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: When it comes to Kankberg, we started the ore production already in – well, the first little things we've done in the  the mine is in production. We are going to process some of – we are doing campaigns in leaching in the leaching  plant in the Boliden concentrator.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: So given the lead times here, this is just to say that the profit of Kankberg will not be seen in any major way this  year, but we are on plan. We are seeing delivery on leaching to start in the end of the year or in Q4. Garpenberg is  on plan and we have done well, quite extraordinary steps forward that we are far into the – or in the construction  of the buildings of the new concentrator. We have the fundaments for or the basements for the grinders. So, some  of the most heavy construction works are way advanced now. We actually started to put roof on the concentrator  building the day before yesterday. I showed it to the board at the board meeting today and I think that it looks like  it's going fast now. You know how it is when you build, a lot of people nothing has happened. But suddenly, when  you'll start to raise walls and put roof on it, well, you see that, "Oh, this is a lot."

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Rönnskär, we have been talking about already. We had the Minister of Environment, Lena Ek, during the  inauguration. Some of you were there and the production has been going real well. Silver recovery in Kokkola was  just started which is the next strategic project which will go in production 2014.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have some picture. This is from 1.1 kilometers down under mine. This is – or under earth or under the surface.  This is the place where the crusher is going to be on 1,087 meters minus. These are the foundations for the head  frame of the hoist, the mine hoist. This is the mill, basements for the mill. This is flotation building itself. And here  we have the roof panels coming on. And also the picture I showed before was also showing the panel walls starting  to be shaping up.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: As a summary, I think that it's quite evident. We are pleased. We have taken some very big sort of steps in some of  the project plans. We have for the first time in over 36 million tonnes right in Aitik, big thing. We have full  production in Rönnskär, big thing. We are starting to produce gold ore from Kankberg, that's big. We are going to  see the tellurium in full production of that, the impact by the end of the year.

file: BOL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 17July2013 815 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Okay, good afternoon. A very special quarter it has been and we have had – seen metal prices declining. We have  had the largest maintenance [ph] store (00:36) shutdowns in our smelters of all times. At the same time, we have  large investments going on here in Garpenberg, where we are today with the board and we're visiting the site and  the project which is on plan.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you look at – and on copper, we have seen a decline from the top 2011 in the early parts, and we have seen the  copper prices going down step by step. It was lower in Q2 than in Q1, and we have seen a decline in the second  quarter and the start of the third quarter.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The reason for the decline here is more the uncertainty about the long-term development of China and its impact  on base metals market and the new projects in copper which many of them are planned to be in production now  and in the following years.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the copper production on slide 15, we can see the good mine production on the light-colored bar and  we can see the line diagram which is an impact or impacted both by high production volume in the mine but also  better grades than we have seen. So, now we have been a bit higher than the 0.20 where we have – where we are  basically this year and next. On the zinc side, similar development, reasonably good month of production and  slightly higher grades in the month.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: But we also do some debottlenecking projects where we install different kind of equipment at a time when we are  in any way standing still for the maintenance. And of course, we also are in a hectic period for the silver recovery  project in our copper – or zinc smelter in Finland, Kokkola.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you start looking at the analysis, and analysis now comparing first – to the first quarter of this year – you see  that the volume effect is positive. And that might be surprising, given the high maintenance stop, but the mine  production has been so good that it's also outweighing the negative volume effect coming from the maintenance  stops in the smelters.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We are here to show the board the underground installations where they are right now when we do the  presentation here, and then we will go in – at the industrial area in our new concentrator which we are currently  building.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Kankberg is on plan and it's going well. The tellurium leaching plant is in production, in full production, so that  goes well. The silver recovery project will start up after the half year of next year, and it's also on plan. We are also  working with the feasibility to expand Aitik to a higher level, we call it Aitik45 to take the ore production from 36  million to 45 million tonnes.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And we're working on that visibility and I'm sure we'll get a question of when will we decide on this and I think  that maybe towards the end of the year or beginning of next year. But we have quite a lot of calculations to do to  see which is the most optimal mine plan, given changes in metal prices and whatever.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The metal prices have been going down. Will they continue down or up? We don't know, of course. We know that  they could go down further from this point but we have no evidence of that happening, so we have no opinion  about that right now.

file: BOL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 18July2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Thank you. Very welcome to this presentation of the second quarter results. The quarter was dominated by the  maintenance shutdowns which were planned in the smelters, which cost a lot of money, which is keeping the – or  lowering the output from the smelters. That said, I think that we have – we're quite pleased with the smelter  results.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Aitik did 10 million tonnes in a quarter and that's the highest we have seen so far. So it's a record production in  Aitik.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The metal prices have increased and we saw the first effect in the end of the second quarter and the metal prices  have continued up since. And if they stay on this level, we have an additional good improvement on the market  terms.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We see a lower supply forecast for zinc, which is what we have seen, so no change. There is only that the closing of  the Century mine, the very large mine is coming closer, and the zinc market tightness seem to materialize, as we  have indicated before, and it's coming closer.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the prices then, this is the zinc price. We can see that it has been going up in the quarter and we see  the blowup in the past couple of quarters and also beyond the second quarter. We see how it was coming up to  $1,300 per tonne; today, it's slightly below $1,300 per tonne, but – no, $2,300 per tonne. So a very nice positive  price trend for zinc backed by the fundamentals, but also by the inventories, the official inventories that you see  on the shaded graphs behind the line, the price line. The inventories or the official inventories are going down.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In copper, it's a more stable situation. And here, we have been expecting inventories to go up, but they continue  down. But there is a very – is a big lack of transparency of the inventories which are not official here. So a number  of question marks. But what we see is that the copper prices are holding up. They are stable and there was a risk  for and there still is a risk for falling copper prices. So that's holding up, whic h is positive.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: New environmental permit for Rönnskär is also a very big thing for us. Let us go a bit deeper on that one. For  several years, for many years, we have been talking about solutions or improvements for our environmental  situation in Rönnskär. Boliden has suggested different improvements and we have proposed investments of SEK 1  billion or in the – around SEK 1 billion. We have been negotiating exactly how to do it and where to do it and the  terms around it and we have now got an agreement and the environmental permit and we are happy to invest  another SEK 1 billion in improvement of the environment in Rönnskär.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Kokkola silver recovery is also an important new project for us. We are – have started initial production and we  are on plan. The production in copper, if you compare the light shaded or light colored bars, as you can see, we are  a lot better than last year when we had this big shutdown. But we are also this year having a shutdown; and that  given, we are very pleased with the volume.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Odda, good production, and we are now with four leaching reactors in production, one was collapsing  or we had a  problem a year-and-a-half ago. A year or a six months ago, we got the new one. We installed it and then we have  maintained the other four, which have been running without maintenance in the meantime. But from now, we are  in full capacity when it comes to leaching in Odda.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we start then by comparing against last year, you will see further there's a very small deviation of only SEK 4  million. That comes from a pretty high positive volume effect. The big volume effect comes from the lower smelter  maintenance and the Garpenberg production coming online.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance, Boliden AB
texts.text: Some of you have read – the report might argue that it should have been an even bigger number than that and  that there is something that you could discuss around that. And it's true that in Garpenberg, althoug h the new  concentrator worked very fine and we got very high volumes, the mine is not really up to speed and we have been  taking out of ore storage in order to fill the smelter and that shows up in the volume that we've been using up  existing inventory.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance, Boliden AB
texts.text: Looking at the cash flow, and as I said before, this is maybe the most positive news that we have in this quarter  with a SEK 920 million positive. This, to a large extent, comes out of the working capital with a SEK 7 95 million of  cash coming out of the working capital. Out of that, roughly SEK 200 million, you will see is due to the improved  process situation in Rönnskär where we have reduced the metal content in the intermediary storages and the  other SEK 600 million is mainly due to timing. I think there'll probably be a question around what is a sustainable  level. And I'll say right now that this level that we have right now is not really a sustainable level. We had a very  low working capital at the end of the quarter, which is linked to a, maybe too perfect timing of shipments coming  in and maybe a too low level of inventories for safety.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: But then of course, we have done something else on the project pipeline. We bought a mine Kylylahti in Finland.  And I think the story is really quite nice. As a mine, you can say it's nothing to write home about. It's a small little  [indiscernible] (0:23:08) kind of copper or a small copper mine, 650,000 tonnes per year of ore, high-grade, but  the primary reason why we bought the mine is that we have got the permits or the exploration rights in a very  interesting part of Finland.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Odda, full leaching capacity from now, I said that already and maintenance shutdown we will have also in Q3  lower than in the second quarter, but still SEK 80 million. So quite significant there too.

file: BOL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 17July2015 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I think also here we have a good balance with zinc being one of the most favorable commodities, and we're going  to see later a very flat price development over a long time. But we also see volatilities and that copper is continuing  the negative trend.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On the production numbers, the maintenance shutdown volumes you can see here on the copper side and we can  see that we have less of an impact on the zinc side. Here, I would also like to point out that the silver production  from our new silver recovery plant in Kokkola, which has not been ramping up the way we had hoped is now  delivering on the internal plans in the past two months, not fully in the quarter, but close.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: To the right here, we see the first deliveries of nickel matte in our new nickel strategy, where we're buying nickel  concentrate from external mines and we're selling nickel matte for refining by external parties. And we will build  up the or we have started to build up the working capital, and we think this is a good strategy, which will  contribute to the profits going forward.

file: BOL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 19July2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On next slide, we can see the volatilities on copper and zinc. We can see that zinc has been – is clearly higher  than the low points if you compare with historic lows. Copper is still around the 90th percentile, slightly above. So,  I would say copper is still low but for a natural reason. It's too many big zinc as copper mines were built.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we look at the production, we can see on copper the lighter colored line on top that is pro forma, including the  production or the metal content in Kevitsa. The zinc on the right, also very  good. And Tara developed well. Garpenberg continues to be very stable.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And at the bottom, we see Kevitsa. And we have the historic performance there. And as you can see after a weak  first quarter, we see improvements and also slightly higher grade. So, you can see the metal content came up.  And in darker blue at the bottom is the June result, the June month where we owned the mine.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We got a positive impact on prices where metal prices have been stronger, partially offset by lower TCs that have  a full impact in this quarter. Regarding costs, there are some items mentioned here, Kevitsa is included,  reclamation reserves, which Lennart mentioned, and also the maintenance, and that explains the cost increase of  just over SEK 300 million. And then – I think the rest have been covered and adding up to a positive deviation of  SEK 133 million.

file: BOL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 20July2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Base metals have had an average growth of between 1% and 2%, copper and zinc growth. Nickel demand has  been declining. It's lower than in Q1, but it's still lower than the demand. So, we see the big inventories of nickel  going down. We are seeing some cuts in smelters production of zinc in China and, in general, I would say that the  metal markets have been developing well.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at this picture, it's seeing or we demonstrate the average of our metal prices and the currencies to the  left. And they are going opposite direction in the big picture, but lately, we have seen both negative trends on  currencies and prices. And the combined effect is a quarter with significant negative impact compared to the  previous quarter, but still on a good level.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Yeah. The financial impact is, however, limited. So, given the big picture, it's nothing to really bring up as a major  problem, but more of a remark. We have compared to the previous year metal prices coming with us and we have  the full impact of the lower TC this year compared to last year.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Copper smelters, we can see the volume, which is considerably down compared to the previous quarter, and  that's due to the maintenance shutdowns, and the contained metal is in consequence of that. Zinc smelters had a  good quarter compared to the previous year and it's less maintenance here, and the Odda expansion of course.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Garpenberg, we have announced earlier very, very big increases in the ore reserve. And since we normally are  saying that the guidance on grade is to look at the ore reserve, but this is not true in Garpenberg. The bigger  additions are after 2030 or after 2025, or something. And, therefore, we are going to be on the average grades of  the reserve before the big additions we did earlier on this year.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Smelters have been through the big maintenance of this year, but we have some remaining. We're going to have  an impact in Q3 of about SEK 50 million, so much less than the SEK 260 million we had this in this quarter. And  we have unfortunately discovered a problem in the dome of the Roaster in Odda. That's the roof or the top part of  the big Roaster furnace and we have to take that in Q4, and it will have an impact of SEK 135 million, which has  not been reported earlier. CapEx 2017, no change of the guidance.

file: BOL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 20July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Now something that has not been quite so good is here on the cost side. And as equally as we're happy with the  good pricing terms in terms of metal prices. There is a flip side to that and it has to do with energy and it has to do  with chemicals, where we are feeling a pretty strong cost inflation right now that explain the large part of the cost  increases that we've had in the quarter, especially compared to last year.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you look at the macro market, as I said, during Q2, we've seen a very good market. We've seen very good zinc  prices, also high copper prices, and the nickel price that was quite good. We had favorable exchange rates and  we've seen a strong output. And when we look at our strong demand, I should say, and a strong industrial output  in the world and that's what's also been reflected in these numbers.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: On the concentrate side, there is still a tightness in the zinc concentrate market that's been shown, although the  supply has been increasing in the world, and there's been a modest increase in the copper concentrate supply.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you look at the prices and especially if you look at them during Q2, you can see that the zinc price is still quite  high compared with the cost levels in the industry, and so is also true for copper, whereas nickel has now come to  the levels where it is possible to make some money for the participants in the industry. You can also see here,  which is maybe interesting for you and the statistics that we have that the cost for copper mines in the world is  going up. Even though it's a little bit small, you can see that it's ticking up. And it's probably also just as in our  case related to increased prices for energy and chemicals.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: I spoke about the metal prices. We've seen a good development. On this slide, you can also see however that the  prices are heading down pretty sharply towards and mainly after the end of the quarter. So zinc from a very high  level going down, copper from a quite decent level also going down, and nickel from a level that's come up is also  coming down. But all in all during the quarter, we had very stable and good prices.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you go into the specific areas or the two business areas, we can start with the Mines or maybe I should [ph]  stop once (00:04:45) – I don't know to what extent you're sitting on, on what kind of quality of line but you can see  here now the new KID 2 crusher or the new surface crusher. And it's a little bit of an interesting picture that you  see to the left that's – you can see on the surface, just a very small part that you see on top but also how much  comes underground in this crusher where all the action is actually happening underground. The total height is  over 70 meters but it's only the first – the 10 meters that you see on top of the ground, the most is going  underground.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In Garpenberg, we have lower zinc grades but I think it was also well communicated, but the production in general  is very well. In Kevitsa, we have the other way around. We have very high grades, and we have a stable  production. I think we have a production record in terms of nickel coming out of Kevitsa.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: So if you look in total in the production, yes, the amount of metal is coming down in copper from the very high  levels that we had with the high grades but the throughput is quite on decent levels. In the zinc mines, as we're  coming down and as the Maurliden mine is being depleted, we will have more difficulty keeping the throughput up,  and the grade is also down with the communicated lower grades in Garpenberg. If you look at the nickel side,  we've had a very good quarter in nickel in general with the high grades. We have a record production of nickel.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Moving over to the Smelters, as I said in the start, we are quite happy with the quarter for the Smelters totally.  We've had here a stable metal price and terms situation, I should say, where the metal prices are strong just as  for Mines, however, the lower TCs makes the total picture more balanced. We've had very stable production. As I  said, the maintenance stops have come in as communicated, there's been no extra problems that we found  during that.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We've also made a decision yesterday in the board meeting for a new leaching plant in the Rönnskär smelter. It's  a SEK 750-million investment for a plant that will take care of old materials and byproducts that comes out of the  existing production. It is an investment that stands on its own merits and makes lots – makes money as it of itself.  It's also taking care of an environmental problem. So had we not been able to do this investment, we might have  had a negative impact instead, because it always depends on where you put the zero line on this one. But we're  quite happy with this investment, and it will be coming up online in about 24 months or 27 months from now.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Smelters production is at stable, generally. We've had good production everywhere and maybe the zinc side is –  what's been the best side. As you know, for the last few quarters we've had problems and some stability issues in  our zinc smelters that has for the time being been overcome and we're doing better production-wise there. And  the other smelter is on par to get up to the speed of the 200,000 ton pace. And also the nickel production has  been quite good in Harjavalta.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the second quarter, we've had very good deliveries from the mining side. So, Mines have been able to reduce  the concentrate stocks with about 25,000 tons, and that shows in the Mines' numbers. That stock is now showing  up in Smelters. So, basically, what we've been doing is moving 25,000 tons one step in the value chain. Of  course, that doesn't have any impact on the group result, but you will see a profit in Mines and then a negative  impact on the elimination. So, good deliveries in Mines but purely a timing effects in the profits.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Volumes side, we've had lower milled production – slightly lower milled production and lower grades in the mining  area. For example in Aitik, furthermore also in Garpenberg, I think you could add comparing to last year. With the  higher production in the zinc smelters, as you might recall last year we've had some process issues in Kokkola  and that is now gone on and the zinc smelters have been operating in a good pace.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: The throughput in Mines is higher. We also have higher free metals in Smelters that have compensated for the  maintenance. So, operationally, it looks good. Prices and terms slightly better primarily due to a stronger dollar.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Thank you, Håkan. One thing that's in the numbers and you should all be aware of is that we've had a new ruling  in the environmental court in Sweden regarding Aitik where some of you might have read about it. It has a short- term effect that we need to put into collateral, SEK 1.1 billion extra related to the decommissioning costs. This  discount has led us to increase the provision for the decommissioning with about SEK 800 million.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: In Garpenberg, we have guided before for the 4.0% grade in zinc for the rest of this year. Now we're also adding  the guidance that we will continue in that level also for the next four quarters for that on average. So the 2019  average is also 4.0%. We're having a higher silver grade for the rest of the year at about 115 g/ton. The silver  grade for next year is the reserve grade, which is roughly 100 g/ton. And 2020 is the guidance for the 3.0 million  throughput volume, and that project is also going according to plan, so far.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have a strong balance sheet, and we have lots of growth opportunities that are not yet in the plans but we  talked about before including Tara Deep, which is also going according to plan, even though it's still a couple of  years up before we will be able to make any decision on that. The Kylylahti prolongation and the cobalt situation is  also moving relatively well. We'll come back to that in later quarters when we have the reserve upgrade coming in  the winter. And the Smelters are well-positioned for the circular economy in general, and the new leaching  investment in Aitik is in line with that.

file: BOL - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 25October2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If we start to look at the market development, I would say that it's very difficult to say where the markets will go  from this point. The decline in metal prices happened in the second half of the last month of September and found  a new level with a volatility, but basically stayed ever since. And the question is now, are we going to see metal  prices stabilizing at this point or will they go up or is this a plateau before further drops?

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If that was metal, if we then compare with concentrate supply from the global mines, higher zinc production and  lower copper production from the world's mines. The zinc concentrate balance was at a deficit in the beginning of  – was in balance after a deficit in the beginning of 2011. And the copper concentrate market was continued in a  deficit. Prices were stable in general. The premiums were stable too. Copper premium were down and below the  benchmark levels.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: You can also, on the same chart, see that the general inventories or the official inventories have been trading or  going down. The treatment charges in zinc are on a low level and we're suffering from the spot levels, and we are  buying quite some or concentrate on the zinc spot markets and the terms are very difficult for zinc smelting right  now. The premiums have traded or gone up over the period.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On copper TCs, the level is certainly better than the previous year on the benchmark levels. And we have seen so  far the spot levels being over the benchmark levels that have lately gone down under the benchmark levels. On  premiums, we have a good level of benchmark premiums and the spot levels are slightly below.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The Garpenberg expansion is on plan. We'll start 2014. And the Kankberg gold mine is also on plan. We'll start up  in the middle of 2012 and ramp up in the second half.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Earnings were SEK356 million compared to SEK238 million. Positive volume effect, high copper TCs, but low zinc  TCs, which is very serious. But that is a problem for the zinc smelters.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We have the expansion project for electronic scrap recycling, and that expansion project is continuing on plan and  everything is built. And we hope to be starting up on plan or we plan to start in the early parts of the New Year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: If we look at the smelter production, it's very visible here. There are shutdowns in the second quarter and the very  strong level of both feed and metal production in the copper smelters and a similar path in the zinc smelters.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: This is a picture from Rönnskär. It was mid-September when the Caldo furnaces came to Rönnskär. It's big, 180  tons each and one spare for maintenance when we produce in the other and very quick change over time when we  have shutdowns here. So it's going to be very efficient with continuous production. And when we start up with this  expansion we are going to be, by far, the number one electronics scrap recycler in the world.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If you look at the 139 on the left, you will see the items that are increasing. It is external services, it is personnel, it  is energy that are coming up. I would just like to point out that the personnel is in line with the projected costs.  But the external services and energy is pushing up and there's inflation involved there.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Sensitivity analysis, this is in line with numbers you've seen before but with lower prices of metals. You will see  that the numbers are slightly smaller. But it is still true which has been true for a long time that copper and zinc  are roughly equally important for the sensitivities to us. If you add up lead, gold and silver, those three together  become also as equal as important as either zinc or copper. So they're about SEK400 million each at 10%  deviation. Now the dollar effect also a bit lower because of a lower base but roughly SEK1 billion with 10% and  movement in the U.S. dollar exchange rate.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Garpenberg is more on the ground and rock mechanics or rockwork. And there we are working more on contracts  which we can slow down if it is becoming very difficult. But all in all, I would say profit, committed CapEx and the  CapEx and cost flexibilities is on a similar level if not slightly better.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: The prices in that hedge portfolio was then US$6,000 for copper and now it's over US$9,000. We didn't have, in  zinc, hedges at that time. And now we have them at US$2,200 per ton. Gold was then US$690 and is now  US$1,380. And the dollar exchange rate to krona was on a similar level. So it's something like 50% higher hedge  portfolio and maybe 50% or more higher metal prices. So considerably better hedge portfolio and better gearing.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: So something to take home and have a look at, quite interesting reading actually. What this boils down to is that  the zinc and copper prices are holding up reasonably well. We have circled in the spike, which you can – if you  look sharply there it was a spike which happened to be right in the turn of the quarter and we have a blowup of the  couple of days before and the couple of days after. This is quite interesting or important to know when you analyze  the result of the process inventory revaluations. So those of you who are doing the detailed analysis of our  performance should be aware of that specific period.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The production numbers are looking very good on copper, which is primarily from Boliden this time. We have had  a good copper output from the Maurliden East pit, which we are depleting in the coming quarters. It's going  towards depletion. On the other hand you see the opposite on the zinc side where we have had a very weak zinc  production in Boliden area. So it's a quite big mix change from compared to what probably some of you have in  your models. On the zinc side, we have also seen – we are in Garpenberg on – in low grade areas, and which is  giving an impact on the output, but as you can see the iron ore product or – the ore production has been good.  Tara is developing well in the quarter.

file: BOL - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 22October2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: What does this surmise to? Well, the metal demand is – China drives the metal demand as always, and the global  macro is reflected by the graphs I showed. The metal and concentrate supply, the mine and smelter industry;  basically, we see after a period of lower results that CapEx spending are cut in most of the companies.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We had some maintenance stop also this quarter. We had SEK25 million in the quarter, and that was basically  [indiscernible] (11:14). We had a little work in Odda as well. We had SEK305 million, as I mentioned, in the  second quarter. The sulphuric acid market is lower or is weaker, and we see lower price levels.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And we also see that the Nordic market is very soft. So therefore, we have to send the acid longer distances. And  it's quite expensive to move the sulphuric acid in chemical tankers or special tanks and so on. So we are seeing a  clear negative impact from the sulphuric acid. The CapEx was SEK203 million, compared to SEK172 million a year  earlier. And also here, the big project is the silver plant in Kokkola, and it's running on plan.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The silver recovery project in Kokkola; it's really a concentrator plant. We are grinding some residues. We are  doing flotation cells in – very small if you compare with Aitik or something like that, but it's a small concentrator  plant, and it's a beautiful piece of engineering that's coming together. And I think that we have a lot of technology  how to operate that. We think we're going to make it on plan. And it's going according to cost as well. It's going to  be a good addition to Kokkola. It will be in startup after the mid-year 2014.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Garpenberg; as you all know, the big investment we're doing right now. We are in really, really critical time. Most  of the deliveries are – but all of the big deliveries are there. We are putting them all together. We're starting o r  we're doing – running all the piping, all the electrical installations. And we are going to continue to do the  installation of all the bits and pieces and controls and all of that. And it will take another six months before we  start operating it. We are on plan, and we think we're going to do it on the cost or the CapEx budget.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have some environmental – what should we say? The permitting – we are – we have a permit coming up, and  we hope that we'll pass swiftly through 2025. I mean, they're always 10 years at a time. But beyond 2025, we have  some discussions going on how to do with the tailing dams? How to do with some of the emissions and some  process equipment?

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And that is already coming into the life of mine plan, when we start to ramp-up, or if we start to ramp up to 45  million tonnes a year. So it's very long term, the things we're going through right now, but they are also very  important when it comes to how to do the detail planning now. So it's – it feels like Aitik is more long-term  planning than ever before.

file: BOL - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 22October2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On the terms, take away the currency for a moment. Metal prices have been going up, in particular, on zinc. When  zinc is going up, it's also automatically pulling the zinc TC, which has a price clause in it, so -called escalators. And  therefore, we had a quite significant improvement in the smelters, which is going negative in the same way for the  mines, selling the concentrates. Else on that, we have seen also copper TC's going the right way and the effect of  improvement plans.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Whereas, the copper market which was assumed to be oversupplied on copper concentrates has a minus. Bu t both  of these numbers are more a reflection of what happened last year where copper was very, very strong and now  compared to that [ph] poor quarter (05:10) we have a minus and the other way around for zinc.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So I think the long-term situation remains that we have a thin mine supply going forward in zinc, and we have a  well supplied market at least for a year or two in copper. Thereafter, I think more and more people are seeing the  effect of low investments on new mining and a possible deficit in copper b eyond that period.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Zinc price, the long-term picture is flat and the last 12 months clearly positive, as you can see on the smaller  blowup of the past five quarters. If we look at copper, in contrast, it's long-term negative and short-term very flat  situation. The quarter had a little bit higher copper prices, as you can see on the black horizontal line over the  quarter, which is higher than in the second quarter where we saw a gradual increase in the quarter. But the longer  term picture is flat and the longer is negative for copper price.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we then go into the operations, and start with the mines. Earnings were SEK 355 million, and that is lower than  the market expectations from what I read. It's lower than last year, and a little bit better than the second quarter.  The impact here of higher zinc price is good for the mines, no doubt, but it's also pulling up the zinc TCs, which is  going negative for the mines and positive for the zinc smelters.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The production ramp up in Garpenberg went very well. We continue to be on plan. The concentrator plant is, and  the volumes or the zinc concentrator production is good. But we continue to take some of the ore from the  stockpiles we have accumulated over, say, two years.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So the mine is ramping up according to plan, a little bit gradual. And the concentrator plant is more doing a step  change and we have prepared for this by building an ore stockpile, which we take ore from. The general situation  is very good. We have a positive or a mix change going to zinc in Boliden, which is temporary. As we know, the  Boliden area is growing a little bit depending on where we choose to mine.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The solid line diagram is showing the copper production, which is down, which is essentially an effect of ore  production and the lower grade in Aitik. But I stress again, for the third time, I guess, that the lower grade in Aitik  is perfect in line with the guiding we have done for 0.20 for the full year. So no problem with that.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On zinc, well, the ore production is increasing. Obviously, it's a question of Garpenber g coming up. The metal  production is going up, but a little bit lower grade than we have seen before, but basically it's a reflection of the  improvement. The lower grade is coming from Tara, where we also had a conveyor belt, which stopped. And it  was, well, collapsing and that took a while to correct. Nothing major, but still. Ore mix in Boliden, I already  mentioned.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We had a leach tank which collapsed a bad accident, a scary situation in right after the Q2 report, and we issued a  press release when we had the full sort of understanding of the impact there. We announced a €7  mill ion Q3  impact and thanks to very active management, very creative solutions. We balance that and actually got a slightly  lower negative impact than anticipated in the beginning. It's only SEK 50 million impact.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: What is more important than the monetary impact areas that no one got hurt and nothing was emitted to the  environment, but it calls for reviews of all the tanks and we certainly have done so. It was not a good situation,  completely unexpected.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance
texts.text: We do have a lower secondary feed, which is something that we pointed out. We do have an issue with the  secondary feed in getting the right material that we want to have, and with the lower second ary feed also comes  lower free metals which is part of the volume, and that comes in there. On the other hand, there's the ramp up of  Garpenberg is positive, and of course, looking year-on-year, positive on the volumes.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance
texts.text: Price and terms, that should not be any big surprises looking at our sensitivities and the changes in the currencies.  And especially the zinc price, you'll come up with a number like that, and I think that's where it might be difficult  because we don't guide is what comes on smelters and what comes on mines. And I think, in general, we're looking  at from the comments I've read, I think there's been some underestimation of what comes on the smelters as  opposed to what comes to the mines. But when the zinc price goes up, as Lennart has pointed out before, a lots of  that goes actually through the smelters through the escalators onto TCs that helps the smelters and actually the  mines you need to pay for.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Okay. So again Garpenberg is a very exciting project. It started on time. We have nine production which is where –  the project is SEK 4 billion, SEK 3.9 billion. Half of it is invested underground, and about half is a concentrator.  The concentrator is a step change. And similar to Aitik, we have enjoyed a very positive development there.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The mine is, of course, a different animal. We are doing, well, all the dev elopments, all the roads, all the  infrastructure systems. And they are taking – when you build a lot of road networks below there, you're taking  capacity on the roads and you take capacity from the ore transportation. So you have to plan it and we have  planned it, of course, years in advance, which made it possible, and thereby, we have overproduced ore for a while.  We had a stockpile. And right now, we are producing more in the concentrator than we actually get out of the  mountain or out of earth.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The silver recovery plant in Kokkola is different though, because the start-up was on time and on CapEx. The  normal trimming situation is also there. But then suddenly, we have this reactor breakdown in the zinc plant. And  the problem there is that the material for the silver recovery is coming from the leach tanks which collapsed. So all  the silver production was zero or very, very close to zero in Q3. So when you have a new plant, you're trimming it.  Y ou're ramping it up and then no material. That's not an ideal. It's, I mean, something else could have gone  wrong, but not exactly the leach tanks feeding the material to it.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As we write in the presentations, the leach tanks are okay. We have repaired, and we have full sink p roduction  from really the turn of the quarter here. But then the material and the leach process takes some time, and then the  trimming will start again or ramping up of the silver. So given that accident, we had a serious delay, which we are  not calling a delay over the project because it is not. But the whole situation there is, of course, unfortunate. We  are saying that we will have the silver production going in November. So give us a month for the other stuff and  then, we should be well on our way there.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Aitik45, interesting. We had a Friday, 11, say two weeks ago or three weeks ago, it was, and we were expecting the  result of the permitting there, and the permits came basically in line with what we expected. So basically, we're  happy with it. We can ramp up to 45 million tonnes. We can continue the plans as anticipated. There is always or  there are always things, which we could have expected to be better and we are not pleased with every detail of it.  But the big picture of what we're doing in Aitik45 is then okay or good.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Garpenberg, we have said 2 million tonnes as a guidance. We are probably on the high side or we are on the high  side. Now that's how we're saying that it's going to be around 2.1 million tonne production in 2014, so good news  there. The pace 2015 has to do much more with the mine production, and we are not changing that guidance.

file: BOL - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 23October2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On the base metals markets, we see the combination now of a slower demand or a slowdown of the demand with  the effect of increased numbers or increased capacity from the copper mines in the world. But the overcapacity is  probably not as severe as one could have expected, given the demand side. There have been many disruptions,  many production problems in many of the mines across the world. And therefore the oversupply is not that great.  On the zinc side, the big Century mine closed a month ago. The concentrator continues for a little, but it is closed.  I spoke with the management there only a week ago at the LME Week where I met them. Lisheen in Ireland is  another big zinc mine that closed, but there are other zinc mines increasing capacity, for example, Garpenberg.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Metal prices are down and the prices are closing up to the cash cost curves and we see that on next slide. Here we  see the max and mean metal prices for – in the different years, and the lines are showing the cash costs. The cash  costs, as you can see, and it's a different quartile. So the yellow line here, if the price is on that level, 10% of the  mines in the world are going with EBITDA negative, and 90% are EBITDA plus.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And as you can see here, the bottom prices, which is pretty much what we have seen lately in the past or recent  period, is closing into the 90th percentile. Typically the floor level of copper and the zinc prices can go down to,  say, 75th and a little below the 75th percentile if we look in history. That has been the traditional turning points.  We can also see that in the copper world, the cash costs are going down. And it is not a question of rationalization.  It's a question of the currencies, soft currencies that we share with Chile, for example. But it's also energy prices  and a couple of other factors.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Metal prices are having an impact also here on the free metals, obviously, and we have TCs development and all.  But basically, we have a very strong production, stable and high production in the smelters.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The new nickel business is also a good thing. We are securing the supply of nickel material to new customers and  we have signed contracts for nickel concentrates, partly with new mines and in new contracts with the mines  delivering before. Well, that's true also on the front end, that we were also supplying some of the material to old  customers or takers.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Metal prices, currencies and the rest, we have seen. If we now look at the going forward, copper grades in Aitik are  going to be 0.21% in 2015 and 2016. Garpenberg pace will be at 2.5 million tonnes by the end of the year, and we  plan to be there. Tara was not performing well and we have the improvement plan continuing to deliver and has to  deliver because it wasn't a great quarter. Rönnskär action plan, we took some major step in the beginning of this  plan on the cost side. When it comes to the production stability and process situation we said that this is taking  longer time. And you have seen it, but we are moving in the right – according to plan.

file: BOL - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 20October2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: On zinc, the picture we have painted before remains the same. A lot of mines closed last year. We see some  restarts going on right now, but minor, so the picture remains positive for zinc. Maybe continued risk for copper  price. The nickel side is very depressed even though we have seen some recovery from extremely low levels  when it comes to nickel price.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: So, I think that those of you who are studying very long-term or very old traditional patterns see that zinc and  copper are sort of moving a bit in parallel, maybe with a higher volatility on zinc. This is a completely different  pattern driven by the many copper mines and the very few new zinc mines having been built.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: As we can see, now, we are at $2,300 per ton or $2,200 per ton, $2,300 per ton on zinc. We have left the cash  cost because of the good macro on demand/supply, little mine supply. Copper are on low levels, no doubt. We  can see lower copper prices on very short times, but as an average, it's very depressed price in copper.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we then compare the metal prices with currencies, we have the average portfolio development, the currency  positions on the darker blue on the left diagram. We have the – oh sorry, on the lighter – currencies on the darker  side and metal prices on the light blue line. As we can see, we have had a quite stable currency picture – situation  for some time. And then later, what we say now, improved terms are coming basically from metal prices.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In smelters, I would say the quarter has been sort of not so special. It's not bad, it's not good. The earnings were  SEK 600 million, down from SEK 820 million a year ago. SEK 397 million in the previous quarter, but there we  had the maintenance shutdowns. The CapEx was SEK 280 million, in line with or slightly lower than last year. We  had improved market terms with the zinc TC following the zinc price-up, because we have the zinc escalators.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the numbers here, it's really a quite average quarter, both in metal produced copper and zinc and  with the throughput in the plants. So, not so much to say about this. I think the positive note is on P200 where we  are clearly ahead of plan.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: I think if we conclude and see where is this company going, first of all, we are in this strategic positioning with  mines and smelters, base metals, and precious. And I think we have invested now in a slightly broader portfolio  with – including nickel. We invested at a time when prices were very depressed. We are getting more precious  metals into the group as a result of Kevitsa but also the strategy in smelters with more complex materials. So, we  are sort of dividing our portfolio over time slightly wider.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: A few things are important here. Metal prices are, as always, very difficult to predict. I think the general macro is  good for zinc. It's risky for copper sale. I think for TCs, it's looking good for copper. It's slightly more risk on the  zinc TC. But as long as the price escalators will remain and the zinc prices are having a positive track, it's going to  probably be a good place to be also in zinc smelting.

file: BOL - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 24October2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The construction market, in particular, is moving well. The base metals had the normal growths, between 1% and  2%. Strong nickel demand growth. And on the supply side, we see the copper market being in balance, or in line  with the positive demand. The zinc smelters are suffering from a lack of zinc concentrates. The zinc is tight. And  we see closures coming in China, both because of fundamentals but also because of environmental situations.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We are seeing a surprisingly strong development on nickel. Nickel demand is very strong, but also supply is  coming very strong. And that is because of the nickel pig iron and the supply from Indonesia and the Philippines  which are coming very strong. So, it's not directly competing with refined nickel, which is sort of the value chain  we are in but still, it's having an impact on that market.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the prices and inventories, I would like to drill into this one a little bit more than we usually do. If we  start with the copper to the upper left here, we see that metal prices have or copper prices have been going up  quite a bit. They are now on around our long-term price levels, so I would say that copper is not very cheap. It's  not very expensive. It's somewhere in the middle where, we think, the long-term prices should be. And the  inventories are low. And it means that supply balances demand quite well.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: This is a great contrast to the zinc market which you see on the upper right here. Inventories have been going  down, down, down, and are down on the very low levels, 2% of global supply approximately. And the zinc prices  are now considerably higher than our long-term price.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Nickel is the opposite, there, we see very low prices continuing and we see the inventories being very high as  20% or over 20% of the global supplies. So, in our portfolio, we have the high priced zinc for fundamental  reasons. And we see the high zinc price and we see the very low nickel prices and in between, we have copper  somewhere in the middle.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we continue to look at this picture, which is showing the volatilities for the zinc, copper, and nickel, you can also  see another illustration where the prices on the vertical line, the maximum and minimum prices we have seen in  different years, and the line is showing the cost level of the industry. The highest of the three lines is the 90th  percentile cost level.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In the middle, we see copper, clearly also a profitable industry where prices are clearly higher than the average of  the 90th percentiles and the other percentiles. And to the right, we see nickel, which is clearly depressed, where a  lot of people are making loss and is not a profitable place to be. And given this, we're very proud of Kevitsa. We're  coming back to that later.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: CapEx was SEK 800 million, a little higher than last year. The production again maintenance and the  concentrators' production, disturbances and lower grades. And there I should also comment that we had rock  stability in Garpenberg. And Garpenberg's production plan [indiscernible] (00:08:41), high grades. We're taking  room after room after room. But then we have rock instabilities. And then we have to do extra reinforcements and  we have to work on those instability. And when we do that, of course, we have to mine somewhere else and it  means lower grades. This is a business typical, is not unusual, it happens time to time and now it happened at the  same time we had maintenance in a lot of concentrators. So, we think that it's more bad luck than anything else.  The cost has been well managed and under control and we have seen a clear positive price impact here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we then go through the production of copper, zinc and nickel, we have the bars which are the throughput in the  concentrators and the line is showing the contained or the metal content. If we start with the copper, we can see  that it's not a good quarter. It's not a very bad quarter but it's clearly bad compared to the previous and we have  seen the metal content is coming up and we're going into higher grade areas in Aitik, even though it was slightly  less than before. Nothing to worry about, I would say.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
