texts.text: On the zinc side, a similar pattern. And there we can say, we probably have a more negative development and it  is due to the Garpenberg situation, as I said, both on the volume and the grade there.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have lower free metals volumes. We have good cost control. And the market terms, as I said, is lower than  before. If we look at the production data here, in copper, it doesn't look very alarming but it's quite a soft quarter.  In zinc, we see a similar picture. So, we don't see it so much here. But on the margin, it's having an impact  obviously.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: The deviations are bigger if we compare Q3 to Q2. Q2 was a very strong quarter and we're SEK 450 million down  on that. Looking at then on the volume side, SEK 650 million negative impact is in mines. The two big deviations  to Q2 are Aitik and Boliden Area. Aitik, as Lennart said, we had some crusher issues leading to lower mill volume  and that also had an impact on grades. In the Boliden Area, it's maintenance. It's, let's say, we have a lower mix  than Q3 and it's the rock instability issues that we talked about in the report.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Smelters is neutral to Q2 when it comes to volume. We would have liked to see a more positive deviation  considering the higher amount of planned maintenance in Q2. We had lower free metals and we had some  process disturbances in the zinc smelters which had a negative impact.

file: BOL - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 24October2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Thank you, Olof. Good morning, everybody. First of all, before going into the real presentation, I hope that you all  see what is now presented on the screen, we'll come back [ph] a little later (00:00:40) talking about it later in the  presentation. As you see, the trolley line that we have built in our Aitik mine, which is the first step that we are  taking now towards electrification of our open pit mines, which is also linked to the announcement we had the  other day of a renewal of our truck fleet. But I'll come back to that later.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we start about the Q3 and about the quarter we've just finished, we have had a good quarter in terms of  production. We've had lower metal prices and you all know about. That's no news. And we'll come a little bit into  also that you know that we have a lagging effect in terms of the final pricing that we always get from deliveries in  previous quarters. That affects us negatively when the prices go down.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Smelters are doing well. We've had increased production which we are feeling very good about. We still have  some production issues, especially in the zinc smelters. But all-in-all, the Smelters performance has been good in  the quarter.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We do have a cost inflation. We talked about that already last quarter and it is still prevailing. We are in a situation  where we have inflation overall in the system of roughly 4%, very much driven by oil prices and consumables  linked to that which is driving most of that. And actually in terms of all the other things we buy, inflations are more  at normal levels.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: You can see also in copper, costs are going up in the world market. Prices are still a bit above. And on nickel,  yes, the costs are going up and the prices are going up. Here, we are thus in a better situation before and we still  think that there's lots of things that can happen in the nickel price going forward.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: But when you look at actual production, I think that's been going very well. The 10.8 million tonnes is a record for  a quarter, linked to the new crusher that's working well. We have grades according to our guidance. Garpenberg,  stable production. We have an increase of grades. In Kevitsa, we also have a stable production and strong  grades. And in Tara, we've had some planned maintenance. And on top of that, there is also some unplanned  maintenance that has led to lower zinc production than we've had in previous quarters, but I would still say,  according to our own measures, according to our plans.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: So, when we sum this up, yes, the copper production is down from the very high levels that we had. And I think,  was in the very high grades but still on a very nice level, the copper production. Zinc production, a little bit low with  the lower output in Tara, and nickel production very healthy.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: On the smelter side, we've had a relatively good quarter. It doesn't mean that we're totally free from issues, but  we've had it good. We have a lower metal prices that hits the – also here, the results. TCs that are lower because  they have to take some little time to get to full effect of the lower benchmark terms that came in with this year. And  also, we also buy a little bit spots with low TCs. But we have a stronger dollar making that up and we've had, as I  said, an increase in production compared to comparison periods despite that we haven't had perfect production  and the maintenance has been according to what we planned and what we have communicated.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: So when you look at that, we have stable production level, copper production looking relatively good, zinc  production in terms of metal, a little bit down. We are not really where we want to be in terms of recoveries  especially in Kokkola. But that's something they're working on and I think we're gaining more stability as we're  talking. The nickel in the matte production is also on a healthy level.

texts.speaker: Håkan Gabrielsson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Volumes are clearly up. We've got high production in both Mines and Smelters. On the mining sites, the mill  volume in Aitik is clearly about last year's and in the Smelters, generally good production but on top of that good  free metals.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: What is also important with this thing is all the trucks are prepared for electrification, even though we so far have  only decided to go ahead with a test trolley lane, the one that I showed you in the beginning, that we need to run  now through the winter to get a full season tryout and see how this works in arctic conditions. It is clearly an  ambition that we have to be able to continue to work on our carbon footprint and financial statement of being able  to reduce the dependency on oil and diesel by moving over to electricity.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: And as I said, all these, the new trucks that we're now putting in, are prepared for electrification and they're also  prepared for autonomous driving once that becomes a reality all the way out. It also – having a new fleet and a  fleet that is a single fleet and makes it possible to work, especially in Kevitsa with the pit design for further cost  reductions. And this will over time be able to work on the slope angles and work on the average ramp width that  will make it quite positive and this is all-in-all, a very positive investment the way that we see it and the way that  we calculate.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: As I said, we talked about the electric trolley. We do have the first line in place, it's only 700 meters. It in itself, it's  a small investment, and it in itself is a good investment as such, but we've decided not to move ahead with further  electrification until we get a full test run out of this one, to make sure that it works in all kind of parts of the year, in  the climate that we're operating in, where there's so far very few experiences around the world in similar climate  conditions.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: That's part of it. But it's also part that we are doing lots of exciting things and we talked about this. We are  expanding. I think we are expanding Kevitsa. We are expanding Garpenberg with the trucks that we just put in  place and that we have announced. It's a large part of why we're having big investments, then we're also having  the big investments as previously announced in Harjavalta, the expansion both of them with the new sulfuric acid  plant and the expansion of the copper refinery.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We're having the leach plant that we talked about last quarter that's coming into Rönnskär. And we're also having  big dam expansions, we talked about that in Capital Market Day, in Aitik and in Tara and in the Boliden area. All  of these things come together in 2018.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We are having, the way that we define maintenance CapEx, is not the big difference from this year, it's slightly  more than SEK 4 billion and it's maybe slightly more than SEK 4 billion next year as well. But all these other  investments, which are expansions or prolongations that are not year to year. For example, we take these dams  that are happening every seven years as opposed to every year. Those get into the non-maintenance CapEx  category.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have a long life of mine of the key mines. And we have stable jurisdictions where we are working. We have a  strong balance sheet. And we have several growth opportunities that we're still working around. Smelters are well- positioned generally for the circular economy. There are many interesting things that could happen around that.

file: BOL - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 12February2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: That we share with many of our competitors who are in typical nature resource countries in Latin  America, Canada, Australia and others, but we benefited even more from the currency exchange  compared to most of our competitors.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Okay, metal prices are very important for us and as we can see, the zinc price went up on a good  slope here and the average for this year 2009 was lower than 2008. We and/or we were at around  beginning of the year or Christmas at around the levels where on about 50th percentile of the cash  cost, which is just about the level we predicted that there should be support for this decline, it  shouldn’t go much lower than around 1,000 and it didn’t and then it has been climbing.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: What is important, though, is to note here the grayish area behind, which are the official aluminum  Shanghai stocks. And normally when the stocks go down, the price go up and when the stocks go  up, the price go down. But now since several months we have a combination of increased prices  and increased stocks.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: 3 TC on zinc and premiums, I would say that it looks, if anything, as TCs on zinc will go down  somewhat when we do the – see the final price settlements 2010. But we are not yet there. But  most metal analysts and most indications are in that direction. It’s far from ready, so anything can  happen on the zinc side. It looks okay.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Copper prices had held up much longer and therefore the year-on-year difference is much more  pronounced than for zinc that last year or 2008 was higher average prices than 2009. We see a  similar development.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: These are the TCs for copper, $75 per ton of concentrate here. And the settlements appear to be  down around 45 to 50 range. It’s not yet ready, but most expectations are probably 46.50 now. That  is a big decline, but you should also bear in mind that a very important other byproduct in the  coppers smelter is the sulfuric acid. And the sulfuric acid was on very, very difficult conditions when  the settlements on TC was high.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Now that TC settlements will be a lot lower, but conditions for sulfuric acid is improving quite a lot.  The bottom line of all of this, nothing is settled yet. We don’t know, but it’s probably not as bad or as  difficult as the decline in TC would indicate.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Going into the business areas, starting with the reason why we gave some guidance on Q3 was we  saw this, this is the mill production and here is metal content and, of course, if this is going down  like this, it means that more than production, it means that the general or average grade is lower.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: That is copper and it’s predominantly out of Aitik. And I think everybody should let me explain  what’s going on here. We are in the commissioning stage of 36 million tons of ore from previous 18.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: When that happens we employ new people, we have double shifts, we are mining in different  sections, we are blasting and we are working in several places of the pit and we’re piling up  different kind of cones. In the bottom we have about 0.45% grade, up on the South side we have  probably 0.21%.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: And the mix change here is depending on or with running the old mill or we using the crusher, in-pit  crusher or we using the new crusher on the top here. We are in the commissioning stage. So we  are going to see variation in grades when we turn in the new 36 million tons and I would say don’t  overreact on that, either if it is very strong grades or low grades in the quarters, it’s going to be  volatile and hard to predict also for ourselves in the commissioning and start-up phase. Zinc  production, good here and grades somewhat low, as indicted.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Exploration activities on the cost side, we have spent more on exploration. We are recruiting  people. We are increasing the drilling and we are generally increasing the efforts here.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: This is a picture, I think, from just I think from yesterday actually. What we do in Aitik, we down mill  the ore production and with high productivity we can convert waste rock to ore. The cut-off is lower       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: This is another picture from the flotation and what do we see here, mine production, expansion on  plan. Cold tests are finalized and we are now in the process of running the conveyor systems all the  way up to the mill and most of the things are tested.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Pumps are tested, control systems are tested. Everything has been running with water in the  system, so without ore and we are now in the next couple of weeks starting to feed ore into the  system for the first time.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: Those of you who were at the Capital Market Day recall we were blasting up here at the top. This is  waste rock until you hit the cutoff point and then you going into ore and it’s going to be low grades  there and then increasing and this is taking several years. So 2014 on pushback six we are into the  cutoff and then we’re coming here. Typically here we are, I think the average grade there is 0.45 or  something. Up here it’s probably 0.15 and here it is below, so it’s waste rock.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: And here is a pit from above and we have this pushback six, which is working on waste rock right  now. Here we have pushback five with very high grades and that’s going to be basically depleted  for this time 2010.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: And therefore we have the indicative picture, as you can recall, it differs. But if this is the average  grade we’re going to be on good grades 2010 and we’re going to have a number of years on below  average grades there. This is a ramp-up from 18 to 36 million tons. Most of it is according to plan  happening already this year.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: On turning from mines to smelters, this is a good result in the copper smelters in Q4 and this is a  good result not least in Kokkola, which is doing production records and all-time highs and it’s going  very nice in the smelters in average.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: On the cost you could be alarmed by a negative cost development, but this is not a negative  underlying cost development. First of all, it’s a slight volume effect driven by the increased  production levels in the zinc smelters.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: The smelters are good in zinc, but exposed and under difficult market conditions in copper. There  are too many smelters in the world. There are too little copper cones from the mines and not only  Aitik, but the whole world of copper mines are seeing grades going down over time.

texts.speaker: Frans Benson, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Operator:  Ladies and gentlemen, very welcome to this fourth and last Boliden results presentation
texts.text: And therefore there is a shortage of cones, which is giving a lot of profits to the copper mines and  leaving little profit over to the copper smelters. Now Boliden is good in electronic scrap recycling  and a couple of other byproducts, so we are probably better off than many, but still the conditions  are difficult. And therefore, we are going to continue to have reduced production in the copper  smelters.

file: BOL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 11February2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: If we start this presentation by going through some more details of the metals markets with a focus  on copper and zinc, fundamental demand in the global markets are continuing to be good and we  saw record highs in both zinc and copper in the later part of the year. High growth in all regions and  we had copper inventory which declined and zinc inventory which went up having the impact on the  prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the supply side, we saw in general a mine production that could not match the end demand and  equally with the demand from the world’s – smelters around the world. But we saw a difference in  the end of the year when the copper con market clearly eased up, and we had the possibility to fill  up our inventories and probably overfilled a little, but it’s clearly a better supply situation in copper.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The sulphuric acid which created a lot of difficulties a year ago in – for the copper smelters, that  market has also improved, both when it comes to the demand and deliveries. Many customers are  really wanting more and more and the prices have gone up accordingly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The market situation for metal – for zinc and copper con were negative and tight in the first nine  months, but eased slightly in the end of the year end and we saw that this is for copper improving  or at least we see the spot TC terms coming up.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With that demand situation, we have seen the zinc prices developing as follows, we have seen –  we saw last year a very strong development and we have seen this year volatility around the levels  between 2,000 and 2,500 and we have seen the inventories continue to grow.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In copper, we saw the last year development, which was similar to the previous one, but after a  somewhat hesitant first half, the copper prices went on and we have seen over $10,000 per ton  days recently.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The other metals, gold, silver, they are looking quite a lot like the copper, very strong continuous  growth or price increase over a two-year period. We had an extraordinary development for silver  and we see the lead markets, which – or prices which have developed similar to the zinc. And,  finally to the bottom right, you see the sulphuric acid contract prices, which has also improved.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The treatment charges there we see – here we have the historic benchmark on spot markets and if  we look at the contract negotiations going on right now and the rumors coming out, it seems as if  the zinc TCs are coming down from the previous year and the copper TCs are coming up from the  year before or from 2010. Premiums have a positive development.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 On the smelters, one of the more exciting long-term developments is of course electronic scarp  expansion. We are increasing from 45,000 tons of electronic scrap to 120,000 tons in the special  line for electronics. We are spending SEK1.3 billion and we’ll start around New Year or early part of  2012, and we are on plan.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have however had some cost issues, part of that is of course driven by the volume increases in  Boliden and in smelters. But we’ve also increased our reclamation costs or reserves for future  reclamation works related to mines. We’ve had continued start-up problems in Aitik, which have  resulted in costs. And if you continue down in the bridge, you can note that we’ve seen strong  development of primarily zinc and copper.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I noted the reclamation costs and we have an increased effort on exploration. Metal prices have of  course impacted the comparison with last year a lot and we have somewhat negative impact from  the stronger Swedish krona.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sensitivities, the usual quarterly update on the annual impact of 10% change of important price  parameters for Boliden and I would like to underline that these are unhedged. So when you do your  calculations you must take into consideration the impact of hedges on these sensitivities. And you  must also be aware about the fact that we have a new hedge program in place for the Garpenberg  project, two and half years, as Lennart noted, around a third of our price exposure to copper, zinc,  silver, gold and lead. Lennart?

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The summary of the fourth quarter of this year is obviously we’re quite pleased. We are never fully  pleased in this management, but we’re – it’s an okay quarter with good development in the  smelters. We have seen the impact of battery availability of copper con combined with our ability to  use copper or to use electronic scrap to produce gold and copper from, which is a very good  business. And we have the combination in Finland with copper battery availability on the nickel  business we’re doing.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Grades will decline, in line with what we have said for a long time and we are continuing the route  to 36 million tons per year in Aitik 2014.

file: BOL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We had SEK125 million one-off in the reclamation provision. The cash flow was slightly negative or SEK480  million negative and we are of course in one of the biggest investment cases or periods ever with Kankberg, the  gold mine in the final stage and final payments of the Rönnskär electronic scrap recycling and we are building very  heavily now in Garpenberg, the zinc, silver mine, so a very large CapEx plans. Metal prices were lower, the cost  was higher and we come back to that and we had also very good exploration results. In parallel with the Q4  results, we also published our exploration records for 2011.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: But we can also see if we look at the blow-up of the period that we have a positive trend since the beginning of the  third quarter. If we do the same analysis for copper, it's a very similar pattern that the copper price has fell quite  dramatically the days before the Q3 endings, and then we have seen copper coming back and you see the average  is a lot lower in the Q4 compared to Q3, but you also see that the beginning of the year has been going in the right  direction.  On smelter treatment charges, we have a very uncertain situation when it comes to the benchmark negotiations  for 2012. I think of all the experts, we have a 50/50. Some think it's going in a positive direction and some in the  negative. What we know though is that the treatment charges for zinc as we speak is not very good and certainly  not in Q4 when it was also impacted by the price escalators and the price adjustments. Copper treatment charges  have been a lot better. But more important than TC is the value of all the by-products and the free metals, which  have contributed well, in particular in the copper smelters.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Metal premiums, well, not a too different or dramatic development. If we see our increasingly important precious  metal, silver, where we are building a lot of capacity in Garpenberg and as you saw today's press release, we are  investing in silver recovery from the zinc smelters in the same concentrates in the world as well as from our own  mines. The value of the silver is too big to leave in the tailing, so this investment is going to take out more of the  silver and the copper – zinc cons than we have today. Positive development on zinc prices over time, even though  over the year from the peak in silver, it has come down and gold is also close to all-time high or at least on very  good levels. The lead prices are trailing or similar to the zinc prices.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: To the right, we see the zinc, where production numbers – ore production was good, but we had a quite sharp fall  in metal content. The reason for it is, as we have said, quarter-after-quarter-after-quarter that mine cannot  consistently be producing over the ore reserve average. And now we are seeing the effect that we are coming into  more normal grades.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We did SEK326 million compared to SEK530 in Q4, and we did SEK356 million in Q3. So solid results we think  from the smelters. We have prioritized electronic scrap production in Q4 and therefore, we – the old Kaldo  furnace, what we call the lead Kaldo, the one where we previously have been doing both lead and electronic scrap  have prioritized heavily electronics in order to accommodate the deliveries we are now taking on, the increased  material flow for the new Kaldo furnace and [ph] EU Bura (14:36) project when that starts in this quarter and be  in full production next quarter. So we have prioritized that and on very little lead and when [indiscernible] (14:51)  on again we're going to take up the lead production more in the old lead Kaldo.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We had lower metal prices, treatment charges have been so okay, premiums are okay, all-in-all, I'd say that the  copper terms are good; the zinc terms are quite difficult. High volumes and prices of by-products on sulfuric acid  has continued to be a strong product and we are earning a lot of money on sulfuric acid right now. The expansion  in Rönnskär on electronic scrap is on plan.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Production on copper as you can see to the left, quite flat, but we have a good mix change with more electronics  now when we used – utilized the very old Kaldo only for electronics. And we can test now all the material feed  system for the new investment in the fourth quarter. So a lot of that has been commissioned already. So we are  preparing step-by-step for the increase when the new investment is up in full production.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Kankberg, this is what the mine will look like or the developments will look like in – at mid year. I think we are  ahead of schedule when it comes to the developments and we are probably going to start slightly ahead of project  plan when it comes to the ore production. We are going to stockpile it and we are going to start the leaching  around maybe a little before the mid year. On the other hand, the tellurium extraction is going to be in the end of  Q3 or beginning of Q4. So I think our guidance before start and the middle of the year is very relevant, and I think  that's what we continue to say, but part of the project is ahead, part is slightly after the half year.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: This is a beautiful picture of 18 of January; I got it in the morning there. It is our colleagues and they are looking  out there when we are pouring out melted metal for the first time. It was somewhere three in the morning on the  drilled down to minus 1200 both personnel shaft and material or ore hoist. I think that has gone very well. We are  smack on plan there. And we – really the hoists and all of that underground infrastructure, the rock work will  finish probably in the first half of this year. So it's really happening a lot now and we're spending a lot of money.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We had got environmental permit. It happened as we had planned and we have got it and we started the  construction of the new concentrator right there. So I showed board earlier today a picture of all the construction  equipment is on-site already. So it's happening. And all-in-all, the project is on plan.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: So where do the costs come from? Well, I have taken out here just to have a sense of where the SEK69 million  come from. And you can see clearly that it's the energy and external services that contribute to largest part to the  increased cost. You also the capitalized costs are – or partly the cost that is capitalized is also going up, because we  are doing lots of waste rock removal in the fourth quarter that comes into that number.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Now, why is this happening, well, it's happening partially because of high inflation and we've been working our  numbers up and down to have a sense of it and it's pretty clear that we especially in the mining side are being hit  more. On certain chemicals that are linked to energy also see the same 20%, the chemicals you will see a more  modest number on and you also see certain other mine particular items like the tires that are also up close to 20%.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the result of Q4, there we had the crisis in the political world that impacted the metal prices heavy in  the beginning of the fourth quarter, but they have recovered since. In Boliden – copper increase in Boliden area  has compensated a slightly lower copper production in Aitik. Zinc grades are down, but that is well communicated  that we have been over the reserves.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Kankberg is also coming close now – the world's largest tellurium mine, two tons of gold – or one ton of gold as an  average and we start the leaching, which is taking most of the gold out of it around mid-year or slightly ahead of  that. And then we have the last, including the tellurium – salable tellurium in Q4 coming up. So that is, of course  an extremely exciting year.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Garpenberg expansion continues. We are building; we are drilling; we are developing, and it's going well. And the  Aitik, I think nothing – well, basically, we are on the way to 36 million tons a year. We had a little bit of a weak  situation in Q4, and we have this rebuild. I don't think we should exaggerate that we are in a good progress there.

file: BOL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 11February2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And on copper, more of a – well, you can see something different. Well, first of all, it's flat, if you look at the last  several quarters, but we can see that the inventories, the shaded line at the bottom, are much better than for zinc,  of perhaps an improved general global economy is supporting the bottom or the bottom of the floor or – of the  prices here.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Lead is probably the one which has been surprising many with an increased car production in China, with start- stop functions in the West, which is driving slightly bigger batteries, and the difficulties to startups lead  production anywhere, whether it's smelters or mines, are holding back supply. So I think I have said that for  several quarters that we're quite excited about the outlook for lead.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: What we read here is a very flat concentrate supply, and metals demand which is up. And we see copper demand  being flat or even a bit negative from negative numbers from China, but I'm not sure that will be the case when we  see an update of Q4 numbers later on.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In December, we had a gear box, which broke down. It was planned. We knew that we have some problems with it  and it was planned to be done in January, but it happened, it collapsed and this breakdown was taking also much  more time than it should have done had we had it as planned in January.  Boliden, just to remind, we are in an ore mix change situation there. We are going to produce less copper because  molybdenum is depleting and we are going to replace that with zinc and we saw that happening in Q4. And else on  that the projects are predominantly or first of all the Garpenberg project is on plan and we had CapEx of SEK1  billion compared to SEK800 million a year earlier. And the full-year results, we publish them once a year and here  are the developments which, I think, you will in your analysis will show what happened with terms, which are the  most important factor here.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In production, we see copper production going down for the reasons I said, both lower in Boliden which is small,  but still it's in addition to the decline and then we had the difficulties with the maintenance and the breakdown in  December. In zinc, it's a quite dramatic effect both of Tara, but the most of it is from Garpenberg.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The good news from today's news flow is definitely the mineral resources. We have increased the resources in all  mines. We have continued reserve increase in Garpenberg and Boliden area, which is very good. Resource  increased in Aitik, which is huge in tonnage, but with low average grade, so it's low grade areas we're adding to the  mineral resources. We have also the new – two new deposits, one of them you know from before, Laver, which is  690 million tons, and the new one which we bring to the resource status today is Rockliden 4.5 million tons with  high grades in complex ore in copper, zinc, lead, and precious. Rockliden also contains arsenic and some difficult  materials, so it's not an entirely simple metallurgical deposit, but it's quite big, and is very rich.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Exploration in the year was accelerating from the year before primarily because of Laver, and that we had a very  intense drilling program to define Laver as mineral resource.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We are going to spend more time in Garpenberg as we now start to accelerate production, but it's – we're holding  the reserve resource levels basically and improving little. In Tara, we are adding, so it's not quite one year of  reduction for each year of production, but we are still seeing that we are sort of depleting Tara gradually. And  those charts are not taking into account Laver or Rockliden.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The other one obviously is Odda where we had this collapse of a leaching tank or a leaching reactor. We said it was  very new when we had the Capital Market Day. We thought it would be a cost or a consequence of SEK30 million,  we are now ready with it, it's up production or production is back again. We're going to have some lower  production in the first half of the year, but it's marginally impact and the bottom line is not SEK30 million, but  SEK40 million so that we were a little bit too optimistic on that one.  Costs are a little higher than Q3 for, basically, seasonality reasons primarily and in line with Q4 of last year.  CapEx, $277 which is a lot down from the previous year when or last year when we were in the final stage of the  electronics recycling. Kokkola silver recovery project will be in production next year.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: We also have some negative development of prices and terms, and some of you might be a little bit surprised on  that because they were stable prices or actually slightly higher prices, but that was on average. And when you start  looking into detail on the graphs that Lennart showed you earlier, you'll see that we had low prices in the  beginning of the quarter which affected the negative, the MAMA or the month-after-month pricing effects from  Q3 that came in as a negative. Then there is also a smaller effect in this month, but it becomes bigger in this  comparison that we do have a sliding scale in terms of several of our by-products of the smaller metals and the  sulphuric acid that we're selling.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: And depreciation is increasing SEK44 million as linked to the investments and very much in line with the plans.  Then there is a positive from others, but, as you'll remember, we had a SEK125 million one-off for reclamation  work at the closed mines last year, and we do not have similar to that, as a P&L effect this year; I'll come in a little  while and talk about what we have this year, which is a balance sheet effect.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Future reclamation costs in operating mines in Sweden, we have done a preview and an overview of all the  estimated future reclamation costs. There is an increase of SEK538 million and this is linked not just to the new  estimates, but also the fact that there are to some extent tougher regulation regarding how much participation  that would be allowed in the future, once these mines shutdown. They will, don't have any effect on the profit and  loss statement or on cash flow for 2012. Starting 2013 they will increase the depreciations of roughly SEK30  million, and then the financial costs every year, the revaluation comes at about SEK10 million.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: It's going well. We have some a bit messy situation in Q4. We have a winter period, which we have said before, is  tricky with a lot of snow and ice, and minus 40 degrees and that – but I think we are confident and it's going  basically well. And some of the changes we have done here are for the better over time.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Rönnskär e-recycling is running at full capacity. Kankberg, the mine started early as you know in the spring of this  year, and if you look at the updates of mineral resources, we have some very good developments in the Kankberg  resources.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Gold leaching started and gold is the main product that went – is going well and we have the tellurium in a  trimming-in period. We have had some minor issues with it, and we hope that's going well.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The silver recovery project in Kokkola is developing on plan, and it's really in the midst of being constructed now.  I was there a couple of weeks back and it's – again, everything what we are doing, if you spend – spend big money,  you get big things, and it's true here too, it's a big silver recovery plant.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We work on the feasibility of Aitik 45, which is – well we work on it. And the Laver conceptual study, we are also  working on and, as I said, we have been doing a lot of drilling in the year in order to prepare for that.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Metal prices have been stable with the exception of the by-products, which are less visible for you or transparent  to you and they have really been giving some fairly big minus in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Lennart Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Operations, we are going to continue to operate low grades up on the sides of the pit in Aitik. We are not going to  remain forever over the reserve average, but we are now for a period going to be lower. We have a mix change in  Boliden area where Kankberg will start which is good against that stance that we have Maurliden Östra which is  Maurliden East which is, basically, a copper open-pit, small one, which is going to deplete and we take back the  lost copper and more zinc in from Kristineberg, as you know, we have the bottleneck of the whole Boliden there as  a mill and so we can choose, the volume is there. We cannot do more than what we have in capacity, but we can  choose to feed it from different places. We have a shift from open pit in this context to underground, which is  higher cost.  Cost programs going on in Odda, continuing, is going really well. In Tara, there was an article in [indiscernible]  (29:53) the other day that we are in negotiations with unions; we need to take the cost down in order to be better,  less dependent on metal prices.

file: BOL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 12February2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: On the other hand, we've had a very strong development in Harjavalta. So copper production and copper business  has been all-in-all sort of partly offsetting the weak performance at Rönnskär by strong in Harjavalta.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at construction, which is the largest segment for both zinc and copper, it's a little bit mixed feelings here  and you can see the declining light blue line in the middle there, which is the U.S. construction industry. But we  also have a blowup or not a blowup, but an early indicator of the construction industry in the U.S., which is the  starting – housing starts, and that has a very positive development, as you can see. So I would say, on construction  it's the same in China, looks negative in the U.S., but relatively sort of positive development in Europe and good  signs also for the U.S.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we look at the price development, it has been both for zinc here and two slides from here copper, is several years  of very, very stable prices. But we can also see the shaded curves in the back there which are the official inventory  levels and after many years of increased, an increased concern of a flooded zinc market, we have seen the official  inventories going down in Shanghai and LME.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The premiums, we have been nervous that the few people having zinc concentrates will hold very hard and be very  difficult to negotiate with if you are a zinc smelter. But as you can see, the zinc TCs have been holding up and are  quite constant and we can see a positive development on the premiums. This is probably been better than we had  expected.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: All right, copper as I said, also here, quite strong or quite flat price development even though it's a slight negative  which is in line with more supply. But all-in-all, I will say that it's more stable than probably many were nervous  of, not too long ago. And if we see the TCs quite as expected, that the TC levels are going up, are trending upwards  and the new benchmark levels is 92 and RC of 9.2. So as you can see, the new benchmark level is considerably  higher. So that is in line with what we've said before. Also for copper, we get a nice premium on top of the LME  price.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we add that to the first quarters, I would say that after the first quarter, we have had, when we had lo w  production in Aitik, very strong winters, a lot of freezing problems and cracks in steel and we had a lot of things to  tell after the first quarter of last year. I will say that production has been going smooth and very well after that.  And with the 10 million we did in the fourth quarter, we ended up at 37  million tonnes in Aitik, which is one year  ahead of plan, we had announced, long time ago that 36 million tonnes will be reached in 2014. So here we have a  project which is advancing faster than planned, we like that.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: So I'd say Aitik and Tara are the good examples. Boliden is, I think, maybe a surprise to some, but we are very  dependent on the other metals than copper and zinc there where we have seen declines.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have also, today, updated the mineral reserves and resources. The total of reserves and resources increased by  about 8% and the increases are primarily from the projects which are not sort of near mine exploration. It's rather   the big contributor to the mineral reserves.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Mineral resources decreased in the areas basically or partly because we lift resources to reserves. Laver and  Rockliden, also Rockliden is a very interesting case where we are starting to see pretty significant volumes and it's  high grades is down to 800 meters or from the surface and down its standing deposits. And if you look at the  numbers there, it looks good but we have some issues also with the metallurgical composition there. So it's not –  it's not only to look at 1.8% copper in the local tones, there are challenges which are a bit open t here, but it's good  news in any case.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: 10 days on copper and four days on nickel or the other way around.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: On the good news is that copper production, as you'll see on a couple of slides from now, Harjavalta has been  having a very good development on free metals, so very much the opposite of Rönnskär. Unfortunately, it's a  smaller smelter, so it's not offsetting the entire problem but still it's going the other way around.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: If we take them unit-by-unit as you can see here, Bergsöe is a small unit, good development, very good returns on  investments but it's a small unit. Odda is negative, we had this unfortunate collapse of a leaching reactor, we have  maintained a good production but we don't have an entirely ideal production mix, it's not a big thing but we're  struggling with a high cost unit and the cost plans we have in – or the action plans are working very well. But  despite that we're on a negative result on the EBIT, we're positive, clearly positive in EBITDA. Kokkola is moving  on like a Swiss clock. It's going real well, higher altitude. So, the finish units here are making up the profits.  Rönnskär, you can see the big decline, I explained that.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: The production, as you can see, is not that hard hit by the problems in Rönnskär which is probably slightly  difficult to understand. But the profit generated from copper smelters, it's not the copper volumes. It's how good  the recoveries are, how much free copper and free gold we can generate, and that is a relatively modest tonnage  but we have too little of that and that's why we have so much impact on the P&L. In addition, we have the  sulphuric acid and the other byproducts. Cost is relatively under control. Action plans are going. Results are badly  hurt by the continued instability and low recoveries. In zinc, not much to say, it's going well.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Now, if you look, instead, year-on-year, I think there are more to comment on. Y ou can see that the profits are  clearly lower, SEK291 million lower than they were a year ago for the same period. And that is all explained and  over explained by the prices and terms where you have lower prices especially for precious metals and sulphuric  acids and also the currency. Those aspects may – being the main contributors to the lower profit level.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: Now if you look at the profitability for the full year, you will also have the same discussions as you saw on quarter - on-quarter. We have in total, a lower earnings of SEK1,7 7 0 million or SEK1.8 billion and that's almost exactly  explained by pricing and terms and that again, is especially a lower precious metal prices and some other metal  prices and the currency and also sulphuric acid playing into  that.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Boliden AB
texts.text: And year-on-year, we have a higher volume. It's also in line with the new production we put in place and the high  production in Aitik. We do have higher costs, but if you look at these costs, a very large part of that increase is  actually electricity cost and that electricity cost for us, some might wonder, why are your electricity costs going up  when the general electricity price in the Nordic market is going down? Well, we have long-term agreements with  our suppliers that are linked to other events than the market price, that are linked to industries and they're also  linked to the tax burden that our suppliers have for their production of electricity. And since that has increased  over the year, that has pushed on to us straight off. And therefore we have had seen increasing electricity prices  over this year. Depreciation are higher, again, with the – all the investments in the last few years coming online.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: It's a process where we are starting bit-by-bit, we're first running all the sub segment or sort of parts, mills,  flotation and pumps and all the subsystems one-by-one. Then you start to fill up with water because you do want  to have abrasive stones in the system. You just run everything on water. And then that is the first real test, acid  test of what you're doing, is everything capable of working together and control systems, and things like that?

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: And then gradually you start to put waste rocks through the system and when everything is running, you start bit  by bit to add a bit of ore because you want to see if some zinc or silver is coming surfacing in the flotation cells. So,  it's really hard to say when you start. I know for sure that we hav e a startup process which is the first half of this  year, and we're absolutely committed to have the first production before the half year or before the turn of the half  year. But it's an amazing project right now.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Kokkola Zinc smelter is almost exactly in parallel with the Garpenberg project. If you talk with one or  the other  and don't know exactly what they're talking about, it's exactly the same kind of phase they are in. Going forward,  of course, we have a big thing happening hopefully this year and we plan to have a decision on Aitik45, 2014. It's a  next development step or stage for Aitik to go up to 45 million tonnes a year and we hope to take the decision later  this year.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: I think we are in an industry which is doing great, great support to a very sound development with less  inequalities in the world and so that will probably continue. The prices have been flat and I don't know what we  shall say about it, but I think the risk of falling copper prices is there but I think if anything maybe less than – than  it used to be.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: We have a benchmark set for copper, but we don't have one for zinc 92/9.2. We have a dollar which is having a  significant impact on us as you know. And if we look at the events internally here, we had the plan to be reaching  36 million tonnes next year and we did 37 million tonnes this year and we had a very strong finish of the year. I  think it is dangerous to put too much into it, but of course, we reached the target, well, one year ahead of plan and  that's good news, no doubt.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: Garpenberg we have spoken about or we spoke about the Kokkola startup, we spoke about Rönnskär, I think it's  going to take a while for us to fix it. I'm convinced we are going to do it. It is going to take some time. And at the  same time, we have Harjavalta on partly extraordinary high levels of free metals, which should probably be  expected to fall back a bit.

file: BOL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 12February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We have been lucky enough to be quite a lot in zinc. We have been talking about the good outlook for zinc for  several years and we have been talking about the risk on the copper side. I think that it's not a coincidence that we  are now in a place – our position it's not a coincidence, it is what we have been delivering or developing over a  long period of time.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we look at the metals markets in particular, I would say that the demand has been basically okay. But on zinc we  have been for years been talking about the scarcity of mine supply, which will have a positive impact on the zinc  pricing. That's happening. Of course some years ago, where we had hope for $3,000 for ton of zinc, now it's a little  more than $2,000, but looking at the general commodities, which are turning down of course zinc has been the  one of the better.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Copper has been plummeting or having had the problem with a lot of new mines coming in the system and the  supply has been increasing, but not as much as anticipated before. And the exchange rates are obvious. This is a  very busy chart; I will not go through it. But if we look at it, I would say that the tendencies of the supply of zinc  and copper are there, but probably not as dramatic as we said or thought say one year or two years ago, but the  picture is very much the same.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I think Boliden was one of the first in large mining conferences to talk about the risk over an oversupply in copper  at the time when everybody were just enthusiastic about the copper outlook. This is a metal price, a combined  chart where we have the weight or the combined, we have the different metals with their proper weights and we  measure it in Swedish krona.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On the zinc side, of course, the Garpenberg is adding to it, but we have a negative impact from Tara where we are  doing two things right now. Number one, we are depleting the higher parts of the Tara mine and the focus of  production is going to SWEX, South West Extension. So much more all the total tonnage from Tara are from the  deeper parts, which is longer transport or longer distances. And it's also an ore body, which is slightly more up in  smaller sections, so we don't have in average as big results as we do in the upper parts.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Exploration in the year was slightly less both in terms of money spent and drill meters. And on the positive note as  I already mentioned, we have extended the life of the Tara mine one year that is from 2019 to 2020.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The graph is looking like this. In Aitik, we have increased the reserves very much but we have taken basically all of  that we define it from the resources and that happened in May when we explained Aitik45 project. Boliden,  basically the light blue is up a little bit, the dark blue is little down, but I would say that we have a good  development and we have good ore value almost 10 years reserve life, the reserve is the dark blue.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Garpenberg, a slight increase in reserves and a very big increase in the resources, as you can see here, it's dou ble  and more than that. Kylylahti we have done no – or rather we have spent a lot of efforts now in exploration, but no  exploration results. So it's basically dust. We are mining out the year and the life of mine is standing still, you can  say right now, but we are right now in a quite hectic ramping up of exploration here. Tara increased reserve  despite the production in the year. So we could extend the life of mine there.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And now we go to the smelters and that we have invited you to have a management mee ting for the smelters  today, so Kerstin's whole crew is here. So, if you like the smelters, you can turn the other way around and our  heroes are up here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And then we've decided to do the C100 program and then we have some bad luck with one reactor or a part of  leaching reactor. Now it's back in production and we enjoy the currencies and returns. And suddenly we  are – we  have invested so well. We have done exactly and had luck with timing there, well done.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance
texts.text: We have a one-off in Premier Gold that's coming here, which is our old gold mine in Canada where we have a  responsibility for the acid treatment that comes in as a cost here. And then also, as you know, every fourth  quarter, we explained that we have a seasonal effect – there's actually third quarter seasonal effect. When all the  white collar people go home and take vacation, we get a lower cost. And then into the fourth quarter, they don't  take vacation and we get a higher cost coming back again.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Head-Treasury & Finance
texts.text: If you compare to a year earlier, we once again had a very high volume development. Here once again, Kylylahti  comes and we have the ramp up of Garpenberg, which was of course not in place a year ago, and we have once  again the higher and stable smelter production coming and helping us here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Y eah, well, most has been said already on the projects here. We are – Garpenberg is delivering fine and we are –  basically, we did 2.2 million tons. We are going to be at the pace of 2.5 million tons. I'll mention a little on that on  the next slides.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Odda, we decided to increase and of course we were already earlier quite enthusiastic about the impact of P100.  And so of course, we'd like to continue and now we take the cell house, which has been in care and maintenance or  not in production. That's been idle for a couple of years and we can now put it back in production and lease space  and going in with all the learnings we have from the P100 projects and we're seeing all that developing to a very  nice smelter.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The concentrator plan when you start it up it starting really as a step change. It has a higher capacity. The ramping  up of our mine, we have been doing for at least two years, in the beginning that led to an over-capacity in the mine  and we put a pile of ore underground. When we did all the trial runs, the starting up of the concentrators we used  part from the mine, but we also use the pile and the pile is empty now.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The Rönnskär action plan is under implementation. Most of the cost reductions came earlier and have been done,  more of the process improvements will follow. That's the basic look of it. And in Harjavalta, we have the nickel  business on our own books as a consequence of the strategy change, we explained in the Capital Markets Day.

file: BOL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 11February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On the TC and the smelters, which are, of course, the big contribution of profits nowadays. We see copper being  oversupplied and copper cons will – or they enjoy from many, many mines wanting to sell the copper con to the  smelters and good terms there. In zinc, it's more pressure on the zinc TCs. And so, on copper smelters, it looks  good. In zinc smelters, it looks good, but not quite as good as for the copper side .

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we look at – I think most of us are wondering. Are we going to see this metal price decline continuing or is this –  are we at the bottom or floors or where are we? These are two diagrams. As you can see here, it's on zinc to the left  and copper to the right. We have the lines, which are representing the cost level of the industry. Y ou can see on the  upper line the 90th percentile and the two below are on the 75th percentile and the 50th percentile.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And, therefore, it can be expected to not go down to the lowest possible levels. So, I would say we are somewhere  on the low side of zinc. In copper, we are already on the levels where the historic lows have been. So, I would say  that if the world is not behaving in a very different way this time compared to history, we are at the low points.  Individual days can probably be slightly lower, but I would say that, in historic terms versus cash cost, we are low  now.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The zinc price itself, if we blow it up, we can see the longer-term trends here. We know that zinc held up very good  compared to basically most – well, all raw materials or almost all raw materials. But it has been sort of influenced  by the general sentiment. Raw materials, bad news, everybody is selling. And it's putting pressure on it. I think  that we have seen in line with what we have also said many times that zinc is probably the metal, which will come  back soonest or sooner of the different metals.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And I think in volatilities, we have seen, the short volatilities, the zinc has been popping up stronger than most  other. And actually we are up – this is to the end of January and we are higher than that right now. But still it's  negative development. Copper is more negative and has been going down also in the beginning of this year, as you  can see on the blow up to the right here.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The precious metals are down. Lead is apart from zinc or probably the only one even beating zinc when it comes to  stability. Also, this we have pointed out for a year or two years that the start, stop functions in cars, the big car  sales in China and so on has been supporting batteries sales and lead is a good commodity.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Acting Director, Boliden Mines
texts.text: And let me just quickly go through them as a sum up. I mean we have a positive development in terms of mineral  reserves that are up in Aitik, Garpenberg and Tara. We have a higher reserve rate for copper  in Aitik, which is  important. And we've been working very hard in out optimization to get this. It might not look much to go from  0.22% to 0.23%, but it is a significant 5% increase in the grade, which will make a difference going forward.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Acting Director, Boliden Mines
texts.text: There are lower grades in Garpenberg and Tara, but it's not lower grades than what we had there historically. It's  the added tonnes that are slightly lower grades than the historic ones. But especially in Garpenberg where we're  making so much money, additional resources do make it into the reserves. We also have two new satellite position  that we will introduce. We have Nautanen, which is close to Aitik. Compared to [ph] dig (15:36) Aitik, it's a  relatively small resource, but it's high grade and it fits well into the profile and production going forward. And we  are quite hopeful that we can turn this into a mine in, say, five years to 10 years.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Acting Director, Boliden Mines
texts.text: So, if you look into the individual areas and here you can see graphically. You see the bar which is the darker blue  here on Aitik. Y ou can see that the reserves are going up. Y ou can also see how big the reserves are compared to  the production. The black line is 10 times annual production. And we had a 27 -year reserve life. And then you can  see lots of resources that could potentially be transformed. And here, you also see Nautanen at the 16 million  tonnes is relatively small. Resources will be underground. It's 15 kilometres away from Aitik. But at 1.4% copper, it  is, of course, much richer than the other Aitik ore and it looks quite promising from that point of view.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Acting Director, Boliden Mines
texts.text: Then going over to Garpenberg, you once again see here that, despite of increased production and we're taking out  2.5 million tonnes per year, we still have an increase in the reserves. However, it's slightly lower average grades  and those average grades is partially because we've been producing over the average grade. And that the  additional tonnes are coming towards the end are a slightly lower grade. But you also see a very high increase in  the resources. And, once again, it's proven that there are resources around in Garpenberg. These are also at lower  grades, but it looks very promising for the long-term in our most profitable mine.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Acting Director, Boliden Mines
texts.text: So, with that, I'll give it back to you, Lennart, to talk about smelters.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The volumes were higher than Q4 and the terms were – higher volume and lower terms. Of course, the impact of  falling prices is impacting the free metals, but is also impacting the zinc TCs. Compared to the previous year, as I  said, it's more strong last year than anything else or it is that. We had some internal profit eliminations where the  accountings were changed. So it's a one-time effect of minus SEK 60 million in the smelters business area.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we go through unit-by-unit, well, look at the yellow bars compared to the light blue bars and the total, I think, it  speaks for itself. What is exceptional is, of course, the more than double result in Harjavalta, where feed has been  good in copper, where the combined copper and nickel capacity is giving us – we can buy profitable products and  process it when we produce copper. We get some nickel and we can produce nickel. This combined nickel, copper  smelter is particular suited to the markets right now.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We also changed the strategy on nickel to do the nickel smelting in our own books. And it is not the reason for the  exceptional result, but it's adding. So, the profit or the strategic move there was good and is going according to  plan. Little Bergsöe has had some issues, not a big deal, but is probably the negative there.

texts.speaker: Mikael Staffas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Acting Director, Boliden Mines
texts.text: If we now compare against last year, we have a slightly lower production than we had a year ago in terms of  volume. This is mainly smelter feed that is slightly lower. And, as Lennart pointed out before, this is not so much  that we're producing bad this time around. We just had a very, very good Q4 for the smelters last  year that we're  comparing with.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we look at the Aitik, it looks like a very low level of profit, but Aitik is hit by SEK 200 million in one -off that we  took the charge of the diesel tax this quarter. So, the underlying result is SEK 200 million b etter. And the little  profit we do in Tara is on the other hand SEK 200 million worse, because it's including a positive of about the  same, about SEK 200 million. So, it's doing a negative SEK 100 million in EBIT.

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Garpenberg grades as demonstrated here or shown here. And we have some rock conditions in Garpenberg in the  end of December, which will we think not hamper the volume. There are some stopes where we cannot mine as  planned. So we have to now quickly redirect our production in Q1 or end of December and into Q1. Which – and,  today, I think it is true unless you have very recent news that we think we will make the volume. But we have to do  stopes with slightly lower grades, not too dramatic, but it's still something we know by now. So, we  inform about  that.

file: BOL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 10February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: John Lennart Kaleb Evrell
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Boliden AB
texts.text: In our presentation today, we cover a lot of the production and the general operations that we have.
