But also in areas such as procurement, process  improvement, taking out – which will result in us taking people out. There remains a lot more we can do in terms  of improving efficiency and effectiveness, and I think the environment means we probably have to.

texts.speaker: Michael Derek Vaughan Rake
texts.profession: Chairman, BT Group Plc
texts.text: It also reflects what we've been saying to you, the very big, big deals just don't seem to be there at the moment,  and that's not a bad thing in many ways, and I think it reflects the strength and depth, the diversity of our order  book. And actually, the other factor, and you see it in the full-year orders, was full year orders was down slightly  year on year, more than all of that is accounted for by the fact that we had less renewals this year. This is why I  said to you a couple of quarters ago, if you looked at the profile of our renewables, there was actually going to be  very few renewals this year and actually next year, for instance, basically in each of the year, only two of our top 20  contracts are actually due for renewal.

texts.speaker: Michael Derek Vaughan Rake
texts.profession: Chairman, BT Group Plc
texts.text: But also the other area, and accounting for about half of the growth, is actually in fiber, fiber in Northern Ireland.  We've got roughly nine out of 10 homes in Northern Ireland that are actually fibered. And you can see that impact  we're starting to see on the business. And I'll talk more about our public-private partnerships that we are doing in  some of these areas. So that's encouraging.

texts.speaker: Michael Derek Vaughan Rake
texts.profession: Chairman, BT Group Plc
texts.text: Fiber. Well, we're absolutely delighted to say, we now have fiber passing more than 10 million homes in the UK.  And team has been working very hard over the last quarter. We've basically done not far short of about 3 million  fiber lines in the last quarter. So it's a real step up in pace. And I think that's now over a third of the UK has fiber,  so that's encouraging and on a retail note, the other CPs can start selling to that base. We still believe there's a  potential over a five-year period to get to about 90% of homes in the UK if BDUK money is made available in the  right way, and we are doing pretty well on BDUK. We announced in March that we were a preferred bidder for  Rutland. We announced in April that we have been appointed by Lancashire, so we're very pleased with both of  these. We won't win all BDUK contracts, let me be very clear, and it just is the way of things, you'll not win all of  them. But I think we've shown in what we're doing that actually we can really deliver. Look at Northern Ireland,  nine out of 10 households, Cornwall is growing really well, and you compare and contrast that with some of the  other public/private partnerships, or even just public, and we were actually really delivering in a big way. We've  got industrial scale, so we will be bidding heavily for that and looking at the opportunities.

file: BTL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 10May2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the BT Center Auditorium and to BT's Results Presentation. Can  you please make sure that you have all mobile devices switched off. There are no fire alarms planned for today,  and in the event of an alarm sounding, would you please leave the auditorium by the two fire exits at the front of  the room.

texts.speaker: Michael Derek Vaughan Rake
texts.profession: Chairman, BT Group Plc
texts.text: On customer service, whilst our global operations have done well, we have not hit our targets in the UK. This was  partly due to the terrible weather which meant we have more faults in the network and more delays to customer  orders where we're working hard to improve this and the overall resilience of our networks.

texts.speaker: Michael Derek Vaughan Rake
texts.profession: Chairman, BT Group Plc
texts.text: One of our key aims is to be a responsible and sustainable business leader. And Ian will talk later about the three  goals that we have set to achieve this. But now, I'll hand over to Tony to talk about the financial results. Tony?

texts.speaker: Ian Paul Livingston
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: We didn't do so well this year. We actually did quite well up to June. We saw improvements and then the weather  struck and it was the worst rainfall in England ever. It was a bit better than that in Scotland and Northern Ireland.  We're worsening than ever. And it affects us and I think also it affects us for too long. We need to learn some  lessons about how we respond and do these things across our business, not just in engineering, but call centers  and the like. But we will learn these lessons.

texts.speaker: Ian Paul Livingston
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: We will give some urban capacity where it's needed, but also we think we can use it as an opportunity for areas  that can't get fiber. Clive will talk about that later. We've been trialing out a little village in Suffolk just to see what  they can get and Clive certainly will talk about his experiences down the pub who were very pleased about the Wi- Fi coverage. What that man does for our business.

texts.speaker: Ian Paul Livingston
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: But it's also important for other reasons, it's important to our customers. A very large number of the contracts  actually want to know they're dealing with sustainable and responsible partner. It's important to our Consumer  customers and small business because they want to know they're dealing with a good and ethical company.

texts.speaker: Ian Paul Livingston
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: It's also important to our people. One of the things that determines engagement, a really important thing, is  actually people want to feel we work for a company that makes a positive difference. And we think we do. And we  said what we call, our North Star Goals, three really big targets for the future. And they're things that only BT can  do. And the first of these, very obviously, is we think it would change the UK if we can connect UK with fiber.

texts.speaker: Ian Paul Livingston
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: Second goal is about carbon. Just now BT roughly saves its customers as much carbon as it uses. And we do use a  lot of carbon, if you think you'd pick up your phone, this actually always connected with big data centers. But by  virtualized data centers, the provision, for instance, of conferencing facilities and Gavin will talk about our audio  and video conferencing facilities. We save our customers a lot of carbon and we've got new things that we think we  can do that can save our customers even more.

texts.speaker: Ian Paul Livingston
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: So our aim is not to be carbon-neutral. We're sort of just about there. It's actually to be a net good, that's why we  call it net good, actually to save our customers 3 times as much carbon as we use. And that move in carbon also,  it's been very important for us, A, it gives us something, it's a great thing to sell to our customers. B, actually we're  receiving quite a lot of money because we've cut our electricity consumption ourselves because there's two bits of  that equation, use less carbon ourselves and on the other side, save our customers more. Good for the  environment, good for our business.

Another example is, of course, the extraordinary weather that we've had across the last 12 months that  meant that delivering against some of the SLAs, particularly where it required repair the next day, if you think  about the flooding and the weather and the storms, that meant for a period it was extr emely challenging.

texts.speaker: Gavin E. Patterson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: And in Openreach, we've hired and trained 1,500 new engineers and apprentices and established a fibre  academy to prepare our workforce for a fibre future. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc

texts.speaker: Gavin E. Patterson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: Secondly, it's seeking input into a consultation on the use of Long Range VDSL. This technology could play an  important role in delivering universal speeds of at least 10 megabits per second, meeting the ask of the  government's new Digital Economy Act.

texts.speaker: Gavin E. Patterson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: We have delivered our cost saving targets from the EE integration and across GS, TSO and group functions. texts.speaker: Gavin E. Patterson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: We will also create new revenue streams in complementary services. For example, leveraging our leading  security proposition, where we have built this business to £500 million in revenues from nothing five years ago,  and by utilizing Internet of Things, where we have transformed our own business to reduce costs and the  environmental impact of our operations across our building estate, fleet and supply chain, and are now starting to  see real traction from our customer base in these sectors.

texts.speaker: Gavin E. Patterson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: This and other efficiencies will deliver around £1.5 billion in cash cost reductions of which £870 million is reduced  labor costs with the balance covering a number of areas including procurement and energy efficiencies. With a  cost to deliver of these benefits is around £800 million, that delivers around a two-year payback.

texts.speaker: Simon Jonathan Lowth
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: Every unit delivered efficiencies through organizational simplification, waste reduction, process improvement, and  automation. Global Services made significant progress in its journey to a more digital unit, with standardized  products and processes requiring fewer people to service our customers.

texts.speaker: Simon Jonathan Lowth
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: Now, several of our current CapEx programs we will scale back over the next two to three years, notably the ESN  build, investment in VDSL capacity, and installation of energy-efficient cooling in our exchanges. As we had  previously explained, this will create the headroom to fund our current FTTP build rate of around £1 million per  annum, even as build costs and connection volumes rise over time. However, as Philip will explain, ramping up  our FTTP build rate beyond our current plans of around £1.1 million per annum will require increased annual  CapEx. For example, accelerating our build rate to achieve 4 million homes passed by March 2021 will require  additional CapEx of about £100 million per annum.

texts.speaker: Philip Eric Rene Jansen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: Meanwhile, we are actively engaged in discussions with Ofcom and government, and believe that our dialog is  both positive and constructive. The industry could see this through the government's Future Telecoms  Infrastructure Review and more recently in Ofcom's consultation on promoting competition and investment in fiber  networks, which proposed some helpful steps in support of investment, such as indexation of Openreach copper  product prices, support for a managed retirement of the copper network and signals around fair bet which  encourage investment in infrastructure for all players.

texts.speaker: Philip Eric Rene Jansen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BT Group Plc
texts.text: This is the base of our best converged network. Next comes FTTP. Now, I'm really encouraged by the progress  we are making with FTTP. You've already heard that the Openreach team is scaling up operations and doubled  their FTTP footprint this year to hit the target of 1.2 million premises passed, and very importantly at the lower end  of cost expectations.

texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
