texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
texts.text: Turning to costs; there has been some speculation about the direction of industry build cost to date  and going forward. Clearly, we have an exposure to commodity prices and we have seen upward  price pressure on materials like timber. However, given that we buy a significant portion of our  materials six to 12 months in advance, we already know that on our centrally procured material cost  for this year, they will be marginally lower.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
texts.text: As you can see from this chart, where we’ve analyzed the build cost for one of our standard 1,400  square-foot four-bed detached type houses, materials make up just 43% of build costs, and timber,  for example, makes up just 5%. Our biggest single cost is labor. And given the low build volumes  across the industry, we are able to control that tightly. One of the biggest material costs relate to  groundwork, foundations, drainage and driveways, and this is an area where there is further  opportunity, in particular using our scale and centralized buy.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
texts.text: We’re also very focused on how we get advantage on new costs that will be coming down the line  to things like zero carbon. I suspect this may be one of the bigger challenges that our sector faces  in the next few years. And with the recent change to building regulations effectively incorporating  Code Level 3, it is with us now. In terms of carbon elements in the code, new homes that get  planning permission after October 2010 have to be built to emit 25% less carbon on the 2006  regulations. By 2013, that becomes a 44% reduction in carbon and by 2016 we move to the zero  carbon standard, a 150% reduction.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
texts.text: We have been investing in this agenda to reduce cost and have made significant progress. We  delivered a fabric-only solution to Code Level 3, which means that there is no need for renewable  technology. And this means we could achieve Code Level 3 at less than 30% of the original cost  estimates of some £3,000 per plot.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
texts.text: The next challenge is to move to Code Level 4 already being asked for on some of our new sites.  And we believe that from trials already conducted, we will again manage to achieve this by building  fabric rather than deploying renewable energy technologies. This increases the savings  substantially and we hope we will start to see the benefits of that soon to enhance margins on  some our very new sites and better access, of course, to new land.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and a very warm welcome to our interim
texts.text: Turning to current trading, we’ve seen a good start to the New Year and sales rates are significantly  up on the first half. For the last six weeks, the average net private reservation rate per site has  been 0.57 as compared to 0.39 in the first half and 0.55 in the prior year. Some of this  improvement, I’m sure, is down to delayed purchases from last year affected by the severe weather  conditions.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 22February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So roll this forward to the 31 of December 2011, column on the right, old land now represents less than half of the  owned and conditional landbank and impaired land is down to 14%. New land is now more than half at 53% of the  total. This transition will continue as new land comes through and we work through the old land.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I'd now like to spend a little more time on our second objective, reducing debt. In the same way that growth in  margins is hardwired into our plans as new land comes through, so is the reduction in debt. If we look at the  profile of our owned land, in reality it's already changing the shape of our balance sheet. The newer sites are  smaller, as I said, on average 106 units. As we've moved away from flats to houses, the level of working capital has  reduced and the level of infrastructure investment on new sites is substantially less than on old. Well, this is  because we've avoided those sort of sites unless they're funded by our public sector partners. But of course at  present we're achieving much greater levels of deferment on new land. But this is likely to reduce as the market  becomes more competitive.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Based on investments made to date, we can already see the effect that this is having. If we look at all sites on which  we are building and split the site capital investment across them, so land and WIP net of land and the trade  creditors, it shows just how different the capital employed is on a per site basis between old and new land. This  chart shows that for the group the average site investment on a new piece of land is around 34% lower than on an  old site, reflecting the reduced capital intensity of new land.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We do not yet know the outcome of the government's proposed changes to the planning system, but we do expect  some improvement. At present, we're having a reasonably good run of approvals overall with more than 8,000  plots and 61 sites approved to date this year. And lastly, we've applied for some funding under the Get Britain  Building program, so a lot of potential which we believe will definitely have a positive impact on us in 2012.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Moving on through the cash flow, you can see land expenditure of £261 million. Then we have expenditure for  land and WIP on joint ventures of £8.5 million. And then other land movements, including land sales for a total  inflow of £3.2 million.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: As you can see, the average selling price at current pricings on owned land is £183,000, higher than the £181,200  achieved in the first half year, and this gives you an indication of future ASP trends. The owned landbank plot  cost-to-ASP ratio is 24%. On conditional land, the ASP steps up significantly to £210,000 which highlights the  ongoing change in product mix. The plot cost -o-ASP ratio on these sites is 21%.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 27February2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Moving on from the cash flow, land spend totaled £231.3 million. This includes £162 million of land creditor  payments. On guidance, I have increased our guidance on land spend by £50 million, and the total cash spend on  land in FY 2013 will be around £700 million. Of this, £360 million will be on land creditors and the balance on  other land expenditure. We generated £28.3 million cash from land sales. We continue to review land sales on a  limited number of sites. The increased investment and joint ventures reflects the acquisition of Fulham Wharf, an  ongoing WIP build.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: On the right is Centurion Fields at Adel near Leeds, is another greenfield site through our strategic land bank. It's  a prime location and with standard David Wilson product represents a low-risk project. This has been something  of whistle-stop tour, but I hope it's given you a flavor of some of the land deals worth securing.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We have a great land-buying ability in the Group. This allows us to maximize opportunities right across the  country. We are successfully securing different types of land from different sources. As a national house builder,  we target a regionally balanced land portfolio. On this slide, you can see the owned and conditionally contracted  land and the result in land supply by region. There are regional variations, but all are relatively close to our Group  to contract are also important parts of our land supply. When factored in, the overall land supply is more than five  years.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We now believe it's just clear that the combination of funding for lending and NewBuy is driving improvements.  Mortgage availability has increased and rates have reduced. To add to this, we are seeing signs of progress with  planning, as local authorities are driving to get their five-year land supply in place.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: So, for this year, we expect around half of our completions will come from new higher-margin land, increasing to  84% in FY 2015. And of course, this excludes joint ventures, almost all of which would sit in the new land  category. Impaired land with a zero gross margin will fall from expected 18% of completions this year to just 4%  by financial year 2015. And to reconfirm, our new land is achieving at least the minimum hurdle rate of a 20%  gross margin.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Moving to our second objective of zero net debt by June 2015. As the chart on the left shows, we almost halved our  net debt last year and we continue to invest in new land. The chart on the right shows the cumulative cash land  spend over the same period. At June 2013, we expect net debt to remain at a similar level to the prior year at  around £160 million, reflecting the full cost level of land spend in the second half. And by June 2015, we have set a  clear target that net debt will be zero.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: And finally, we're focused on cashing in on our low-returning assets, which are effectively a drag on returns. We're  working through the older land as quickly as possible using schemes like FirstBuy and Get Britain Building to  accelerate output where we can. In addition, where it makes sense, we'll accelerate the use of old land through  land sales and swaps. And as David has said, proceeds from land sales in the first half were around £28 million.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We will also continue to seek to defer land payments where possible to match cash outflows with revenues. The  construction phase is also fundamental. We will always minimize up-front infrastructure requirements. We've  significantly increased the use of standard product, which ensures faster, more efficient build. And we control our  work in progress through our nine stages of build, which are tested against demanding metrics for every one of  our 400 developments.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 27February2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Looking at costs in more detail, when buying land, we do not assume any future house price inflation. Our hurdle  rates are 20% gross margin and 25% ROCE. If land does not achieve these hurdles, then we do not buy it. On  infrastructure and Section 106 costs, we are seeing some minor inflation, but no issues.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: On materials, there are cost increases, especially for bricks and timber, as a result of the supply -demand  imbalance. Our material costs are locked down for the balance of full ye ar 2014. For full year 2015, we are  forecasting low single-digit increases in material costs, currently around 4% of our material costs are fixed until  June 2015.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Spencer Park, Hemel Hempstead [ph] you saw (23:53) from public land. Our North London division, part of the  Southern region, was selected by the HCA as preferred purchaser for this greenfield site. 357  units, it will be dual  branded with both Barratt and Dav id Wilson product. The purchase benefits from attractive deferred payment  terms, which helped to drive the forecast ROCE significantly ahead of our minimum hurdle risk.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: The Wedgwood Estate in Staffordshire is a prime development opportunity in a greenbelt location. This was a  competitive bidding process with the Wedgwood Group seeking a partner with similar brand credentials and a  proven track record. It will be a David Wilson development offering 209 executive homes, largely from our  standard product ranges.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Here is an update on the slide we showed in September, which shows the performance of all new land sites we  have started, completed since May 2009. In total, this covers 2,935 units on 60 sites.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Building on this, we have now made a commitment that every one of our new schemes will be delivered to the  Design Council's Building for Life 12 standard under our own program, Great Places. This is something we've  been  doing on specific sites for the last two years. And we've seen great results in terms of sales performance, and  importantly, in the acceptance of our schemes through the planning process. These are real capabilities that  deliver real advantage to our business, better homes for our customers, a lower cost to serve and better access to  land and planning.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 25February2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Baggeridge Village is a Greenbelt site on the former Baggeridge brickworks. It is well located for key employment  areas around Birmingham with good transport links. It was purchased from Wienerberger, with whom we've  worked in partnership to secure our planning over a number of years. This scheme comprises 181 units of which  30% are affordable. Launching in early March, again, we've seen considerable interest for this development. 2,000  people have registered to date, which is about five times the level we'd expect to see for site of this size.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Aldgate Place is a joint venture with British Land, located adjacent to our recently completed Altitude  development. This scheme will include 463 residential units as well as a hotel and approximately 30,000 square  feet of retail and commercial space. The site is well located on the fringe of the city and adjacent to the tube. We  will use our expertise from the Altitude development. And indeed, many of the teams will [indiscernible] (21:43)  to work on Aldgate Place, providing good continuity and efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: We continue to look out and use alternative offsite manufacturing options, for example, timber frames and  spangled panels, reducing our dependence on bricklayers. And importantly, we're continuing to invest in tr aining  programs and have recruited more than 450 graduates, apprentices, and interns over the last 18 months. So  overall, whilst we continue to see some pressures on build costs, we are actively managing all aspects. For FY  2015, we expect total for build costs to increase by around 3% to 4%.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Cost pressures seen in 2014 had moderated, and we've launched new initiatives to drive even further efficiencies  across the group. The land market remains attractive, and we continue to secure excellent sites. And our focus on  strategic land is helping secure a greater proportion of our future land requirement.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: They've already committed to releasing more public sector land over the next parliament. And they're keen to  launch their Starter Home initiative, which could help [indiscernible] (29:28) as we move through the next five- year period. We believe a labor-led government will continue to support first-time buyers and newbuild through a  Help to Buy type scheme, and will commit to releasing more public sector land, and will be encouraging local  authorities and regions to push on and drive development faster.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: They will, I am sure, implement some form of tax on more expensive properties, but this is likely to affect only a  handful of the properties we sell. And of course, both the main parties will be promoting garden cities  [indiscernible] (30:06), to effect net [indiscernible] (30:08) over the next five years. They will provid e growth  opportunities in the longer term, especially for the larger players.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: Turning to land, we've set out clear criteria and targets for the landbank. We will maintain a regionally balanced  4.5-year land supply, owned and conditional. And we'll continue to seek to defer payment terms where possible  and appropriate to drive up returns. Our focus is now on securing our longer-term land position by acquiring  strategic options. And as you can see, we have clarity on where our land will be sourced out to FY 2017, with  strategic land making up 20% of our completions. As you've heard from Steven, we're making good progress with  16% coming from strategic in the first half.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: And on land, while we have rebuilt our landbank, it is now all about security of supply till the end of this decade.  As we extend our strategic land position, we will see the benefits and margins, and we will be less buying more  expensive, shorter-term sites.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 24February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Cooper
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The deal works in two ways for us. Firstly, reducing legacy assets further and so improving returns and secondly,  freeing up cash for future reinvestment. Outside of this action, we expect these legacy land and WIP assets to  reduce by further circa £85 million in the current financial year, but the rate of reduction will then slow thereafter,  given the large and long-term nature of the remaining land assets in this category.

texts.speaker: Neil Cooper
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of the potential for future margin growth, this is a chart that I think you've seen before, but which we  have updated. As you can see, the share of expected full-year completions from old land in a combination of dark  and pale green is declining in scale.

texts.speaker: Neil Cooper
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Over the next two years, we anticipate the old land working down by around 10 points to around 4% of annual  completions, reducing the gross margin dilution impact from this category, which we estimate will make up  around 13% of completions in this current year.

texts.speaker: Neil Cooper
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Rounding up on the land bank, this chart reflects the breakdown of the land bank as of 31 December. 92% of the  owned and conditional land bank is now higher margin new land. And total ASP in the owned land bank is  £258,000, which will be a good point of reference for the ASP coming through the P&L in the near term.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to build costs, our materials, our supply chain has performed well and we are expecting minimal  inflationary pressure on build materials overall, especially with the decrease in oil prices which we are starting to  see some benefit from.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to land, our strategy is to run a fast asset turn model with a relatively short [ph] owned (18:49) land bank  driving returns and minimizing risk. We continue to target a 4.5 -year owned and conditional land bank. All of the  land in our owned land bank has outline or detail consent. And we are either on-site or getting it into production  as quickly as possible.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: We continue to see good availability of excellent land opportunities across all our operating divisions, stemming  from the increased amount of planning consents nationally.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Looking at our owned land bank in more detail, we have a very efficient land bank with 88% of our sites having  200 units or less. This gives us good outlook coverage for our land bank and mitigates location risk. Smaller sites  are often less capital intensive from an infrastructure perspective and increase the asset turn of the business.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Equally, the higher government percentages in London and Southern are result of our continued strength in  public land. The West is also high, reflecting some large [ph] HCA (21:07) sites that we've approved in the last few  years. Flatted content, including London, represents 20% of land approvals. This marks a big shift from 2008  when we delivered 49% flatted content. *

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Additionally, the 183 out of 292 local authorities in England and Wales do not currently have a five-year land  supply. So, this will help us to bring forward more strategic land. Overall, we [ph] have seen (24:43) 300 basis  point margin [ph] uplift on completions sourced (24:46) from strategic land ac quired since 2009.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: We've transformed our operational land bank and are now focused on securing our land supply out to 2020. So,  thank you. And I will hand over to David.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 22February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: This next slide shows our widening geographic spread across the capital. As you can see, we have a diverse and  balanced portfolio in terms of locations. The green represents our live developments with the pink showing our  future developments, which either have planning or currently into planning. The orange shows recently closed  sites where sales have completed. We continue to focus on building across a wider geographic spread, resulting  in much less exposure to Zones 1 and 2. For instance, the last five sites we have exchanged contracts on in  London, which represents over 3,200 plus are all located in Zone 3 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Firstly, looking at strategic land, you can see here that we have significantly increased strategic land completions  in recent years. We continue to secure strategic land. And during the first half, 24% of total completions were from  this source. Our previous target was to deliver 20% of our completions from strategically sourced land by FY  2017, and we now see 25% has been achievable in the medium term, helped by the National Planning Policy  Framework. We continue to keep this target under review. In FY 2017, we are forecasting circa 24% of total  completions will be from this source, up from 22% in the prior year. Overall, we're seeing a 300 basis point margin  uplift on completions sourced from strategic land, acquired since 2009.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: In the half, we approved almost 700 acres across 17 locations and we converted of 1,400 plus across 10  locations into our owned land bank. The housing white paper published earlier this month, makes it clear that in  future, local authorities will need to define accurate housing targets, promptly to prepare local plans and that  ensure about the new home targets are met, and this will help us bring forward more strategic sites.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: For example, we have reduced roof pitches by 5 degrees, which doesn't affect the customer experience, but  saves us around £700 per house. We've also increased the use of combi-boilers, because they have become  more efficient and which can save us up to £1,200 per house, and also reduce the running cost for our customers.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: And the third key area of focus, which offers a significant opportunity for margin improvement is layout  optimization. Our new product ranges are designed to maximize the layout efficiency, they are more regularly  shaped and further enhance our ability to improve plotting efficiency. The resulted increase in site densities are  also in line with the direction of the housing white paper, which support higher density schemes and more efficient  use of land.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Interim Chief Financial Officer, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: The government's housing policy remains very supportive and we welcome the recent publication of the housing  white paper, which will clearly allow a full debate on addressing the country's housing needs. The lending  environment remains positive, especially for new build. And finally the land market remains very attractive. So let's  now have a look at housing supply and demand.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Interim Chief Financial Officer, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: The National Planning Policy Framework has also been positive, as well as the government land release  program. The government has continued to show a favorable view on increasing land supply and planning  approvals. The housing white paper indicates that they will clearly continue to exert pressure on cancels to  properly assess housing needs, put a local plan in place and then to be held to account. There were some  measures outlined in the white paper that could put pressure on the housebuilders with regard to stalled sites.  However, given our fast build and sell model, these are unlikely to significantly affect Barratt.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Interim Chief Financial Officer, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: On the left hand chart, you can see that in the regional market, land prices have grown, at a slower rate than  house prices would imply. This still remain well below pre-downturn prices. Equally with an increased industry  focus on strategic land, the supply demand pressures on the land market have not returned in the regional market  to pre-downturn levels. The London market as we've outlined before is clearly quite different. As you can see on  the right, land prices in Greater London have moved ahead of house prices, although there has been a significant  pullback in the last 12 months. The land market remains tough in Central London and we are not seeing any  viable opportunities to buy in Zone 1 or 2. So, as Steven has mentioned, in London, we are focusing on Zone 3  and outwards as well as on large more complex schemes and also government land release.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 21February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: On strategic land, this has very much been an ongoing story since 2012, and it will continue to have a positive  impact, both on our land supply and our margin for years to come.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Now, looking at land supply. The chart on the right shows that nonurban greenfield land prices have grown at a  slightly slower rate on house prices over the last few years, and they still remain well below pre-downturn levels.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Another key driver to improving margin is product. Last year we launched our new ranges which will deliver  simplified build and improved layout coverage. To give you an update on progress, we have identified 157 sites  for our new Barratt range. We are currently building on 81 of those sites, up 59% from September. We have  completed the first 267 plots from this new range, which has been well received by customers and contractors  alike. Contractors like the [ph] Simply Designz and Footprint (00:15:04) as they are less complex, making them  easier and quicker to build.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We are seeing cost pressures on some materials, timber and insulation, for example. However, many products  and commodities remain freely available with competition in the marketplace ensuring minimal inflationary impact  moving forward.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: For example, we plotted the new product on one of our sites in Yorkshire, and we used timber frame to speed up  delivery and capitalized on pent-up demand in the area. Build times for the whole site were about six months  faster than expected using the more traditional methods of construction. We continue to look at other methods of  construction and we have successfully trialed light-gauge steel frame and large-format block.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: However, we recognize that the supply chain for these materials is not well established. And traditional methods  of building will continue to dominate the industry, certainly in the short to medium-term. We are also looking at off- site construction, including things such as pre-cast concrete garages illustrated on the photograph on the  photograph on the slide, foundation systems and pre-insulated roof panels.

file: BTRWL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 6February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Deputy Chief Executive & Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Now, looking at land supply. The chart shows the impact due to NPPF on increasing the amount of consented  land into the market. This is currently circa 362,000 annual consents. It also shows that greenfield land price  growth remains modest and prices are still well below the pre-downturn levels.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Deputy Chief Executive & Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Turning now to build costs. On materials, we've experienced modest inflationary pressure in line with our  expectations, with timber, bricks and plastic drainage product seeing higher-than-average increases. We  anticipate similar inflationary pressure to continue through FY 2020. 98% of pricing for our materials spend is  fixed until June 2019, with 40% of spend already fixed to December 2019.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Another way for us to address the skills shortage is to increase the use of modern methods of construction. We  continue to develop, trial, and implement alternative construction methods across the country. We've increased  the number of homes that we're building with timber frame, also with light gauge steel frame, and large format  block. Overall, on the half year, we've increased this by around 23%. But we also continue to trial other alternate  methods. We've outlined previously about developing pre-cast concrete garages, something that we are now  bringing into production and other house builders are using that solution as well, which will clearly alleviate some  of the pressure in terms of bricklayers with regard to the build on garages. We aim to use modern methods of  construction in 20% of the homes we build by 2020.

file: BTRWL - Q3 2014 Sales and Revenue Call Interim Management Statement 8May2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-May-14.pdf
BTRWL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 8September2010 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Sep-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: 4 Sites with an ASP below 200,000 have a plot cost of 33,000. On average, these plots would be  selling for a £150,000, so the plot cost to ASP ratio is 22%. In the same way, for sites with an ASP  above 200,000, the plot cost to ASP ratio is 26%. There is a strong correlation between increasing  ASP and increasing plot cost to ASP ratio, due to the build cost being a lower proportion of the  total.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: Let’s now look at the profile of net debt and land creditors. If we look over the last four years, you  can see that the period on net debt have reduced very significantly from the December 2007 peak  of 1.7 billion. And land creditors have been in a range of 450 to 660 million. We recognized the  trade-off between land creditors and net debt and we managed that relationship very carefully. The  gearing, based on net debt to net tangible assets is 18%.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: As you will remember, we started our cost savings program back in 2007. So, much of the big  savings were achieved in prior years. And if we look specifically at build cost or building material  and labor across our standard house types, on an average they’ve decreased by around 15%,  peaked to trough. We’ll continue our efforts to reduce costs, wherever possible through better  sourcing, product innovation and increased quality.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: Turning to land buying, our strategy has been to take advantage of attractive land opportunities, but  through a very tightly controlled process. Every land proposal must meet our minimum hurdle rate  of 20% gross margin and a 25% return-on-capital employed, based on operating margin. But more  recently, we’ve upped the margin hurdle rate to reflect our success last year. As of the 30th of June  2010, we had agreed terms on 527 million of land, equating to 96 sites, just over 13,300 plots. Of  this, 66% of the value is in the South and 77% of the products was houses. We will continue to  pursue land opportunities where the returns exceed our new hurdle rates, but we do expect the rate  of land acquisition to slow, given our success over the past year.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: Shard End Urban Village is a regeneration project in Birmingham and is a great example of how our  partnering philosophy has been used to create truly mixed use of sustainable communities. With  Barratt originally selected as a preferred developer in 2008, the downturn caused the scheme to  become unviable. Since then, the land cost has been substantially reduced. We’ve worked with  stakeholders including Birmingham City Council to secure a significant level of grant funding.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: The site will include 191 units comprising two and three-Storey buildings in a mix of flats and  houses. The benefits of the scheme include the provision of much needed regeneration along with  the enhancements of Barratt’s reputation with the largest local authority in the country, which will  hopefully lead to future public sector land initiatives and partnering arrangements.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: And lastly, Renaissance is a flagship project to regenerate the heart of Lewisham. It’s a great  example of our approach in London where we worked closely with the local authorities and public  sector agencies to secure land and investment opportunities. Here we’re working with land owners  and Lewisham Council and the site will deliver 788 new homes as well as a state-of-the-art leisure  center.

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: We’re also continuing to focus on our strategic land position, given its long-term benefits. As of the  30th of June 2010, we had around 60,000 potential units of strategic land coming from 11,000  acres. Our strategic land portfolio is also reaching a greater level of maturity and we anticipate  approximately 15,000 units being consented over the next couple of years and clearly we would be       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Bob Lawson, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning and actually, we’re delighted to see some of you who’ve been able to make it
texts.text: And last week, we announced that Plymouth Community Homes have selected Barratt for the first  phase of regeneration of North Prospect, a project which will generate around 250 new homes and  refurbish 60 existing homes. This is one of the first sites to be awarded as part of the Delivery  Partner Panel and represent a great achievement for Barratt. We look forward to similar successes  across the country in coming months.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 14September2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Sep-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: And our second half house build margin at 8% sits well against most competitors and reflects real business  performance. As a result, we return to profitability at a pre-tax level last year. As new land has come forward,  outlet numbers have grown and this has and will help drive margin recovery.  Finally, net debt is reduced to a gearing level of just 16%. Whilst land creditors have increased as a result of new  full margin land purchases, it reflects our strategy to allowing the payment for the raw material we buy with the  sales that we achieve. And our refinancing in May has improved the efficiency of our balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Kitchen/breakfast rooms with light pods, bringing the garden into the home; bedrooms with greater use of Velux  windows. In total, we have 100 sites planned delivering around 10,000 units. And we will re-plan more sites with  the new range wherever possible. Now you will be aware that there are big changes being proposed to our  planning system. This has sparked substantial public debate about whether it's right to make it easier to build new  homes.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Importantly, we are finding our quality, service and cost credentials are a strong differentiator. This is particularly  true with public sector where we've started well. As one of the few house builders on all three Delivery Partner  Panels, we now have five major sites awarded to us. As the public sector land release program progresses, we  expect to do well going forward with this initiative.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We have 4.3 years supply of owned and unconditional land based on FY '11 volumes. We have 1.1 year supply of  conditional contracts. On guidance, we anticipate reducing the overall land bank over the next couple of years to  around four years supply and the conditional land bank will be around one year. This will be based on prior year  completion volumes.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: The portfolio is maturing. In FY '11, we gained consent for just over 900 plots on four sites. In the next few years,  we are targeting planning consents for around 15,000 plots. However, as you're aware, the planning environment  is at present a little uncertain, particularly on large strategic proposals. In addition, the delivery from strategic  land sales or a substantial investment in a large site. We will continue to balance the relative benefits of  operational and strategic land.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 12September2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Sep-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: In terms of land delivery, over the next few years, we'll continue to make good progress. In this financial year, we  expect delivery from newer higher margin land to increase to just over 50% and completions from impaired land  with impaired land less than 5%. And where the market opportunity exists, we will continue to look at ways to  speed up this transition through asset sales or by increasing sales rates on older sites.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Though water is always a lot of focus on the length of land banks, a more important measure is the number of  outlets as this is what actually drives completions and returns. With an average operational site size of around 100  units, this enables us to drive a much higher output from a shorter operational land bank than a number of our  competitors.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: And in terms of our target funding structure in today's environment, our aim is to deliver zero year-end net debt  by FY 2015 or sooner, if market conditions allow. So the owned land bank and long-term work in progress will be  funded by our shareholders and land vendors in the form of land creditors and our working capital requirements  by our banking partners. In terms of land creditors, currently they equate to around 35% of our owned land bank.  As the land market becomes more competitive, we expect this to reduce to around 25%.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Looking ahead, we'd expect to see a further shift. Our new land, excluding London, has an average 15% social  content. Looking at the green and brown segments, these are one, two and three-bedroom houses, the first and  second move up categories. Combined, these have increased from 29% to 44%.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We are constantly looking to refine our site to improve profitability and have re-planned well over 50 sites in the  year. We use the size of group to procure materials as efficiently as possible. Today, around 85% of materials are  sold centrally under Group supply arrangements, which benefit from highly competitive commercial terms. We've  also significantly reduced the cost of building homes to Code Levels 3 and 4, down more than 50% from our  original assumptions on which much of the land was bought and we'll continue to drive lower-carbon solutions  more effectively in the future.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: For example, the review of site security will help save about £3 million. Using a newly developed alternative  foundation system will save £1.2 million, and introducing a Group procurement agreement for radiator valves will  save around £1.1 million. Every site now goes through a formal review process consisting of a 400-point checklist  that challenges every aspect of cost and design. In addition, we expect to deliver approximately £45 million  savings over the next four to five years. The savings are in our numbers, which David will go through shortly.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Average gross margin on impaired land has remained at zero, and average selling price at £163,000. Non- impaired old plots now stands at 16,476, both of the green segments on the chart, down from 22,690 last year. The  average margin on this non-impaired old land is 9%. New land and the owned land bank now stands at 20,755  plots and 47% of the owned land bank, up from 31% a year ago.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Moving on to land creditors, land creditors at June was £726 million. On the slide, I've cut the land creditor  balance by various categories to give you some more color. The bar on the right shows that around one-third of  our land creditors are with government bodies. 87% are land creditors in respect of new land acquired since 2009.  And then the column on the right splits out the land creditor on land overdues and plot-by-plot payment deals.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 11September2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Sep-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: The next segments down cover shared equity and NewBuy. In the second half of FY  2013, the dark purple band  shows the rapid take-up of Help to Buy, which made up 7 % of total completions. The transition to Help to Buy has  been quick and take-up strong. It is a very attractive product for our customers and incurs no cost to the  business.  Investor completions in the green segment picked up significantly in the year, from 9% in the first half to 15% in  the second half. This, in part, reflects the greater second half weighting of our London region, but also the increase  in buy-to-let lending.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Looking at the land market, our hurdle rates remain at 20% gross margin and 25% return on capital employed.  And all new land meets these requirements as a minimum without assuming any future house price inflation. In  Central London we see a strong demand for less complex sites. Land price increases in Central London had been  site-specific driven by competition and house price inflation in that area. Barratt London's experience and  capability in delivering complex and technically challenging sites has become an increasingly important  competitive advantage. This has helped us to secure some great land opportunities in the capital. Our JV partners  have also been positive for us in starting new developments.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Turning to public land, the release of public land is a key element of the government's strategy for driving the  economic growth and addressing the housing shortage. It's calculated that 40% of housing land is in public  ownership. The government's plan is to release land for 100,000 new homes by 2015. It is also targeting at least  £5 billion of asset sales from land and property between 2015 and 2020. Our specialist public land team supports  our divisions in bidding for these opportunities. These bids are often complex, and are won on many criteria  including design and environmental credentials, not just on price alone. Barratt is a member of all four HCA  Delivery Partner Panels as well as the GLA Panel.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Moving down to infrastructure costs, these are stable. We are achieving some reductions on the Section 106 costs  through renegotiation, but this is modest.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 10September2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Sep-14.pdf

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: Completions by land type in the year were in line with our expectations. Completions from new land were 65% of  the total for the full year and 68% in the second half. As you'll see from Mark's presentation, the proportion of  completions from new land will step up again significantly in FY  2015.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Today, I want to look at the strengthened performance across our six regions, pricing trends and the positive  momentum we've seen during the year, our cost control and supply chain management and the land market, and  finally, how we are securing our future land supply, and in particular, our increased emphasis on strategic land.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Looking forward, brick and block supply issues are easing with additional UK capacity now installed. And we don't  expect to import bricks going forward. In addition, we have increased the use of alternative building methods such  as timber frame.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: We approved almost 21,500 plots, equating to £1.2 billion. Our land buying targets remained the same, a 4.5 -year  land supply excluding JVs, regionally balanced land portfolio, to defer payments where appropriate and minimum  hurdle rates for gross margin and ROCE. In the short-term, we are looking to acquire land well above our  minimum hurdle rates, reflecting the success of our land buying in FY  2014.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Strategic land is becoming a more important land source for the group, not only does our acquisition rate stepped  up significantly over the past year, the conversion of strategic land from our existing portfolio to our owned  landbank has also significantly increased. NPPF places a presumption in favor of sustainable development. This  has helped our landbank team secure and promote an increasing number of new sustainable sites  through  Planning Commission or Local Plan allocation.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: On the right, the chart details the land status of our strategic plots. 65% of our plots are either on  allocated sites or  in local authorities that need additional allocations to meet their five-year land supply targets. Our strategy is to  focus on the acquisition of sites with shorter delivery time scales and in high quality locations.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Let me now highlight a few of the excellent land opportunities we've secured over the past year. Catford Green was  owned by the GLA and brought to the market through their developer, Partner Panel. The site forms part of the  wider regeneration of the Catford Town Centre and will provide nearly 600 new homes including 170 affordable.  It has excellent transport links, and it's just 11 minutes into London Bridge.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Watling Street, Milton Keynes is a greenfield site we secured through off-market discussions with the vendors [ph]  J.J. Gallagher (26:10). It's a good example of how our strong established relationships with key land owners can  help secure first-class land opportunities. It's a large site in a prime location within Milton Keynes which has  excellent commuter links into London and the midlands. It will be released in phases and dual-branded,  maximizing the sales opportunity.

texts.speaker: Mark Sydney Clare
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our focus over the last 12 months has been on building our longer-term land position. And as you can see, we have  clarity on where our land will be sourced out to FY 2017 with strategic land making up at least 20% of our land  supply. This ensures that we are managing the cost of land effectively with our reliance on short-term operational  land decreasing. The focus now is on securing our land out further to 2020 and I expect strategic to play an even  bigger role going forward.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 9September2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Sep-15.pdf

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to the cash flow. As ever, lots of numbers, and I will highlight a few. Our net cash investment in land  increased to £269.8 million. That reflects the step-up in land payments as the business grows, and we maintained  the land bank debt. On guidance, we expect the total cash spend on land for FY 2016 to be around £1 billion. Of  that, around £500 million will relate to land creditors at June 2015 and the balance on other land expenditure.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: To give you a little more detail on the rundown of the old land, this chart shows the old land plots grouped by site  size. You can see the significant reduction in plots achieved this year, down by around 3,500 to 7,000.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: For example, we used timber frames in almost 1,000 homes, and we expect this to increase to around 1,300 in FY  2016. We're also using increasingly the use of room-in-the-roof solutions, a pre-assembled roof with around 1,200  units expected to use it in FY 2016. So after seeing some pressures on the build costs, the areas of greatest  pressure remain a relatively small percentage of our total cost base. In FY 2015, we saw total build cost increases  limited to 3.5% and we are expecting a similar increase in the current year.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to public sector land. Our skill in developing public sector land is a key strength to the group. With the  government committed to releasing land for development, it is an excellent land source, especially in the more  competitive South East. In the year, 25% of our completions were from publicly sourced land. We expect this  percentage to reduce slightly as we increase the delivery from strategic land.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: This is a David Wilson Homes development in a fantastic location, close to Edinburgh City Centre. The land was  acquired from the publicly-owned Scottish Water. It was a competitive process and our success in securing the  scheme reflected our track record in Edinburgh. It's an excellent site that again sold well, with margins and  returns significantly ahead of hurdle rates. Reflecting the strength of our relationship with Scottish Water, and the  quality of this development, we secured the next Scottish Water site also in Edinburgh.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our land bank is in good shape. Our focus is now in securing our longer-term land supply out to 2020 and  beyond. As Steven said, we aim to increase the participation of higher-margin strategic land while still delivering a  significant proportion of public land.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our target of a minimum gross margin of 20% is in line with our land acquisition hurdle rate. That's a level that I  not only see as being achievable but also sustainable given market conditions. We will see some constraints on  margin expansion, overage agreements for example, where we'll share some of the upside with landowners. And  build cost inflation will also be a drag on margin, but we've demonstrated, and again Steven has outlined this  morning, that we feel we do have good controls around build cost inflation.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to return on capital employed. I'm very pleased with the group's progress on ROCE. We've increased  this by 440 basis points to 23.9%. Our target of at least 25% is again in line with our minimum land acquisition  hurdle rates. As I highlighted earlier, our remaining legacy assets on the balance sheet stand at just over £650  million. At nearly 18% of net assets, they remain a significant drag on our ROCE performance. As we see these  assets run off and profitability continue to improve, we are very confident of achieving our ROCE target and  driving it beyond the 25% level.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 7September2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Sep-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Cooper
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Moving to focus on the land bank. This chart reflects the breakdown of the land bank as of 30th of June with 93%  of the owned and conditional land bank now new high margin land. During the year, 86% of our completions were  from this new land with 14% from old land. Over the next two years, we anticipate old land working down to below  5% of annual completions which will obviously reduce the gross margin dilution impact from this category of  completions. The total average ASP in the owned land bank is £261,000 which is a good reference point for the  ASP coming through the P&L in the near-term.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Group Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Turning to strategic land, during the year, 22% of our total completions came from strategically sourced land, up  from 17% in the prior year. Our previous target was to deliver 20% of completions from strategically sourced land  by FY 2017, and we now see 25% as being achievable in the medium-term, which has been helped by the NPPF.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: So if we look at what we are focused on now, we are identifying opportunities for the business in areas such as  product design and specification. To support this, we have recently launched a new Barratt housing range, which  will simplify the build process and reduce the build costs whilst continuing to offer the great design of a Barratt  home. We believe that we can increase our operating margin and we have a number of focused initiatives to drive  this, varying from upgrading our commercial systems to reducing waste on site.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 6September2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Sep-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: At the half-year results, I explained how changes to roof pitches could save £700 per house and how expanding  the use of combi-boilers could save up to £1,200 per house while reducing running cost for our customers. As  well as reduced build costs, these new ranges have more efficient floor plans which support plotting optimization.  The simplified designs reduced build complexity and help address trade skill shortages. Their more regular  footprint is also better suited to modern methods of construction.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We're also busy working on many other initiatives to improve our margin across the business. Improving densities  and coverage on both our existing and new developments remains a major opportunity to deliver additional profit.  To complement our new product ranges, we have updated and rolled out comprehensive plotting guides to our  divisions. These guides are designed to help maintain our class-leading street scenes and also support greater  land utilization. They give good examples of high quality compliance schemes as well as standard grid solutions  to optimize product use and drive returns. For example, improving coverage by circa 1,000 square feet per acre  can add 3% to our margin.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: We have held six regional workshops with almost 400 employees and design consultants attending these briefing  sessions. But one thing I do want to emphasize is there is no compromise to the quality of service or build  standards. And this is evidenced once again by the group being awarded the maximum HBF 5 Star rating for  customer satisfaction for the eighth year running, meaning more than 90% of our buyers would recommend us to  a friend. In addition, 74 of our sites received NHBC Quality Awards, more than any other housebuilder for the 13th  year in a row, making us the clear industry leader in terms of site management and build quality.

texts.speaker: Jessica White
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: At 30th of June, we had a four-and-a-half-year's supply of owned and controlled land in line with our operating  framework. The graph on the left-hand side demonstrates the progress we have made in terms of reducing the  cost of our land in the land bank over the last five years to 18% of selling price. This was a reduction of 1.7  percentage points in the year.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Let's just have a look and remind ourselves in terms of our operating framework. Again, we've provided this  operation framework over a number of years. In line with the last few years, we continue to have minimum land  acquisition hurdles of 20% gross margin and 25% return on capital employed. As Steven's outlined, we're seeing  some really fantastic opportunities in the land market. We're being able to buy land above our minimum hurdle  rates. We will keep these hurdles under review and we will increase them formally if we can buy land at higher  rates for a sustainable period of time.

file: BTRWL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 5September2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Sep-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Now, looking at land supply. Land prices remain broadly flat, and we continue to see excellent high-quality  opportunities across the country. The chart on the right shows the effect of the NPPF on increasing the amount of  consented units in the land market and the moderating effect of that on land prices. Despite strong competition for  land, inflation has been relatively minimal over the last 10 years. Revisions to the NPPF were published in July  and reinforced the government's commitment to see more land coming through the planning process. We see a  very good future supply of consented land available for purchase.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: All right, now, turning to build costs. In FY 2018, we saw build cost inflation of circa 3% in line with our guidance.  Looking to 2019, on materials, we are expecting some modest inflationary pressure. We continue to see cost  pressures on some specific materials such as timber and plastic drainage products. 96% of our material pricing is  fixed to December 2018 with 75% fixed until June 2019. The remainder are not due for renegotiation until later in  the year.

texts.speaker: Steven J. Boyes
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Deputy Chief Executive, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Now, in previous presentations, I've given you more detail on our supply chain and our customer first approach.  Today, I just wanted to touch on affordable housing, a critical area of the business that represents almost one-fifth  of our volumes. Affordable housing content is set by the local planning authority when granting planning consent.  We, therefore, have a wide range of affordable content across the business and sites can range from 0% up to  50% content depending on local needs.

texts.speaker: Jessica Elizabeth White
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: Turning to the balance sheet. Our gross land bank increased by £68 million to £3 billion. Land creditors were  33.6% of the owned land bank, a reduction of 310 basis points in the year and within our operating framework of  30% to 35%. We expect land creditors in FY 2019 to be 30% to 35% of the owned land bank. In the medium term,  we will reduce our usage of land creditors to 25% to 30% for the owned land bank to continue to dig here and  further strengthen our balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Jessica Elizabeth White
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: As we've said previously, during FY 2018, we've consistently been purchasing land in excess of our old hurdle  rate. The land approved at these higher margins will come  through to the profit and loss account as these sites are developed over the next few years.

texts.speaker: David Fraser Thomas
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Director, Barratt Developments Plc
texts.text: So, moving on to the mortgage environment and the two charts, which I have shown you before. But I do believe  that they are very important indicators. texts.text: Page 7, a shot now on the large Qatargas contract, which we are very pleased to have been awarded. Qatargas  is the world's largest LNG producer. We are now their primary supplier for Inspection, NDT and Asset  Management services for all their assets in Qatar. This contract illustrates the success of our [ph] OpEx  Strategic Growth Initiative (00:04:00). It has been awarded as a result of the newly developed Integrated Solution  Approach. The aim is to replicate this across Bureau Veritas globally.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: As an illustration on Page 9 of how BIM is critical for B&I project management. We are currently working on the  Shanghai Planetarium where we provide technical and management services for the whole lifecycle of the asset.  The benefits are numerous, quicker, safer and cheaper for the customer. For instance, it enables a 70% reduction  in design changes to be resolved by the BIM technology.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: A word now on the upcoming [indiscernible] (00:17:33) 2020 regulation, which will benefit a number of our  businesses from 2019. Ship owners can meet the new standards using low-sulphur compliance [ph] fuel oil  (00:17:47). This will support our Oil & Petrochemicals business. An increasing number of ships are also using gas  as the fuel, which will support the LNG segment for New Construction where we have a leading position. Ships  may also meet the [indiscernible] (00:18:05) emission requirements with the [indiscernible] (00:18:08).

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Turning to Industry, page 27. The business confirmed it's positive growth of 2.2% organically with 2.8% in Q2 as a  result of our successful diversification. Oil & Gas CapEx-related activities, 15% of divisional revenue, are now  showing easing rates of decline, being down to 12% in Q2 after minus 17% in Q1.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Oil & Gas OpEx was slightly up, with solid volume increase largely offsetting price pressure. We achieved a 20%  organic growth in Power & Utilities OpEx with the ramp-up of large contract wins in Latam. This segment is now  as big as the Oil & Gas CapEx business, accounting for 14% of divisional revenue. The margin was stable year- on-year.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: We expect the business to return to slightly positive organic revenue growth. Overall, our strategy of  diversification will continue to pay off. For the year, we expect to see Oil & Gas CapEx markets bottoming out.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Q2 benefited strongly from most customers anticipating audits ahead of the revised standard transition decline. At  the end of June, 96% of Bureau Veritas' clients were in the transition process or already complied with the new  QHSE Standards.

texts.text: Thank you, Sami. Very, very clear presentation. Thank you. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I'm going to start with what we call the oil and petrochemicals product testing, 9% of 2014 group revenue is  generated by oil and petrochemical product testing. texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The story is a little bit different for oil sands and oil sands represents today less than 1% of group revenue. In this  context, the negative impact could reach 3% of product-related revenue.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second, 8% of the group revenue is related to CapEx projects involving all types of projects onshore, offshore,  LNG of the world with diversified customers. If oil price remains low, some projects could be delayed mainly in  Latin America and in North America.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Activities related to shale gas in North America are quite limited, last year around €20 million. The negative  impact in this case could reach 15% of CapEx -related revenue.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last but not least, 6% of the group revenue relates to existing operations and processes. We anticipate some price  pressure that could be compensated by more volume. An improvement in GDP growth  could benefit to other group activities, certainly Consumer Products and manufacturing investment. texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Looking at the top line figures, which Sami will take us through in detail, we see that Bureau Veritas posted a solid  revenue growth of 11.1%, up 5.6% at constant exchange rate. texts.text: Looking now at selected growth initiative within the 2020 strategic plan.
