texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We particularly focused geographically on Southeast Asia, Middle East, Europe and business-wise on Oil & Gas  OpEx and Power OpEx. We already recorded some key wins, significant ones. ConocoPhillips, OMV, EDF, Saudi  Aramco for an overall contract value of about €60 million over 2 to 3 years, thanks to the launch of this new  strategy.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second one is Agri-Food. What did we do in 2015 regarding this initiative? Agri-Food is an excellent example  of the shift from a geographical to a metrics organization. By recruiting a market leader and reinforcing the team,  we defined a global offer to target this market, which has already resulted in new contracts with blue -chip clients.  For example, we won a contract, which is a contract for sustainable fishing for the Peruvian Ministry of  Production; we have certification with top-five food processing corporations; and Harvest audits in Latin America  with Monsanto.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In our 2020 strategy, there are four levers and I will take you through three of them. The first one, account  management. We have decided to invest massively to develop marketing and sales at BV. €8 million organic  increase in spending in 2015 to provide all TIC services, not just food TIC services; a large international contract  signed with Airbus for energy efficient audits, by the way, we have also some other opportunities to sell TIC  services to this client; signature of a frame agreement with large corporations like Shell or Plastic Omnium.

texts.speaker: Sami Badarani
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Two activities on the other side of the spectrum at the bottom of the page have negative organic growth. Indust ry,  with the impact of the Oil & Gas price drop, with the ending and slowing down of the CapEx projects; and GSIT,  with the significant impact of the geopolitical environment in the Middle East, with a double -digit drop in the  Iraqi contracts.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil & Petrochemicals had a very good year attributed to the accelerated trade. Our clients took advantage of the  low price of oil to refine greater volumes. Agri delivered double-digit growth. Metals & Minerals upstream market  suffered again because of the commodities' price decrease, iron ore down 40% and copper down 25%. However,  we were very proactive in restructuring and protecting the margin in the commodities business.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The outlook for 2016 now. So for this year, we expect further reduction in upstream Metals & Minerals. Oil &  Petrochemicals trade activities growth will rely more on new services such as marine fuel services or oil condition  monitoring, outsourced testing and measurement services.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moving now to Industry. We recorded a double-digit growth in power, and other sectors such as manufacturing  and transport are also performing well. No surprise, Oil & Gas had a negative impact on our business in Industry.  Again, we succeeded in rapidly restructuring the business to protect the margin.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Oil & Gas, we will focus our efforts and energy on downstream refining. We will continue to face market  pressure in the Oil & Gas industry. At the price of oil today, no doubt about it.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In conclusion, compared to 12 months or 18 months ago, we are now in a new context. Many companies are facing  a new paradigm that will I think process for some time now. With commodity's prices lower than in the past and  unstable geopolitical situations in many countries. The challenge for companies today is to be extremely agile to  the environment. At BV, this is exactly what we are doing. Adapting our structure to the situation, diversifying our  exposure to be more resilient with the execution of the 2020 strategic plan, moving towards a more market centric  organization, leveraging key account programs and the digital approach.

file: BVI - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Nicolas Alain Marie Tissot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Slide 11 shows that growth initiatives delivered €80 million contribution offsetting the negative impact from  activities in the down-cycle mainly coming from the oil and gas CapEx activities. Growth initiatives contributed to  the performance of the Commodities, Certification, Construction, IVS, and Consumer Products businesses, which  Didier will specifically comment on during the business review.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: For 2017, the market environment will remain challenging for categories such as bulk carriers and container  ships, partly offset by more positive activity in passenger ships. The in-service ships segment is expected to prove  resilient with the exception of the offshore market which is more sensitive to fluctuation in oil prices. New  regulations will be supportive of the in-service Marine revenue growth.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Moving to Industry. Industry business was down 9.7% on an organic basis in 2016. Oil and gas CapEx, which is a  force of our Industry business, declined by 20%. We were able to offset part of this growing in OpEx-related  activities. Excluding oil and gas, the situation is a mixed picture due to the negative impact of nuclear CapEx  contract ending in Argentina. Margins are holding at 13.1%. Cost reductions contributed to offset the price  pressure from oil and gas. On BV 2020, there are a number of OpEx wins that demonstrate the effectiveness of  our strategic initiatives. In 2016, OpEx oil and gas and power and utilities were up mid to high-single digits.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Looking at the next slide. This slide is basically the rationale of our 2017 outlook. Oil and gas CapEx market is not  going to rebound in 2017 due to the current oil price. We will bottom out in this activity in H2 2017. In this context,  we decided to grow our OpEx activities. As demonstrated on the right-hand side of the slide, our strategy is  working as OpEx is now bigger than CapEx.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Factoring in recent market dynamics, oil and gas, and Marine down-cycle essentially, the contribution on the  potential of each of the eight growth initiatives unveiled as part of the 2020 ambition, Bureau Veritas has decided  to focus its development efforts on five initiatives going forward: Building & Infrastructure; OpEx in specific  sectors, oil and gas, power and utilities. And chemicals; Agri-Food; Automotive; and Smartworld. Representing  around 30% of group revenue, these five initiatives should generate incremental revenue from 2015 to 2020.  They will bring the growth and the diversification the group is seeking.

file: BVI - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 1March2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: In 2018, we have started the year adding around €75 million of annualized revenue with two acquisitions in  support of our OpEx and B&I growth initiatives. Lubrication Management, specialized in oil conditioning  monitoring, EMG which we closed this week. EMG brings to Bureau Veritas new expertise in the U.S. with a  sizeable platform in construction and technical assessment and project management assistance. This enhances  our growth profile and resiliency by increasing our OpEx exposure as 90% of EMG is OpEx-related services.

texts.speaker: Nicolas Alain Marie Tissot
texts.profession: Finance, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Less than a-third of the portfolio has a minus 45 bps impact on group margin with minus 20 bps coming from  Marine & Offshore due to lower volume of activity, notably for New Construction and Offshore Services, minus 25  bps resulting from price pressure in Oil & Gas and change of mix in Industry. Operating margin by business will  be further covered in the business review.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Looking further at the Marine & Offshore market, we can observe some positive trends in new construction in  particular dry bulk and containers as well as LNG carriers. In addition, the world fleet continues to grow at a  steady 2% thanks to the international trade growth, thus supporting our in-service activity.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: The Metals & Minerals segment confirmed its recovery, up 5.7% in organic growth supported by both trade across  all geographies. And upstream activities, excluding coal, we saw significant uptick in Q4.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: For 2018, thanks to the ramp-up of several contract wins, the situation should stabilize. Margins increased 90  basis points as a result of the mix, LEAN efforts, and the operating leverage. We expect the Agri-Food &  Commodities business to improve its course compared to 2017, fueled by a recovery in metals and minerals  markets, healthy Agri-Food businesses, and stabilizing Government Services.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Turning to Industry. Organic growth was slightly down by 0.8% for the year and nearly stable in the last quarter at  minus 0.2%. Oil & Gas CapEx-related activities remained under pressure with the end of large contracts. It has  been partly compensated by growth in Oil & Gas OpEx and solid performance in other end markets such as  Power & Utilities and Automotive. Growth was strong in Africa and the Middle East; robust in Latin America,  primarily led by Brazil due to geographic and sector diversification. Margins declined 100 basis points due to two  factors: the negative mix effect of Oil & Gas CapEx decline and the push towards OpEx; and [ph] second  00:23:42, some persistent price pressure in Oil &Gas OpEx activities.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: In line with BV 2020, we continue to gain solid traction in OpEx-related services, already delivering 18% organic  growth in Power & Utilities. We expect the business to return to slightly positive organic revenue growth overall.  Our strategy of diversification will continue to pay off given our initiatives in Power & Utilities and Automotive.  Throughout the year, we expect to see Oil & Gas CapEx markets bottoming out with declining H1 and stabilizing  in H2.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Further on Industry, we can clearly see that our strategy of diversification to OpEx is paying off. Over a two-year  period, we have increased our OpEx exposure in Oil & Gas and Power & Utilities by 10 points to 57% of our  revenue. In terms of Oil & Gas CapEx, we will bottom out of this activity in 2018 before returning to growth in 2019  if the improving trend is confirmed.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Our Chinese business now represent 17% of the B&I division. It is growing at double-digit, thanks to the energy  and infrastructure project management sectors. France grew at the low-single digit due to a slow start but Q4  showed a nice uptick. CapEx work is on an upward trend. We saw good level of sales included the Grand Paris  project. Margin slightly improved on mix and volume.

file: BVI - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 28February2019 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Lastly, 22% of our revenue relies on our clients' CapEx decisions, a combination of new buildings and  infrastructures, new energy projects, notably in Oil & gas and new ships. All these markets are today recovering. I  will come back with comments on each of our businesses, but first, François will walk us through the excellent  financial performance. François?

texts.speaker: François Chabas
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Focusing on the last quarter, Q4, we delivered 4.4% organic growth. Best performers where Marine & Offshore,  up 6.9%, mainly driven by new construction activity in China. Industry, up 6.2%, benefiting from a successful  OpEx diversification, together with improving Oil & Gas CapEx activities. As anticipated, Certification declined by  3.5% organically. It reflects the end of the three-year standards revision period.

texts.speaker: François Chabas
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: In 2019, we have already started the year adding around €30 million of annualized revenue with two  announcement in support of Agri-Food and B&I growth initiatives. First, BVAQ in Singapore, a joint venture  created with AsureQuality, a New Zealand company, to provide food testing services; and second, Capital  Energy, a company providing consulting and support services for energy efficiency project in France.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Looking at 2019 perspectives, in the shipping market which is recovering, we expect Marine & Offshore full year  organic growth to be positive. This reflects a recovery in new construction, notably led by China as shown on the  slide. Our order book is very diversified by type of ships with bulk, cargo, tankers, passengers, and cruise ships.  LNG vessels, resilient in service activity, including the offshore-related activities. Profitability-wise, we expect  margins to improve.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Agri-Food, Agri-Food grew by 4.4% organically, thanks to a strong Food performance. The agri segment grew  only slightly, affecting notably very poor weather conditions and other external factors. Growth resumed in Q4,  supported by contract wins and new services in precision farming.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Oil & Petrochemicals is up by 1.9% organically, reflecting robust performance in Europe and low in North  America. In the U.S., the price pressure inflation on cargo inspection business is offset by strong performance for  our strategic initiatives, marine fuels and oil condition monitoring.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Turning to Industry, the business confirmed its recovery up 3.5% organically, with acceleration in Q4 at 6.2%. This  results from our successful OpEx diversification, together with improving Oil & Gas market conditions.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Oil & Gas CapEx-related activities represent 15% of divisional revenue. It improved during the year with H2 up  3.6% after minus 15% in the first half. Oil & Gas OpEx was up mid-single-digit, with strong volume increases,  partly offset by continuing price pressure. We achieved 17% organic growth in Power & Utilities OpEx with the  ramp up of several contracts in Latin America.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: Further on Industry and specifically on Oil & Gas. Two points to highlight. The first one, our OpEx business  represents 60% of our revenue as a result of the success of our strategic OpEx growth initiative. Therefore, Oil &  Gas CapEx is now less than 4% of group revenue compared to 10% at the peak in 2015.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: We achieved double-digit growth for Supply Chain, Energy Management, Forestry, Food Management System  and Organic Certification. Margin was strong, improving by 65 basis points to 17.7%. This reflects a strong  organic increase, which mostly offsets the significant negative forex impact.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: The outlook for 2019, Certification business is expected to deliver a slightly negative organic revenue growth, with  the impact from the QHSE and Transportation transition which ended in September 2018 and of course, creates  challenging comparable for the first nine months of the year. Solid growth elsewhere, primarily driven by Food  schemes, Sustainability, Training and Customized audits. Profitability-wise, we will focus on margin protection.

texts.speaker: Didier Michaud-Daniel
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bureau Veritas SA
texts.text: And third, concerning Environment, we are getting a reduction in CO2 emissions by 10% per full-time equivalent  employee.

file: BVS - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 18August2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: And if we look at product, we've been talking consistently about our main product being a two-storey family home.  If you look at the right-hand column here, this reflects the mix acquired over the last period from the 1st of  January 2012 and it's very typical of what we've been doing for the last five years. So 76% of the product we  bought in terms of land coming through the model is two-storey traditional; 20% three-storey which includes our  five and six-bedroom room room-in-the-roof products, so essentially acting like large family housing; and only 4%  in the apartment market. This is the mix you should expect to come through our business. And it's very suited to  the greenfield traditional housing sites we've been acquiring.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: And we are involved in that process from an early stage. So we're not talking about some investment committee  that sits on a weekly or a monthly basis to assess a whole range of opportunities. This is about being in with the  teams managing land opportunities through casting to one side those that we feel are not appropriate and actually  moving forward with those that we think are. And we believe over time, it gives us the ability to make better land  decisions.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: And this is a really important piece of data. So we thought we'll try and give you a little bit of a picture of what this  may look like over the next few years. So some hard projections to start with. For the end of 2014, we currently  believe we'll have around 120 owned consented sites in our land bank. That will also have 100 of those sites will be  opened for business at that point, around 100 outlets. And if we move forward acquiring 40 sites thereabout for  the next three years with the level of closure that we would expect over that timeframe, we can see land bank  growing to around 140 sites to 160 sites.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: Now, the way you should probably model this, is that we put 40 sites into the machine. Having started at 120 sites,  we are probably going to close on average about 30 sites. So with the full-year land bank model, so we're staring at  120 sites, we will be exiting on about 30 sites closing them down and bringing 40 new sites into land bank. So net  10 new sites per annum is a very simple way of looking at this model.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: And I would suggest there are three things that you should take onboard at this stage about Bovis Homes. First is  we recognize there's a cycle. It's not if the next housing downturn happens, it's when the next housing downturn  happens. Inevitably, if you're in a cycle, you will see a period of time when things are not quite as good, and we're  planning for that. So we're not putting our head in the sand and saying that won't happen. Secondly, we are  continually monitoring through the land acquisition process, what is happening in a land market, and we're trying  to assess the sustainability of the land market. And at that point in time when we feel it's not sustainable we,  inevitably, will throttle back our ambitions.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: And thirdly, we've done this before. If anything is right about Bovis Homes in the past, it was its decision to pull  back from the consented land market at a point where it became unsustainably expensive and we can do that  again. So if we look at the chart on this slide, there's 10 years' worth of data here. And you can see from the orange  bars and the chart which represent consented land spot market purchases that as the land became unsustainably  expensive we were pulling back from the market. As we went through the downturn, we were lowly committed in  terms of land acquisitions. As we came in to the flat period, that stagnant period within the cycle, we were big on  consented land. The orange bar is jumping up to a significantly higher level.

texts.speaker: Jonathan Hill
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: The record half year of land investment in the first half of 2014 has resulted in the gross land bank, increasing to  £846 million. And the increase in land creditors has resulted in the land asset net of creditors, only increasing by  £35 million since the start of the year. Land creditors represented just over 20% of the gross land bank which we  view as a reasonable level going forward.

texts.speaker: Jonathan Hill
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Bovis Homes Group Plc
texts.text: The proportion of Southern plots in the consented land bank has increased 75%. And as David said earlier, 49% of  the land bank has been sourced through conversion from the strategic land bank. And as David outlined earlier,  we are very focused on delivering that higher level of strategic land investment as well as the strategic land  conversion.

texts.text: We are seeing more outlets come through as David mentioned, and so the sales and marketing are set up across  the coast with those. texts.speaker: Earl Sibley
texts.profession: Group Finance Director
texts.text: Again, looking forward, in terms of our expectation of net debt at the end of the year, we expect that to be  somewhere between 0 and £50 million. texts.speaker: Earl Sibley
texts.profession: Group Finance Director
texts.text: So our balance sheet has picture of our net assets that have now increased to £895 million or £6.66 per share, and  the topline shows the continued investment in land, so our gross land bank now at £966 million. Our land  creditors have moved up and now represent 27% of our gross land bank. We think that is a sustainable level going  forward. Our work in progress has increased with the greater number of sites and also to feed that second-half  weighting in terms of volume.

texts.speaker: Earl Sibley
texts.profession: Group Finance Director
texts.text: The ASP has also improved in the land bank, so up 4%, which reflects higher value plots coming into the land  bank, lower value being traded out, as well as market improvements in the period. And as I mentioned, the 2015  additions are expected to deliver a return on capital of 29%.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our focus continues to be on the south of England and into traditional semi-rural and rural locations, and that is  typically a greenfield site. And we still have the view that the investment we're making in land today over time will  allow the business to progress towards its medium-term target of 5,000 to 6,000 houses per annum. So, the  growth strategy is still here. It will drive shareholder returns, but it is flexible.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then very positively on the left-hand side, the planning permissions are coming out of the system now, above  200,000 per annum in an environment where we're building about 130,000 houses. texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, coming back to land, and that is the key driver of our growth. Our view is still that we will buy around 40 new  assets with planning consent per annum. We will adjust as we go based on conditions but for the  time being, 40 a year is still our ambition. And we see the strategic land bank as being very important in how we  get those 40 through into our consented land bank. And we still have a view that the strategic bank that we have  will help us get to a position where around 50% of our land requirement will come through a strategic source.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've sold some land in the first half of this year and we'll continue to sell land to replenish our capital for  investment and to assist the funding of new acquisitions. And if you do the math, at 150 outlets in today's sales rates with our 23% to  25% social housing sort of ratio that gets you to the medium-term volumes we're planning.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We're doing exactly what we said we'd do in terms of where and what we're buying. So 71%  of our private housing land bank is now a portfolio, a range that we launched in 2011, so the half – first half of  2015, 71% is already now locked into standard portfolio housing which we know our customers love.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: 82% of our land bank is the greenfield housing, and within the 18% that's grown, 5% of that is Filton, and 3% of  that is Gloucester. And if you've been to those sites, they both feel pretty green. So, even though we have an 18%  brownfield, in a sense they're more greenfield. And 56% of our land bank is going to be for a traditional two-storey  private home. 23% of our land bank is social housing, so that ties in neatly with the contribution in the first half of  this year, and you should assume that will be roughly the contribution going forward. But, mainly our business is  focused on two-storey private housing.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie

texts.text: But it's important that we manage our business across that cycle. So we believe that, currently, we're about 18  months into the pricing and activity upswing in this cycle. texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking at the land market, we're in a very positive place. We've seen increased planning supply. The planning  system is throwing off more planning consents. But we've also seen, generally, a relatively constrained group of  buyers, particularly the smaller private housebuilders who, still, are constrained in terms of capital. If you  combine those two features, we have a land market that's acting in a very orderly way. In fact, Knight Frank, in a  recent report, suggested that greenfield residential values in 2014 increased by only 2.3%. And that tells me that  what that is saying is the land market is reacting sensibly to higher house prices but higher build costs, giving a  land value that is not radically different from year-to-year between 2013 and 2014. That's a very orderly position,  certainly compared to what we may have seen in previous upswings.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We're also seeing a very well controlled mortgage market. It's open for business, but it's well controlled both by  MMR and by the Bank of England's influence. This certainly [ph] appeals to us (07:56) to be a point in the cycle where we should  be and are investing assertively in residential land. And you can see that here. texts.speaker: Jonathan Stanley Hill
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: The work in progress has stepped up since the start of 2014 with building work in progress up £7 million and  infrastructure roads and sewers up by £16 million, reflecting the increased numbers of active build sites.

file: BVS - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 22February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, we've said consistently over the years that the only way we see to grow our UK [ph] household (05:10)  sustainably is by driving it through land investments. And we've continued to do that. So in 2015, we have added a  further 6,058 new consented plots into our business, 35 sites acquired, and we closed the year with 142 owned  assets with planning consent, and that's 11% increase in the number of sites controlled by the business.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our PRS prices were set during 2014 when we did – contracted on the deals that we are now delivering. And with  our Social increasing 6%, overall, our average selling price was up 7% in the year. In terms of volumes, you'll see  that we have a 10% increase in our private volumes, and our Social content increased to 22% of the mix from 19%  in the previous year. As you see in the slide, at the moment, our land bank now contains 24% as a proportion in  terms of our Social, and that's not a bad guide in terms of our Social going forwards.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So a slide we've shown before, just showing the progression on our housing gross margins. So hopefully you can  see the generally positive trend over five years. Our land investment in the current land market as you might  expect is delivering stability in our land costs. The build costs have increased as we've talked about, driven by  labor inflation in the market.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are controlling our materials costs through our Group-wide agreements with our key suppliers. And most  importantly, and I'll show you in a moment, there is future growth embedded in the land bank going forward.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, segmentation, geographically of our land bank. So you see, aligned with strategy; now 76% of our lands in  Southern base. We have 41% of our land bank, has now been sourced from strategic land conversion. And  pleasingly, the average cost per plot has remained relatively stable in the current land bank – in current land  market will be slightly higher from last year.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our focus remains on buying traditional housing sites, so mainly two-storey, typically greenfield in the south of  England excluding London. And our aim continues to be to drive this growth to a position where we can run the  business at a steady state in a stable market of between 5,000 homes and 6,000 homes.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Bottom left tells you that the UK planning system has continued to throw off increased levels of consented land.  And for England, the data will suggest in recent times, the rolling annual average is now around 240,000 consent  per annum. That is enough if we sustain that level to meet the government's ambition of delivering over 200,000  new homes per annum. If we can find the people to build them, the land is coming.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So how does this look? As we look at from here, having had two significant years of land investment, but we're still  maintaining a view that around 14 new sites with planning consent per annum will support the growth in our  business and our volume plans. We still feel the strategic land bank can ultimately deliver something around 50%  of the new land that we require to replenish our land bank, and we will make further land sales to manage the  capital in our balance sheet and assist the funding of the new land.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And the fourth bullet point, on the left, I'll draw your attention to the average profit within our land bank as we  move forward in current day prices and costs is £63,000 per unit and that's up within a year, on the prior year's  £56,000. So the land bank quality is improving. Within the chart, you will note that the dark blue bars, which  represent the number of sites that we owned, has grown significantly. And it's actually accelerated away from the  light blue bars, which represent the average sales outlets within the year.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And as that land comes through the income statement, not much of it has landed yet in the income statement, but  as it comes through, we are confident that will give us the source of higher returns coming through our business.  And the quality of our land bank is starting to show the efforts we've made in our strategy. So our focus on our  standard portfolio housing range, 71% of our private houses in land bank are now going to be portfolio houses.  That's excluding our site in Sherford, which is a very unique design code. 83% of our entire land bank is now  greenfield, very much in line with the strategy that we have, and 57% of the land bank will be for a traditional two- storey private house. And actually if you just look at the private plot in the land bank at 75% of our private plots  will be for a two-storey traditional home. So the land bank now reflects exactly what we've been trying to do in  strategy terms for the last five years.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Strategic land bank over 23,000 plots at the end of the year, 68% of that is in the south of England so very much  mirrors the consented land bank position. So this land will give us strong replenishment of our southern assets as  we go forward. We added 19 new strategic assets during the year, converted 11 assets, and we still maintain the  ambition of delivering around 50% of our land requirements from the source.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And if I look at how we've been doing on conversion, in the four years from 2012 to 2015, we've been adding  around 40% replenishment. And whilst that is positive and has allowed the land bank to step up to 41% sourced  strategically at the end of 2015, I think the really important thing is that the pipeline from strategic is filled. We  have seen significant progress during the year and we now have around 8,000 plots within the strategic land bank  that have planning agreed.

texts.speaker: David James Ritchie
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As we grow the business, our management of capital and allowing us to drive stronger capital turn is essential, and  some of that comes from agreeing ongoing deferred terms with our land vendors. And you can see it from our land  creditors, that has been a success as we've increased the deferment on our average piece of land. It's also by land  sales, and so those land sales whilst they may bring profit, they also bring cash back into the business to support  our new investments and also seeking development partners, either other builders or joint venture partners, that  allows us to share new assets, so bigger assets can be acquired but split between a number of developers.

texts.text: We're also reviewing our end-to-end production process, including how we work better with our Group-wide  material suppliers to ensure all developments have the materials they need when they need them, as well as our  use of other construction methods, the timber frame, and the amount of direct labor we employ across the  business. We're getting new operational resource into the organization, and we'll embed the use of our new build  management system that we implemented during 2016.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We continue to maximize the use of our standard product, now representing 74% of our land bank, greenfield  representing 84% of our land bank, and this still includes our sites at Filton in Bristol and Gloucester, which were  predominantly green to look at when we bought them, but both having an existing use were categorized as  brownfield. And in terms of products, we now have 72% of our plots – of land being private homes and only 7%  apartments.

The revised Section 106 is currently going  through its JR period, and that allows us to amend the infrastructure commitment to reduce the peak funding  required and deliver a lower proportion of affordable homes to support the commercial returns of the scheme.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The planning environment under the NPPF remains positive. texts.speaker: Edward Francis Ayres
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: We've also bolstered our strategic land department by employing new strategic land directors located in the North  Midlands and the South to support our existing land and planning teams. texts.speaker: Edward Francis Ayres
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The group also has longer term strategic land holdings, which are typically greenfield held under option  agreements. And once  a positive planning status is achieved, they will be included in the strategic plots reported.

texts.speaker: Keith Derek Adey
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The total number of owned and controlled plots has risen to 37,931 notwithstanding the reduction of Barking  Riverside. texts.speaker: Keith Derek Adey
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: We focus on return on capital when assessing our land opportunities and continually review the balance sheet to  ensure that all assets are generating the best return possible. Whilst adopting this approach, we have maintained  a high return on capital employed of 25.1% with this benefiting from historical house price inflation and faster- than-anticipated sales rates.

texts.speaker: Edward Francis Ayres
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The initiatives included within the Housing Bill and White Paper require local authorities to expedite the planning  process thereby providing further support. This positive planning environment helps to ensure that the land  market remains attractive and, accordingly, there is good availability of land that returns above historical industry  levels.

texts.speaker: Edward Francis Ayres
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The build quality has resulted in 43 of our site managers achieving NHBC Quality Awards. And relative to our  size, this is one of the best performances in the sector. Our long-term approach should ensure that customers  have confidence to buy from Bellway in the future in order to maintain good quality and sustainable returns for our  shareholders.

texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The gross margin improved further to 25.9% above the average intake margin expected when acquiring land  assessed on today's selling prices. texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: In terms of the planning environment, our investment in our strategic land department is now showing benefits. file: BWYL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 27March2019 1200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: Turning now to our second strategic objective, driving down costs, in the past six months, there's little to suggest  that the pricing environment has changed and we still experience price inflation of around 3%. We're driving down  costs in the business through a number of key initiatives. Our new group head of procurement is making excellent  progress in rationalizing group deals. And to give you an example, through standardization of our product and  commitment to volume, we have renegotiated terms of our suppliers for drainage, radiators and boilers and those  alone have generated savings of £750,000 per year. And our savings are not just focused on materials, we've  also renegotiated our electricity supply contracts for temporary buildings and offices throughout the UK. And this  has generated savings of around £300,000, and together these two items total £1 million of procurement savings  per annum. The introduction of our standard house type range, the Artisan collection has given us the platform to  improve our buying power and is fundamental to making the group more efficient. To just give you a few numbers,  53 sites are in the planning system. Our first units are already under construction, 500 units are – completions are  expected in FY 2020. Over 2,000 completions are expected in FY 2021. Our range has been extended to 43  individual house types and we anticipate savings of £2,000 per plot for each Artisan home.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: In addition, the COINS accounting and valuation system that we've implemented is now in six of our divisions and  is now gathering momentum. In May of this year, we also plan to roll out a new group-wide cost initiative, not  based on build cost savings, but also based on site based overheads. And I'll give you a little bit more detail of our  ambitions and targets in the autumn. All of these measures: procurement, Artisan, COINS and standardization in  aggregate will help mitigate margin pressure in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: In summary, the business is in good shape. With our cost mitigation measures, our land buying program and our  capacity for growth, we have a strong platform for the years ahead. Thank you.

texts.text: The bar charts on the right show how the average selling price of private and social housing completions has  risen. texts.speaker: Keith Derek Adey
texts.profession: Finance Director & Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: Return on capital continues to be a key driver for the business and to give you some examples, it is an important  metric when assessing land opportunities, we focus on sales rate, not just price in order to maximize the  efficiency of land investments. And  lastly, we are mindful of investing too many long-term capital intensive land assets that could be detrimental to  returns. By adopting this approach, the capital turn has risen to almost 1.2 times and the pre-exceptional return on  capital employed has risen to 23.9%.

texts.text: Our East Midlands division acquired the strategic greenfield site in Ibstock, Leicestershire, buyer an option  agreement with an option period of five years at 87% of open market value in February 2012. texts.text: The election result has provided further stability and commitment to the NPPF program, with increased support for  the quick delivery of more affordable houses via the new Starter Homes Initiative and Productivity Plan. The  Productivity Plan provides greater emphasis on brownfield redevelopment as opposed to greenfield, which is a  group priority with 66% of the group's owned and controlled land bank being on brownfield land.

texts.text: Large capital intensive developments such as The Residence at Nine Elms have also contributed to the  increasing WIP. The gross investment on this site, including the land value is approaching £123 million, and  Jason will elaborate on trading there in a short while.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: In that regard, 10 of our site managers have been awarded NHBC site – Health and Safety Awards, and 49 of our  site managers have been awarded NHBC Pride in the Job Quality Awards, which proportionate to volume output  is the highest number of any national house builder. As a result of these efforts, we are delighted to have  regained our five-star status as a home builder.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: The planning environment is positive, evidenced by the increased number of planning permissions in the country.  Whilst the number of planning approvals granted by local authorities is increasing, there is a tendency to these  consents to be granted on larger sites, in order for the councils to meet their targets in respect to their five-year  housing supply.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: Larger sites can sometimes be a constraint to output, as most localities are constrained by natural sales demand  and construction resource. In addition, although larger sites can provide the certainty of supply, we're also mindful  of the greater investment risks that they sometimes pose. The average site size contracted by Bellway in the past  year was around 120 units, roughly equivalent to two to three-year supply. This achieves an appropriate balance  between securing operational certainty set against the disciplined approach to investment.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: Going forward, the planning outlook remains positive, the housing white paper is favorable including a number of  proposals which should help streamline the process; measures such as brownfield first and a standardized  method for calculating housing need. Set against this positive backdrop, we continue to identify attractive land  opportunities with a forecast gross margin and the return on capital is above historical norms.

file: BWYL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 16October2018 725 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Keith Derek Adey
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: Following the events at Grenfell, we have, as you would expect, undertaken a detailed review, and we've  identified a small number of high-rise buildings where ACM was used. All of these obtained the appropriate  building regulations sign-off at that time, but nevertheless, as a large responsible developer, we believe we've got  more than just a legal obligation to our customers. We're, therefore, working with others to design replacement  solutions where it's appropriate to do so, and we believe the net cost [indiscernible] (00:13:13) of any remedial  works is less than £6 million. And this is fully reflected in the reported gross margin. And I'm [ph] drawing  (00:13:22) this out not because I see it is a material sum, but to give you some comfort that we believe the  expected costs of remediation are fully reflected in the balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Keith Derek Adey
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: You may recall we used to talk about achieving price rises of 10% to 15% when new sites in London were first  released to the market. This is simply no longer the case and, hence, the challenge going forward will be to offset  some of the reducing benefit of house price inflation with improved land buying hurdle rates and a reinvigorated  focus on cost control.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: And the key theme of this range is the flexibility of the elevational treatments. Each house type can be plotted with  either a brick, weatherboarding, tile cladding or rendered elevation, and this allows us to create a variety of street  scenes and address particular design codes and character areas, yet still meet my ambition of standardization.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: And this approach maximizes the usage across the country, which explains why we've been able to plot some  6,000 homes in such a short space of time. Our internal layouts have been based on customer feedback and  represent the way people want to live today. And similarly, our new standard specification is developed to live in,  in 2020 and beyond. And some of the new features include hardwiring for broadband, USB points, LED  downlighters, but notably, electric car charging points on some of our new developments. Aside from the new  designs and features, our house types are more efficient and easier to build. Early prototypes and detailed  program have indicated we're able to accelerate build times by up to two weeks per house.

texts.speaker: Jason Honeyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Non-Executive Director, Bellway Plc
texts.text: I also want to focus on stronger brand recognition, and we are committed to maintaining our five-star status as a  house builder. This year, we achieved a record score of 92.1% for customers who would recommend Bellway to a  friend. And we are only one of two major national housebuilders to achieve this accolade. Last year, our site  managers won 49 NHBC Quality Awards. And relative to our volume output, this is the strongest performance in  the sector.

texts.speaker: Pierre Jean Sivignon

texts.text: Revamped hypermarkets and now also five recently revamped Bairro supermarkets turned in an encouraging  sales uplift. We intend to pursue our renovation program in 2016, thus increasing the attractiveness of our stores.  This has a direct impact on the evolution of our traffic which has been positive quarter-after-quarter for now over  a year. Atacadão continues to perform very well. Its model is particularly well-adapted to the Brazil current  economic climate. We pursue our multi-format expansion in the country with further openings of Atacadão and  further openings of convenience stores in 2016.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On the same time, we should also mention that we have two important strategic moves. The one was the  completion of the DIA spin-off and the other one is the start of the rollout of the Carrefour Planet in Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I will give you an update on the four model stores, which are the stores that are now in place since almost a year  and where we can read the real benefits of the Planet concepts. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let me now turn to a few other lessons learned over the past month. The first one is concerning the environment.  We faced and we are still facing, a longer and deeper downturn in Europe than I think what anybody expected a  few months ago. That means that we are in an increasingly tough environment that leads us to look at whether we  can further deepen our cost savings, and how we can optimize our capital expenditure, or review its allocation and  its phasing.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, what I'm talking to you is just an adjustment in timeline because we do believe that the target still remains  valid. Now, at the same time, evidently, we will adjust in a very pragmatic way our investments, as I said,  particularly the store expansions and renovation plans that we have put forward. This is also slightly impacted our  rollout of Carrefour Planet, but you will see it in a while that we are talking minor changes, in particularly  Southern Europe, which is Greece and Italy.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Europe, we are reexamining our cost savings. We are adapting to the new situations that we see, or that we can  see in front of us in Southern Europe. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, let me introduce Carrefour's new executive team, since I was talking about that. We have the two words that I  would like you to retain, there is continuity, but there is also change. texts.profession: Executive Director Growth Markets, Carrefour SA
texts.text: This following slide is to provide you with a detailed update on the efficiency part of our Transformation Plan. texts.speaker: Pierre Bouchut

texts.profession: Executive Director Growth Markets, Carrefour SA

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA

But as you can see, slight  changes that has been put into the plan. France is pursuing as foreseen, Belgium as well. But as I said, in Greece  and Italy, there has been some adaptions.

file: CA - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 30August2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Well, I mean, the people of Carrefour invented IPR, and it was quite an original concept. And they didn't quite  understand and how the consumption would evolve. The essential point – the most important thing that has  occurred over the last 10 years is that there has been a dispersion of the distribution channels of the retailer  channels, and the idea was to provide a supply, which is more in keeping with the customer requirements. I mean,  we see that there is oil prices and indeed there is a consumption of the non-available part or the unavailable part  of revenue.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We've got car parks. We've got land. That hasn't been fully used. And so value can be derived from that. But we  have to maintain those. When a company manages real estate and when you've got people also working in stores,  when you do that in a company such as Carrefour, then there is a breaking point or break in communication.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Then we have cost controls. We are absolutely convinced that even if the economy improves, no longer can we be  constantly – we must be constantly alert and vigilant as regard to costs. We have to maintain our competitiveness  – competitiveness of our offering, we have to train people to ensure quality, and then we've also got economic  pressure to manage, which will lead us to managing cost differently. Now, quite obviously, we have to focus on  human resources for that. Perhaps we have to spend less but spend better. We have to think in terms also of  energy; energy costs are going to rise in the coming years and rise very steeply, also we have to set up cost controls  and we have to banish waste.  Now, this was a term that was used in France for a long time, and people largely ignored it but now in fact we have  to do it. If we place this policy at the individual level, in fact, 400,000 people within the group, and we have to set  simple objectives, but then we have to express that in the smallest time unit possible and we have to take action.  And so we have to see where wastage is taking place. And then if we step back from that then indeed we have to  make sure that people are encouraged to stop wasting energy.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We've been trying in the past to create a sort of fizz, a buzz by adding our own brand to all this. And this is a very  clear example. We don't have to work for another 25 years in order to compete with the brands, which should lead  finally to a sustainable economy.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Small electrical goods, I hear a lot of excellent work has been done, because in the Planet project there were a  certain number of things which were extremely good. And these small electrical products, why are these selling  well today? Well, because SEB, the brand SEB, has done an excellent job. They've created market share. They've  created identity. They've created style. And so this has given new dynamism to this market.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: So electrical goods for the home, this is the real subject. Sometimes, we have to send people elsewhere. And in  order to overcome this problem, we need two things, a proper showroom with really good stock control in our  stores and, secondly, the ability to deliver and install these goods. And thirdly, we need an e-commerce sales  channel which genuinely works.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: And then our human capital is good, but it does require further attention. It's just like gardening. From time-to- time, you have to trim, you have to cut back. You have to cut away the dead wood. You don't saw through the  trunk; no certainly not. But you have to put in some extra fertilizer, turn over the soil, water every day. In other  words, you have to reinvest in your human capital in order to reactivate it. This is the question, reactivating  human capital. In order to reactivate, I think we have to simplify the tasks that we give people. We have to help  them, we have to train them, because we've tended to neglect the training of some of the simpler tasks we have.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now, you might be somewhat disappointed with that on an intellectual level, but I am used to that. I feel that,  well, we're going to do this. I think it will take three years; otherwise, we won't do things properly. And then in  three years time, we have to think again to move onto the second stage, onto the following stage. So, I'm very  confident. I want that to spread within in our environment and also we will need everyone. But indeed, Carrefour  should get going.

texts.text: So, of course, we are trailing behind, but I'm European. I believe that we should still believe in Europe and it is  essential for Carrefour to have strong positions in this part of the world. So back to what I was saying, it is – what  we can see here is a better sort of climate – psychological climate in the company, a situation where it's not a  situation where people are dominating one another, but there is rather emanation between the various operating  positions. So people are working together rather than against one another. So this is of course very productive, but  at the end of the day, this serves the interest and indeed, the very safety and – of the group. It's better to have this  sort of emanation to achieve synergies.

Retailers which are now disclosing results by nature impacted one after the other by the context. That's not a  surprise. And what we could say is that there are a couple of things that we really – there are a couple of points  that we need to take into account in order to chart Carrefour's future. texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Taking about the environment, I'll say a few words about France and then I'll walk through all our countries,  France, Europe and Latin America, then Asia. In France, well, I don't need to dwell on the situation. Our country  is mostly depressed. There are big difficulties in transforming the labor market to make it more nimble, less costly  and, at the end of the day, to make it more lucrative for employees.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: In China, we are making sustained investment, which is logical and credible in the food sector particularly in  terms of food safety, which is, of course, a major preoccupation for the government. And we are also working in  terms of the environment and air pollution. So, we are going ahead with our plan in China at the same speed. At  the same time, we are trying to tidy up our network somewhat. We've been present there since 1995 and we  believe that it's useful to take a look at some of our sites in order to decide on their future developmen t or not.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We've had to undertake a specific task there and that was the modernization of our hypermarket format,  modernization in terms of the environment. We're offering customer service. So far, this is giving us good results  and the satisfaction surveys are very positive. So, we believe that this is a development, whic h could extend to a  worldwide movement. We need to conserve non-food business. We sometimes reduce sales areas, but we add an  extra design concept to the stores.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: It's due in part to an effect of the product mix linked to the drop in fuel prices and, therefore, based on oil prices.  But the improvement of the margin is also due to the action plans we've set up in several countries, combined with  the increase in sales volumes, particularly in Latin America.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

So, we can say that  our operating costs have been well-controlled because this is due to account rises in salaries and energy costs in  Latin America and Asia, and of course the impact of the new [ph] task on (7 :41) tax in France. We've been able to  compensate for these increases by our various plans for greater efficiency in all our zones.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer

There will probably  be a decline in the production of basic products, which will probably lead to a diffe rent relation to labor. Wages  are growing. Social awareness is also growing, but with utterly Chinese discipline. So, it's up to us to be able to  exploit the situation with the advantage of our history because we arrived in China in 1995.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer

The climate turns out to be one of the most unpredictable but also one of the most marking aspects in general  retail.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: I'll not forget Atacadão that a lot has heard about is very dynamic as a branch in our company. It's still performing  at quite remarkable rates. And now we devote a non-negligible part of investments in this country to Atacadão. I  think that in the current period, this is a model that's very well-suited to an economic climate where the economy  is not very promising.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: And therefore, China, under the aegis of its increasingly powerful government, is undergoing a major revolution  which is, on the one hand, to get control back over the banking sector and approach the country of factories that  have a negative impact on the country and the environment and also substitute production for more high-value  products and also focus on domestic consumption. This is a massive overriding trend that's China-wide, and  that's only seen over the long term but this is something that we strongly believe in. Therefore, we need to show  patience and also work hard.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Now I wanted to say a couple of words about France. France is still the bedrock of the company, the historical  basis, the cultural base of the company, a great platform. It's still a great society. France has resisted very well in  the climate that we all know about. It is still redeploying in logistical terms to meet the demands of multi-format. It's  still working on the competitiveness of its hyper-markets, which was not simple because we faced a very strong  price war with unprecedented promotional activity, and yet the company is doing reasonably well in spite of a few  ups and downs in revenues, but that's also related to climate aspects, as I said earlier.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: But the climate in France was really rotten, and it's still the case. And so, traditional consumption from spring  onwards are barbecues, camping, implements, but also clothing and everything that this means in terms of food,  sausages and bacon, and all the alcoholic beverages you need to go along with that. That suffered.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Greenways, which is the latest small site that we've acquired, we signed it two days ago. It's an organic website.  It's very selective. And it offers brands that retailers do not yet have because suppliers do not make them  available. But now we have a site and a great team that will fit in the whole organic universe and then will play its  role in bringing us forward. This small organic site is added to the mix. We'll have a Carrefour portal through which  consumers can go to Rue du Commerce, [indiscernible] (29:30) or now Greenways and [indiscernible] (29:32)

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: I'm extraordinarily upbeat about the future of Carrefour even in a complex geopolitical climate. I'm absolutely  convinced that this company will remain the leader in retail with a huge general food platform. The major base  business for Carrefour will remain food with a specialized positioning on sincere high-quality products that are  focused on well-being. People should no longer sacrifice quality for stupidly low prices. You also need to maintain  your price image, though. I'm absolutely convinced that the model that we are building will be extremely resilient  and modern.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Slide seven. Here, we can look at our operating costs. Leaving aside the asset costs, the operating costs have  increased by 3.6% at constant exchange rates during the half year. If we expressed it in percentage of sales,  excluding fuel, the curve is eventually flat, so the operating costs are up 10 basis points. It's the ratio excluding  fuel that is most representative of the change in our costs, because fuel prices have been very volatile. So, our  operating costs are under control. They're stable in France. They reflect the rise in wage costs and energy costs  in Latin America and in Asia. But those rises have been offset by the various efficiency plans that we've been  implemented in all those zones.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: So, in conclusion, we can say that this was a half year marked by strikes and social unrest. As you know, there  were floods. There was a shortage of fuel during the second quarter. And then there was these rather strange  meteorological conditions that I've already mentioned. But despite all these, our operating margin is stable, and  our ROI amounts to €312 million.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: CSR contributes to deep-seated changes in our product offering by highlighting the categories that Mr. Plassat  talked about earlier that meet new aspirations, control change, organic local products, environment-friendly fair  trade, good for health. It also helps systemically both our effectiveness and efficiency by fighting wastage and by  implementing retail solutions that respect the environment and our society's aspirations. I can see that more and  more, in all countries, this is the expression – the direct expression of Carrefour's genetics.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: What has happened in the last six months in this area, I shall be brief, so I won't give you a detailed rundown of  our action plans. Some of them were discussed during the general meeting, by the way. We are carrying on with  our action, as part of the method that was defined to use market reference tools, direct involvement of the board  in the company, dialogue with all stakeholders, implementation of performance measures. And that include, by  the end of the year, the creation of a new CSR index that will be our Carrefour CSR index.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: A few examples of striking achievements in the half year. In the fight against wastage, which is covered by a  document that you were given when you entered the room, as part of our objective defined a few months ago to  reduce our carbon emissions by 40% by 2025, we've implemented an internal carbon price. We are the first  retailer doing that in Europe.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: We also launched our two Tous AntiGaspi brand, all against wastage, to sell secondary products and to enhance  food donations. To protect biodiversity, we've launched our sustainable fishing approach in France, and we – this  is also a first. We obtained MSC's sustainable fishing certification for our [ph] Fishtiv (01:12:50) departments in 33  stores. And we also made progress in agro-ecology as part of [ph] Filia Kinetica (01:12:58) in several countries.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: We are the first pesticide-free strawberry in France. That worked very well. And in Poland also, we had a new so- called raspberry tomato with a very special taste that consumes a much fewer pesticide than similar tomatoes.  And in our work with our partners, in France, we launched a new ambitious initiative to support SME based on  innovation and intensifying the retail dynamics. And we also signed the ILO handicap and disability charter  supported by the retail and handicapped network that we're sharing this year. Everyone's mobilized in our CSR,  and our teams will remain mobilized in the next few months. Thank you.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: I don't have more to add. You saw that the strawberry tomato absorbed a few pesticides than others. The lady  here loves tomatoes. And we're also embarking in an area where we want to make healthier, more affordable  products. And Carrefour is the company that brings all causes together, trying to outperform the others to make  sure that health, well-being and personal fulfillment are the cornerstone of our relationship with consumers.

file: CA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 30August2017 1215 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Aug-17.pdf
CA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 26July2018 1215 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We also delivered on making our processes lean and efficient. I had said in January, a great ambition in terms of  cost reduction, €2 billion by 2020. The question was, whether we could change Carrefour habits to be more cost- effective. We completely reshuffled our organization to manage spending. We have already reached €520 million  of worth cost reductions, mainly on distribution costs, thanks to [indiscernible] of contracts and systematic  renegotiations. This cost reduction dynamic will accelerate in 2019 with new initiatives such as our joint  purchasing alliances with Tesco and Système U.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: In parallel, we are transforming our offering. You know we have a profound ambition for the company: to become  the world leader of the food transition for all. We are now transforming this ambition into commercial proof points  through strong commitment on food quality, safety, access and responsibility.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We are still committed to the elimination of controversial components from our private label. For instance by  removing 100% of additives from our dairy products, and we decided to switch to full sustainable packaging for  our products by 2025.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: To reach our full transition ambition, we are also rethinking our relationships with our suppliers, turning them into  partnerships. This new approach towards our suppliers also apply to the agricultural sector, with whom we have  developed balanced and long-lasting partnership. And our joint buying partnership with Système U will only  strengthen this ambition to renew our way of supporting the agricultural sector. In line with our plan, we also made  this semester our first investments in price competitiveness; for instance, in supermarkets in France, and  hypermarkets in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Matthieu Malige
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Let's focus on the cost reduction plan in H1. The cost reduction plan is ahead of schedule with gross savings of  €520 million achieved in H1 as part of the overall objective of €2 billion in cost savings by 2020. The majority of  these cost cuts came from distribution costs in H1. First gains on direct costs were also recorded. This should  ramp up in 2019 as the full force of the purchasing alliances Carrefour has concluded comes into effect.
