texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and thank you very much for be with us – and for this
texts.text: Now second, or another positive event in terms of cost management. We managed to decrease our  cost base of 950 – or 590 sorry – I wish it was 950, but it’s €590 million. This is unprecedented in  Carrefour history. We had managed to kill costs in 2008, which is already a record for us of 150  million. So what you clearly can see here, this is not a cost killing exercise. This is the first fruits of  the transformation plan. This is the way we are working differently in order to take out cost on a  sustainable matter.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and thank you very much for be with us – and for this
texts.text: As explained on this following chart, our inventory reduction plan is on track. Our inventory were cut  by €221 million over the last 12 month. This represent 2.3 days of COGS at constant exchange  rates and this is in line with our two-day reduction target for 2009. We therefore maintain our seven- day reduction target for 2012.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and thank you very much for be with us – and for this
texts.text: First of all, it is about CCO: Carrefour Category Optimization. It’s a tool that I explained to you in  June that we have developed in order to be more precise in our offer.

file: CA - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 3March2011 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: In 2010, we acted on many fronts and our Transformation Plan produced many solid achievements.  By the way, these bolster our confidence that we have chosen the right strategy and that we are on  the right track. But I must also say that 2010 yielded some disappointments. I will not use the  challenging environment around us as excuse; we did not achieve all our targets, and I’m clearly  not pleased with that.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: Now turning to our business, 2010 gave us several reasons for satisfaction. First of all, our  Transformation Plan is delivering strongly. Our considerable efforts on both cost reductions and  improving purchasing conditions yielded combined savings of €910 million, a figure that is clearly  above plan. 2010 also saw the successful launch of Carrefour Planet, which we are about to begin       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: 3 Now let’s look in a greater detail of our scorecard and how we stacked up against our targets.  Overall, we could sum-up 2010 by saying, good progress, but not all box ticked. We fell short on  two targets. The first is current operating income, as I already explained and the second target, we  missed is inventory reduction. We managed to keep the inventory stable in 2010, but this fell well  short of the – our commitment to reduce it by two days.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: To sum-up, the storms of 2010 did not blow the Carrefour ship off its long-term course. Our  Transformation Plan is on track and we have several achievements under our belt even though we  expected or we do expect continued headwinds in 2011. We continue to make progress and see a  brighter and stronger future for the Group and its shareholders.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: Altogether, when adding up those €580 million cost saving to the €590 million realized in 2009, this  represents an all-time high €1,170 million cost reduction achieved by Carrefour over two years. And  we are, therefore, well on target to attain the €2.1 billion cost saving objective announced for 2012  as a part of our Transformation Plan.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: We rolled out also the Carrefour Express and the Carrefour Market throughout Europe, Asia and  Latin America. And finally, we tested our six Carrefour Planet hypermarkets in Europe. And we will  start, by the way, rolling out the concept this year after very positive results in our pilot stores.  When I say that, let’s take a closer look to the result.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: So that was for the Carrefour Planet. Let me come into another important part in the Transformation  Plan and that is the cost savings. Cost savings is one of the key pillars of our Transformation Plan,       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: As I told you earlier, we have tested the model in six stores, three countries for six to eight months  and we have now defined the final model. We are now ready for the takeoff to the new planet.  Between now and mid 2013, we will rollout the concept in 213 stores at the same time as we are  renovating another 287 hypermarkets implementing the many of the planet features, that’s an  extraordinary ambitious plan.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: You see here the price communication, the discount part on the dry grocery, frozen food, you see  here the wine part and here you see the housing, you see the Mode, this is the fresh part, some  clients. This is a new multimedia as you know that was not really being done in the initial pilot  stores and that is the new Carrefour Planet.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: Now let me bring you back from the planet to the earth and show you some of the key targets for  the year. As you saw earlier, we are ahead of our plan of operating costs and savings. Over the  past two years we have taken out more than €1 billion of costs of which about €200 million in Dia.  In 2011, we have targeted another €550 million of costs cuts. That target by the way included €70  million at Dia, so our updated, unchanged pro forma target for this year is €480 million.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: On our inventory reduction, I told you earlier that we had fallen behind our target. This year we will  aim to reduce inventories by the two days that we missed last year. We will achieve these targets,  thanks to I would say, to the rollout of the new back office IT system, continuous improvements in  our supply chain and by adopting measures that we have taken in other countries, such as Poland  and Spain.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: We will cut our inventory by two days. We will now roll out, as I said, 92 new Carrefour Planets in  the G4 and Greece, and we will spend €2.9 billion in CapEx to further our priority projects.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
texts.text: And by the way, this is the right moment with a Carrefour Planet rollout, we have now an attractive  concept that we can optimize by developing the sites and galleries around our hypermarkets. And       corrected transcript

file: CA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 8March2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: The third elements on that slide relates to the transformation cost necessary to implement our efficiency  initiatives, and that amounted to €120 million in the full year, out of which 88 – €89 million represents  restructuring charges. On the positive side, and that is now the green box on the right, we booked €255 million of  net capital gains, the bulk coming from the sale in December of a real estate portfolio comprising 97  supermarkets.

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Let's now look at our investments. Our 2011 investments were up 27% compared to 2010 when adjusted for DIA  and reached €2.3 billion for the year. A few remarks, firstly, the increase over 2010 is largely due to the Planet  rollout, as shown on the left-hand side of the particular slide. We spent €1.3 billion on remodeling, maintenance  and Planet altogether. This represents a significant increase compared to the €838 million spent in 2010 and  include around €369 million of Planet-specific CapEx. Secondly, I would like to stress that we have maintained  our expansion CapEx at broadly the same level in 2011 versus 2010.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Thank you, Pierre-Jean. And after this complete picture of 2011, let me turn to some of the key actions in 2012.  And let's start first with an update on Planet. Thank you. As you all know, 2011 was marked by the continuation of  the rollout of Planet. And we promised you to give you an full update once we had, I would say, a critical mass of  the stores, as well as been operating sufficiently long so that you could start to draw some relevant conclusions of  the results.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: So, if I want to sum things up, I would say, there are many, many positive trends, including an improved shopping  experience and sales outperformance, but the Planet did not deliver everything that we were hoping for this  concept, and notably, in the non-food. And you know that the non-food was one of the key factors in the Planet  concept. And I would also say that their performance were significantly different in the three main countries  where it was rolled out. So, this is why I would like to go a little bit further in the analysis and have a look into  what was the performance in the main countries, which means Belgium, France and Spain.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We've seen EBITDAR margin improvement versus the non-converted stores in Belgium. And if we talk EBITDAR,  it is because this is the real, I would say, store performance that we are measuring in order to have a clean  measure as possible when we are seeing what is the progress of the store when we have converted them into  Planet.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: So, let's now turn into Spain, which is on this next slide here. Here we have now 39 stores that has been converted.  Spain is today the country that has the biggest number of Planet. And Planet accounts today for 36% of our  hypermarket sales in Spain. Now, our overall Planet sales have strongly outperformed the non-converted stores  in, I would say, an extremely difficult environment that we have seen in Spain. Planet store has seen their sales  drop limited to 1.3%, but you can see that the non-converted stores, they have been dropping 7.1%. The traffic is  up 3.9% versus the non-converted stores. And we have also seen quite some strong market share gains once we  have turned the conversion into Planet.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now, the sum of these issues is that it has prevented us from, I would say, deriving full benefits of the Planet  concept in France. In terms of profitability, also here it meant that we did not improve, but we will not de-grade or  lower the margin either. We maintained a stable EBITDAR margin in our converted stores.  So, having looked now in terms of general and specifically in the three countries, where do we go from here? Well,  as you see on this slide 34, our overall assessment is even though Planet stores are outperforming non-converted  stores in terms of sales and in traffic, and that the sentiments are very positive coming from our clients, the results  to-date are still below our expectations.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now, that said, the third action will evidently be that we will draw on the best of what we have seen in the Planet  stores. And we will deploy the best practices in our hypermarkets, which need to be remodeled, by the way, on a  worldwide basis. We have gained plenty of best practices that can benefit from our hypermarkets in all our  markets.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: So, as you can see, we are acting very, very pragmatically. Planet is a very good project. It has initiated a promising  – in a very promising and favorable period, now two-and-a-half years ago. But today, the environment has  dramatically changed and we need to adapt to that. It is necessary with the financial discipline to really selectively  go through the CapEx. And we need to, by the way, in France also, be sure that all the operational issues have been  taken care of before we have any further deployment.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: With that having said, I would like now to hand over to Noël to give you – he will give us an update on project  Reset, as well as what are the Planet's plans in France. Noël, please.

texts.speaker: Noël Prioux
texts.profession: Executive Director-France, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now, the organization, out-of-stocks, and then Planet deployment, Lars has already talked about attitude  concerning Planet. For France, very clearly, we're going to put things on hold. There's going to be a pause in the  rollout of Planet, just three stores in 2012. These were already in the pipeline and they will be launched during the  first half year.

texts.speaker: Noël Prioux
texts.profession: Executive Director-France, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Before we convert any more Planet stores, we're going to work on the concept in depth. We want to develop the  think there is still many improvements to be made, notably on the non-food side. And so, that's the aim that we've  fixed before we restart the rollout of new Planet stores.

texts.speaker: Noël Prioux
texts.profession: Executive Director-France, Carrefour SA
texts.text: If you find something cheaper elsewhere, Carrefour will refund the difference; Carrefour Low Prices plus  Confidence. What about quality? What is your quality commitment? Oh, come on, follow me. 24 hours ago, those  charts were in the water. That's what we mean by quality commitment. No MGOs (sic) [GMOs] and our price  guarantee. No, no, the water is just for the fish. 20,000 French producers and breeders have committed to help us  offer you the lowest prices plus quality.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now, in Spain, which has also seen a very sharp, I would say, downturn, we are working here on, I would say,  boosting our commercial momentum by deploying Planet, because this, as what you saw, was one of the levers  why Spain is resisting well knowing the environment we are finding. So, either it is the Planet deployment or it is  the best practices that we are now taking out to the rest of the hypermarkets in Spain, and at the same time, we are  strengthening our price competitiveness particular, I would say, in the southern part of Spain. You might also  have seen some very specific targeted promotions whether it's been to the seniors where we are not charging the  TVA, for instance, for the seniors. This is all just to be close to our clients in a very difficult situation. At the same  time, I would say, that with the restriction of the capital expenditure, expansion is carried out through franchising  where we, for instance, had agreed to franchise the food stores at the BP petrol stations.

texts.speaker: Lars Olofsson
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: In the environment we are facing, I felt it was the right time to pass on the baton to the new management. As you  know, I informed the Carrefour Board that I was not intending to seek a renewal of my mandate at the Carrefour  Shareholders Assembly in June 18. And it will be Georges Plassat that will be joining us as from the 2nd of April in  view of taking over and succeed as Chairman and Chief Executive at the Shareholder Meeting. I know Georges  personally very well back since, I think, some 33 years. He's an experienced retailer, a very strong manager, and a  man with lot of convictions and passion, and I wish him every success personally, as well as for Carrefour.

file: CA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 7March2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: So again, we really have to put the customer back at the heart of our business and that requires decentralization. A  sensible, organized decentralization, the decentralization all the same. And it also means that the store managers  have to be able to adapt to the local environment without the negative impact on our business.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now we know that up until things changed in Carrefour, ownership of the land surrounding our stores actually  accounted for 30% or 35% of our income. So we have to remember that. So again, we have to make sure that we  can properly maintain and protect the site as a whole if you've got a Carrefour banner. The entire shopping area  has to be up to scratch. So we have to be very good because we can't just manage properly our stores and manage  abysmally badly our property.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Now I have also said many number of times that we have to make sure that we have local supplies also for fresh  produce, which means that in fact we truly have fresh produce for our customers but also we create work  indirectly in the environment, immediate environment in which we operate. This is something that was done in  the past, sometimes neglected but I think that we're coming back to it. And all of these sort of industries in fact, all  of these sectors when they are supported, feed into our customer base.

file: CA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 5March2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: For the entire year and for the second semester, I would say that Belgium also saw its profitability increase.  Romania had its profitability go down slightly but with a slight improvement for the second hal f. In Europe, we  continue adapting our offer and our costs in – against the environment as you know.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: China. China, we're still focusing on local management. Most of the regional managers are now Chinese. We keep  supporting the government on food safety, which is a key issue in China. Also, we're making progress on energy,  rolling out new control methods to control energy consumption. And at the same time, we want to address the  issue of formats and offers in cities we didn't know and which we are currently addressing or attacking so that the  return on investment in the future, in our future growth, be positive and relevant.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Taiwan. Well, we urgently need to take our time. Our company is robust. We have good locations, good  management. We've had the climate problems this year, plus a food safety problem. They've had a few warnings  for commodities this year.

file: CA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 5March2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy CEO & General Secretary
texts.text: We are the leading general retailer in terms of this service. And as well as this new service in the non-food sector,  we have our drive-in stores which are an essential part of our cross-channel offering in food. At the end of 2014,  we had 438 drive-in stores, which correspond to the demand of our customers. They are a complementary feature  to our hypermarkets and supermarkets. And finally, our portal carrefour.fr in December received something like  8.5 million single visitors. And innovation continues. Recently, we invested in the Partech fund in order to make a  contribution to the creation of new ecosystems.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy CEO & General Secretary
texts.text: Our fourth priority will be to continue to work on support functions. First of all, the logistic system in France, we  are continuing to adapt this to serve the multi-format cross-channel approach. This upgrade will enable us to  make savings in cost and energy with two key indicators, the cost per kilo and the cost per kilometer transported,  all this in order to improve the service that we offer to our stores.

file: CA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 10March2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre Jean Sivignon
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let's move on now to slide 7, analysis of our operating costs excluding costs of assets. The costs have increased by  6.1% at constant exchange rates during the year. As a percentage of sales excluding fuel, the increase is 20 basis  points. So, overall, operating costs have been well-controlled, perhaps taking into account wage rises and energy  cost increases in Latin America and Asia, and also the impact of the Tascom sales service tax in France. The rise  was compensated for by our efficiency plans in all the countries where we are present.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: Carrefour is a major stakeholder in its industry. And we would like to take on our responsibility when it comes to  corporate social responsibility. We are the industry leader in France. And we're amongst the top companies in all  countries where we are present. We're all also aware of the fact that this responsibility, which should make us a  stakeholder that pays attention to its environment, is at the same time a must when it comes to creating value to  better serve our customers.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: The CSR policy of Carrefour is in line with a mid- and long-term vision of our business and of the contribution of  our company to society. Quite simply, what we mean is doing a good job. This is a motto and you've known it for  quite some time now. This vision is, of course, based on the own characteristics of the company, being local  because thanks to multi-format, usage of new technologies, and a broader international experiments. All actions  will be used to better serve the priorities that we have defined. The impact of CSR is also key when it  comes to  efficiency and when it comes to motivating the 380,000 workers, employees of our company. It helps foster and  better mobilize our partners, suppliers, local stakeholders and all civil society representatives.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: No need to dwell on the methods that we use to boost our CSR approach. They were already described and they're  based on international standards and benchmarks, which are known, and they are detailed with the useful  indicators in the year document of the company.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: Action taken by Carrefour in 2015 are based on three priorities, the three pillars of our CSR, and the wastage,  biodiversity, and relationships with our partners. And those were recognized by those who look at these or  monitor these policies and our ranking is 96B on the CDP assessment, which means we're in the top of – we're  ahead of other French groups in this particular sector. And we improved our ranking by 7 points on the  RobecoSAM/DJSI Assessment.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: We got the prize in France – we got several prizes and awards in France and abroad. The ESSEC Prize for  Responsible Trade (sic) [Retailing] (29:13) in France, the Good Energy Award in Italy, the Top 10 in Sustainability  of the Chamber of Commerce in Argentina and another award by the Forbes Magazine and the Best Energy  Efficiency Program of the Y ear in Romania.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: Now, to highlight that this is really – well, I'd like to focus on two subject that's marked our performance in 2015:  the commitment of Carrefour for climate and the fact that we really want to focus on agroecology. Climate, as you  know, was one of the key topics of 2015 with the COP21 and we're actively involved with other companies as part  of the French business climate pledge and the UN initiative called Caring for Climate.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: As far as this is concerned, we officially committed ourselves to cutting by 40% our CO2 emissions in our stores by  2025, and by 70% by 2050. This target is based on a program of actions using all possible levers. First of all,  Carrefour last autumn decided to voluntarily set a price for CO2, to include it in our investment calculations.  Setting the price of carbon means you add to the initial cost of the technology, the cost of CO2 that it will be  releasing during its life. I would like to recall that Carrefour released 3.58 million tonnes of CO2 in 2015.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: Secondly, savings will be generalized in our stores, thanks to closed cold storage units, using LED lighting,  centralized meters, optimization of cold and the hot streams, in compliance with ISO 50001.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: Number three, innovative experiments will be multiplied, creation of self-sufficient stores. The objective in terms  of consumption is 250 kilowatt-hours per square meters, plus the new methodologies to monitor our energy  consumption, plus corrective action will be implemented immediately. The share of renewa ble energies in our  supplies board continue to increase. Carrefour will continue producing electricity directly on its sites. Also,  intermittent energy storage was tested, and we would like to cut our overall consumption by 2.5%, and by the way,  it's 5.9 terawatt-hours in 2015.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: HFC gases are no longer used in our new facilities, and it's been the case since 2015. They're replaced by CO2. We  have 260 cold production units based on that technology in seven countries, including in areas where it is  particularly hot.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: Last but not least, CO2 emissions coming from transport were cut by 14.3% over the past five years, and will be cut  by at least as much within the next 10 years. We should also like to focus increasingly on agroecology across the  world, and would like to focus on a more environmentally-friendly agriculture – or farming. This is at the heart of  our food business, and this is in line with the needs of our customers.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: As for many other areas of CSR, agroecology is a very useful source of innovation. It is a powerful tool for progress  and differentiation, which will help better and sustainably meet the needs of consumers. Carrefour has long been  committed on these issues, which sometimes lead to challenging debates but always useful debates, like on GMOs,  something that we – or GMOs that we do not want to have in our quality sourcing approach.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: There are many issues behind this word agroecology: cutting usage of pesticides and the chemical fertilizers,  integrated farming, circular economy, reduction of antibiotics, bio controls, better valuation of waste coming from  crops, closer sources of supply and animal feed.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: As far as sustainable fishing is concerned, I mean our concerns are the same. We need to focus on the best  practices, the most respectful practices for nature, and which can help foster biodiversity. We are the industry  leader as far as this is concerned. We work with several organizations, like the Marine Stewardship Council, in  order to better qualify the choices made by our company.

texts.speaker: Jérôme Bédier
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & General Secretary
texts.text: In all countries, the local offering was increased. The number of local products in France is now – we now have  60,000 local products. 5,000 SMEs account for 9% of our sales in Belgium. In 2014, we launched a new project,  which meant that 680 local producers could provide more than 7,000 products to the stores that were less than  40 kilometers away. SMEs also have their own specific action programs to streamline their administrative  relationships with our company, to have a better referencing, to have involved SMEs on CSR actions based on self  tests, for instance.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you very much, Jérôme. Well, I believe that the number one development in the retail sector is that we  want to have a smarter approach. This is a rough environment, and things are changing. And we are moving  towards what I would refer to as being intangible, and this is precisely what Jérôme just said. I mean, he's been  focusing on CSR, and this is something that is currently being implemented throughout the company, and of  course, there might be reluctances here and there, because it's not immediately profitable. And people don't  necessarily immediately see the advantages of that CSR approach, but he has my full support.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And I'm convinced that different leaders of different countries of Carrefour know that we have to focus on these  strategies, focused on the society, on the environment. All stakeholders know that. There's a good reason for that.  Our stores are showcases of what we do, and we can't just focus on prices.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As far as financial results are concerned, I think everything was said, we are the re. This is the result of balances  that we've been developing for quite some time, different formats which are balanced. There's a new balance in  terms of financial ingredients. We have contained debt, kept to a very reasonable level. We have free cash flo w. We  still have CapEx capacity whenever necessary, expansion, remodeling, and at the same time, new IT and logistics  systems. So I would say that the teams of Carrefour in 2015 spared no efforts, and I should like to welcome the  investments of our shareholders, generally speaking. And also, I should like to say that you have economic,  societal and environmental elements which helped lead to these results, and which is the result of a lot of work.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The key asset of Carrefour today is that facing the development of the Internet. The food business will still be a  major business in the future. No one can deliver a customer in their home than the local convenience stores for  distance reasons, for time reasons and for the – because of the quality of the product. Also, you may order books,  and you do order books and you might sell books in hypermarkets, we're the number one bookstore in France, by  the way. But as far as food is concerned, food will indeed help keep that social bond linked between consumers  and their environment. The other day, somebody asked me whether from home sitting on your sofa, using your  mobile phone or smartphone, whether you could actually order from anywhere, all products at the best price. Y es,  it is possible. How long? We might die before that, but I don't know. But I believe that physical trade will be  profitable in the future provided – and that's the challenge because there are pressures in terms of efficiency,  because the digital world is very efficient because there is no contact between people and the product, but we have  to be humane in our approach. And this, indeed, is what we are doing at Carrefour. If we keep food in our DNA,  then we will win the game.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We'll talk about China later. China, despite the trouble because of the transformation the country is actually going  through, is leading a low-cost manufacturing business and moving towards added value activities, focusing more  on the environment. And at the same time, we – they try to have domestic consumption pickup. And this means  that the fresh produce in Carrefour and the fresh food offering in China is developing and expanding. It will take  time, but it is working. So, we are multi-format in China, too, because we have Easy, which is the word we chose  locally for convenience local stores.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And so, if we do focus on food, then this is the basis of our global development. This is the first stage, the first step,  and we need to consolidate the physical foundations of our business. Y ou cannot change the rest. If you get – if we  get closer to our consumers with physical local stores, we have cut the distance, we have customized the services,  and this, in turn, means we can be a – we can help cut carbon emissions and we talked about that earlier.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Henceforth, we're working in a global business where the issues at stake in terms of image, in terms of corporate  responsibility, in terms of environmental issues, but also in terms of tax issues, economic issues, social issues, are  all enormous. So, it's important that we should raise the level of understanding of our management staff. That, I  think, is the major task that lies ahead of us.

file: CA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 9March2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: As I said earlier, Carrefour has been anticipating for years the main trends in consumptions. Sometimes, we were  too far ahead with organic, but it's now a signature for the group's positioning. It was also the case for the food  value change that we revitalize everywhere we are.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: The growing demand for quality requires that we have a very stringent approach, but also an ability to  communicate and educate customers also show transparency about our products. The new diets that we can see  emerge in every country whatever the economic or consumption maturity levels point towards vegetarian diet.  Everywhere, food consumption seems to be declining in volume, but customers' aspirations are to carry on  consuming meat with higher quality. We can see gluten-free, homemade flexitarian locavores. There are so many  terms that show that consumers are very demanding about their food and that, of course, is line with an ambition  for wellbeing.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We hear people recommend that we reduce the surface area in our hypermarkets that maybe the case in some  places. But it's, for me, that's not at all the way forward. And freeing up surface areas too violently in  hypermarkets to recycle them for additional shop space around hypermarkets, although now we are in a world  close to overcapacity, this is not the right solution. It may be a trendier solution. It maybe opportunistic in certain  areas, but it's not a structural solution for hypermarket.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: The acquisition of specialist websites like Rue du Commerce, or Greenweez, or Croquetteland, the development  of [indiscernible] (25:52), all that contributes to accelerating e-commerce, which will now irrigate all of our physical  formats and create Carrefour's own ecosystem.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: The other growth drivers for the future are new energy rejuvenation and re-energization for non-food that we want  to focus on fast-moving consumer goods in non-food and bring them closer to our convenience stores with  exclusive brands like Tex, but also now PASS, Klindo, Mandine in specific universes and they're now really  bearing fruit.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: This principle is now beginning to prove that it's on the right track. We have great management teams and they'll  carry on managing and steering this tool towards a brilliant future, and that's what I can say about Carrefour. I  could talk for probably too long about Carrefour. That's why I'll stop and give the floor to my friend, Pierre-Jean.

texts.speaker: Georges Plassat
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: And do not forget the role of CSR, which is very often seen as something superficial. But, in fact, the company is  adopting a more fundamental CSR policy because our societal and environmental responsibility is stronger and  stronger. We are being scrutinized and monitored. And so, it's fundamental to abide by these principles.  Therefore, by doing so, we'll make our mission easier to make high-quality food affordable for all by protecting the  environment and protecting our social equilibrium.

file: CA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 28February2018 1215 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-18.pdf
CA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 28February2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: A year ago, one could be entitled to doubt the ability of Carrefour to face up to such a challenge. One year after, it  is, in fact, that Carrefour has been able to call into question a lot of fundamentals to pursue a large range of  structuring actions and to start [ph] learning (00:01:33). You will remember that we did set for ourselves two large  ambitions by 2022, to become the only channel reference for our customers and to be the global leaders for food  transition. To achieve that, we have one demand to make our economic model more healthy. I've had the  opportunity a month ago to share with you the results for 2018, I'm not going to return to that. I'd like to share with  you three main objectives that we've been able to achieve into the last year.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: The first one on food transition. We did preempt a leading position, a promising position a year ago when we did  set ourselves the objective to become the world leader for food transition for all. It was only one ambition and in  under one year, we've been able to take into stride this objective across the world. First of all, Act for Food was  the first time that a retailer is committed across the world or global campaign towards food quality anywhere  across the world and across our stores, online, our customers have understood and perceived that Carrefour was  leading a new battle.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: Each country has taken 20 commitments to [ph] privilege (00:02:55) the French organic products to get rid of  antibiotic treatment and pesticide. And now we are present on all future topics beyond food offering, to cut out  food waste, plastic packaging, and also for animal welfare. Under a period of one year, we have led a major  change for our leading brand name on all these topics. It is the sign that our topics have taken into stride this  ambition and being successful to transform and turn them into concrete results.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: We have set the ambition to achieve one-third of our turnover with the Carrefour brand by 2022 and, Carrefour  brand is going to be strongly revamped towards food quality, with 1,500 new products are rehandled or reviewed  in 2019. By the end of this year, we would have 1,000 Carrefour [ph] pure (00:09:35) products, organic products  and the range Carrefour Veggie that we'll provide and we'll offer two times more SKUs. We have decided also to  convert all our Carrefour baby products to organic baby products by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: First of all, it's not the same roof, the physical roof of our store must be cut and decreased for our customers,  group shopping faster. That's why we have decided to pick up the reduction of 100,000 square meters in France,  down to 400,000 square meters by 2022 at group level. Where the surface of stores is cut, the reach of  [indiscernible] (00:11:56) stores must grow at the same time to win new customers. It is the objective of opening  and expansion of drive stores and opening of pedestrian drive, but also the development of home deliveries from  hypermarkets and click-and-collect with collection within two hours. It is also the objective to expand for Sunday  shopping, with over 160 hypermarkets open on a Sunday morning by the end of 2019.

texts.speaker: Alexandre Bompard
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: In terms of proximity, we have three main objectives. We are going to increase our expansion target to 3,000  opening of stores, proximity stores by 2022 against 2,000 that we have planned in the plan. We are going to  strengthen our differentiation with innovations of formats and we're going to launch new format in 2019 namely on  the ready-to-eat or ready-consume segment. We are going to increase the development of our specialized or  dedicated formats, Carrefour Bio or Carrefour Organic, and I hope, very often, So bio, as well as the  internationalization of our digital offer with Greenweez and Planeta Huerto.

texts.speaker: Matthieu Malige
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Carrefour SA
texts.text: As you've understood, the powerful dynamics of transformation that started in 2018 and the results we obtained in  the macroeconomic context makes us trust in the relevance of the plan for 2022. We have reviewed a certain  number of key elements of our strategic plan: the simplification of assortments, with a reduction target which was  at 10% initially and which is now at 15%; reducing our surface by 400,000 square meters by 2022; over 3,000  new convenience stores to be opened and a savings scheme of €2.2 billion against €2 billion initially – €2.8 billion  of cost reduction plan, sorry; a transfer of non-strategic real estate assets; €500 million and €5 billion also of  revenues from organic products in 2022.

file: CABK - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 14May2010 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-May-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: My final remarks will be on Industrial assets. I will not go into all the details, but the most relevant  ideas. Gas Natural has a much better-than-expected quarter, with 10% in net profit. Also good  news is that the domestic gas and power demand had a recovery in that period. We remind you the  stability of the business with 60% regulated portion, and all gas supplies hedged for 2010. And we  also highlight the company has successfully delivered in three key aspects, which are synergies,  disposals and debt refinancing.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Regarding Repsol, net profit was up 30%, supported by rise in oil prices, but certainly the most  important thing to bear in mind is that the company has just presented a compelling four-year  strategic plan by which, A, the upstream will clearly be the future growth engine after this recent  two-year periods of very successful findings; B, the downstream investments already made will  represent a competitive advantage and will also represent an important increase in margin, which is  a very significant factor for Repsol results; and C, YPF is going to be one key asset from which  value has to be captured. All in all, will represent a future period for major opportunities in Repsol.  About Abertis and Telefónica, there’s a lot to say, but we’ll only highlight that, despite the domestic  situation, they continued growing in its bottom line, given its defenses and also its diversification.

file: CABK - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 29April2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-11.pdf
CABK - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 19April2012 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan María Nin Génova
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman & CEO, CaixaBank SA
texts.text: As far as reduction in terms of loan, the most important thing is in terms of percentage, the reduction of our  exposure to real estate developers, which is a reduction of 15.1%. Also, you can see the reduction of our exposure  to something which is real estate, which is ServiHabitat.

texts.speaker: Gonzalo Gortázar Rotaeche
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, CaixaBank SA
texts.text: If we look at the real estate developers' book and we go back to the beginning of the crisis, we have brought it  down now by 28% compared to around 7% for the system. We're obviously targeting further reductions and rapid  reductions in this portfolio.

texts.speaker: Gonzalo Gortázar Rotaeche
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, CaixaBank SA
texts.text: The impact of that €1.5 billion is on that green line, the 107 basis points, but that is more than offset by the fact  that deductions that we had that were being absorbed by this €5 billion of preferred stock are no longer absorbed  by the preferred stock, by that Tier 1, they come now directly to hit core capital.

texts.speaker: Gonzalo Gortázar Rotaeche
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, CaixaBank SA
texts.text: The good news is that as we're moving and transitioning from managing the bank on Basel II to Basel III is that  these deductions on a Basel III basis we were taking them in any case. So when you look at Basel III, we only have  the positive 107 basis points, the green bucket there. We do not have the negative of the deductions so that's why  our Basel III fully phased in at the end of this quarter, three quarters before even implementation, is now at  10.5%; obviously a very, very comfortable number for us.

file: CABK - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 25April2013 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan María Nin Génova
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, CaixaBank SA
texts.text: We have continued rightsizing efforts which are critical to improve profitability. So, in terms of branch reduction  plan, you can see how we are moving from the situation pre-Banca Cívica and Banco de Valencia, so 2011, from  5,200 branches to 5,700 branches at the end of this year. This means that we will incur in a 19% reduction of  branch network since 2011. 90% of this reduction is in core regions of Banco de Valencia and 50% in core regions  of Banca Cívica, 25% reduction since 2007, which includes Caixa Girona and Bankpyme.

file: CABK - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 24April2014 1100 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-14.pdf
CABK - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 23April2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-15.pdf

So, the two columns on the right here  and you can see the green circles. 6.3% up in NII, 11.6% up in fees, 72.8% in insurance. This is I think something  we are very happy with and shows that our activities actually delivering results that are sustainable and of high  quality.

file: CABK - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 27April2018 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-18.pdf
CABK - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 30April2019 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-19.pdf
CABK - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 30July2010 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Commissions were also up, so commercially speaking the company is doing very well. On the other  hand excellent cost management, despite the retail expansion, costs went down 16%, so also very  good news on that side. Net profit, finally, was lower, but this was mainly because of lower market  related income. The basic point here is the core business, the core operating business is  performing really well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I’ll move forward to the Industrial portfolio just to spend some time in Gas Natural Fenosa figures,  top – mean bottom line figures, as you can see, up. This includes the effect of Unión Fenosa  acquisition. So, in a pro forma basis, EBITDA is substantial 4% up. Worth to mention the recovery  in gas and power demand, both in Spain and especially in LatAm, which will be for sure more  sustainable.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Stable business performance; also important to remind you 60% regulated business almost totally  hedged for 2010 against gas demand, and I guess the pool price. This, together with the  diversification, the geographical diversification gives a lot of stability in the performance of the  company.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator

texts.speaker: Juan María Nin Génova
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Criteria CaixaCorp SA
texts.text: Finally, results benefit from, once again, cost reduction measures we have taken the year before, we have taken  during the first half of the year, and we will continue to take on the next quarters.

texts.speaker: Juan María Nin Génova
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Criteria CaixaCorp SA
texts.text: Finally, as a highlight, deterioration of real estate market leads to more conservative approach in the developer  book. We have insisted several times that we see the situation as a situation that comes into the market by waves.  We had the very first important wave. All those big developers you know perfectly well, and the earthquake is  provoking new movement. This part – this first part of 2011 has been the real fact on the second wave we have  announced. The small, medium size, very small developers are falling one after the other. And this is so, and this  has meant that in order to recognize the situation, as we did before, we have taken all kinds of measures in terms  of NPLs, et cetera, et cetera, and provisioning.

texts.speaker: Juan María Nin Génova
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Criteria CaixaCorp SA
texts.text: Of course, we are moving towards a better situation in terms of net interest income. Gonzalo Gortázar will  comment more on this. But net interest income has been clearly compensated by fees and  other income, so that, as I said, pre-impairment income is positive in terms of 1.3%.

texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: So a word about the environment, I would say, the crisis looks over. What do I mean with  wavering? I mean, I think it’s an upward trend, but with some oscillation. So we saw one in October  and November. We do not exclude that there will be more period of uncertainty, but there is a good  demand. Our customers are eager to reinvest in technology after a few years of diet. Of course,  their ability to commit on long-term projects strongly depend on the economical environment.  Today, it looks fine, but we will monitor it pretty tightly.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: Another effort will be expand even beyond the infrastructure place, what we call new business  model. We have set up now a true BU on Smart Energy. And based on some acquisitions like  Skvader, we will grow the scope of service around Smart Energy. There will be other parts of IBX is  BPO service, but the rest is SaaS services. So you will see us showing ambition in what I call new  business model. This does not mean that we will stop doing our historical efforts, so a clear  differentiation for the Group is its consulting arm. We will invest in consulting, both in content and  possibly some acquisition to complete our map of consulting skills.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: But the rest of Outsourcing in the UK is growing fast at 14%, thanks to contacts we signed at EDF,  Environment Agency, House of Fraser, Anglian Water and so forth. Systems Integration in the UK,  plus 4% and it’s practically only on the back of financial services, with RBS, HSBC, FSA and so  forth.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: Prices. So prices also show a pattern of stability. Here and there we have some green shoots. And,  as Paul said, overall we are in a mood now at the beginning of 2011 to continue to anticipate  something like plus 1% on prices, which will be at the same time the consequence of the quality of  the market and also the quality of our productivity efforts because, as you know, the under-runs are  embedded in our price KPI. If we look at Technology Services, you have a decline of prices, which  is the consequence of our massive move to offshore. But onshore still in 2010, we have a decline of  minus 2.2%. texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: All these are, I would say, the classical levels, on top of which I add two. One is the fact that the  prices should increase by 1%. And another one is that if we manage well the way we operate and  the supply chain, the utilization ratio of Capgemini should increase a little bit.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: Let me start at the top with the top-line initiatives which we introduced in 2010. And if you’ll  remember there were five of them. Application lifecycle services which has now evolved into the  two Apps businesses, business information management, infrastructure transformation services  which has been now tucked underneath and combined with the infrastructure outsourcing to allow  us to design, build and run, testing, and smart energy services.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: We’ll continue to evolve those in 2010 and you’ve already seen two this year introduced. You saw a  Master Data Management campaign as a subset of Business Information Management, and an  extension of our Smart Energy offering into the home, the meters inside the house. And so those  are two offers and we’ll continue to come up with additional campaigns to support the top-line  initiatives.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: An example that I would like to highlight is what occurred last year in the metering area. We had a  very strong asset, so this would be the purple portion there of the offers inventory. We had a very  strong asset of the utilities that we were servicing in Canada. We were servicing four major utilities  in Canada. By taking that we packaged it into the smart energy solution top-line initiative at the  beginning of the year, which allowed us to take those qualifications, take those solutions, take that  knowledge management and apply it to utilities throughout the world.

texts.speaker: Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this call on our full year results and hopefully some ambition
texts.text: To help accelerate that we identified a software company in the Nordics called Skvader which gave  us a proprietary solution of how to manage meters which accelerates our ability and improves the  margin by having this software, which in a matter of six months we became the number one player  in the Nordics, having the most meters under management of anybody, 1.3 million meters under  management. So in a very short six-month period we came from nowhere to the number one player  in the Nordics region in smart energy services.

file: CARL.B - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 17August2011 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Jørgen Buhl Rasmussen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: The efficiency agenda remains a high priority and during 2011, we have started the implementation of some large  projects, which would be in total levers in the Carlsberg journey towards becoming a more modern FMCG  company.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Buhl Rasmussen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: In addition, weather conditions in Q2 were unexpectedly poor, so consequently, the Russian beer market declined  by 1% for the first six months, with a 2% decline for Q2. Aside from Russia, most other markets in the group were  on plan. The overall Northern and Western European market grew slightly for the first six months and the Asian  beer markets continued their overall growth trend.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Buhl Rasmussen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: Let's now turn to the regions, and begin with Northern and Western Europe on slide six. The overall Northern and  Western European markets grew slightly for the first six months, with variation between markets. The growth was  supported by favorable weather conditions in some markets. Again, we managed to grow our market share for the  region. The gains are driven by our intensified commercial focus, including product launches.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Buhl Rasmussen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: Based on our analysis of consumer behavior and revising our pricing models and sensitivity analysis, we conclude  that the substantial consumer price increases taken from November 2009 of around 30% has delayed the market  recovery, as consumers need more time to fully adjust. In addition, weather conditions were particularly weak in  Q2.

texts.speaker: Jørn Peter Jensen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy CEO, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: The efficiency agenda is still ongoing and we have started the roll out of some large group projects. The Business  Standardisation program was implemented in May in our Swiss business and will be implemented in more  European markets. SKU harmonization is another important lever in our efficiency efforts. During the six months,  we started the rollout in the Nordic countries.

texts.speaker: Jørn Peter Jensen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy CEO, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: And now to slide 15, please, for the income statement. As you can see in the table, organic net sales increased by  DKK2.2 billion or 8%. We have been through the organic revenue development, so I'll move onto gross profit.  COGS were impacted quite significantly by higher input costs, barley in Eastern Europe in particular and COGS  per hectoliter increased by 6%, in line with our expectations.

texts.speaker: Jørn Peter Jensen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy CEO, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: Consequently, we have revised our market expectations for Russia down this year from previously 2% to 4%  growth to now a low single-digit Russian market decline. It is primarily the lower Russian gross profit from  reduced volumes has filtered through to operating profits and reduced our expectations for Russia for the year. In  our outlook, we have also included the poor weather conditions in many Northern and Western European markets  in July, which we are mitigating through accelerated efficiency improvements.  Our outlook does not take into account any significant change into consumer sentiment caused by a further  deterioration in the macroeconomic environment. We will continuously evaluate the development per market to  be able to take necessary actions and adjust our investments in sales and marketing, if consumer sentiment so  requires. Hence, we have reduced our operating profit expectations with operating profit now expected to be  around DKK10 billion compared to last year's DKK10.25 billion. Net reserve outlook has been adjusted  accordingly and we now expect an adjusted net profit growth of 5% to 10%. Jørgen, please.

texts.text: Please turn to slide three. Overall market development was mixed between regions. Eastern Europe grew modestly, driven by our Russian market that  grew by an estimated 2%.

texts.speaker: Jørgen Buhl Rasmussen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: The UK market declined 5% in Q2 and, therefore, around 3% for the first six months, with the poor weather more  than offsetting the Jubilee and the European Championship. Mainly driven by strong performance in on-trade,  our market share improved by 70 basis points to 17% in the UK.

texts.speaker: Jørn Peter Jensen
texts.profession: CFO & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: The very positive cash flow from real estate was the proceeds from the sale of the brewery site in Copenhagen,  which had a positive cash flow effect of DKK1.9 billion. All in all, free cash flow was DKK2.6 billion, up DKK1.7  billion from last year.  And then to slide 18 and our outlook. Overall, we keep our earnings outlook unchanged for the year, but have  made some underlying adjustments reflecting the significant negative weather impact in Northern and Western  Europe in Q2 and July, and the positive impact from the euro-ruble exchange rate.

texts.text: On supply chain efficiency, we have specific programs and targets for production, material costs, logistics and  savings from specification changes. texts.text: Finally, although the ban of PET of more than 0.5 liter does not come into effect until January 1, 2017, we will stop  the sale of the above 0.5 liter PET already in Q4.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: With respect to SAIL'22, we are accelerating our investments in our strategic priorities in order to strengthen our  core business and change the growth profile of the group. texts.speaker: Cees ‘t C. Hart
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: To mention a few of the targets, we're going to reduce water consumption in our breweries by 50%. We want to  be CO2 neutral by 2030. And already by 2022, we target 100% use of renewable electricity at our breweries.

texts.speaker: Cees ‘t C. Hart
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Carlsberg A/S
texts.text: Profitability improved significantly, driven by solid price/mix and tight cost control. Our Russian volumes were  severely impacted by the PET downsizing. In response to this  significant change in the marketplace, we adopted a value-based approach to drive further value in the market.

texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]
texts.text: Looking at the organizational health of the business, we are also moving in the right direction. Our  competencies in areas such as commercial finance, supply chain, digital and data have strengthened. texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]
texts.text: The brand also grew in several markets in Western Europe such as Denmark, Norway, Serbia and Bulgaria, as  well as in the Turkish license market. The new  looks and the number of sustainability improvements have been launched in Norway, Finland, Sweden, Denmark,  and the UK, and will be rolled out across other Carlsberg markets such as China, India, Malaysia, and many more  during 2019.

texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]
texts.text: The roll-out of the DraughtMaster system continued, supporting the availability of our craft & speciality portfolio in  the on-trade. The system is available in all Western European countries and the process of converting all steel  keg installations in the Nordic markets is well underway and expected to be finalized within the next two to three  years. In 2018, we increased the number of DraughtMaster installations by approximately 35%.

texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]
texts.text: Slide 6 had a few comments on our sustainability efforts, which are driven by our sustainability program, Together  Towards ZERO. We have four ambitious sustainability targets being zero carbon footprint, zero water waste, zero  irresponsible drinking, and zero accident culture. For each of these ambitions, we have defined clear, measurable  and sign-based targets for 2022 and 2030, all measured against a 2015 baseline.

texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]
texts.text: In 2018, we continued our efforts to achieve the targets. Our sustainability report will be released later today, and  it contains a wealth of information on our progress. Let me briefly touch upon two of the areas. Our ambition for  CO2 emissions is to reduce this at our breweries by 50% in 2022 and reach zero by 2030. Compared to the 2015  baseline, we have reduced emissions by 20%. Our brewery in Sweden became the first brewery in the group to  run on 100% renewable energy and all our breweries in Western Europe now run on 100% renewable electricity.

texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]
texts.text: Water usage is another important area for us as we have reduced our water usage by 9% per hectoliter compared  to the 2015 baseline, taking us down to 3.1 hectoliter. In among the most water efficient breweries in the world,  but we still have some way to go to reach our target.

texts.speaker: [081MJM-E Cees 't Hart]

We saw good performance for the Carlsberg brand, speciality products  and alcohol-free brews while Tuborg Green declined due to price increases.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola Hellenic Bottling Co. SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Volume in the water category declined by 8% in the quarter, mainly resulting from lower sales in Ukraine, Greece  and Italy. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Turning now to each of our reporting segments. Overall, macroeconomic conditions continue to be challenging in  the established markets segment. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Volume continued to decline in Greece. Unemployment reached new record levels of 27% and is expected to  increase further. texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: We maintained value share in both sparkling beverages and the overall non-alcoholic ready-to-drink category. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
