texts.text: Turning to input costs. Comparable currency-neutral input cost per case declined by 3.8% in the half year, in line  with our expectations. The key drivers for the decline were lower resin and sugar prices driven by lower oil prices  and some well-timed pre-buys.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let me add some more color on the phasing of the input costs in the year. In the first half, we had a continuing  benefit from the favorable input cost environment in late 2015 and the execution of several pre-buys early this  year for the first half. However, we do expect that in the second half of the year, our currency-neutral input cost  per case will increase due to the following factors. First, the impact of the growing world sugar prices on our  unhedged exposures in the remainder of the year. Second, the anticipated improved sparkling mix this summer  compared to prior year. Third, the cycling of the low oil prices in the second half of last year, which will be  reflected in our resin prices. Taking all this into account, we continue to anticipate input cost per case on a  currency-neutral basis to marginally increase in the full year.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking at the volume growth by country, the key drivers were Nigeria, Romania and Poland. In the Established  markets, volume declined by 2.8%. Volume declines were experienced across almost all geographies and in  particular, Italy and Ireland partly impacted by poor weather and weak performances in most categories except  from Energy.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Italy, performance was partly impacted by weather. Key driver of the decline was Sparkling, down by low-single  digits. Good performance from Coke Zero and Fanta, supported by Coke Life only partially offset the decline in  brand Coca-Cola. Water decline was driven by the delisting of smaller brands, excluding this impact, Water grew  by more than 3%. Energy also grew well capitalizing on the distribution expansion for Monster.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Sparkling, a decline in trademark Coca-Cola was partly offset by a 3.3% growth in Coke Zero and strong  growth in Energy. Macroeconomic and trading environment remains challenging. Switzerland performance was  impacted by a wet weather, leading to a low-single digit decline in volumes. Growth in Energy only partly offset  declines across all other categories. Coke Zero and brand Coca-Cola also performed well.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Energy category remained on its growth trajectory with growth from both Burn and Monster, reflecting the strength  of our dual-brand Energy strategy. Juice volumes increased by low-single digits helped by the growth of Cappy.  Our focus on increasing single-serve contribution delivered results, with package mix improved by 1.4 percentage  points in the first half.

file: CCHL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 10August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: PET resin prices were up year-on-year, driven by higher oil prices. Our extensive pre-buy program mitigated  these increases, driving total resin costs flattish year-on-year. The growing contribution of finished goods  purchases in the mix pushed total input cost per case higher in the period.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Water grew by 0.7%, driven by strong performances in Italy, Switzerland and Nigeria. In Russia and Poland,  volumes suffered from the cooler weather, and in the case of Poland, the shift to a smaller package size as part of  our revenue growth management strategy.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Energy is a strategically important growth category, and therefore, the 17.6% increase is particularly pleasing.  The strong trend we have seen in recent years continues, as we build Monster volumes, which grew by 34.6%  organically. Including new market launches, Monster volume demonstrated 43.2% growth.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Turning now to the reporting segments and some of the big markets in each segment. Established markets  volume increased by 1% in the half with growth in the majority of our countries. Water and Energy were the  growth drivers, more than offsetting declines in Sparkling, Juice and Ready-to-Drink tea.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Volumes declined in Italy by low single digits in the period, although the second quarter was much stronger than  the first. It's good to see the Water strategy we implemented in 2016 delivering, with high single-digit growth in  volume and improved net sales revenue per case.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Energy continued to grow well, with good performance in Monster. Sparkling declined overall, as the growth in  Coke Zero was more than offset by declines in Coke Regular and Light. Volume in Greece grew by mid single  digits in the first half, a very good performance driven by Sparkling, Water and Energy. Sparkling growth was  driven by Coke Zero and the introduction of Coca-Cola with Stevia and zero calories at the end of March.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: In Poland, we saw wet weather in the second quarter and a weak NARTD market, which impacted our volumes  negatively. Despite this, we recovered most of the volume we had lost in the first quarter and finished the period  with a low single-digit decline. Sparkling volume grew driven by a strong performance by Coke Zero and Fanta  following the launch of new flavors. Energy maintained its robust performance.

file: CCHL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 9August2018 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: We delivered a strong set of results in the first half, as the evolution of our portfolio gathers pace. Our new  categories, flavors, reformulations, and packages, are gaining traction across our markets, with 34 million cases  of volume in the first half, representing 3.2% of our volume. These new product launches and tailored commercial  activation enabled us to capitalize on favorable weather conditions and the FIFA World Cup.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: PET prices did increase in the first half of the year, in line with higher oil prices. However, with careful  management and certain well-timed pre-buys, we secured better pricing than market spot rates. Aluminum saw  rate increases in the first half of the year, but with good management of contracts and favorable hedges, we have  minimized the impact.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: We also have a 40 basis point headwind from one-off costs. These include increased environmental fees, sugar  tax, our investment into the redesign of our revenue growth management framework, partly offset by the positive  impact of the Croatian bad debt that we talked about.

file: CCHL - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 7November2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Looking at the key components, higher EU sugar and PET prices were partly offset by lower world sugar and  aluminium prices in the quarter. We have covered fully our sugar requirements in the EU, Russia, and Nigeria for  the remainder of the year. At the same time, we have fully covered our aluminium requirements.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: In Poland, volume grew across most of our key categories, with the exception of water and energy, both of which  declined by high-single digits. Sparking beverages grew by low-single digit, driven by Trademark Coca-Cola  products. Juice grew by strong double digit for a third consecutive quarter as a result of our successful switch from  Tetra to 1-liter packages.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Coca-Cola Zero continued its double-digit growth in the third quarter. Energy continued its solid performance,  supported by recent launches of Burn Blue and Monster Rehab. We increased our volume shares in the sparking  category during this quarter.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: As a final remark, this quarter we celebrated two key milestones. Our inclusion in the Dow Jones Sustainability  Index for the sixth consecutive year ranking first in Europe and second in the world in the beverages sector as well  as our inclusion in the FTSE 100 and the FTSE All-Share indices, which we believe will benefit our shareholders  through the enhanced liquidity.

file: CCHL - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 6November2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to input cost. Currency-neutral input cost per case declined by 3% in the quarter and by 4% in the nine  months. The key drivers for this decline were lower EU and world sugar costs in line with expectations, as well as  sustained favorable PET pricing, which more than offset marginally higher aluminum costs in the quarter. Given  the increased visibility for PET price for the remainder of the year, we still expect the full year currency-neutral  input cost per case decline to be towards the upper end of the low-single digit range.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Water performance was mixed, with growth in Nigeria and Greece more than offset by the impact of weather and  our continued focus on cutting unprofitable SKUs in the Developing markets, where single-serve increased by 4  percentage points in the mix. As a result, Water volume decreased by 5% in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Greece, our performance continued to improve, helped by increased tourist traffic in the summer period. Water  was the key growth driver, while Trademark Coca-Cola products also turned positive following several quarters of  double-digit decline. Looking ahead, we are encouraged by the good Q3 performance, but we are also mindful of  the fact that the underlying conditions remain challenging. The environment is characterized by near-record high  unemployment levels of 26%, and the political landscape remains fragile.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Switzerland, volumes declined by mid-teens, cycling a strong summer quarter in the prior year. Adverse  weather conditions resulted in negative volume across all categories. Although Sparkling was the main  underperformer, we gained share in volume and value in the category. Package mix improved in both the  Sparkling and the Water categories, driven by our OBPPC initiatives.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Performance in Hungary remains volatile, with volumes declining by mid-single digits in the third quarter and- low single digits for the first nine months. Increased competitive pressure and adverse weather conditions  negatively impacted volume performance, particularly in Sparkling and Water. Coca-Cola Zero continued double- digit growth, while Energy maintained the positive trend, reflecting the strong performance of our new product  and flavor launches. Juice was a key incremental growth driver, helped by the positive impact of Cappy Pulpy.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Volume decline in the Czech Republic was mainly driven by our strategic decision to focus on value-accretive  volume and, to a lesser extent, by increased competitive pressure, lower promotional activity and adverse weather  conditions. Package mix improved by 2.8 percentage points in the quarter, driven by increased distribution of  single-serve packages in the Sparkling beverages category.

file: CCHL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 14February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Turning to input costs, currency-neutral input costs per case grew by 1.6% in the fourth quarter and 0.9% in the  full year, in line with our previous guidance of low single-digit year-over-year growth in 2015. Looking at the key  quarter four drivers, higher EU sugar costs, as well increased PET and sparkling contribution in the mix, more  than offset lower world sugar and aluminum prices, and once again, our revenue growth initiatives enabled us to  fully offset total input costs in absolute terms.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: We expect a stable input cost environment for 2014, with currency-neutral input costs per case remaining broadly  flat year-over-year. Within this, increased PET prices and higher aluminum total costs are expected to offset lower  average sugar prices.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: In Czech, the volumes declined by mid-single digits predominantly driven by declines in water. Coca-Cola Zero  grew by strong double digits, while energy grew by mid-single digits reflecting the strong performance of Burn.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Trademark Coca-Cola products grew by 12% while water grew by strong double digits, supported by our new PET  capacity. We continue to execute on our strategy in the country, focusing on expanding further distribution and  volume per outlet of our core brands, driving availability across the board, and finally, selective introducing  OBPPC initiatives.

file: CCHL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 18February2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to input cost. Currency-neutral input cost per case declined by 7.2% in the quarter and by 4.8% in the full  year, slightly better than our expectations. The key drivers for the decline were lower EU and world sugar costs in  line with our expectations, as well as better than expected resin prices, which followed the sharp decline in oil  prices as the year progressed.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Taking the scenario of further FX deterioration, firstly, to the extent that this deterioration is linked to oil prices,  this will have a positive impact on our input costs, mainly resin. In addition, in the medium-term, lower oil prices  are expected to positively impact the economies and the disposable income of many of our European countries,  supporting our top-line performance.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Water in the fourth quarter grew by 1%, helped by positive contribution from Greece, Austria and Poland, taking  the full year decline to 2%. In a year that was impacted by continued SKU rationalization in some of our big  markets, our strategy delivered 2% growth in Water single-serve packages with package mix improving by 1.6  percentage points.

file: CCHL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 19February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to input cost. FX-neutral input cost per case declined by 9% in the full year, in line with our expectations.  The key drivers for the decline were mostly lower EU and world sugar prices, as well as improved PET resin prices,  which are correlated to the declining oil prices.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning now to 2016 and the volatility we have experienced so far in the year. Let me walk you through an  analysis with regard to the impact of oil prices on input costs and foreign exchange, two key drivers of our  financial performance.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Oil prices are fairly closely correlated with resin prices, which account for approximately 8% of our cost of goods  sold. In addition, oil prices impact the currency exchange rates of major oil exporting countries, in our case,  predominantly the Russian ruble.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As you will appreciate, for any given oil price movement, the resin price and the ruble exchange rate move in  opposite directions, thus, providing to some extent a natural hedge to each other, albeit not one-for-one. The ruble  rate has a greater impact than the resin price movement.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In our example, we have depicted the year-on-year impact of FX and input costs on EBIT from a $30 oil price  movement from current spot prices. This chart is not to scale, but it shows the following. At the current oil price  and FX spot rates, we expect a €135 million negative FX impact on the P&L versus prior year, as well as a low- single-digit growth in input cost per case. This is the left-hand side of the chart and this is the scenario for which  we have built our actions for the year.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: If the oil price were to move $30 higher today and stay there for the remainder of the year, we would expect an  €80 million negative FX impact on the P&L versus prior year, as well as a mid-single-digit growth in input cost  per case. This is the right-hand side of the graph. Therefore, in this example, a $30 oil price increase generates a  €20 million relief versus the total P&L impact estimated at the current spot rates.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: This natural hedging mechanism between FX and resin costs that I described ensures that oil price swings either  side of the current spot rate scenario generate relatively small-size impacts to EBIT, relief if the oil price increases  or hit if the oil price reduces from current spot levels. In other words, we have prepared for the current  challenging spot rate scenario and expect that any oil price upside will generate a small benefit to the bottom line.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In conclusion, we expect to continue on the volume growth trajectory of 2015, accelerate the FX neutral NSR per  case growth to pre-2015 levels and deliver cost improvements. Driving these three pillars ensures top-line growth  and profit margin expansion in 2016. The successful execution of our mitigation strategy in 2015 gives us  confidence that we can deal with the 2016 headwinds as well.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Water grew by 5% in the year, demonstrating good performance in most of our countries, particularly Ukraine,  Poland and Romania. Additional investments behind our brands and promo intensity in the markets with  affordability concerns were key drivers along with the good weather in Q3.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Sparkling beverage category was the main growth driver in the segment, supported by Water and, to a lesser  extent, by Juice. In Poland, volume increased by 7% in the year. We saw good performances across most of our  categories with Sparkling beverages growing by 7% driven by good results in the organized trade. Still beverages  also grew by 7%, driven by Water performance.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: At current oil price levels, input costs are expected to be a low-single-digit headwind in the year, mainly driven by  world sugar. Taking into account our hedge positions and the current spot rates, the adverse impact on EBIT from  foreign currency would be in the region of €135 million for the full year. Our actions in cost management are  expected to result in a significant reduction in operating expenses as percentage of net sales revenue, supporting  EBIT margin growth.

file: CCHL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 16February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Turning to input cost, currency-neutral input cost per case was broadly stable in the full year. EU and Russian  sugar prices, which we had contracted at favorable levels at the end of 2015, were offset by increased PET resin  prices, closely correlated to rising oil prices in the year.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Within the category, Trademark Coca-Cola increased by 0.7% with a 6% increased in Coke Zero and  approximately 5% uplift in Fanta and Schweppes. In Juice, growth in Developing did not offset declines in  Emerging and Established, ending the year down 3%. Water volume declined by 2%, impacted by cycling the hot  summer in 2015, as well as the delisting of certain low value brands in Italy.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Turning now to our performance by segment and focusing on some of the bigger countries. In our Established  market segment, volume declined by 2.3% in the year, mainly as a result of lower Water and Sparkling. 2016  performance had benefited from particularly good Water volumes in a hot summer. In Italy, volumes declined by  3% in a challenging market condition with ongoing depressed consumer sentiment.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: The launch of Coca-Cola Life and Monster in the market as well as good performance by Coke Zero and Fanta  helped slow the decline in Sparkling category, which was down nearly 2%. Water was negatively impacted by our  strategic decision earlier in the year to delist mainly low value Water brands. Excluding these low value Water  brands, Water volumes increased by low-single digits. We were pleased to improve our single-serve mix in the  year as a result of our OBPPC actions especially in Sparkling.

texts.speaker: Dimitris Lois
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: At current commodity price levels, input costs are expected to be high-single digit headwind in the year, mainly  driven by resin and higher oil prices. Taking into account our hedge position and current spot rates, the adverse  impact on EBIT from foreign currency is expected to abate to the levels of around €15 million for the full year.

file: CCHL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 14February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Turning to input costs, currency-neutral input cost per case was down by 1.4% compared to the prior year, slightly  better than our latest guidance which we had revised downwards as the year unfolded. The main driver for the  input cost improvement was sugar where we achieved rates that represent a high teens percentage decline  compared to the prior year. PET prices did increase in the year in line with higher oil prices. Aluminium saw rate  increases, but with good management of contracts, favorable hedges, and light-weighting, we minimized the  impact.

texts.speaker: Michalis Imellos
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: We also have a 30 basis points headwind from one-off costs. These include increased environmental fees, sugar  tax, our investment into the redesign of our revenue growth management framework, partly offset by the positive  impact of the Croatian bad debt we have talked about.

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Within our Still drinks portfolio, Water increased by 3.2% in the full year with positive results in all segments. We  are continuing to grow volume, but our focus is on growing volume and value in a balanced way in this category.  The successful launch of GLACÉAU smartwater in ten of our markets in April is only one initiative that helps that  strategy. Juice was up by 0.3% in the year with the Developing segment being the main driver of the result. We  have plans to continue growing this category which has suffered in the last three years.

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: In Poland, volume increased by 10% backed by good economic growth and higher disposable income. All  categories apart from ready-to-drink tea grew. Sparkling was up by 8%, driven by Coca-Cola Regular, followed by  Coca-Cola Zero and Fanta. Energy continued to deliver excellent results with volumes increasing by 67% in the  full year with Monster volumes supported by promo activations as well as Zero variants and new flavors. Water  saw a 24% increase as the result of the water trade plan to support the category at an attractive price point which  we started early in the year.

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Water, Juice, and Energy delivered positive results offset by Sparkling. As we look ahead, I can say that having  made further changes to our price/pack architecture in the fourth quarter; we saw encouraging results from the  business in December and January.

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: 2018 was an important year for our sustainability agenda. Having delivered excellent results in most of our 2020  sustainability target and having achieved two important 2020 targets ahead of time, we introduced new and  ambitious commitments to be met by 2025. These include bold targets and initiatives on packaging, recycling,  water reduction, youth empowerment, and gender balance.

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: We also signed up to the Coca-Cola Company's World Without Waste program. We are particularly proud to have  ranked among the top beverage companies in the Dow Jones Sustainability Global and European Indices for the  past five years, and our new 2025 commitments underscore our ambition to remain a leader in this area.  Sustainability is deeply embedded in our corporate DNA and purpose. For us, it is not just about what we achieve,  but also how we achieve it.

texts.speaker: Zoran Bogdanovic
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Coca-Cola HBC AG
texts.text: Our vision, strategy execution and achievement of our commitments are simply impossible without our people.  Therefore, nurturing the potential and supporting the development of our people is our passion and a key driver of  our sustainable growth. I would like to thank our people for their hard work, passion and dedication to deliver on  our operational and financial targets, sustainability commitments and, ultimately, our medium-term strategic plan.

file: CCLL - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 23March2010 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The strength of our revenue and cost performance in the first quarter 2010 was clearly masked by  rising fuel prices. Fuel prices this quarter were 80% higher than last year and that cost us an  additional $176 million or $0.22 per share. However as a result of our ongoing efforts to reduce fuel  consumption, I’m happy to report that our fuel consumption per ALBD declined 3.1% in the first  quarter, continuing our multiple year savings trend.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Turning to our 2010 outlook. I’ll skip the net revenue yields as Howard will discuss that shortly. texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We're wrapping up our planning process, which has me very excited about our business going forward. Fuel and  environmental related investments will temporarily impact our cost progress, primarily in 2015. Frankly, I'm  personally impatient to realize even stronger results more quickly, but it is clearly in all of our best interest to  make the investments in environmental stewardship and energy-saving technology that we are planning for next  year. Not only do we view sustainability as a core guiding principle, these one-off expenses next year will yield  financial benefits to us for many years to come.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As you know, higher fuel prices had a meaningful impact on our business model accounting for a 5  point reduction  in return on invested capital to-date. Without mitigation, the impending ECA requirements were originally  expected to have further $0.35 reduction on earnings when effective in 2015. We plan to aggressively rollout our  new technology developed over the last three years limiting the cost impact of ECA to approximately $0.10 in  2015, and virtually eliminating any impact whatsoever by 2017 while protecting the environment.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: At the same time, we have a series of technology initiatives in progress related to energy efficiency in areas like  propulsion, lighting, and air conditioning to name a few that we will continue to rollout during the resulting  accelerated drydock schedule. These initiatives have a quick payback period as we continue to stead ily reduce fuel  consumption in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: It is gratifying to say we have reduced our fuel consumption by another 5% this year and 25% since 2007, meeting  our stated goal of delivering a 20% reduction in carbon emissions ahead of schedule while sa ving more than 1  billion gallons of fuel and $2.5 billion of fuel cost during that period. This efficiency improvement is a testament to  the breadth of efforts undertaken to reduce consumption onboard the existing fleet and the energy efficient  advances that have been designed into the new ships delivered during this time period.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Having completed our planning meetings with all our brands for 2015, the cost picture is taking shape. As we  indicated in the press release, we expect net cruise cost per available lower berth day to be up around 3% for 2015.  The majority of the increase is due to significantly higher drydock days in 2015, as we're working hard  to  accomplish a number of things: First, installing exhaust gas cleaning systems, or EGCs, more commonly known as  scrubbers, which will reduce the impact of the new 2015 ECA requirements. Second, installing new fuel efficiency  technology to reduce fuel consumption. And third, completing the vessel enhancements we announced last year.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: As we look further out to 2016, we expect that the majority of the higher drydock costs in 2015 will be reversed  since we currently anticipate a lower level of drydock days in 2016. I'm pleased to report that the various cost  initiatives that we're working on for 2015 and beyond are beginning to take shape and are expected to completely  offset inflation in 2015. However, we won't rest there. Over the years, we've developed an excellent track record of  cost control and we'll continue to focus on leveraging our scale and reduce costs further in 2015 and beyond.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: As Arnold indicated, we are aggressively rolling out the EGCs on our ships. The current schedule calls for EGCs to  be installed on 16 ships before the beginning of fiscal year 2015 and 42 ships are expected to have commissioned  EGCs by the end of fiscal year 2015. We expect these efforts to mitigate the vast majority of the impact from the  new ECA requirements.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: As we indicated in the press release, we currently estimate that the new requirements will cost us about $0.10 in  2015. Going forward, we expect about half of this to disappear in 2016 and the remainder should just about  disappear in 2017 as the result of the installation of EGCs on additional ships.

texts.text: In the first half, our brands generated 75% of the entire cruise industry's positive coverage. Fathom and Cuba are clearly  garnering a lot of attention, generating over 18 billion media impressions from our corporation since the brand  launch.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Concerning sustainability, just last week, we published our sustainability goals. We continue to reduce our  environmental footprint as evidenced by our 2% fuel consumption reduction in the third quarter, and remain on  track for a 2% consumption reduction this year.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: These ships will be the most efficient in our fleet and have the largest guest capacity in the world through  innovative design comfortably accommodating up to 6,600 guests. texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As we discussed on previous conference calls, we increased our capital expenditures for a variety of vessel  enhancement projects and exhaust gas cleaning systems to meet the [ph] eco (18:27) requirements without having  to utilize a more expensive fuel grade. We have made excellent progress on both these areas and most aspects of  these investments are expected to be completed by the end of 2016. With the increase in using capital investments  as well as new ship deliveries, we expect depreciation expense to be $1.8 billion in 2016, approximately $0.20  higher than 2015. We experienced a similar trend in 2015, but it was ultimately masked by currency movement.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Despite the lower price of fuel, we remain committed to continuing fuel consumption reduction. Given the timing  of our investments in this area, we expect fuel consumption on a unit basis to decline 1% to 2% for 2016. Lastly, at  the current spot prices for fuel, we expect a $0.20 benefit in 2016. However, we do expect this will be partially  offset by the stronger U.S. dollar which will cost us approximately $0.10 based on current FX rates most of which  will impact the first half of 2016.

texts.text: In addition, over the same four-year period, we will deliver just one ship each for Holland America Lines, Costa in  Southern Europe, P&O in the UK, and P&O in Australia. texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Carnival Plc
texts.text: Additionally, we launched the initial phase of our yield management system this quarter, helping us drive  incremental revenue yield over time. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Chief Accounting Officer, Carnival Plc

At this point in  time, cumulative advanced bookings for the first half of 2019 are ahead of the prior year at prices that are in line.

texts.text: As a result of our ongoing efforts to reduce fuel usage, our consumption per ALBD declined 4% this quarter,  this quarter were 39% higher than last year, which cost us $0.21 per share. texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: Before turning to the 2012 outlook, I would like to update you on our recently implemented fuel derivative  program. The program was intended to mitigate a portion of our economic risk attributable to potentially  significant fuel price increases. As part of this program, we will evaluate various derivative products and  strategies. To date, we have bought zero-cost collars for approximately 10% of our estimated fuel consumption for  the second half of fiscal 2012 through fiscal 2015, with ceilings ranging from $125 to $135 and floors ranging from  $71 to $75.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: However, we will forecast realized gains and losses on fuel derivatives by applying the current Brent oil prices to  the derivatives that settle in the forecast period. Based on this approach, and the current prices, we are not  forecasting any realized gains or losses for 2012 under our current fuel derivative portfolio.

texts.speaker: Howard S. Frank
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Operating Officer, Carnival Corp.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: Now looking at the full year 2012. As Mickey stated in the earnings release, this past year has been the most  challenging year in our company's history as a result of the Costa Concordia incident. The ship incident had a  profound impact on each and every employee of the company, both shore side and shipboard, and has driven all of  us to reinforce our commitment to the safety of our guests and crew. We have taken numerous steps to identify  lessons learned and best practices. In addition, we have and will continue to implement improvements to our  procedures and our training programs. Furthermore, we have improved the structure and organization of our  health, environmental, safety and security-related audit functions. Over the next few years, we expect to fully  recover from this ship incident and continue to build on our leadership position.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: Another multiple year trend worth noting is our fuel consumption. As a result of our operating companies' efforts  over the years, we expect in 2013 to use 24% less fuel per berth than we did in 2005. This is a substantial energy  saving, which clearly reduces our environmental footprint.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: I want to share with you our current rules of thumb about the impact that fuel price changes and currency changes  have on our results. To start with, a 10% change in the current price of fuel excluding the impact of fuel derivatives  represents a $0.30 per share impact for the full year. Please note that the impact of a 10% change obviously moves  along with the price of fuel. Just to be clear, the price of Brent was just under $110 a barrel when we determined  our guidance.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: The second rule of thumb relates to our fuel derivative portfolio where the next 10% increase in the price of Brent  for the year will not result in any realized gains as the price of Brent would still be within the band of our  tolerance. However, the next 10% decrease would result in a $4 million loss.

texts.speaker: Howard S. Frank
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Operating Officer, Carnival Corp.
texts.text: We are also forecasting lower fuel pricing and a 5% improvement in fuel consumption. Net cruise costs other than  fuel are expected to increase 1% to 2%, as David mentioned. All of this translates to an earnings per share range of  $2.20 to $2.40, or approximately a 20% increase in earnings if you're using the midpoint of $1.88 per share in  2012.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: At the moment, we have collars for roughly half of our consumption for 2015 with floors starting at $80. I'd say roughly speaking because in these calculations we assume a  static relationship between the price of Brent and the price of bunker as each moves up and down. We all know the  relationship has a tendency to move over time but the correlation is reasonably good over the longer term.

Second, we are planning for a slight increase in dry dock days  from 470 days in 2017 to 505 days in 2018, impacting cost metrics by 0.2 points. Partially offsetting these two  items is about 1 point of cost saving benefits from further leveraging our scale.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Chief Accounting Officer, Carnival Plc
texts.text: I will finish up by sharing with you our current rules of thumb about the impact of currency and fuel prices on our  2018 results. To start with, a 10% change in all relevant currencies relative to the U.S. dollar would impact our  P&L by approximately $0.46 for the full year and $0.02 for the first quarter. For fuel price changes, a 10% change  in the current spot price represents a $0.20 impact for the full year and $0.05 for the first quarter. Fuel expense in  our guidance is $1.5 billion for the full year. The third rule of thumb relates to our fuel derivative portfolio. A 10%  change in Brent would result in a $0.05 change in realized losses on fuel derivatives for the full year and just  $0.01 for the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Carnival Plc
texts.text: So far Ocean Medallion has received 36 billion favorable media impressions for our company and has won  recognition globally for our innovation efforts including being recognized by Fast Company as one of the Top 10  Most Innovative Companies in the travel category. texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Carnival Plc
texts.text: We also had many notable achievements in our sustainability efforts including the opening of our significantly  expanded Arison Maritime Center in the Netherlands, delivering state-of-the-art maritime training through cutting  edge bridge and engine room simulators and curriculum, and we opened three state-of-the-art fleet operations  centers around the globe to provide real-time support ship to shore, 24 hours a day.

texts.speaker: Arnold W. Donald
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Carnival Plc
texts.text: On the environmental front, we exceeded our target unit fuel consumption reduction of 25% three years ahead of  schedule and we made history just this week, with guests sailing on our first ever cruise ship able to be solely  powered by even more environmentally friendly liquefied natural gas. We are fully committed to continuous  improvement in health, environment, safety, and security.

texts.speaker: David Bernstein
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Chief Accounting Officer, Carnival Plc
texts.text: Now let's look at 2019 booking trends. In September booking volumes for 2019 have been running significantly  ahead of last year well into the double-digit and well ahead of capacity growth. As expected prices on bookings in  September for the Caribbean program are significantly higher as we lap the 2017 weather impact in September.  However, prices on overall bookings in September are in line with the prior year driven by our EA segment  sourcing in Continental Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The slide 12 summarizes the business unit sales growth and operating performance. With the  exception of Oil and Mining Services, all business units contributed to the double digit sales growth.  Looking at profitability, Textile Chemicals was the only business unit that reported single digit  EBITDA and EBIT margins before exceptional items. All other business achieved double digit  margins on the back of the aforementioned factors. The business unit, Industrial Consumer  Specialties, reported strong demand in almost all of its business segments, both on a year-on-year  and quarter-on-quarter view. The de-icing segment had a strong season due to the favorable cold  and wet weather conditions across Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Demand improved in all segments driven by recovery in automotive and decorative paints, but also  from the upswings in the plastic industry that started some months ago. In printing, pigments for  non-impact printing application such as laser and inkjet printers experienced strong growth.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Similar to the Group overall, Performance Chemicals faces challenges from rising raw materials,  energy and logistics costs. The business units will implement selective price increases in order to  compensate the rising raw material costs.

file: CLN - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 6May2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the Industrial & Consumer Specialty business unit, demand for chemicals from the construction,  painting, coating, agro-chemicals and lubricant industries remained strong. However, volumes were  negatively impacted by a decline in the de-icing business, which suffered from mild weather  conditions, particularly in Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the North American market, ICS significantly strengthened its market position with the acquisition  of Octagon Process, a U.S. de-icing specialist. In the Masterbatch Business Unit, demand from  customers in all end-markets remained at good levels in a challenging environment with higher raw  material costs and supply constraints from specific pigments and additives.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The global oil drilling and refinery activities in the Oil & Mining Services Business Unit remained at  high levels. The EBITDA was lower compared to the previous year, as a result of the time lag  associated with implementing higher sales prices and rising raw material costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Therefore, OMS will continue to increase sales prices to eliminate the margin squeeze effect. OMS  also expanded its presence in the attractive North American oil market with the acquisition of  Prairie Petro-Chem. This transaction significantly enhances Clariant’s presence in the Bakken  Shale located in Saskatchewan, Canada, positioned to be North America’s number one oil and gas  market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sales in Performance Chemicals were 6% higher in local currency driven by additives. This  business unit contributed with double-digit sales growth based on strong demand for non- halogenated flame retardants. A new plant for non-halogenated flame-retardants will go on stream  in mid-2012 to meet the strong demand for these products. Emulsions and Detergents &  Intermediates experienced mid-to-high-single digit sales growth, while sales in Paper Specialties  were slightly below the level of the previous year.

file: CLN - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 3May2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Steiner
texts.profession: Head-Communications & Investor Relations, Clariant AG
texts.text: Industrial and Consumer Specialties benefited from a good demand in Personal Care, Construction Chemicals and  Crop Protection. On the other hand, as already mentioned, the weather sensitive de-icing business had a weak  performance due to the mild winter in North America and the cold but dry winter in Europe.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Steiner
texts.profession: Head-Communications & Investor Relations, Clariant AG
texts.text: Catalysis & Energy experienced the normal seasonality with a weaker first quarter. However, on a comparable  base, sales and profitability was above prior year despite start-up costs for battery material production. Order  intake and order backlog are at very good levels, clearly above prior year.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Steiner
texts.profession: Head-Communications & Investor Relations, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Functional Materials, a recovery in the water business combined with good performance for performance  packaging in food and feed additives resulted in a clear improvement both year-on-year and sequentially. The  business unit, Pigments, saw a softening of demand year-on-year while pigments for decorative coatings in the  United States and the plastic segment started to recover, especially towards the end of the quarter, demand in the  printing segment remained weak as some destocking in the segment continued.

file: CLN - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 30April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: From a regional perspective, Latin America continued to grow double digit on the back of particularly high  demand for Oil & Mining Services, Industrial & Consumer Specialties, Masterbatches and Pigment Products.  North America and Europe grew at a more moderate pace, helped by cold and wet weather conditions favorable  for the de-icing and refinery businesses. The flip side of those weather conditions in Europe was a slow start in the  Crop Protection business as well as into the painting season affecting the Pigment business results.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: To give you an idea on sales and EBITDA contribution of the business areas, the figures from the full-year 2012  are shown on the next slide. It becomes evident that currently the Catalysis & Energy business area is contributing  over-proportionally to profitability while Natural Resources and Plastics & Coatings are slightly diluting the  Group. With rising margins in the Oil & Mining business, we expect Natural Resources to become a more  important contributor to profitability in the years until 2015.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In the first quarter 2013, Care Chemicals has clearly outperformed the other business areas, achieving 13% growth  in local currency; followed by Natural Resources increasing sales by 4%. While Care Chemicals was able to  increase its margins as a result of a favorable volume mix effect and lower production costs, Natural Resources  margins were 40 basis points lower due to a one-off charge. Although Catalysis & Energy were lower year-on-year,  the business area increased its margins on the back of lower SG&A expenses and a favorable product mix despite  still high costs in Energy Storage. Plastics & Coatings in contrast, experienced lower sales and margins. The  Pigments business was basically unchanged versus prior year while Masterbatches and Additives reported  negative growth, the latter compared to a still higher base in the previous year period.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Catalysis & Energy, sales were strong in the Petrochemicals segment, especially in North America and in  Asia/Pacific. On the other hand, the Syngas and Specialty Catalyst segments had a slow start into the year mainly  due to timing of changeover cycles in large ammonia plants in Syngas and a slow start in fuel upgrades. Although  demand has picked up slightly, the start-up business Energy Storage still experiences the impact of a weak  demand for electric vehicles and stationary energy storage.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Natural Resources sales in the Oil & Mining business units grew double digits. All three business lines, Oil,  Mining and Refinery, contributed to the strong result. In contrast to Oil & Mining the Functional Minerals  business did experience negative growth. While demand for Food & Feed additives remained high, Water  Treatment and Foundry Additives continued to remain weak.

file: CLN - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 30April2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: An announcement on the closing of the Leather Services divestments can be expected very soon. In addition, we  continue to streamline the portfolio by selling the Water Treatment business during the first quarter and just  recently agreed to sell our 50% stake in the ASK Chemicals joint venture. Excluding the related impairment  charges, net income rose 18% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: This weather-related impact and the currency fluctuations were nearly compensated by a strong volume  development and a better pricing, therefore, the gross margins eroded only slightly. The EBITDA before  exceptionals actually grew 8%, in local currencies and matched the previous year's figure in Swiss francs. The  corresponding margin rose by 40 basis points to 14.1% from 13.7% on the back of a better performance in all  business areas.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Looking now at the development of the businesses, three out of four business areas achieved dynamic sales growth  in local currencies and were able to increase the margins. Catalysis & Energy achieved significant growth and was  also positively influenced by reduced dilution from the Energy Storage business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Natural Resources, growth has been achieved in all businesses with the exception of Refinery Services and  Plastics & Coatings that improved economic conditions led to better results. Only Care Chemicals was flat in local  currencies while margins were significantly lower.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Catalysis & Energy, there was good sales growth in Europe, in the Middle East, and in Asia Pacific, with the  latter benefiting from strong growth in China in the Syngas and Petrochemicals business. Sales in the start-up  business, Energy Storage, were above previous year's level. Energy Storage was able to optimize its cost base by  closing a smaller production unit in Canada by the end of 2013. The business will continue to reduce costs in order  to achieve breakeven in 2015.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA margin of the business area increased to 20% as a consequence of lower cost base in Catalysts and  the reduced dilution from Energy Storage. Going forward, the business area will return to growth in 2014 after a  soft 2013. Business activity in the Middle East is expected to pick up, and production rates of customers in the  United States are projected to rise.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Sales in the Natural Resources business area grew 7% in local currencies. Good sales growth has been achieved in  all businesses, particularly in Mining Services and Adsorbents. Mining Services reported double-digit sales growth  due to market share gains predominantly in Asia Pacific and Australia. Demand for Adsorbents for the  purification of edible oil and crop remained healthy, allowing high single-digit sales growth in this business. Oil  Services benefited from strong growth in North America after the acquisition of deep-water assets in the Gulf of  Mexico. Refinery Services in contrast suffered from mild weather conditions in Europe.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA margin before exceptional items of Natural Resources increased to 15% as a result of higher volume  and improved cost base and a better product mix, which more than offset the significant currency impact and a  lower contribution from the ASK Chemicals joint venture.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: And in Plastics & Coatings, sales increased 6% in local currencies compared to the prior-year period. Similar to the  fourth quarter 2013, all three businesses, Pigments, Masterbatches and Additives contributed to growth. Pigments  achieved particularly strong sales growth in all regions. Sales in Europe were stimulated by the positive impact  from the mild and favorable weather conditions and by a slow recovery in Southern Europe. However, growth in  that region is still comparing to a low base.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Masterbatches sales in local currencies increased in all regions with the exceptions of North America, where  underlying sales growth could not compensate for the impact of unfavorable cold weather conditions. In the  Additives business, demand for halogen-free flame retardants continued to recover. The EBITDA margin before  exceptionals of 15.1% was above the prior-year period as higher volumes compensated for the unfavorable  currency developments.

file: CLN - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 29April2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: EBITDA stayed around the same level as last year, Care Chemicals, Catalysis & Energy, as well as Natural  Resources had an increased absolute contribution to EBITDA in the first quarter of 2015, while Plastics &  Coatings was negatively affected by a slow start into the quarter, particularly in Coatings. The better contribution  from the higher-margin business compensated the volatility in currencies and raw materials.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Looking at the reported figures for the businesses during the first months of 2015, we are satisfied with the  performance of three out of four business areas. Care Chemicals, Catalysis & Energy and Natural Resources all  improved underlying sales and profitability, and are on track to reach their targets.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Please also note that after having sold our Energy business, we will refer to this business area as Catalysis, starting  with Q2 2015.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Sales in Natural Resources grew by 8% in local currencies. This was attributable to strength in oil and mining  services, as well as to a good growth in the purification business. The underlying growth, excluding the water  treatment divestment effect, was actually 13%. The margin improved to 16% as growth in higher margin  businesses contributed to a better profitability.

file: CLN - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 28April2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: All our business areas contributed to the profitability improvement on the back of an outstanding positive mix  effect, efficiency gains and the differentiated steering of the Plastics & Coatings business area.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Overall, the performance improvement was broad and came from all activities, while sales growth was more  pronounced in Care Chemicals and Plastics & Coatings the development in Catalysis and Natural Resources was  solid versus a high previous year basis.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: While the margin improvement should not be extrapolated going forward, it represents a good start and forms a  good basis for the year 2016. Two major contributors to the profitability improvement were Natural Resources  and Plastic & Coatings.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Natural Resources continued to increase the EBITDA margin in the first quarter of this year despite of a  particularly adverse environment. The Business Area increased the margin significantly by 170 basis points year- on-year due to strict cost control and disciplined margin management across the business units.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Sales in the Catalysis declined by 4% in local currencies on the back of a very strong first quarter last year. Sales  growth for the Business Area was impacted by the missing sales from the Energy Storage business, which was sold  in February 2015 last year.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Natural Resources declined by 2% in local currencies, compared to a strong quarter in the previous year. There  was good role in Latin America and Asia, whereas North America, Europe and the Middle East and Africa  declined. Sales growth of Oil and Mining Services was negative, versus a very strong first quarter 2015. In North  America, the growth in the U.S. could not offset the weakness in Canada. Sales in Asia, Middle East and Africa,  Latin America and Europe were below previous year's levels.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Despite the lower top-line level, the EBITDA margin before exceptional items of Natural Resources expanded to  17.8% in Q1 2016, from 16.1% in Q1 2015. The improvement is the result of a strict cost control and disciplined  margin management across the businesses.

file: CLN - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 27April2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: On page 9, we see that Natural Resources sales grew by 17% in local currency. The sales were lifted by solid  growth in Functional Minerals as well by acquisitions in the Oil and Mining Service business, which contributed  16% sales growth in local currency.

file: CLN - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 25April2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Let us now move to slide 8. Natural Resources sales grew by 2% in local currency. Sales in the Oil & Mining  Services business growing single digit, lifted by the improving demand in Oil Services in the last month of the  quarter, offsetting a temporarily softer Mining business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Sales in Functional Minerals decreased slightly in local currency against a very strong comparable base. The  positive development in the Foundry business could not fully compensate the slight softness in the edible oil  business, which is subject to the quality of the respective crops, and hence, the weather conditions. However, we  expect Functional Minerals to return to a slight growth on a full-year basis.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: EBITDA margin before exceptional items declined to 15.2%, burdened by the continued price consciousness of  the oil market. This, however, should improve throughout the year due to the sales pipeline of the business and a  generally improving market in the Oil & Mining Services business.

file: CLN - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 30April2019 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: On business area level, Care Chemicals and Catalysis, both reported a significant progression year on year, while  Natural Resources also delivered a sound profitability improvement quarter on quarter as anticipated with a  decent progression from the Oil & Mining Services business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: On the regional level, in Europe and Asia, Care Chemicals sales grew in mid-single digits in local currency, while  North America was hampered as mentioned before by the Aviation business due to unfavorably mild weather  conditions in this region, as well as the prolonged shutdown of a key supplier in the U.S. The shutdown of this  supplier will regrettably also negatively impact sales in the Care Chemicals in the second quarter by an amount  estimated to be in the mid-teen million range.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA margin after exceptional items in Natural Resources lessened to 12.5% from 14.3% in the same  timeframe of the previous year, as the result of weaker demand in the more seasonal Refinery projects and the  continuingly challenging price environment in Oil Services. However, the margin increased quarter on quarter as  anticipated. The sequential progression was the result of a good margin improvement in the Oil & Mining Services  business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Natural Resources, and Oil & Mining Services in particular, is right on track and progressing towards its 2021  targets, with strongly higher sales, mainly listed by good Oil & Mining Services demand but also solid growth in  the Functional Minerals. The profitability is improving sequentially as anticipated.

file: CLN - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 29July2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Ulrich Steiner, Head, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Thank you very much. Ladies and gentlemen welcome to the Clariant half-year and second quarter
texts.text: An important prerequisite for profitable growth is a stable platform. We estimate our achievements  sustainable. This is the reason why we started Clariant Excellence, our Lean Sigma based  continues improvement initiatives early on in 2009. In the meantime, we have trained 69 so-called  black belts. These are fully dedicated project leaders. Close to 500 green belts, partly dedicated  project mangers. More than 113 black belt projects are under implementation. In 2009, we realized  more than CHF13 million benefits and we are aiming for a multiple this year.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Steiner, Head, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Thank you very much. Ladies and gentlemen welcome to the Clariant half-year and second quarter
texts.text: 4 absorbing the higher costs. In fact, raw material costs are in the range of 45 to 50% of sales, which  means that we only needed 2% sales price increase to fully absorb higher raw material cost of 4%.

file: CLN - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 27July2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: While profitable growth is our focus, we still pay enough attention to finalize the projects related to our Global  Asset Network Optimization initiative, GANO. Those projects will not only lower our cost base by more than CHF  100 million annually, they will also further reduce our sensitivity towards fluctuations in exchange rates. Both  relocations of Textile Chemicals to Asia and Paper Specialties to Spain will further improve our natural hedge with  costs better matching sales in terms of currencies. Due to the dedicated project teams behind those relocations, it  seems to be possible that from today's point of view, GANO project could be completed around mid-2012. That  means more or less one year ahead of schedule.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Thank you, Hariolf. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. Before taking you through our Q2 results, let me start
texts.text: Let me now give you some comments on facts and trends observed in the business units. In ICS, demand  remained strong in many end markets. The business units successfully increased prices and launched Green  product a trend with increasing importance for both our customers and Clariant. Masterbatches also saw a robust  demand from customers in all end markets, although some softening was noted at the end of the quarter. Several  investments like in Turkey and Saudi Arabia have been done to meet the anticipated growth in those regions.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Thank you, Hariolf. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. Before taking you through our Q2 results, let me start
texts.text: OMS experienced a good demand in all regions also driven by the growing investment into unconventional oil and  gas development. Following its strategy, OMS invests currently in strengthening its business line in mining  services where several new opportunities arise, especially in flotation.

texts.text: The Süd-Chemie integration as well as other projects and initiatives are well on track or even ahead of schedule. texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Moving on to the individual businesses, you can see that the non-cyclical business units were overall resilient to  the slow down. In Industrial & Consumer Specialties, demand was strong in Personal Care and Crop Protection,  while the industrial businesses such as Construction or Energy were weak.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Catalysis & Energy sales picked up from a weak first quarter and were significantly above prior year. Order intake  businesses developed differently, while adsorbents and performance packaging made good progress, water  treatment remained difficult.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA increase was driven by stable gross margin and a favorable margin development in the Catalysts  business combined with lower SG&A and corporate cost. And even better performance has been prevented by the  weakness in the Natural Resources business area, namely in Water Treatment and temporarily in Mining Services.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Moving forward to the performance metrics of the business areas, it becomes evident that sales growth was driven  by growth of 8% in Care Chemicals and 6% in Natural Resources. Soon after the first quarter of 2013, the Catalysis  & Energy business area is contributing over proportionally to profitability. All other business areas reported below  previous year margin for different segment specific reasons.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Natural Resources, growth was mainly driven by strength in Oil Services while Mining was impacted by the  delay of a key project in Africa. Functional Minerals was slightly below the previous year level, but improved on a  sequential basis. Mid single-digit growth in Adsorbents and the flat development in Cargo & Device Protection,  could not fully offset the significant demand contraction in Water Treatment. The EBITDA margin mainly  decreased as a result of weakness in Water Treatment.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: One remarks to where we stand in the three large acquisitions with respect to the deep -water project. The  integration of Süd-Chemie is nearing completion with 95% of sales integrated and will be accretive this year as  planned. The divestment of the three businesses to SK Capital will close by end of September while we have  defined two independent projects for the two remaining businesses to be divested.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA margin of the business area increased to 28.2% in the second quarter of 2014 from 25.9% in the  year-ago period due to a lower production cost base and a reduced dilution effect from the Energy Storage  business.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Sales in the Natural Resources Business grew 9% in local currency. All regions excluding Europe contributed to  growth, with particularly good demand from the Americas and the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA margin before exceptional items in Natural Resources increased to 12.7% from 9.4%. Higher  volumes and sales prices, the lower cost base, and a better product mix more than offset the significant currency  impact.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee

The business area, Catalysis, Care Chemicals, and Natural  Resources, operate in markets with high margins and with potential for profitable growth in order.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, despite the demanding environment marked by economic and political uncertainties,  Clariant continues to be a more profitable and resilient specialty chemicals company. This was achieved on the  back of a stringent execution of our strategy by means of innovation, sustainability, growth, and efficiency gains.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Hence, the EBITDA margin rose by 80 basis points to 15.3% in the first half of 2016. The improvement in  profitability primarily stemmed from good advancements in Care Chemicals, Natural Resources, and Plastics &  Coatings.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Net income amounted to CHF128 million compared to CHF143 million in the previous year. The decline was  mainly due to higher restructuring costs mainly resulting from back office process optimization projects,  application development streamlining, and higher interest charges. When adjusted for the proceeds from the  sales of the energy storage business in the first half of 2015, net income was comparable year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the next few minutes, I will focus on the development of the businesses in the second quarter, which was a  very strong quarter surpassing the high base of the previous year. The good sales and profitability development  was mainly driven by Care Chemicals and Plastics & Coatings. Natural Resources grew 1% in local currency  largely driven by functional minerals. Despite the moderate top line growth in Natural Resources, EBITDA margin  before exceptional items could be substantially improved.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We confirm our target for the mid-term to achieve a position in the top tier of the chemicals industry. This  corresponds to an EBITDA margin in the range of 16% to 19% and a return on invested capital above peer group  average.

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications
texts.text: As you may have read yesterday, we continued to streamline our portfolio and divested the energy storage  business to Johnson Matthey for a total consideration of $75 million. texts.speaker: Ulrich Bernhard Steiner
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications
texts.text: This is all the more remarkable, as last year's result was helped by a net positive mid single-digit million  contribution from the one-off item in natural resources. The improved EBITDA was the consequence of  significantly higher volume and the resulting better gross margin.

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications
texts.text: However, EBITDA margin was slightly lower. There are mainly three reasons for this development. Firstly,  currency still impacted the EBITDA by a negative 30 basis points. texts.speaker: Ulrich Bernhard Steiner
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications
texts.text: During the fourth quarter, net working capital will come down again. We are confident of reaching our target of  lower than 20% by year end with further potential midterm. texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications
texts.text: Let me now give you some details on the most important developments and trends in the businesses and on the  performance of the business area. Growth in all business areas was good with double-digit increases in Catalysts  and Energy and in Natural Resources.

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications

texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations & Group Communications

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Looking at the figures of the business areas for the first nine months of the year, Care Chemicals and Plastic &  Coatings were the main drivers for the good sales growth and profitability gains.
