texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Despite the market headwind, Latin America continues to have robust sales growth which still could not offset the  market decline in other regions. While Functional Minerals is anticipated to continue to grow particularly in  emerging markets, the decline in oil prices will continue to impact the short-term dynamic in Oil and Mining  Services.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: However, client is convinced that offering new solutions and better services to the oil industry will allow the  business unit to continue to outperform the market. Overall, Clariant has a healthy pipeline in Oil and Mining  Services and is committed to the oil and mining industry as shown by the recently announced acquisitions of Kel- Tech and X-Chem in the United States of America.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: These acquisitions were closed on October 1, 2016 and were well received by the customers. We, therefore, are  confident that Clariant will continue to strengthen its position as a leading partner in the oil and mining industry.  The EBITDA margin before exceptional items of Natural Resources expanded considerably to 16.4% from 15.7%  in the prior year. This advancement is the result of disciplined cost management across the businesses.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Natural Resources improved by 1% in local currency compared to a strong quarter in the previous year.  Functional Materials continued to deliver a good sales performance in all regions, mainly supported by emerging  markets in North America and is primarily driven by the edible oil purification business.

file: CLN - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 31October2017 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: We see the benefits of our achievements based on innovation efforts, our focus on sustainability and the clear  commitment of our employees reflected in these results. Clariant is well on track to reach the 2017 targets.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: On slide 7, we see that Natural Resources sales advanced by 18% in local currency, driven by the acquisition in  the Oil & Mining Services business and the continuing sustained growth in Functional Minerals. Excluding the  acquisition in Oil & Mining Services in the U.S., underlying sales in Natural Resources rose by 3% in local  currency.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: We also announced today that Clariant has taken further steps towards the commercialization of bioethanol and  the related licenses and enzymes and has set up a new business line called Biofuels & Derivatives as part of the  business area, Catalysis.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Clariant will invest in the new full-scale commercial plant for the production of cellulosic ethanol from agricultural  residues using the sunliquid technology. The plant is anticipated to deliver the first batch of product in 2020 with a  sales potential in the mid-double digit million range. This project is a good illustration of innovative and successful  biotechnology expertise.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Moving on to slide 13, in the third quarter, sales in Natural Resources advanced by 16% in local currency. The  acquisition impacting the Oil & Mining Services business contributed 13% in local currency growth. Sales grew  slightly in the Oil & Mining business, excluding the acquisition effects. Despite the slight growth, oil is still facing  an ongoing adverse industry environment particularly in terms of pricing. Functional Minerals delivered growth in  local currency, notably Asia reflected a strong sales development with particular strength in China.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Natural Resources, the EBITDA margin before exceptional items declined to 13.3%, burdened by pricing  constraints, continued weak demand in Latin America and the one-time negative impact from Hurricane Harvey.

file: CLN - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 31October2018 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Continuing with Natural Resources on slide 7, Natural Resources sales grew by 7% in local currency. Sales in the  Oil & Mining Services business exhibited double-digit sales growth, bolstered by continuing demand improvement  in the industry. Though all three business lines contributed to the growth, this increase was mainly driven by oil  services and refinery.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Sales in Functional Minerals grew in the low-single digit range in local currency. The growth in the Foundry  business compensated the temporary softness in the edible oil business. As you know, the Purification business  for edible oils is subject to the quality of the respective crops which are dependent on the weather conditions.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: In the business line Biofuels & Derivatives, Clariant held the groundbreaking event for the construction of the  large-scale commercial sunliquid plant for the production of cellulosic ethanol made from agricultural residues in  Romania in September of this year. This plant will testify to the competitive viability and sustainability of the  sunliquid technology on an industrial scale. At the same time, it will be a reference facility for the worldwide  marketing of sunliquid licenses. By 2021, we expect sunliquid sales of CHF 100 million, of which license sales  and sales from bioethanol will each amount to approximately CHF 50 million.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Moving on to Natural Resources on slide 13, in the third quarter, sales in Natural Resources advanced by 14% in  local currency. This growth was supported by a demand increase in the Oil & Mining Services, as well as by solid  growth in Functional Minerals. The double-digit sales growth in the Oil & Mining Services business reflected the  improving demand in the oil market. Both Mining and Refinery sales grew in the high-single digit range despite the  continued curtailed demand resulting from a customer's facility failure in Mining.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: The sales progression in Functional Minerals exhibited an increased single-digit growth in local currency. Both the  Foundry as well as the Purification business contributed to this positive development. The price consciousness of  the oil market has not yet abated and is reflected in the comparable EBITDA margin before exceptional items of  13.2% versus the prior year. Quarter-on-quarter, this represents a 320 basis point improvement to the EBITDA  margin.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Steiner, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Clariant Full Year and Fourth Quarter Results 2009
texts.text: 8 works. The company today operates on the basis of a solid liquidity and a strong balance sheet.  Cash generation has improved significantly, and our cost-saving measures have started to  sustainably improve our operating results. Our Global Asset Network Optimization efforts will bring  our production network to competitive levels.

file: CLN - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 15February2012 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon. It's a real pleasure to welcome you today here in Zurich. 2011 was a
texts.text: successful year for Clariant despite strong headwinds from currencies and a challenging business climate in the  second half of the year. Our company achieved its best performance in more than 10 years.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: The Personal Care business within Industrial & Consumer Specialties offset some weather-related weakness in de- icing. In Oil & Mining Services, we had a good quarter in the Middle East and North America, driven by new  contracts and the successful launch of new products and technologies.  Additives experienced ongoing strong demand for non-halogenated flame retardants. The best quarter ever was  recorded by Catalysis & Energy with the expected seasonal peak in the Catalyst business. Demand was  exceptionally high for environmental catalysts in particular. In Functional Materials, demand for Diagnostics and  Pharmaceuticals packaging as well as for Food and Feed Additives rose further.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: Exolit, our non-halogenated flame retardant product line has been further developed and will soon be introduced  to new applications, such as printed wire boards. A superior performance of those new materials have been  proven already.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: In the field of battery materials, we have developed the best-in-class lithium iron phosphate cathode material.  First production has been started in Canada earlier this year. Joint ventures and cooperations with leading battery  producers like LG Chemicals and others are already in place or coming soon.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: Industrial Biotechnology is another field of interest. It will be one of the focus of our R&D activities within the  next five years. Clariant has developed a new process for the production of biofuels and bio-based chemicals from  lignocellulose. A demonstration plant in Germany will start production in 2012.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: And last, but not least, the research teams in the Catalysis business have created a new hydrogenation catalyst that  is highly selective and already used by four of the top 10 ethylene producers worldwide. The new catalyst has been  nominated for the 2011 ICIS Innovation Award.

file: CLN - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Function Materials, the picture was mixed between the individual businesses. Adsorbents, food and feed  additives, and performance packaging is up reasonably well, while foundry and water treatment faced some  challenges in their respective end markets. As a consequence, margins were lower compared to the previous  quarters, but remained basically unchanged compared to the fourth quarter 2011.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: In the Additives business unit, flame retardant sales remained under pressure due to a slower than expected  penetration of halogen-free products into the marketplace. Mid-term, we are confident that this business will pick  up again significantly and therefore further develop our product offering for other applications.

file: CLN - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 19February2014 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Already in 2013, three of the four business areas achieved good growth. Care Chemicals and Natural Resources  outpaced the rest of the group. Investments into those businesses in recent ye ars now show results.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: Volume in Plastics & Coatings recovered from a difficult 2012 when this cyclical business suffered from a weak  economic environment. Catalysis & Energy caught up nicely in the fourth quarter and nearly closed the gap to the  previous year. Also, no significant improvement in the start-up business, Energy Storage, has been observed.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member, Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: For Catalyst, we expect demand in the region to recover in 2014 and to accelerate after that. The Water Treatment  business in South Africa has just been sold a few days ago as it did not fit into Clariant's portfolio from a strategic  point of view.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member, Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: The net income was unchanged at CHF 85 million, given the lower interest costs after the repayment of debt  during 2013 and a positive tax income. Restructuring and impairment costs increased to CHF 64 million, as costs  for the divestment of Water Treatment have already been booked in the P&L stateme nt.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member, Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: These levels are sustainable as they result from the divestment of capital-intensive businesses such as Textile  Chemicals, Paper Specialties and Leather Services. The higher restructuring and impairment costs in a year -on- year comparison are due to the charges connected to the sale of Water Treatment, as well as costs for a smaller site  closure in Canada linked to Energy Storage and some measures to increase Clariant's operational efficiency.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member, Executive Committee, Clariant AG
texts.text: In Natural Resources business area, sales growth was mainly driven by strength in Oil Services. Mining Services  achieved good growth on the back of strength in Latin America, while Refinery was slightly below last year as mild  weather conditions in Europe impacted its cold-flow additives offering for middle distillates. The Adsorbents  business grew in the high-single digit percentage range and it contributed substantially to the margin  improvement in Natural Resources.

file: CLN - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 18February2015 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Catalysis & Energy posted a strong growth of 7% fueled by all major businesses and a good change-out cycle in the  Petrochemical business. Sales growth of 8% in Natural Resources was largely based on strength in Oil Services  and Mining Solutions (sic) [Mining Services] (09:07). In Plastic & Coatings, all businesses contributed with mid - single-digit growth with Pigments contributing most to year-on-year-progression.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Further down the P&L statement, the gross margin was higher year-on-year, thanks to an improved operational  efficiency and a tempering negative currency effect. Raw material costs were down slightly year-on-year as well as  compared to the third quarter. Reported EBITDA before exceptionals decreased to CHF 232 million from CHF  235 million in the year ago period. This corresponds to a margin of 14.6% which is below the strong 15% recorded  in the fourth quarter of 2013. This decline was basically due to a base effect in Natural Resources; in the fourth  quarter of 2013, we had a positive contribution from our ASK joint venture which boosted margins.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: In the Natural Resources Business Area, sales growth was mainly driven by the strength in Oil & Mining Services  as well as good growth in the Purification business. Due to the sale of the Water Treatment business, the reported  sales growth of 3% in local currency does not completely reflect the strength of this business area. The underlying  growth was 7 %.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee
texts.text: The EBITDA margin before exceptional items of Natural Resources decreased to 15.3% in the fourth quarter of  2014 from 20.9% in the same period a year ago. The decline was due to a base effect, as the EBITDA in the fourth  quarter of 2013 was positively impacted by one-time effects, mostly attributable to a positive contribution from  the ASK joint venture, a business we sold in June 2014.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Performance, growth and innovation characterize our thinking and our actions at Clariant. These three themes are  the driving forces for a sustainable success that ultimately benefit customer, employees, environment,  shareholders and help us to generate value. The actual plan behind these three themes is very clear. Performance  means, on the one hand, cost efficiency. We continue to reduce cost and increase efficiency with Clariant  Excellence measures but also by finding and implementing new ways to do our business.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Glucamides are the foundation of new Clariant products for the application field of Personal Care, Industrial  Home Care as well as Crop Solutions. And, in addition, we spent, two weeks ago, eight days, nine days with the  global management team of Clariant in Houston just to explain to our people what does it mean gas, energy and   oil. We also visited our labs in the Houston oil service headquarters and we got to know that Glucamides also can  play a very interesting role in enhanced oil recovery. Therefore, it's a very, very promising new product family and  an excellent example on how we try to manage our innovation pipeline.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: And Glucamides based on renewable raw materials with an excellent bio-credibility and an ecological profile  directly will bring us to sustainability. Sustainability is another trigger for us to generate value. We are convinced  that we can only add value to our business if we operate sustainably and when our  products and solutions helps  our customers to improve their own sustainability performance. Therefore, testifying our [ph] commitments  visibly (32:08) on a strategic corporate level, we introduced it to the corporate strategy as additional pillar to  innovation, to growth, to profitability and to portfolio management.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: Sustainability for us is not just a buzzword, it's a key driver for growth and innovation and will increasingly  influence Clariant's operation, our activities, our products, and our portfolio. And our results – our efforts show  results within the last years. We could establish Clariant among the most sustainable specialty chemical  companies worldwide. Today, we are included in the global Dow Jones Sustainability Index and graded among the  top five companies absolutely in the chemical industry, there is just Akzo and DSM ahead of us and this is a  program for us now.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Executive Committee
texts.text: We are committed to continue on this path. This is the reason why we have started what we call the portfolio value  program in order to establish clear sustainability criteria for the product portfolio. On this basis, products and  solutions have been classified as sustainable. For instance, products with an outstanding sustainability profile will  be identified with the EcoTain label. And let me add as well, and products without sustainability profile will be  excluded from our portfolio. This will further drive integration of sustainability into our business and the  company as such.

file: CLN - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 17February2016 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The progression of our EBITDA margin came predominantly from the business areas Care Chemicals, Catalysis,  as well as Natural Resources, which all significantly increased the EBITDA margin throughout 2015 compared to  the previous year. This is in respect to [ph] the advancement (6:42) given the demanding and uncertain economic  environment we saw in 2015.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Natural Resources, sales growth in local currency was 4% as a result of higher volumes. The growth was  primarily driven by the Mining and Refinery business. Oil services also contributed to the growth despite a strong  previous year. The EBITDA margin before exceptionals of Natural Resources expanded to 16.9% from 14.7% the  previous year. This is an expansion of a solid 220 basis points year-on-year. The improvement is a result of a  better mix effect and improvements in cost positions across all businesses.

texts.speaker: Patrick Jany
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The industrial business experienced underlying good demand, but was negatively impacted by the very weak de - icing business. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: One example of our recently launched innovation includes our TexCare polymers. TexCare polymers prevent soil  redeposition on fabrics for improved whiteness and can close the performance gap at low-washing temperatures.  They address the trend and need towards low water and energy consumption in both developed markets where  there is a need for sustainability and cost reduction as well as in emerging markets where there is a water scarcity.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Clariant offers the innovation. Clariant offers with the TexCare polymers includes improved performance and/or  reduced formulation costs at the same performance as well as low-temperature washing claims. These can be  offered in tailor-made solutions for our customers.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: As you know, the global liquid fuel consumption and the greenhouse gas emission from transport are rising. This  in tandem with the limitation of fossil resources, energy, security, climate change and environmental protection  represent essential issues concerning today's society, governments and also the energy sector. Reduction of  greenhouse gas emissions and alternative sustainable sources of energy must be found to reduce dependence  on oil. This is most evident in the transport sector.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: In the U.S., in the EU and China, politicians had laid down legal frameworks to promote the use of climate-friendly  energy sources, such as advanced biofuels. The requirement for superior sustainability through the use of  agricultural base thereby not competing with land requirements for food and feed has led us to develop the  sunliquid technology, clearing the way for the second generation of biofuels.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: Until now, agricultural residues posed many obstructions as a feedstock for the production of biofuels such as the  stable structure of lignin, [ph] a lignocellulosic (00:21:11) material is difficult to break down and, hence, the sugars  contained in straw remain largely unused, thereby leading to a costly process with a low yield of ethanol  produced. However, with the development of the Clariant sunliquid technology, we could address and resolve  these challenges and are therefore in pole position.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: The sunliquid process is based on feedstock specific biocatalysts, which efficiently provides access to the difficult- to-extracted sugars, which are contended in the straw, an integrated enzyme production, simultaneous C5 and C6  fermentation and an energy-saving ethanol separation method. This gives rise to an efficient, extremely economic  and therefore competitive process for the production of cellulosic ethanol, which in turn is almost carbon neutral.  This process also overcomes the food versus fuel debate and offers an efficient way to reduce greenhouse gas  emissions in the mobility sector.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: The sunliquid process, as shown on slide 18, comprises four steps, starting with mechanical and thermal  pretreatment, which reduces straw to fiber bundles. The second step is the enzyme production, which is an  integrated part of the process itself, making the overall process very cost efficient. Tailored microorganisms which  are added to the straw, rapidly produce a large quantities of enzymes.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: The straw fibers are liquefied by means of these enzymes, which are especially tailored to the raw material used.  The enzymes release all the available sugars in the straw and convert these sugar polymer chains into C5 or C6  monomers sugars like glucose or xylose. The insoluble lignin is then removed and employed as fuel to provide  the energy required throughout the entire production process. The sunliquid process is therefore energy self- sufficient, as no additional energy from fossil fuels is needed.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: In the third step, all C5 and C6 sugars are fermented simultaneously with the help of special fermentation  organism, thereby converting sugar into ethanol. Due to the use of this especially developed fermentation  organism, 50% more ethanol is being produced compared to a similar process. And in the last step, ethanol is  separated from water in a very energy efficient, highly integrated process using specialized absorbers. So, that  separated pure ethanol can cut carbon emission by around 95% when compared to normal gasoline.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: As within the production process, that makes the Clariant sunliquid technology so unique? Number one, the  Clariant sunliquid technology offers a distinctive chemical-free and simple thermal pre-treatment, which enable an  optimal hydrolysis. Number two, the unique process integrated enzyme production reduces costs to a minimum.  Number three, enzymes can be adapted to the new feedstock, allowing for efficient hydrolysis with maximum  yields.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: Number four, organisms used for fermentation can ferment all sugars therein both C5 and C6 sugars in a one-pot  reaction, leading to 50% higher ethanol yield than other processes. Number five, the byproduct lignin is used as a  fuel and fulfills the entire energy demand of the plant. No fossil fuel is needed in the process. Number six, in  addition, vinasse and other byproduct from this process can be even used as an organic fertilizer.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: So, what does that mean in terms of outlook for the Business Line Biofuels & Derivatives? Let's turn to slide 19.  As we just mentioned, the Clariant sunliquid process is a unique process that converts any lignocellulosic  agricultural residues into cellulosic ethanol in a highly efficient, extremely economic, energy neutral and  sustainable process. Governmental programs in the U.S., EU and in China with other countries to follow require a  statutory minimum volume of advanced biofuels being used starting latest by 2020. We therefore expect annual  sales coming from both licenses for the sunliquid technology as well as from bioethanol sales from the production  plant in Romania of at least CHF 100 million by 2021.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: The EBITDA margin will exceed 40%. Furthermore, the conversion into cash will be highly attractive. In  September 2017, Clariant already announced signing the first technology license agreement with Enviral. In the  end of October 2017, we approved the investment of a new full scale commercial cellulosic ethanol plant based  on its sunliquid technology. First production coming from this plant is anticipated for 2020.

texts.speaker: Hariolf Kottmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman-Executive Committee & Executive Director, Clariant AG
texts.text: I'm delighted to see the high market interest in sustainable advanced biofuels and also to announce that the entire  bioethanol production output of the plant is already contracted for several years. Besides the success of sunliquid  in advanced biofuel production, we see further application of the sunliquid platform in the production of additional,  highly sustainable downstream products. This opportunity from our innovation pipeline represents a further upside  potential, a strong further upside potential not yet included in our guidance. The Business Line Biofuels &  Derivatives is established as part of the business area, Catalysis, since the beginning of 2018. On one hand, you  have heterogeneous catalysts and on the other hand biocatalysts that's the reason for this decision.

texts.speaker: Anja Pomrehn
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Clariant AG
texts.text: Thank you, Hariolf. Thank you, Patrick, for taking us through the achievement and the progression of the full year  and also the fourth quarter 2017 and as well as the elaboration of the uniqueness of our sunliquid technology,  which really offers a great opportunity and excellent upside potential in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Ernesto Occhiello
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Thank you, Patrick. Ladies and gentlemen, after going through the financials of last year, I would like to focus a bit  more on the future. On September 18 of 2018, Clariant announced a step change into higher value specialties by  not only announcing a collaboration opportunity between Clariant and SABIC, which will lead to the creation of a  new business area High Performance Materials and the divestment of the remaining Plastic & Coating business  area, but also by announcing an updated strategy for the various Clariant businesses. Therefore, I want to explain  to you what Clariant will further address to foster the progression.

texts.speaker: Ernesto Occhiello
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: So, let me start by giving you the first example from Personal Care, which reflect how we address customer  experience. Therefore, please move to slide 17. One of the essential requirement to be successful in Personal  Care is the ability to identify natural and renewable ingredients which match the trend of naturality, health and  safety. Many of our customers try to follow this trend. However, the reality is that whenever an existing synthetic  ingredient is exchanged with a natural one, often the entire formulation of the respective product must be  adapted. You might read silicon-free on a bottle, but in effect, by exchanging one ingredient for another, it is often  necessary to add another synthetic ingredient due to the formulation change in order to achieve the same  performance, the same texture, as well as a comparable feel of the end product.

texts.speaker: Ernesto Occhiello
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Concurrently, Genadvance has a superior ecological and sustainability profile, which I will elaborate in more  details on the next slide, slide 18. Genadvance Hydra, for example, is a natural moisturizer with an exceptional,  improved after-feel, especially on damaged hair. It is 100% naturally derived, silicone-free and it is biodegradable  within only 10 days. Its biodegradability is, therefore, two to three times faster versus traditional products for this  application.

texts.speaker: Ernesto Occhiello
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: Furthermore, while the traditional conditioner consists of up to 95% water, the Genadvance conditioner soap bar  barely contains any water. Hence, there is significantly lower water requirement during the production process.  That can create formulation and formats that meet unusual needs. This formulation innovations and the  advantages that the products not only require significantly less water during the production process, but the new  formats such as bars and powders also reduce the volume and packaging needed. This is particularly convenient  for customers who travel given the reduced packaging size, the lighter weight, and the fact that the end product is  no longer in liquid form. Thus, the product can be taken in your hand luggage when boarding a plane.

texts.speaker: Ernesto Occhiello
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Clariant AG
texts.text: On slide 19, you can again see the significantly enhanced performance of another Genadvance product line,  Genadvance Repair, as well as our formulation expertise using natural ingredients. With the application of our  technology expertise, the performance of the original formulation was exceeded while using 20% less active  ingredients. Overall, this can lead to up to 25% cost saving in the production process and hence making it  financially and also ecologically very attractive.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: I'd like to start on page 3, the summary. If you look at the environment, the low interest rate environment  continued into the first half 2018. You see that also the numbers later, even though we have 49 basis points  funding rates. Consumer market was quite stable. I'll talk a little bit more in the next page. But now overall, I think  the market conditions were quite good for us. On the competition side, basically no change, aggressive  competition, both in auto and in personal loans, but nothing new, I would say, we have faced for the last couple of  years.

file: CMBN - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 3March2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert Oudmayer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: So if we start with page 3, just a few words on the environment, quite favorable with interest rates at historical low  level and foreseen to stay stable through 2014. The Swiss economy grew around 2% and [indiscernible]  (00:00:39), the consumer market was slightly down, I'll talk a bit later about the market more in detail. And also  the environment very stable competitive and regulatory environment, so we didn't see any new entrants coming  into our market on the competitive side in 2013.

texts.speaker: Robert Oudmayer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: On auto, bit of a different picture, market went down 6.2% in 2013. Probably this has been – has to do with the  new CO2 law, which was implemented the 1st of July 2012. A lot of people registered their cars in the first half of  2012 and if you see the second half of 2012 and the second half of 2013, the market has been flat. But overall  6.2% decrease in the market. We expect that market to be around 300,000 in 2014.

file: CMBN - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 26February2015 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert Oudmayer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member of the Management Board, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: So, if you look at the highlights first on the environment, interest rates at historically low levels, these turned  negative and that's basically a funding environment that we had never seen in all those years. Swiss economy,  around 1.7% up last year, and with all the events from the beginning of this year are expected to moderately grow  in 2015.

texts.speaker: Robert Oudmayer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Member of the Management Board, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: As soon as we have more information, we will try to do this, also taking into account the potential mitigation  actions that could be undertaken by us. The potential impact on our business will anyway not be expected in  2015.

texts.speaker: Antoine Boublil
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Member of the Management Board, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: Finally, you see, the GE line down to CHF 500 million in terms of the term loan and the revolving line being fully  capped as an undrawn credit line. Now, talking a little bit about the SNB and the environment there, I think as  every bank in Switzerland SNB will charge cash to all cash that is deposited at the SNB. I mean, for this year we  see something in the context of about a couple of million of charges at the 75 basis points negative rate that  they've indicated. But we also at the same time has a significant amount of debt that is maturing in 2015 and as  we reprice that debt we think this is going to more than offset the SNB charges that I just described. So, and at  the same time, we will continue to pursue our strategy to extend duration of funding.

texts.speaker: Robert Oudmayer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Cembra Money Bank AG
texts.text: If we start on page 3, the environment is a bit of a mixed bag for us. First of all, there is some good news because  the low interest rates continued, inflation is turning positive, consumer confidence is turning positive, so that is  good for us. So, the consumer market has been recovering. First time in a couple of years we've seen a growth in  the consumer loan market. So, overall good. But on the other hand, we have those two things that are bid against  us which is the interest rate cap, so leaving at first 18 months with new interest rate cap, 10% for personal loans  and 12% for credit cards and then the domestic interchange went down from 50 basis points to 44 basis points as  of the 1st of August, 2017. So, a bit of a mixed bag.

CNA - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 28July2010 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: The start of the year saw one of the coldest winters on record in the United Kingdom, however the  company’s – the country’s infrastructure including our own power stations and storage assets  performed well, satisfying the very high levels of energy demand.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In the downstream business, our continued focus on customer service together with a competitive  pricing proposition underpinned the financial result we have achieved. As a result, we were able to  lead the market with a third price reduction within 12 months. Consequently, whilst consumption  was higher as a result of the particularly cold winter, the average customer bill was in fact slightly  lower in the first half of 2010 than in the same period of 2009.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: We also continue to make good progress in both residential services and British Gas business,  which are central to our strategic priority to grow British Gas. And as we look to the future, we are  taking a leading role in emerging new markets and technologies that will help our customers reduce  their energy consumption over time.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In our U.K. upstream business, commodity prices remained low for much of the period. However,  the business benefited from contributions from Venture, British Energy, and from the newly  commissioned gas-fired power station at Langage. And we also had considerable success in our  gas exploration appraisal and development activities.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: At both the national and international level, it is widely recognized that this is an important time for  energy policy, if carbon targets and security of supply considerations are to be met. In the U.K. the  proposals that the new coalition government has put forward represent an important first step  towards creating a stable environment for long-term investment.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: 2 Nick Luff, Group Finance Director  Thank you, Roger. Good morning, everybody. As usual, let me start with some commodity price  context for you. I think as you all know U.K. gas prices were unusually low through last winter,  despite the high demand due to the cold weather. Prices, as you can see on the chart, have risen  since the end of winter and curve now implying price is close to 50p for this coming winter and for  2011 implying they will average some 25% higher than they did in 2010. Power prices did follow  gas prices, they didn’t fall quite as low as coal was pushed to the margin wherein gas prices were  quite low. As you can see, from the spreads, gas is now back of the margin and dark spreads are  back about spark spreads.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Here is the divisional breakdown of the results and you can see the key driver was the U.K.  downstream, of course, but all four business units reported higher results than they did for the first  half of ‘09. So I will have a look at each of those in turn starting with U.K. downstream, British Gas,  up some 80% to 842 million. Within that the two resident – two energy supply businesses did  particularly well, as you would expect, given the cold weather and the low wholesale price, in  contrast, services, which is adversely impacted by cold weather, of course, was slightly down.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In residential, as Roger highlighted, we led the market with a tariff reduction in February, and as a  consequence, added over 220,000 energy accounts and the high customer count did lead to higher  revenue for the business, the lower tariffs were actually offset the higher consumption, and as  Roger explained, the average bills actually was slightly lower in the first half of 2010 compared with  2009.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: The services business did continue to grow, increasing revenue by 6%, but costs were higher  because of the high callout rates we had in the cold weather. As a result, margins pushed down to  15%.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: BGB, on the other hand, significantly expanded margins, partly due to a move away from high- volume, low-margin customers, but also benefiting from the high margins on the incremental  volumes they sold due to the cold weather. Revenue in BGB was actually down as average selling  prices came down with commodity prices, but those higher margins meant that we still more than  doubled profits.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Turning to the upstream here, operating profit up 45% to 485 million, albeit we have put significant  additional capital in here, of course, with the Venture and British Energy deals. Within that, the  detail, gas and oil production volumes up significantly, of course, with the addition of the Venture  assets, but the realized price for gas was quite well down, obviously that’s the lower wholesale  price, but also remember in the first half of ‘09 we have the benefits of forward selling that we’ve  done in 2008 when prices were a lot higher.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: On the power side, the gas generation fleet performed well; we added Langage, of course, that  came on stream fully in March and existing the stations also produced higher volumes as coal was  pushed to the margin. The power segment here, of course, also includes our 20% share of the  stake in British Energy.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Storage performed well operationally in the first half and, of course, financially had for the first four  months of the half year, had the high SBU price from the 2009-10 storage year, which is almost 47  pence. As a result, profits reached almost 100 million. As we’ve already announced, the SBU price  for 2010-2011 storage year is somewhat lower, just under 40 pence; that will, of course, impact the  second half and on into 2011.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In North America, Direct Energy had a good first half, well ahead of 2009, which of course was hit  by the one-off bad debt charges we reported this time last year. Here’s the detail on that, as in the  U.K. the downstream energy supply businesses did well. In residential, customer numbers were  actually slightly down, but the low wholesale price allowed us to expand margins to over 8% as a  consequence, profits up to 110 million. And it’s up over 20%, even if you add back the one-off  charges to last year’s figure.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Business energy supply continued to grow, power sales volumes up some 18% and we were able  to expand margins there as well, which were up to over 3%; as a consequence we more than  doubled profit.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Upstream as in the U.K. has been more challenging, gas production and power generation volumes  were about the same as ‘09, but realized spark spreads for the power station in particular were well  down. As a result, we weren’t able to cover their fixed costs and hence the segment did report a  loss.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Turning to the cash flow, you can see how the strong operating results converted into strong cash  generation. We had EBITDA of approaching 2 billion, although the cold weather and the high  consumption that resulted from that did mean we had a working capital outflow in the first half. The  unwinding of the mark-to-market position on out-of-the-money contracts meant that we did have a  margin cash flow in, recovering most of the margin cash out we had at the start of the year.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: For the full year, the right hand column, we have trimmed our forecast for operational CapEx. It’s  now less likely we’ll see any significant spend on the Baird storage project until next year, so that’s       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: So in summary, then, a strong performance for the first half, both operationally and financially. The  U.K. downstream was the main driver, helped by the cold weather and the low wholesale price, but  the other business units also contributed to the increase. We won’t repeat that downstream  performance in the second half, but overall we are trading in line with expectations, which of course  have risen since we put out the IMS in May when we explained just how strong the first half was  looking.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: As I said earlier, the forward curve does imply some quite significant rises in wholesale prices for  2011. If prices do rise as the curve implies that clearly will have implications on retail prices;  however, we are confident that British Gas capacity advantages and its service levels, its cost  structure will be sustained. Upstream would of course benefit from high gas prices, albeit we’re  expecting slightly lower gas production volumes next year because we’re unlikely to run  Morecambe quite as hard as we did in the first half of this year.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Returns on the CCGTs are more difficult to predict being dependent on the spark spreads we can  achieve in the market, but clearly the nuclear and wind assets would benefit directly from any uplift  in the power price. As ever, there are a number of variables, the main ones being the weather and  commodity prices and how those play into retail prices, but overall we are comfortable with where  market expectations are right now.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Sam Laidlaw, Chief Executive  Thank you very much, Nick, and good morning, everybody. As you just heard, Centrica has  performed very well in the first half of this year and delivered a strong financial result. Importantly  this is underpinned by good operational performance across each of our businesses. And we’ve  now got a balanced business model, which is able to perform well in both high and low commodity  price environments and we’re well positioned for a low carbon future.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: And in our upstream business, the assets have performed well with gas production up by 41% and  our gas-fired power generation fleet again achieved excellent reliability levels. Langage became  fully operational and our share of British Energy also contributed to earnings.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: 5 now exceed offline. This in turn drives lower coal volumes, lower costs and improved customer  service.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In February, we led the market with our third price reduction in 12 months, which made us the  cheapest supplier of gas and electricity. And today, we remain the cheapest supplier for electricity  across Britain, and on average, the cheapest dual fuel supplier.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Consequently, we’ve seen significant customer account growth during the period. We added over  220,000 energy accounts in the first half, with very strong growth seeing in response to the tariff  reduction. Now included in this are 50,000 additional valuable joint product households, if you take  both our energy and services products.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Clearly, the recent sharp upward movement in wholesale gas prices, which have risen some 50%  in the second quarter together with our price reduction has led to significantly lower margins in the  second quarter. Hence, our guidance that our earnings are likely to be heavily skewed to the first  half of the year.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In British Gas services, the exceptionally cold winter led to a record level of callouts. Now to put this  in context, our engineers were fixing as many as 35,000 boilers a day during the cold weather  around double the usual number on a typical winter’s day.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Our Central Heating installation volumes are up 17% year-on-year, as a result of more  competitively priced offerings, shortened sales lead times, and improved retention rates as well as  of course benefiting from the Government’s boiler scrappage scheme.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: As with residential, our business net promoter score continues to increase. As we look to the future  and our indigenous resources dwindle to be replaced by lower carbon alternatives, the U.K. clearly  faces the very real prospect of significantly higher energy prices and this is already starting to be  reflected in futures wholesale market.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: 6 British Gas, therefore, has a vital role to play helping customers to reduce their bills as well as their  carbon footprint through energy efficiency measures and new technologies, leading the  transformation to the low carbon world.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: We therefore very much welcome the Government’s Green Deal initiative and aimed to be at the  forefront of delivering energy efficiency savings both in the home and for our business customers.  And we are the only energy supplier to be involved in the Government’s Pay As You Save pilot.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: And in February, we announced the go ahead for five biomethane demonstration projects, which  will be the first of their kind to enable an injection of biogas directly into the grid. And our existing  interest in solar, biomass, heating and fuel cell boilers make us a leader in microgeneration.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: We’ve installed 100,000 smart meters to date in homes and businesses to build momentum for an  early nationwide smart rollout. We’ve now published open systems architecture standards and  announced our technology partners for the initial phase of the rollout. Now these are important  steps towards our target of installing 2 million smart meters by 2012 and to help the Government  beat its target of 2020 for all U.K. households to have a smart meter.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: We also continue to build our relationship with local authorities in the public sector where we can  also bring our expertise in energy supply and energy efficiency to bear through our successful  Generation Green campaign, which raises awareness of energy efficiency measures amongst  school children, we’ve now reached 10,000 schools in the U.K., 750 of which will also benefit from  our contribution of £15 million worth of solar panels.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Turning to the upstream, we’ve made good progress in our gas and power business during the first  half. Despite the lower gas prices for the first quarter, particularly when compared with our hedge  position in 2009, the business delivered respectable returns. The integration of Venture with our  existing activities has been successfully completed, greatly enhancing our capabilities.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: We’ve had considerable success in our upstream development projects. In early 2010, we  successfully drilled and brought onstream the third development well at our Chiswick field in the  North Sea, with the fourth well expected to come on stream this quarter, and in March, both the Eris  and Ceres gas field commenced production. And work on our F3-FA platform continues to progress  with the platform due to be installed later this year.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: We’ve also had considerable success in our exploration and appraisal activities. Earlier this month,  we announced the successful drilling of the second appraisal well in the western region of the  Cygnus field, completing the appraisal of this field. The full reserve potential is now being assessed  in what could potentially be one of the most significant undeveloped gas fields on the U.K.  Continental Shelf.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: 7 In LNG, the business continues to grow. We expect to shortly complete our Trinidad acquisition,  and have so far this year taken delivery of 9 cargoes into the Isle of Grain terminal, despite low  NBP prices in the first quarter and increased competition from emerging markets. In power  generation, our CCGT fleet has continued to show excellent reliability at over 99%. With gas-fired  power stations displacing coal-fired generation for much of the first half, low factors were relatively  high at 59%. However, spark spreads have remained tight in a well-supplied market.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Our new 885-megawatt gas-fired station at Langage entered full commercial operation in March,  and is now established as one of the most efficient power stations in the U.K. merit order.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In offshore wind, we completed the joint venture agreement with DONG and Siemens for  development of the 270 megawatt Lincs project. All major contracts for this project have now been  awarded and onshore contracts and cable installation have commenced.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In nuclear, our 20% share of output from the British Energy fleet in the first half of the year was 5  terawatt-hours. Having been adversely affected by lower output from Sizewell B, which has been  offline since March for inspection and repair. This station is however expected to return to service  later this quarter.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In nuclear new build, engineering studies continue. We welcome the recognition from the  Government but appropriate mechanisms will be required to enable investment in low carbon  generation including a floor in the carbon price, and we will engage closely with Government to  ensure that an economic solution is reached.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: In gas storage, Rough continues to achieve excellent operational performance with reliability over  99% in the first half. Rough performed a particularly important role during the cold weather in  January, helping to maintain supplies during periods of record demand for gas. The capital program  of the last few years has further enhanced the withdrawal and injection capabilities of the asset as  you can see on this chart.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Following the narrowing of winter/summer spreads, the average price we achieved for the storage  standard bundled units, as Nick mentioned, has declined. This potentially impacts both the level of  underlying returns achievable from Rough, but also the economics of our three potential new gas  storage projects.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: As to our two other gas projects, Baird and Bains, engineering studies continue, although these are  complex offshore projects, which have slower cycle times and further works required to ensure the  satisfactory returns on investment can be achieved. Decision on both these offshore projects is now  expected in 2011.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: 8 However, weak commodity prices and tight spreads have continued to impact our North American  upstream business holding back the overall result. We expect that the soft price – gas price  environment in North America may continue to be with us for a while, and therefore, while our  strategic goal remains to increase our upstream hedge position, we will be very focused on  ensuring that any upstream investment is robust in a low price environment and indeed we’re  examining some opportunities at the moment in this context.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: Our North American business energy supply division has performed extremely well. We saw higher  electricity volumes and an improved focus on sales channels, which have resulted in strong growth.  Further benefits were achieved through a highly disciplined approach to customer acquisition and  more focused pricing to reflect credit and collateral utilization.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: And in North American services, our acquisition of Clockwork materially increases the scale of the  business in a cost effective way, whilst also providing a platform for growth through its established  franchise model. The transaction also enhances our ability to offer combined energy and services  product in a greater proportion over the key deregulated markets in which we operate, up from 35%  to around 55%.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: By leveraging our experience from the U.K. services business, the transaction marks a further step  in the delivery of our strategy to build a larger, more vertically integrated energy business with a  strong energy services offering and is very well positioned to take advantage of new energy  efficiency legislation in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Interim Results
texts.text: The combination of a robust organic cash generation with the optionality of a range of investment  choices provides a sound platform for delivering both growth and returns. And we now have a  balanced business, positioned for growth in both high and low commodity price environments and  leading the transition to the low carbon world.

file: CNA - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Roger M. Carr  Chairman & Deputy President, Centrica Plc  Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our results presentation. Centrica performed well in  the first half, demonstrating the value of the vertically integrated international business model and the caliber of  the management team. Importantly, this performance was achieved in the face of economic headwinds and  climatic condition that were very different from the previous year. The challenges facing the company where those  that were general to many businesses in the developed economies and some that were specific to the UK energy  industry in particular.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Pressure on consumer spending in a period of modest economic recovery constrained the pace of growth in  central heating installations and other parts of our service business. Equally, the tax imposed on North Sea gas  undermined forward post-tax earnings and our capital investment plans. We have continued to contest both the  fairness and wisdom of this tax. However, the government has shown little appetite for amending a policy decision  which has both undermined economic growth and UK energy security of supply. It's also a little regrettable that  while the sharp increase in wholesale gas price necessitated an increase in our retail prices, the position has been  exacerbated by the increase in upstream tax.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We haven't given up, not but there are no longer optimistic in our thinking of a favorable outcome. Within the  company, management continued to address the cost base in order to mitigate the impact of escalating wholesale  gas prices in the UK and preserve both margin and our competitive edge. These actions facilitated growth in  customer numbers in British Gas in the first six months, but they couldn't offset the need to recover major  commodity cost movement through the price increase that we announced in July.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I would emphasize, however, that the financial and managerial disciplines applied to all investment that we make,  whether at home or abroad, will continue to be rigorously enforced by the board. In the current climate, our  strong balance sheet gives us the ability to take advantage of any opportunities as they arise. Accordingly, I would  confirm that it is our intention to maintain this financial flexibility and reward shareholders with a progressive  dividend policy and profitable expansion of our successful business model.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking forward, the fragility of the UK recovery, the political turbulence in oil-producing countries and the  aftermath of the nuclear disaster in Japan will continue to bring both uncertainty and challenge to all energy  companies. In these circumstances, I can assure you that the Centrica management team under Sam Laidlaw's  leadership will be alert to the issues, innovative in their planning and determined in their actions to ensure the  business is correctly balanced in cost, asset base and business mix to meet the conditions that prevail.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Roger. Good morning, everybody. As usual, let me start with some commodity price context. As you all  know, 2011 has been a turbulent period for energy prices. The unrest in the Middle East and North Africa, of  course, has pushed up oil prices. And we have seen a significant increase in global demand for gas, driven by the  nuclear outages in Japan and economic growth elsewhere in Asia.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Prices here in the UK, where we're increasingly dependent on imports, particularly LNG, have risen in response  and month-ahead NBP prices averaged £58 per therm in the first six months of the year, up over 70% against the  same period last year. Power prices have tracked gas prices upwards, as you would expect, and with the UK system  well supplied, spot spreads have remained depressed.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Dark spreads have recovered somewhat, albeit not to the levels we saw two to three years ago. Meanwhile, the  disconnect of the North American market has been confirmed, with plentiful domestic gas supply there, meaning  there's been very little impact from the rising prices elsewhere in the world. And also in the U.S., reserve margins  remain healthy in most areas and spot spreads remain low there, too.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: That commodity price environment coupled with much warmer weather in the UK has made difficult trading  conditions for Centrica, certainly challenging against the very strong and favorable conditions we had this time  last year. Nevertheless, the group posted a good set of results, as you can see here.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Going through each division in turn, starting with downstream UK British Gas, here profits came in £518 million.  As we expected, the profitability of the residential energy supply business halved compared to the very strong  result last year when we had the very odd combination of high consumption, due to the cold weather, coupled with  very low wholesale prices. In contrast, this year of course, we've had much more normal temperatures apart from  April, actually which was unseasonably warm and higher wholesale prices.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Residential services, as Roger mentioned, faced a tough environment with competitor activity and low consumer  confidence. However, we did continue to grow our services activities, with revenue up 8%. Profits were also  following the very clod winter last year. The warm weather this year has impacted business energy supply albeit to  a lesser extent than the residential, but you can see the profits are down there. The economic climate is having an  impact on both volumes and margins in that business.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turn to the upstream, here profits came in at over $0.5 billion, beating what was, in fact, a very strong  performance in the first half of last year, so a very good result overall. With the ending of the major loss-making  [ph] INC (9:13) contracts, we're now reporting the upstream UK segment in two simple parts, as you can see gas  and power. Midstream and trading activities, we split between two and allocated appropriately.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So starting at the top right, you can see gas production was down as expected, with the Morecambe decline not  entirely offset by the increase in production from other fields. Oil production, on the other hand which of course is  increasingly valuable in this price environment, was up in part due to the increased interest we have in Statfjord  field which we bought more of last year. You can see from the bottom left chart the benefit we had from the higher  wholesale prices coming through, our realized gas price up 27%, our realized oil price up 37%

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power, we have two quite distinct stories. Nuclear performance was excellent, output there up over 25%, one of  the best performances in the British energy fleet for some several years. And of course, that output was more  valuable, albeit again, hedging does delay the full benefit.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In contrast, the CCGTs were struggling. We did manage to hold up the realized spot spreads, as you can see, due to  hedging and peat running, but with low market spreads, we run the fleet much less and as a result were only just  able to cover our fixed costs. And as a result, the power segment as a whole, despite that strong nuclear result, was  slightly down.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: North America had a very strong half year. Profit was up 25% to £174 million. Within that, residential energy was  slightly down. We didn't have quite such favorable conditions as we had in the first of 2010, when we had the  falling commodity prices. Nevertheless, customer growth is strong, in the U.S. Northeast in particular, and Texas  operationally performed very well, albeit we were hit there by the cold weather in February, when power prices  spiked to $3,000 per megawatt hour. The ECPA in Ontario is beginning to impact customer numbers there, albeit  the financial impact we won't see until the second half and into 2012.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Business energy supply continued to grow strongly. Power sales were up 21% and scale benefits meant we were  able to widen margins further, so profits are up even more, up 30% to £58 million. Services was slightly up, but  the second half is much more important for that business, given its seasonality.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turn to the upstream, cash production was up and the profit contribution from gas production was also much  higher, despite the low gas price. And that was due to Wildcat Hills acquisition, which boosted production and  reduced our unit operating costs quite significantly. The three Texas CCGTs, on the other hand, struggled,  that hit us downstream. We do expect a similar pattern in the second half in North America, with Ontario now  beginning to hold back residential, but the other three business units performing strongly.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Here's the breakdown of CapEx. As you can see, upstream gas remains the most significant area of investment. In  the first half, the main components within that were the new developments, Ensign and York. It was lower than  the first half of 2010 upstream gas, but we felt that would reverse in the second half as we step up those  developments at Ensign and York. We also continued to spend on Lincs, the wind farm, which is in the UK power  segment there and that also will see higher spend in the second half.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Coming down to the bottom, acquisitions, in the first half included the Gateway acquisition, the energy supply  business in the U.S., Wildcat hills, the Albertan gas business, and PH Jones in the UK. Those two together total  over £100 million. They were offset, though, by the proceeds from the sale of Oxxio, which competed in June,  leaving you with the net £26 million that you see there.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So in summary then, a good performance for the group as whole in tough trading conditions, albeit down on last  year, and good operating performance right across the group, with upstream production and nuclear output being  particular highlights, and good profit growth in North America.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thank you very much, Nick, and good morning, everyone. As Nick mentioned, the first half of 2011 has been a  contrast, in North America, gas and power prices have remained low as a result of the shale oil and shale gas  phenomenon.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Self-sufficiency has disconnected North American Market from other worldwide energy markets. We're also  operating in a challenging economic environment, with falling disposal income and weak consumer confidence.  And against this backdrop, the UK energy system is entering a period of transformational change to ensure that  the country has the secure low carbon energy to meet the requirements of the next generation.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
