texts.text: In parallel to the necessary reform of the electricity generation market, Ofgem has proposed certain changes to  retail markets. While we agree with the need for greater transparency, choice, and simplicity for customers, there  is a risk that the current proposals may have unintended consequences. We therefore continue to engage with  Ofgem to ensure the optimal design of any changes to the future market rules.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In our UK upstream business, we delivered strong operational performance, notably with a 25% increase in  nuclear output and we're making good progress on our investment pipeline of new projects in offshore wind and  in gas development. And in North America, we continue to develop to deliver growth, building on our platform in  key competitive markets. So in summary, despite challenging market conditions, we've made considerable  operational progress and remain on track to deliver earnings growth for the full year.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to British Gas in more detail, in residential energy we added almost 160,000 customer accounts in the  first six months of the year. We now serve over 16 million accounts for the first time in over five years. We  continue to raise the standards of our customer service and recorded a further improvement in our net promoter  score.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And we've seen significant increase in the number of online transactions, which have doubled to over 10 million in  the first half of the year alone. And this is an important trend, not only in terms of being a cost-effective channel,  but also because it provides more opportunities for customer engagement. We now have made over 100,000 sales  through our [ph] Saindsbridge (19:44) energy affinity program, a good example of how we can acquire high value  customers through attractive competitive offerings.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Earlier this month, we announced price increases for residential gas and electricity necessitated by the sharp  increase in worldwide gas prices. We recognize the impact that this will have on our customers and continue to  provide extra help for our most vulnerable customer through our essentials program, which over the last year  amounted to discount of some £180 to those households most in need of help.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As a result of the weak economic environment, services customer numbers declined slightly at the start of the  year, but grew progressively through the second quarter, recovering the lost ground. The number of central  heating installations was broadly flat, with some customers deferring the decision to replace their boilers.  However, our services business remains well placed for further growth, albeit at a slower rate than previously  expected.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: New markets also provide us with additional growth opportunities and importantly, will help us to deepen our  customer relationships. As such we've gone early on the government's flagship energy efficiency policy, the Green  Deal. Our home energy plan is now enabling customer to install efficient new boilers, insulation, and solar panels,  all at no up-front cost.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Our own in-house insulation team has now completed over 100,000 installations just 15 months after recruiting  its first employee. We're now the largest installer of solar PV panels in the UK and we are leading the installation  and roll-out of smart meters, having installed over 350,000 to date.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Another growth area is the provision of energy services to the social housing sector. Building on our agreement  with Mears last year, we acquired PH Jones in April, enabling us to achieve a step-change in our capability in this  important sector. We've also launched our electric car charging proposition and we're now the preferred supplier  and installer of charging points of both Nissan and Renault and as a result, expect to have a significant share of  this rapidly growing market by 2012.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning now to our upstream activities, we achieved strong operational performance both in gas and oil  production and in power generation. Overall, production volumes in the first half were around 10% lower than in  the same period last year. That really reflected Morecambe's running patterns.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: However, production levels from our other fields were significantly higher, with F3FA and Babbage coming  onstream and strong production from our existing assets, particularly Statfjord, Grove and Chiswick. For the full  year despite the Morecambe shutdown, we expect total production volumes to be around 50 million barrels of oil  equivalent, subject to the running patterns for the reminder of the year. We have also move forward a number of  new gas field developments. In February, we announced the decision to develop the York and Ensign fields at a  cost of £450 million, which between them, are expected to bring over 30 million barrels of reserves into  production.  In March, we took the decision to develop the Rhyl gas field in the Irish Sea and we expect to achieve first gas this  year from Ensign and in 2012 from York and Rhyl. Our drilling program has also continued to be successful. All  five of the production wells drilled so far are contributing to our production and in exploration, the discovery at  Pegasus warrants further appraisal. And in May, we took the delivery of the first LNG cargo under our contract  with Qatargas, marking an important step in our relationship with the world's largest LNG supplier.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power generation, the reliability of the nuclear fleet was much improved. The output from our wind farms was  also much better, with more favorable wind conditions particularly in the second quarter. However the low spot  spread environment meant that we took the decision to move four of our older CCGTs into short-term  preservation mode. This has reduced our operating cost whilst enabling us to return the units to service within a  few days if commercially viable.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to our investment projects, we are making good progress on the Lincs wind farm development. The  onshore substation is largely complete and the fast foundations are in place and we expect to generate first power  from Lincs at the end of next year. As we look to the future, it's now widely recognized that this is a pivotal time  for energy policy in the UK.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Following the publication of the white paper earlier this month, we'll continue to engage closely with the  government on electricity market reform to ensure that the overall framework translates into stable and attractive  investment opportunities. However, there remains much to be done and to be resolved and we will only invest  when it's in the best interest of our shareholders to do so, with an appropriate balance between risk and rewards.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In the case of new nuclear build, following the events in Japan, it's clear that the program will be delivered later  than originally hoped. And we expect to have clarity on the revised time table towards the end of the year. New  nuclear is an important option for us, but we will only invest if we were satisfied that the returns represent good  value for our shareholders set against the commercial risks.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As we said at our Investor Day last month, North America presents an attractive growth opportunity for Centrica  outside the UK, leveraging our core expertise. In direct energy residential, our operational performance has been  strong with the Texas transformation program, in particular, delivering real results. We have also successfully  launched our pre-paid offering, helping more customers to take control of their energy requirements.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Direct Energy business continues to make good progress, with electricity volumes up by over 20%. In an  increasingly competitive market, we continue to focus closely on operational efficiencies and customer service for  complete and we expect to see a more significant contribution from the services business in the second half of the  year. Clockwork gives us a robust platform for growth through its established franchise model.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So in summary, we've made good operational progress in the first half of the year, demonstrating the resilience  and flexibility of Centrica's business model in an environment of sharply rising wholesale gas prices and falling  consumer confidence and disposable income. However, given the challenging market environment and the  headwinds this creates, close management focus on costs is required to ensure that we retain our competitive  position.

file: CNA - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 26July2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Under Sam's leadership, our plan has been to build a more sustainable business model, vertically integrated, cost- effective and customer-friendly, with meaningful geographic diversity. And over the last five years, step by step,  much has been undertaken to achieve these objectives. But this year, our £1 billion investment in Norway, the  generation of first power from Lincs offshore wind, the expansion of our North American interests, almost  doubling in size in 36 months.

texts.speaker: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Nevertheless, recognizing that long-term success is a function of short-term achievements, the financial  performance in the first half has been good, particularly given the challenges of the general economic climate and  the competitive market conditions. It's important however to remember that the notable improved profitability in  British Gas reflected both the traditional first-half weighting and compared with a particularly unusual period of  warm weather and a low consumption in the previous year. While showing material growth year-on-year therefore  the level of profit remains only that which is appropriate to maintaining a sustainable business model, which in  turn will enable the Group to continue investing in long-term security of supply.

texts.speaker: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking forward, the work undertaken by the management team in reducing cost and improving customer service  will without doubt be vital to maintaining profitability and cementing continued customer loyalty in the face of  upward pressure on commodity, environmental, social and regulatory costs, which are outside of our control but  inevitably impact retail prices.

texts.speaker: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I would emphasize to you that the financial discipline of sound economic returns and shareholder value are the  bedrock of all our investment decision-making and will remain so when evaluating all future projects, including  new nuclear build.  In the meantime, we will continue to develop Centrica with customers at the heart of the business by continued  drive on organic growth, cost reduction, asset replenishment when necessary, customer additions when available  and upstream expansion when appropriate to our business model.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Roger. Good morning, everybody. As usual, let me start with the commodity price backdrop to these  results. Outturn gas and oil prices were actually very similar to H1 2012, as they were in the comparative period in  2011. However, they have been at these high levels for longer, so more of the effect was felt both upstream and  downstream without the delay from hedging seen last year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Spark spreads were of course very low, much lower than in H1 2011, impacting the running pattern of our CCGTs  and feeding through into outright power prices. In contrast, our competitors in the last year, before the end of free  carbon, benefited from the much higher dark spreads for their coal stations.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Commodity prices were not however the most significant external factor in the year-over-year performance. As  Roger mentioned, that was the weather. You will remember the first half of last year was unusually warm. This  year, despite a warm Q1, overall the average temperature in the UK was slightly colder than normal. Gas  consumption per customer for British Gas increased by 5% as a result. That did mean that the British Gas  residential segment produced a more normal level of profit in the first half and the Group as a whole was well  ahead of H1 2011 as a result.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So starting with downstream UK, British Gas. Here, profits increased by 9% to £563 million. Within that,  residential energy was up significantly with the more normal weather driving higher volumes than last year.  Higher average retail prices covered higher external costs, both commodity and non-commodity, as we continued  to control and reduce internal costs.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Residential services, which now includes new energy activity, continues to perform well despite tough economic  conditions, with cost control enabling a 14% increase in the first half. The services business remains on track for a  10% growth in the full year. In contrast, we were not able to mitigate fully the impact of the difficult trailing  conditions in the B2B market and weak volumes and margins being squeezed there, leaving B2B's result down at  £93 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Moving to the upstream, profits there increased by over 25% to £682 million. Both gas and power contributed to  the increase. Gas production volumes were up by 6% driven by the assets acquired from Statoil and our increased  interest in Statfjord field, both of which were owned for two months of the first half.  These additional volumes offset lower production from Morecambe, where we did have some gas blending  challenges as well as seeing the continued natural decline of that field. As you can see, liquids production was  broadly unchanged with the acquisition of assets in Total, which does include a fair amount of oil production not  yet fully completed.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Hedging [indiscernible] (8:26) that realize prices upstream last year so we did see higher realized prices in 2012  despite market prices for gas and oil outturning at similar levels. The power result was perhaps surprisingly  strong, in part reflecting the profit recorded when we sold down 50% of our interest in the Round 3 Irish Sea Zone  for offshore wind development, bringing in Don as a partner. However, the underlying trading result from the  CCGTs was still poor, although our realized spots would only fall a little, that was due to peak running and  hedging and low market spark spread, and then we run the stations much less. In contrast, nuclear output  remains high with slightly higher realized prices also helping the overall nuclear result.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: At £36 million, storage was only slightly down on H1 2011. We did have low SBU prices for the first four months of  the year but the business is now benefiting from the higher SBU prices for the 2012/13 storage year. The full-year  profit is set to show improvement as a result.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Despite the expected decline in Ontario and unfavorable weather, residential energy still posted results of over  £100 million benefiting from the three acquisitions made in 2011. We will see further benefit from these  acquisitions in the second half although there will be some integration costs associated with the Energetix and  NYSEG acquisitions that we announced two weeks ago.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Business energy supply was slightly up, with underlying growth more than offsetting the effect of the milder  weather on volumes.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Services in North America was also slightly up, with the result held back by the impact of industrial action that has  now been resolved. And with North American gas prices reaching new lows in the first half, conditions were  challenging for upstream business and you'll see we did record a small loss there.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And power spend on the Lincs windfarm stepped up as we near the data of first power and we'll see high spend on  that project for the next 12 months, offset by any sale of the transmission assets after the Lincs joint venture.  Acquisitions there include the assets acquired from Statoil and the additional interest in Statfjord. That line also  includes some payments for the assets acquired from Total, albeit there is more to pay on that deal in the second  half.  The amounts flowing through the cash flow for all three of those deals is less than the announced headline prices,  reflecting the cash generated between the effective dates and the closing dates. That cash is retained by the  vendors but knocked off the acquisition prices.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In summary then, a good first half benefiting from more normal weather in the UK and from acquisitions  upstream. Looking forward, we have seen a drop-off in commodity prices, particularly oil, but hedging means that  the upstream result for this year is largely protected from that. Trading conditions are tough for BGB and for  upstream in North America, but we continue to see growth elsewhere, both organic and through acquisition, with  cost control also contributing to the results. So overall, we remain comfortable with our expectations for the full  year with the usable variables of commodity prices, the weather and the competitive environment.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And we've made important strategic progress, driving long-term growth in British Gas with high levels of service,  leadership in energy efficiency and innovation together with a simplified energy offering. Delivering a substantial  increase in the size and geographic diversity of our upstream gas in all the business and crystallizing value in  offshore wind through our partnership model, and building scale in North America adding customers in key  markets and driving efficiencies, making good progress towards our targets of doubling the profitability of the  business. And across the Group, we're continuing to generate strong cash flows, deploying capital where we see  attractive returns and delivering year-on-year real dividend growth with a total increase in the dividend of more  than 55% over the last five years.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The investments that we made in our systems in call center technology is delivering real results, contributing to  improvements in MPS and enabling more efficient handling of customer calls and targeted sales efforts. We've  now enrolled over 4.5 million customers through our affinity programs, and we have upgraded our online offering,  recording a 10% increase in the number of transactions, with over 3 million customers now registered online. And  we're continuing to help our customers reduced that energy consumption with around 250,000 customers taking  up our free insulation offer, so far this year. We've now installed over 600,000 smart meters for residential and  small business customers and see considerable benefit from our decision to go early, inline with the strategy for  the smart connected home, and we continue to lead and our support for the vulnerable. Once again, significantly  exceeding the levels required by government with British Gas having the widest eligibility of all oil suppliers for  the warm home discount.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We are also simplifying our energy offering by launching a new bill design at a simplified tariff structure all  consistent with the objectives of Ofgem's Retail Market Review program. And in British Gas business, while  We signed our first multi-year energy performance contracts working in partnership with our customers to deliver  energy efficiency savings, a good example of growth in business services. In British Gas Services, we continue to  see strong retention of our core products, underlying the value customers place in our services, particularly in the  tough economic environment.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Upstream in Centrica Energy, our recent North Sea acquisitions have delivered a step change in the business,  taking as much of the way towards our 75 million barrel production target and transforming the scale of our  Norwegian activities. Now that we have successfully achieved this, we'll focus on bringing reserves into  production, with over 1 billion barrels of 2P and 2C reserves in our portfolio.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: On our development projects, we expect to deliver around 140 million barrels of reserves equivalent into  production in the next three years. We achieved first gas at Ensign in May with Seven Seas, Atla and Rhyl expected  to follow over the coming months. Our York project remains on track for first production early next year and at  Valemon part of the package of Norwegian assets we acquired from Statoil construction is progressing well, as you  can see in this photo.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We're also making considerable progress in offshore wind bringing links online working towards final investment  decision on Race Bank and crystallizing value by selling down a stake in our Round 3 permit in the Irish Sea.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We are having success with the launch of a number of innovative customer propositions. Our power to go prepaid  product continues to attract new customers, enabling more people to take control of the energy requirements. And  in the U.S. Northeast, we've introduced Free Power Saturdays' encouraging customers to take advantage of off- peak periods of demand. These products are welcomed by the regulators who are increasingly recognizing the  benefits that competitive markets can bring.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning next to DE business, where we are delivering further organic growth. Electricity volumes were up 8% in  the period. Much of the growth is coming in the small commercial business segment, where we are making good  progress with the bespoke solutions and high levels of customer service. We've also seen strong renewal rates in  the commercial and industrial market as we focus on reducing costs and continually improving our cost top price  competitiveness.  In North American services, we are driving growth through our established on-demand business model, but we  are also developing proportions to cross sale services to the energy customer base and over time to introduce  service protection plans in each case, building on our experience from the UK services market. Upstream in North  America, the business continues to face a low gas and electricity price environment although the price for liquids  has remained relatively high. In power generation, we've seen some recovery and spreads in Texas, but the market  remains extremely volatile.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We therefore optimize the running patterns of our CCGTs to capture the power price volatility. Our £500 million  Group-wide cost-reduction program is well on track with little over half of the savings expected to be realized this  year. Our aim is to sharpen the business, maintaining a competitive edge, while continuing to deliver high levels of  service.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In Centrica Energy, we are closing our loss-making King's Lynn power station with the future of our Peterborough  and Roosecote under review. In North America, we are achieving scale benefits both from organic growth and  recent acquisitions, and our cost structure will also benefit from the move of our head office to Houston.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In gas and oil, we're investing some £900 million per annum delivering reserves into production and sustaining  our reserve life. In offshore wind, we're bringing Lincs on-screen and working towards final investment decision  on Race Bank. And in North America we're continuing to seek value-added acquisitions further in-housing the  scale of the business in competitive markets.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We also welcome the progress the UK Government is making on electricity market reform, and in particular, the  recognition of the role of gas is part of the longer-term energy mix for the country. We have a portfolio of options  across the range of technologies in offshore winds, New Nuclear, biomass, new build CCGTs and indeed gas  storage.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In this respect, the clarity provided yesterday by the government around the medium-term ROC banding for low- carbon technologies is helpful in informing our future investment choices.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So in conclusion, we've made good progress in the year to date, delivering growth and sharpening the business to  diversity of the business, delivering a step change in our upstream gas in oil portfolio, and further enhancing the  scale in North America. And this is all in the context of our distinctive integrated business model, with a leading  customer focus downstream business, strong cash generation across the Group, and an attractive portfolio  investment options delivering both growth and value for shareholders.

file: CNA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 31July2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Roger M. Carr
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Okay. Well, good morning, everybody, and welcome. As you remember, the first half of the year was materially  influenced by pretty unusual UK weather patterns with low temperatures and that resulted in higher than normal  seasonal gas and electricity consumption. And the effect in the UK was an increase in energy used by British Gas  customers and additional demands on our Services business. The impact of higher consumption on profit,  however, was largely offset by the substantial increase in environmental costs associated with the government's  low carbon policies, particularly the ECO program, as well as some higher commodity costs.

texts.speaker: Roger M. Carr
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As we said before, recognizing the economic challenges faced by many of our customers and the impact of  exceptional cold weather, in May, the board determined that any benefit arising from higher consumption during  the winter would be used to maintain our price competitiveness and in this context, we have absorbed the  significant increase in environmental costs during this period.

texts.speaker: Roger M. Carr
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, Direct Energy achieved profits modestly above the previous year despite pretty challenging  market conditions. Upstream, Centrica Energy performed well. But low spark spreads continued to undermine  power generation profitability. Investment in our North American operations with our Qatari partners, coupled  with a decision to enter into a joint venture for shale gas in the UK, helped to secure potentially important sources  of gas for the longer term.

texts.speaker: Roger M. Carr
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We entered the second half with a revitalized management structure and further opportunities to develop the  business both in the UK and North America. And in this context, the announcement yesterday of our North  American Energy Marketing acquisition does mark an important development for the business, aligned with our  strategy of investing in core markets where we see attractive growth opportunities.

texts.speaker: Roger M. Carr
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power generation, we welcomed the progress made by government in setting out their energy policy  framework. However, further detail is required in order that we are able to identify and measure the economic  returns of these projects and then compare them with other uses of our capital.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Roger. Good morning, everyone. As usual, let me start with the commodity price backdrop for these  results. As you all know, UK gas prices were volatile in the first half and the average outturn price was higher from  the same period in 2012. The same is true for power prices.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: This helped the upstream of course but did give us high input costs in the downstream. Oil prices on the other  hand were lower. In North America, the outturn Henry Hub price was materially higher in the first half of this  year compared to last, albeit still at much lower levels than in the UK. This helped the upstream to some extent,  but did lead to some pressure on margins in the U.S. energy supply businesses.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: UK spark spreads remained low, as Roger mentioned, meaning our CCGTs ran even less than last year and the  market is indicating very little recovery for the rest of this year and into 2014. The cold weather, as you would  expect, had a significant impact on consumption in the UK. Although the weather in the first half of 2012 was  cooler than normal, 2013 was substantially colder again, and each month colder than the seasonal norm. Gas  consumption per customer for British Gas residential increased by 13%, as a result.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Here are the Group figures – the Group performed well against this commodity price backdrop with higher  operating profit in each business unit. Group revenue was up 14%, reflecting the higher wholesale gas and power  prices, and higher gas consumption in the UK and increased gas and oil production as a result of the 2012  upstream acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So, here is the divisional breakdown of the results. Running through them and starting with British Gas where  profits increased by 1%. The colder weather resulted in higher residential gas volumes, as I said, and therefore,  high revenue. However, increased external costs – commodity, transportation, environmental, meant that  residential energy came in only marginally higher than last year at £356 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: These results do include £300 million of ECO costs, equivalent to half a year of our estimated cost for the whole  two-and-a-quarter year program. This is a significantly higher cost than for the CERT and CESP programs that  ECO replaces, largely absorbing the benefit of higher volumes due to the cold weather.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: But cold weather did result in some additional costs in residential services, some of which will come through in  the second half as we recover our backlog of our annual service visits. However, we saw the benefit of 2012 cost  savings in the first half in services, mitigated the impact of the China economic environment and resulting in an  8% increase in profit.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Then when it comes to North America, Direct Energy again delivered a profit growth, up 6%. Note that this  business unit no longer includes the Canadian upstream gas business, which has been transferred across to  Centrica Energy and we've restated the comparatives to reflect that switch.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: However, organic profit growth in the U.S. North East, further operational synergies and previous acquisitions  meant that the profit for DE Residential as a whole was only slightly down. Business energy supply, which now  includes power generation and midstream activity, grew once again, brought its volumes up 17%. There has been  some upward pressure on margins, as I said, but an improved result from the power business more than offset  this, leaving an increase in profit of over 20%. Services also performed well with higher revenues and higher  margins leading to an 18% increase in profit.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Now into Centrica Energy, now including the Canadian gas production business, as I said, here profits increased  by 16% to over £800 million. Total gas production volumes were up by 19%, and liquids production was even  more by 31%, with a full period impact from the assets acquired from Statoil, ConocoPhillips and Total in 2012,  together with first production from the York and Rhyl fields has more than offset the natural decline in the  existing assets.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Volumes in the second half will include production from the Suncor asset acquisition in Canada, which is expected  to complete around the beginning of September. The achieved gas price was higher than last year, reflecting the  higher wholesale price while the achieved liquids price was also up, but the lower market oil price duped the  impact of forward hedging and FX movements. Although costs increased reflecting the increased scale of the  business and industry inflation, overall gas profit increased by 32%. [indiscernible] (10:27) as Roger mentioned,  trading conditions remained very challenging for the gas-fired generation fleet with our CCGTs no longer  benefiting from free carbon allowances and volume slightly down on last year reflecting lower market spark  spreads. As a result, our CCGTs were significantly loss making.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Nuclear output was once again good and nuclear profit was up slightly compared to 2012, benefiting from higher  wholesale prices. Overall, though, power profit fell by 32% despite a £29 million profit on disposal, relating to the  sale of our interest in the Braes of Doune wind farm.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Then to storage, storage benefited in the first half from the higher SBU price for the 2012-2013 storage year. As a  result, profit increased by over 30% to £47 million. However, as you know, summer winter spreads have narrowed  considerably and as a result of the SBU price achieved for the 2013-2014 storage year was much lower. We  therefore expect profitability in the second half to reduce significantly.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Organic CapEx was just over £700 billion, as you can see. As expected, the majority of that is invested in the  Upstream business with significant spend at York, Statfjord, Cygnus and Valemon. And in power, most of the  spend was on Lincs, which we move towards final commissioning of the wind farm in the second half. The second  half will also see continued investment upstream with further spend on Cygnus, Statfjord and the additional wells  at in York and also at Grove and Kew. We also have a final spend on Lincs, potentially offset by the sale of  transmission assets out from the joint venture. Overall, we still expect to spend around £1.5 billion organically for  the full year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The full-year acquisition number there you see includes £700 million, which includes working capital relating to  the Hess transaction we announced yesterday. We also expect to complete the acquisition of gas and oil assets  from Suncor in Alberta, our 60% share equating to around to £400 million and to close the smaller acquisition of  Bounce Energy in Texas. These deals will use some of the balance sheet headroom that we have. However, the  acquired businesses will generate additional cash flow but once we get into 2014, and have a full year of that cash  flow, the impact won't be that significant. So, we'll still have a strong position and freedom to deploy the cash  generated by the Group as a whole to make further investments or return it to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In summary then, we delivered good earnings growth for the first half despite economic headwinds. In particular,  impacting BGB and weak market conditions for gas flow generation in the U.K. We saw further profit growth in  North America while upstream gas profitability increased, reflecting higher production and higher realized prices.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Continued weak spark spreads and reduced gas – seasonal gas spreads will impact the business in the second half.  However, we will look for further organic growth in U.K. services and in North America. And we'll continue to  benefit from the integration of previous acquisitions. Overall, we remain on track to deliver full-year earnings  growth in line with expectations.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: I'd like to put the first half performance in the context of the new strategic priorities that we set out in February to  meet the challenges of a rapidly changing energy landscape. To recap, we will innovate to drive growth and service  excellence. We will integrate our national gas business linked to our core markets. And we will increase our  returns through efficiency and continued capital discipline. And our vision remains the same, to be the leading  integrated energy company with customers at our core.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: British Gas and Direct Energy, both continue to develop innovative solutions to help our customers manage their  energy requirements. And the acquisition of the Energy Marketing business from Hess, which we announced  yesterday, marks an important step towards our growth targets in North America.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In Centrica Energy, our recent contract with Cheniere for U.S. gas export, the acquisition of further upstream  assets in North America in partnership with QPI, and the purchase of a stake in the Bowland shale license in the  UK, all helped to secure a potentially important sources of gas for the long term.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We've made further progress in delivering organic projects, and we retain a range of investment options across the  Group. And importantly, we remain on track to delivering our £500 million cost reduction program by the end of  this year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Downstream, our customers remain at the heart of what we do and we'll help them save money wherever we can.  We've already implemented many of the recommendations set out by Ofgem in their Retail Market Review to  make the supply of energy simpler, deeper and fairer, including our unique Tariff Check with allows customers to  make sure that they are on the most appropriate tariff for them. We'll also move to a single standing charge, and  later this year we expect to simplify our offering with just four core tariffs.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The new ECO program is well underway, delivering carbon savings and efficiencies to some of our most  vulnerable customers in partnership with local authorities and other community organizations, albeit at  significantly higher cost than the previous environmental initiatives. The ECO program alone has increased the  British gas cost base by some £100 million in the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: During the first half, we've seen further benefit from the investment in our industry-leading digital platform. A  third of our UK residential customers are registered online. And we now receive more customer contact through  digital channels including our top-rated smartphone app than by any other method. We are also leading the  industry in putting customers in control of their energy use. We have now installed over one million smart meters  in homes and businesses.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: British Gas Services delivered good operational performance during the unusually cold weather, attending a  record 1.6 million boiler breakdowns in the first half. We're also launching a number of new services propositions  with packages tailored specifically for landlords and tenants. In British Gas business, the environment remains  challenging. With a new management team and structure in place, we are making improvements to position the  business for the future. Our systems upgrade project, which we expect to deliver improved service at lower cost, is  progressing to plan.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We also continue to develop our services proposition for businesses and have commenced work on eight energy  performance contracts across the country. In North America, the recently announced acquisition of Bounce  Energy gives us a market-leading online capability, which will allow us to acquire new customers at a much  reduced cost. And in Texas, we are launching our free electricity Saturday's tariff building on the time-of-use  offering, which our customers in the U.S. North East already enjoy. Whilst across Direct Energy, retention levels  have improved reflecting further advances in the quality of our customer service.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We also saw organic customer growth in Direct Energy Services, while in Direct Energy Business we are achieving  higher volumes reflecting strong sales activity from the prior year. And the acquisition of Hess Energy Marketing  business which we announced yesterday will transform the scale and capabilities of our B2B operations in North  America.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to the Hess transaction in a little more detail, the acquisition will make Direct Energy the largest business  gas supplier on the U.S. East Coast, and the second largest power supply – supplier in the competitive U.S. retail  markets. The transaction builds on our existing North American B2B model with focus on long-standing customer  relationships, tailoring the offering to meet their specific energy requirements.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The acquisition will also strengthen our position along the gas value chain, linking gas supply from producers,  including shale producers in the Marcellus, through transport and storage to the gas and power customer base.  Over time, these integration capabilities will play an increasingly important role.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Operational performance from our international gas and oil portfolio upstream has also been strong in the year- to-date. Including 100% of the assets to be acquired from Suncor, we are on track to deliver a production increase  of nearly 20% for the full year, with the combination of new fields coming on stream and the benefit of  acquisitions more than offsetting the natural decline in the underlying portfolio.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In upstream project delivery, York and Rhyl achieved first gas earlier this year, and we've approved plans to bring  a further 86 million barrels of reserves into production over the next three years. Costs are increasing in some  regions, in particular, the UK North Sea, however, we are now able to direct an increasing proportion of our  capital towards the most attractive developments across our international portfolio.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In UK power generation, the nuclear fleet continued its good operational performance. Our gas-fired power  stations achieved high levels of reliability and success in bidding into the Store contracts. But with the  combination of a well-supplied market and relatively cheap coal and carbon, the environment for gas-fired  generation remains extremely challenging.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Our £1 billion Lincs wind farm, capable of supplying power needs of 200,000 UK homes, is now substantially  complete and will be officially open tomorrow. In the year-to-date, we've taken significant steps to strengthen our  position along the gas value chain, in line with our strategic priorities. Our 20-year agreement with Cheniere to  export liquefied natural gas from the Sabine Pass facility in Louisiana represents an important opportunity to  secure gas supplies for the future under a capital-lite operating model. And the acquisition of operational gas and  oil assets in the Western Canadian sedimentary basin from Suncor was our first investment under the  memorandum of understanding with QPI that we signed back in 2011. The assets are in a region we know well and  offer potential reserves upside, as well as allowing us to benefit from any increase in wholesale prices.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Last month, we also announced the acquisition of a 25% stake in the Bowland shale license in Lancashire in  partnership with Cuadrilla and AJ Lucas. Shale gas has the potential to make a long-term contribution to the UK  energy mix. And this acquisition gives us an important option for a relatively small initial outlay. We welcome the  government's announcement concerning tax allowances relating to shale gas, although much remains to be done  to determine its commercial viability in the UK.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: For the full year, we expect to invest around £1 billion in the North Sea Upstream business, with work progressing  on projects such as Cygnus, Valemon and the UK – and Kew in the UK. These investments are important for the  UK, helping to secure long-term supplies of gas for our customers. In upstream gas and oil, we have a pipeline of  investment opportunities building on our existing portfolio.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power generation, we await further details from the government in respect of our Race Bank Offshore Wind  Farm to ensure that there is efficient attractive framework for investment. But we also retain the option subject  again, to the necessary incentives, to build further offshore wind projects in the Round 3 Irish Sea Zone as well as  new build gas-fired generation and also potentially gas storage. And we continue to see attractive acquisition  opportunities, both downstream in North America and upstream across the portfolio. However, as with all  investment decisions, we will only deploy capital where we see appropriate returns for shareholders.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In conclusion, we've delivered a strong performance in the first half of 2013. We're on track to deliver full year  earnings growth in line with expectations, driven by a growing customer base downstream, volumetric growth  upstream and our £500 million cost reduction program. We have made good progress against our strategic  priorities, continuing to lead in innovation and customer service and expanding our activities along the gas value  chain and the transaction we announced yesterday marks another important step towards the growth targets for  Direct Energy.

file: CNA - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 31July2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In February, I talked about my early discussions and listing sessions with some of our most important  stakeholders: politicians, regulators, the media, and above all, our customers; helping to build an understanding of  the true costs of energy and of the contribution we make to the country's energy security.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: It is important that we establish a common set of facts about energy in the UK, so that all parties to the debate  can have a rational exchange of views. As part of our contribution, you will have seen that we recently published  our Energy Choices for the UK report. This is a serious and detailed piece of research, which examines whether  the country could meet its climate change ambitions in a way that is more affordable for households and  businesses.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The enquiry by the competitor – Competition and Markets Authority into the UK energy market will also bring  some clarity to the debate. And these are all part of a process, which will inevitably take some time as we seek to  rebuild trust in the industry.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: It has established a downstream business of substance in North America. It now has balance in its upstream  portfolio across the Atlantic Basin. It has a power generation business that benefits from low carbon baseload  nuclear, alongside renewables and gas-fired generation, and a growing mid-stream business.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Importantly, the partnerships, structures and culture that have been nurtured under Sam's guidance provide a  very solid platform for long-term growth, delivering returns to shareholders and securing the future energy needs  of our customers. And on behalf of the board, I'd like to take this opportunity to thank him for his enormous  commitment and contribution.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And we're delighted that we've been able to recruit a successor of Iain's caliber. He will bring an impressive  combination of experience and skills of our business. He currently heads a retail brand familiar to millions of  people, and he also possesses a deep understanding of the energy sector built up over a lifetime in the industry.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In the meantime, I remain deeply impressed with the commitment that Chris with his British Gas and Direct  Energy teams are showing to get our service back to levels that are rightly expected by our customers.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In a challenging first half, impacted by the unusual weather on each side of the Atlantic, I have been consistently  impressed by the quality, values and commitment of the people that I have met during my first months as  Chairman. I have no qualms about the momentum, direction and pace of this company as we deliver the senior  management transition. And much does remain to be done this year. You will hear in a moment about the plans  that we have in place for each part of the group.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Rick. Good morning, everyone. As usual, I will start with commodity prices and the weather. The  weather first, looking at the bottom right chart there, it has been mild in the UK, certainly in contrast to the very  cold early part of last year. Residential gas consumption per household for British Gas was down 24% as a result.  That meant lower bills for consumers, of course, and lower sales volumes for us.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Across the Atlantic it was a very different story, with extreme low temperatures caused by the polar vortex;  increasing demand for gas and power, but causing havoc in wholesale markets.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Gas prices reacted accordingly, as shown on the top – the two left-hand charts, falling sharply in the UK, but  increasing in the U.S. With UK spark spreads remaining low, power followed gas prices down here, squeezing  dark spreads.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Oil prices held up in dollar terms, but with the pound strengthening, they were down in sterling terms. Those  weather conditions, warm in the UK, extremely cold in the U.S., and the low UK gas price, had a significant impact  on the group's financial performance with adjusted operating profit down 35%.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Revenue actually increased with additional contribution in North America from the Hess Energy Marketing  acquisition, more than offsetting lower revenues in the UK energy supply businesses, due to lower consumption.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Here's the breakdown of the operating result and you can see the lower profits in all four business units. Starting  with British Gas, here profits were down 20% to £455 million. BGR, impacted by the warm weather, came in at  £265 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Given that we do not intend to change retail prices this year, but with lower commodity costs offsetting rising cost  elsewhere, we are forecasting full year post tax margins of just over 4%, assuming normal weather in the second  half of the year, of course.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: BGS was slightly down to £129 million. We delivered an 11% increase in boiler installations, and retention of  existing contract customers was good. However, new contract sales proved challenging, leaving customer  numbers down around 2% and impacting profits.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: BGB was also impacted by the warm weather and profit dropped to £61 million as a result. However, we expect  second half profitability to improve, in part reflecting our ongoing cost reduction program and the implementation  of a new billing system.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, we reported a substantial decrease in profit, reflecting margin pressures due to competitive  market conditions, but also the $110 million of cost related the polar vortex that we have flagged in previous  updates. The strength of the pound also impacted the figures when translated back to sterling.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Excluding the vortex costs, the DE Residential result was down, impacted by margin pressure and the expected  decline of our Ontario business. DE Business was also down, before taking into account the polar vortex costs.  That was despite a strong contribution from the newly acquired Hess business, and reflected the low margins for  business written in second half of last year, when we had those very competitive market conditions.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to the upstream, Centrica Energy came in at £526 million, 34% lower than last year. Overall international  gas and oil production increased by 9%, but that increase came from Canadian Gas, which does earn lower  margins.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The falling UK gas price and the lower oil price in sterling terms squeezed pre-tax margins for European  production, but the after-tax result was protected by hedging. The tax charge was also reduced by investment  allowances in the UK, leaving after-tax profits up almost 30%, despite the lower pre-tax margins.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We remain on track for full year production close to 83 million barrels. Lower UK gas prices will bring down the  pre-tax results by more than current market forecasts imply, but the expected contribution to earnings after tax is  unchanged.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In UK power, the spark spreads meant market conditions remain challenging for our CCGT fleet, which continued  to lose money. In contrast, the nuclear business performed well with a 7% increase in generation volumes leading  to a small increase in profit. Underlying wind profitability also increased, as we received a full contribution from the  Lincs offshore wind farm. However, we did recognize a £40 million charge relating to the write-down of our Round  3 wind investment, following a review of the economic viability of the Celtic Array project. That reduced overall  reported result for power to £61 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Organic CapEx in the first half was up a little on last year, as we invested in the Cygnus and York projects  upstream. We have pulled back upstream CapEx in response to lower UK gas prices, but with the in-flight  projects progressing well, particularly Cygnus and, in Norway, Valemon, we now expect to spend this year around  £1 billion before the upstream CapEx falls next year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: On the M&A front, we closed on the Bord Gáis acquisition on June 30, so that is in these first half numbers, but  that was more than offset by the Texas CCGT sale; hence, the £329 million inflow you see up there. The second  half will see us complete the $200 million sale of our stake in our existing gas assets in Canada to QPI, as well as  the receipt of the $450 million cash element of the Ontario home services sale, offset by the reinvestment of some  of that cash into the small solar acquisition that we announced earlier this week.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We do have a number of other disposal processes underway as we seek to ensure capital is deployed where we  see the best return and growth prospects. As well as the Ontario home services sale, which we signed last week,  we have already announced our intention to sell the three largest CCGTs in the UK. We will also potentially look  to release capital from our gas assets in Trinidad and Tobago, and from our operational wind farms in the UK.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So in summary, while first-half EPS was down significantly, we expect second-half earnings to be in line with last  year. For the year as a whole, that will give us EPS of between £0.21 and £0.22, slightly below previous  guidance, reflecting the write-off of our Round 3 wind investment. Despite the lower earnings, cash generation  remains strong and we are maintaining our commitment to real dividend growth, as well as planning to complete  this year's £420 million share buyback.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Looking further ahead, we expect the business to return to growth in 2015, assuming more normal weather  conditions, and as the benefit of our recent investments flow into the results. And with that, for the 15th and final  time, I will hand over to Sam.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: With our brands and distinctive combination of energy and services propositions, our customers remain at the  very heart of the business. And the group is stronger as a result of the investments we've made over a number of  years, both downstream and upstream, with scale operations on each side of the Atlantic supported by a  balanced portfolio of upstream assets.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And as we look ahead, innovation and smart connected technologies will increasingly become the key  differentiators between energy suppliers, giving customers greater control over their energy needs in the home.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As Rick outlined, we have to engage with all our stakeholders throughout the period, particularly our customers.  We believe that if we're to regain their trust, there needs to be an open and honest dialogue about all the  components of the energy bill.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Now the chart here shows the evolution of the average British Gas dual fuel bill over the last five years. As you  can see, customers have faced a substantial increase in their energy bills, reflecting higher commodity costs, and  more significantly in recent years, higher network delivery costs and environmental and social charges.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We believe that there is effective competition in the energy market, and that it brings significant benefits to  consumers, delivering choice, innovation and some of the lowest energy prices in the European Union.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Through our vertically integrated structure, we're also able to provide protection against the volatility of energy  prices and deliver scale efficiencies for the benefit of both customers and shareholders alike.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The UK's energy policy was formed in a very different market and economic context, in a world pre-shale gas,  pre-credit crunch and with the expectation that the cost of renewables would rapidly reduce through technological  advances. Now much has changed, with the emphasis progressively shifting from environmental concerns to  affordability and now towards security of supply. We, therefore, believe it's relevant to look again at the energy  choices available and the competing priorities faced.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In this context, as a contribution to the wider energy debate, we published our Energy Choices report last week.  This gives an in-depth review of the cost of current energy policy and sets out a series of alternative choices, all  within the existing carbon reduction framework and without compromising our long-term de-carbonization  ambition. We proposed three core principles to ensure that the country can meet its carbon reduction  commitments in a most cost-effective way.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: First, to prioritize the lowest-cost, least-regret options; second, to set simple and cost-effective de-carbonization  targets; and third, to support those most affected by carbon reduction programs, whether they are energy- intensive industries or vulnerable customers. Together, we believe these measures can help to ensure a  sustainable, low carbon energy future for the UK while minimizing the costs for the consumer, and potentially  saving as much as two-thirds of the current estimated policy cost.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Some eight years ago, we recognized that we needed to strengthen our business model to respond to changing  energy markets, increasing security of supply and climate change concerns, and competitive pressures. And as  we look at the group today, we now have a well balanced and much more resilient business. This is true both  geographically, with scale businesses and investment options on both sides of the Atlantic, and structurally along  the gas value chain, with our vertically integrated model aligning us more closely with our peers and delivering  benefits through lower collateral requirements.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And in British Gas Business, we're making good progress on the implementation of the new billing system, and  we remain on track to deliver targeted reductions in operating costs totaling £100 million, at the same time as  delivering improved service to our customers. We also continue to drive improvements in technology and  innovation. Two-thirds of our residential energy customer interactions are now through digital channels, half of  those via a smartphone or tablet, and we see mobile and online technology as a core part of the customer  proposition.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Last month, we installed our millionth residential smart meter, substantially more than any other supplier. Over  350,000 customers now receive our unique smart energy report, helping them to understand and manage their  energy consumption. And the launch of Hive has also been particularly successful, with over 100,000 smart  thermostats now sold to date. The brand NPS for customers using Hive is substantially higher than for the wider  customer base, and some 80% of customers say they would actively recommend the product. Innovation provides  an important source of differentiation in the market, as well as a choice for the customer, at the same time helping  to improve the overall perception of British Gas.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In Services, new boiler installations have picked up and we are focused on returning to contract growth through  the development of attractive propositions. We're making further progress in simplifying the core customer  account interactions, such as moving home and paying by direct debit. And we're on track to complete the  migration of our customer accounts on to a new residential billing and CRM platform later this year, which will  deliver a more integrated customer experience across both energy and services.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: This autumn, we are planning to launch a new energy and services product, providing a new source of account  growth. And we're also leveraging our leadership in smart connected homes with the trial of free Saturdays or  Sundays time-of-use tariff. We've commenced trials of our smart connected boiler product, and our virtual in- home display, which enables customers to track their energy consumption in real time, either online or via their  smartphone.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, we now have a scale business in deregulated markets, with over 4 million residential and  services accounts. And in our commercial business, annual gas and electricity sales now exceed 200 terawatt  hours. However, the current market environment has been challenging in energy supply, with higher gas prices  and intense competition. And it's essential, therefore, that we improve the cost competitiveness of the business,  using our enhanced scale to drive synergies, alongside innovation to enhance customer choice.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We are on track to deliver our $100 million cost reduction program by the end of this year, with a number of  initiatives underway across the business, including investment in our billing systems, consolidation of our services  operating systems, and integration of our energy and services call centers.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We added nearly 100,000 residential energy accounts in North America during the first half. And we've also been  successful in driving sales through digital channels, which nearly trebled following the acquisition of Bounce  Energy last year. And in DE Services, we recorded a small increase in the number of customer accounts, with  further growth in our protection plan offerings.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Last week, we announced the disposal of our Ontario home services activities, releasing capital from an area of  the business which is no longer core to growth. We're focusing our efforts on the U.S. market, particularly the  potential from protection plans, and combining energy and services offerings, which we see as a central part of  our strategy for Direct Energy. And our acquisition earlier this week of Astrum Solar further enhances our product  range in this rapidly growing area of the market.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In DE Business, the Hess acquisition is performing ahead of its investment case. We've retained key personnel,  and customer service remains strong. Moving forward, we see further opportunities to deploy our dual fuel  capabilities, and continue to develop advantaged positions along the gas value chain.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Although the legacy DE Business was significantly impacted by the polar vortex in the first half, we're now seeing  a repricing of risk and a substantial uplift in the margins, up some 35% for gas and 33% for power, compared to  the second half of 2013. As a result, we expect to deliver a much improved financial result in the second half of  this year and well into 2015. And earlier in the year, we completed the disposal of our three CCGTs in Texas, with  proceeds being returned to shareholders through the share repurchase program, while we continue to access the  power through offtake agreements.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So we have clear priorities in place for DE for the second half of the year, targeting disciplined margin expansion  alongside customer service, value, and choice. In DE Business, we expect to build on the sales margin expansion  we saw in the first half of the year. We'll also complete the integration of the Hess Energy Marketing acquisition,  and we'll look to capitalize on our enhanced dual fuel capabilities, whether as the leading aggregator of Marcellus  shale gas production, or through helping customers switch from fuel oil to gas.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And in Services, we continue to drive growth through innovative products, with targets to achieve over 250,000  U.S. protection plan customers and 100,000 energy and services bundled products by the end of this year. For  the longer term, as in the UK, we believe that connected home propositions will become increasingly important.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: To date, we've sold over 10,000 smart thermostats, initially in Alberta, and have signed an exclusive partnership  with Nest to sell 100,000 units across North America over the next 18 months. Upstream, in our gas and oil  business, we now have a balanced portfolio with expertise across the Atlantic basin, most notably adding to our  positions in Norway and Western Canada, to complement the assets in UK waters.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power generation, we have a business that benefits from low-carbon baseload nuclear production, alongside  renewables and gas-fired generation. And we've developed strong relationships with world-class global partners,  Qatargas and QPI, Statoil, GDF Suez, Cheniere and EDF, to name but a few. With lower UK wholesale gas  prices and increased unit cost of production in the UK North Sea, our focus is on improving returns through  operational efficiency and capital discipline.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Gas and oil production in the first half was good, with solid production from our core assets in Europe and higher  production in North America, following the Suncor acquisition. We've now aligned our interests in Canada with  QPI, further strengthening our strategic partnership. And we've continued to make progress on our projects,  including the large scale Cygnus and Valemon projects.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
