texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: In addition, we continue to look for opportunities to increase our reserves through acquisition where  we can add value. The chart shows our upstream gas and oil production profile. As our existing  production declines, ongoing investment and development will be required to maintain production,  at around the 300 bcf per annum level. You can see the significant contribution from Statfjord with  its long, stable production profile.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: In power generation, we achieved strong reliability across our CCGT and wind portfolios. Our new  gas fired power station at Langage is performing well, having entered full commercial operation last  March. Nuclear contributed over half of the power generation operating profit in 2010. The business  is well placed to benefit from higher power prices as part of a balanced portfolio of low carbon  generation assets. And we were pleased to secure the five-year life extension for Hartlepool and  Heysham, which extends their accounting lives to 2019.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: Work continues on new nuclear build, subject to the outcome of consultation over Electricity Market  Reform, we expect to make our final investment decision on Hinkley Point in 2012. In offshore wind,  all major contracts have been awarded on the Lincs projects, and onshore works have begun and  offshore construction will commence next month.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: In gas storage, Rough once again delivered excellent operational performance. The exceptionally  cold weather saw the net reservoir volume hit a new low last March, followed by record injection  season over the summer and unusually high levels of demand in the final quarter of 2010.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: In residential energy supply, we’ve improved customer retention and cut the level of bad debt in  Texas. We’ve also successfully launched an innovative prepayment offering using our experience  from the UK market. And we continue to enter new competitive markets in the U.S. North East,  which is an attractive source of growth for Direct Energy.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: We maintain our focus on the most valuable segments of the market and as a result we saw the  attrition of low value customers in the first half of last year. However, we’ve been increasing our  customer base in the North East adding 90,000 customers in Pennsylvania and Maryland. And in  Ontario the market environment has become more difficult with the Energy Consumer Protection  Act impacting both customer acquisition and retention.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: In services in North America, the integration of Clockwork is progressing well. The transaction was  completed in July making Direct Energy the market leader in the home energy services market, to  provide a platform for growth through Clockwork’s established franchise model.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: Upstream, low gas and power prices significantly affected the returns from the business. However,  we have continued to look for investment opportunities where we can add value. And the Wildcat  Hills acquisition enabled us to add over 240 bcf of reserves at an attractive price and at lower unit  cost than our existing gas production.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: The transaction also improves the vertical integration in the business, so that direct energy is now  able to meet around 35% of our customers gas demand from our own production. Overall, we’ve  made real progress in North America as we move towards our ambition of doubling the contribution  from this business. North America represents an important opportunity for growth, competing for  capital alongside the other investment opportunities available across the group.

texts.speaker: Sir Roger Carr, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Centrica Preliminary Results
texts.text: We expect to achieve continued growth in 2011. Market conditions remain competitive, particularly  in the UK downstream energy supply. However, we are well positioned for growth across much of  the rest of the group. We have an investment program for 2011 of some 1.5 billion, over two thirds  of which we expect to direct towards our UK gas and power upstream businesses. But we remain  alert for value enhancing acquisitions and carefully targeted investments, both upstream and  downstream, where there is an appropriate fit with our portfolio.

file: CNA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 23February2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In the wake of Fukushima, escalating wholesale gas prices, political uncertainty at home and abroad, and the  mounting consumer hostility to all energy companies; I'm pleased to say that Sam and the team did an effective  job in delivering the goods.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We've been able to make substantial investment, reduce our electricity prices to consumers, and reward  shareholders with an 8% dividend increase. All of this has been achieved without overstretching our balance  sheet, dislocating the business, disturbing our employee relationships, or diluting our commitment to  apprenticeship training and executive development, which is a tribute to management and a reflection of Centrica  values.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Secondly, we are a vertically integrated customer-facing business underpinned by carefully judged investments in  upstream power and gas assets, which in their own right must deliver value and growth. The board has also given  its support to a number of major contracts during the year, including the LNG agreement with Qatar, the contract  with Statoil, and a series of smaller but equally important investments made to secure long-term supplies, deepen  our reserves, and enhance our earnings.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking to the future, I would emphasize that the application of our funds to all our investments, including wind  and new nuclear, will be made only if the economics are sound and the returns attractive and secure. Shareholder  value is our priority when making these investment decisions.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: 2011 was certainly a turbulent year for commodity prices. Oil didn't hit the peaks of 2008, but it averaged $110 a  barrel, its highest ever level across the whole calendar year. UK gas prices were volatile, low demand mainly due to  warm weather pushed prices down at the beginning and at the end of the year, but events in Japan caused them to  spike up sharply in March.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: NBP averaged 58 pence per therm, 50% up on 2010 and the trend remains upwards. Gas prices for next winter are  currently around 15% higher than for the current winter. Power prices followed gas prices upwards, but with a  squeeze on spark spreads which remained depressed throughout the year. Spark spreads have fallen even lower in  recent weeks as gas prices have risen and coal-fired generation does have a significant advantage for 2012, but this  is of course the last year of free carbon allowances.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In the US, gas prices fell further from the levels that were already very low by international standards. We have  seen some recovery in recent weeks as some companies have scaled back their shale drilling, but the differential to  prices elsewhere in the world looks set to stay.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Our integrated model stood up well to that commodity price volatility. We were still able to post an increase in  earnings despite the winter months being some of the warmest on record and despite the increase in tax rates for  our gas and oil production in the UK

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Here are the key financials for the Group as a whole. As you can see, revenue rose 2% to £22.8 billion mainly due  to higher upstream revenue resulting from the higher prices. Downstream revenue was actually lower than in  2010 despite higher retail prices as consumption fell due to the warmer weather with the result that average  customer bills were actually lower than they were the year before.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Starting with UK downstream. British Gas, where we posted results of just over £1 billion. Within that, we saw  residential energy margins move back to more normal levels and a lower result from BGB, but services still  delivered 10% growth in challenging market conditions.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In BGR, gas consumption was down sharply by over 20% as we went from one of the coldest years on record to  one of the warmest. That resulted in lower revenue despite higher unit average retail prices; 13% higher for gas,  10% higher for electricity. Margins were within our 6% to 7% target range, but obviously well down on the  unusually high levels of 2010.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Services continued to grow despite the weak economy holding back installations in particular. Revenue grew by  3% and the cost reduction steps we took allowed us to increase margins and deliver a 10% increase in profit. BGB  also faced challenging market conditions with the warm weather and weak economy both impacting consumption.  We were pleased to be able to hold margins, but we are seeing more competitive pressure in the B2B energy  sector, emphasizing the need to push on with the development of our services offering for business customers.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to the UK upstream, here operating profit was also over £1 billion, an increase of some 33% from 2010.  That growth was driven by the much higher gas and oil production profits. As you can see, gas production volumes  actually fell entirely due to lower output from Morecambe, the field of course is in decline, but more significantly  was that we chose not to run Morecambe for seven or eight weeks as we prioritized economic value over short- term profits.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Much of that shortfall in gas volumes was made up by higher more valuable oil production, which is up 6%. We  also benefited from higher realized prices for both gas and oil, up 24% and 22%, respectively.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power, the CCGTs continued to suffer from the low spark spreads with realized spreads and power generated  both down significantly. Four of the stations were put into preservation mode for parts of the year and we've now  announced proposals to close two stations and switch three others to peaking operation.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In contrast, the nuclear fleet performed extremely well, generating over 55 terawatt hours for the first time since  2005 and benefiting from higher power prices. Wind also did well with much of the load factors resulting in a 21%  increase in output.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Overall, the power segment increased profit to over £250 million as you can see despite the CCGT only just  breaking even.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The storage result was well down as expected. Average SBU prices were almost 30% lower reflecting the collapse  in summer/winter differentials and that flowed through to the bottom line resulting in the profits you see there of

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, Direct Energy had a very strong year with profits up by a third to £312 million. Within the  overall DE result, residential energy fell back to £161 million as we were not able to completely offset the decline  in Ontario with growth in Texas and the US Northeast. The business was also impacted by the sharp spikes in  Texas power prices due to extreme weather in both February and August. Nevertheless, margins remained healthy  and at 6.7% were actually higher than those for residential energy in the UK.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Business energy continued to grow strongly, adding volume and expanding margin. In services, this was the first  full year of the Clockwork business acquired mid-way through 2010. Good growth in on-demand work and tight  cost control enabled us to almost double profits to £28 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Upstream, our power stations in Texas were beneficiaries of the price spikes there due to the extreme weather  with output up some 36%. We also increased gas production in Alberta by 39% due to the Wildcat Hills  acquisition, which also contributed to much lower unit operating costs. Overall, we were able to eliminate the loss  seen in 2010 and indeed, the upstream business recorded £13 million of profit.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We do have a number of exceptional items in the 2011 results, which is shown on the screen there. Continued low  spark spreads and our proposal to close or downgrade five of the stations has resulted in us taking an impairment  of £226 million on the CCGTs in the UK. We have a Group-wide cost reduction program underway related to  restructuring costs of around £150 million this year and a similar amount expected next year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Our exit from Continental Europe has caused us to reassess the pipeline capacity contracts we have there and the  tolling contract we have for the Rijnmond CCTG in The Netherlands. With lower gas spreads and spark spreads  even lower than the UK, these contracts are out of the money and we've taken a provision of over £200 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The last two exceptional items, the deferred tax impact to the higher tax rate on UK gas and oil production and the  loss on the auxiliary service during the first half. There will be a further deferred tax rate of around £60 million in  2012 due to the restriction of tax relief on decommissioning costs to 50%, which is only being legislated for in this  year's finance act, a year behind the increase in SCT.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Here's the breakdown of the £1.6 billion of CapEx just coming up. There it is. As expected, upstream CapEx  stepped up to over £600 million as we put capital into a number of projects including Ensign, York, Seven Seas,  and Rhyl.  We also continued to invest significant capital into offshore winds with spend on Lincs making up around two- thirds of the £300 million spent in the power segment.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Looking into 2012, we foresee further significant organic development in upstream gas, where we further spend  on York and Rhyl with significant investment also planned for Kew and on Valemon which we acquired from  Statoil. Subject to the timing of the final investment decision, we may also see significant spend on the Cygnus  project.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Power includes most of the remaining expenditure on Lincs although our net investment into the joint venture  could vary depending on where we get to with project financing and on the potential sale of transmission assets  out of the project. 2012 could also see the first significant spend on Race Bank, our next offshore wind project.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: So in summary then, a good set of results with profits up ahead of 2010 despite some headwinds across the Group.  Upstream gas and oil production and nuclear generation together with the very strong growth in North America  were particular highlights. We were able to increase the dividend by 8%, reflecting our confidence in the Group's  long-term earning capability as well as our strong balance sheet position and strong cash flows.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: For 2012, we're looking to improve on the profit growth we achieved last year. With retail prices currently above  last year's average and assuming normal weather, BGR should have higher revenue which with normal margins  should translate into better profits for British Gas as a whole.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to the performance in the year, let's start with British Gas. I'm particularly pleased that once again, we  achieved an increase in our net promoter score in both energy and services and for the first time, achieved a 4 star  rating from Consumer Focus. And we continue to differentiate ourselves through innovation with constantly  improving online offerings, new propositions for the smart home of the future, as well as our successful  partnerships with Nectar and Sainsbury's. All of which are helping to provide customers with additional choice  and value.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Early in 2011, we faced significantly higher wholesale prices for electricity and particularly for gas alongside  rapidly rising environmental and transportation and distribution costs. This required us to increase our tariffs in  the second half of the year leading to increased churn and a small reduction in the number of energy accounts  over the year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In a rising price environment, it's even more important that the industry engages closely with customers and all  stakeholders. We therefore led the way with our honest conversation to help customers understand the drivers  behind energy prices and to explain the steps we've taken to simplify their bills and I'll return to this later. We  were also the first of the major suppliers to implement a price reduction this year with a 5% cut in our standard  electricity tariff, making us once again the cheapest major supplier for electricity.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In British Gas Business, the results of the year were impacted by the effect of warmer weather and the economy.  The number of customer supply points reduced slightly, partly reflecting site closures. In this environment, it's all  the more important that we deliver high levels of service tailored to the needs of our customers while expanding  our range of business services offerings. And we continue to achieve growth in new markets. The business now  generates revenues in excess of £250 million per annum and we expect it to make a positive contribution to  operating profits this year. In summary, the downstream business is performing well despite difficult market  conditions.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning now to the UK upstream business where we achieved strong performance across the portfolio. In gas and  oil, work on our projects is progressing well. We brought new production onstream at F3-FA and Goosander, we  further improved the performance of existing assets such as Grove and Chiswick, and we're benefiting from new  acquisitions such as the stake we acquired in the Statfjord field from Shell in 2010.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We've also added to our reserves ending the year with 440 million barrels of oil equivalent 2P reserves, more than  replacing our production for the year. And as you can see on the chart, we have further reserve additions to come  base. We've also strengthened our partnerships with leading worldwide gas producers to bring gas to the UK,  taking delivery of our first LNG cargoes under the Qatargas supply contract and entering into a new 10-year  agreement with Statoil.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In power, conditions have been tough for gas-fired generation. However, this was more than offset by improved  output and achieved prices of both nuclear and wind. And on our Lincs offshore wind farm development, we're  making good progress and expect first power later this year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Here's our upstream production profile as of a year ago. With the business capable of sustaining production at the  50-million barrel a year equivalent level, in itself reflecting the scale and capabilities that we added through the  Venture Production acquisition. And here is the corresponding pro forma position for 2012 with production  comfortably around the 70 million barrel oil equivalent level. This includes production from the recent Statoil and  Statfjord field transactions as well as the acquisition from Total that we announced yesterday. You'll see from the  chart that in addition to increased cash flow and earnings, we are now less reliant on exploration to maintain  production.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In business energy in North America, we had another good year and although competition is intensifying, we were  able to achieve further volume growth while sustaining our margins and consolidating our position as the number  three player in the US market. In services, following the acquisition of Clockwork in 2010, we now have a solid  platform for growth and through the Home Warranty of America transaction, we will have the capability to sell  insurance-based contracts alongside our on-demand products. While upstream in North America, we delivered a  much improved result despite the lower gas price and the weak spark spread environment. In gas production,  we're benefiting from high volumes and lower cost base and in power generation, we were able to capture the  benefit of power price spikes during the extreme weather in Texas.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In summary, our goal is to sharpen our competitive position across the Group, upstream and downstream, whilst  also enabling the business to invest for growth for the benefit of both customers and shareholders. This slide gives  you some further color. On the right, you can see the split across each area of the business with around two-thirds  of the savings being targeted in British Gas. But savings will also be in Centrica Energy, Direct Energy, and indeed,  the Corporate Centre.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In British Gas, the savings amount to a 10% reduction in operating costs in our core business over the next two  years even after allowing for the effects of inflation. Here we're benefiting from our systems investment, increased  online penetration, back office efficiency savings, and more streamlining of our support operations.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In Centrica Energy, the priority is to deliver continued growth from the enlarged business. However, we've also  been able to identify efficiency savings here in our supply chain and support functions together with savings from  the proposed closures in our CCGT fleet.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In British Gas, we now have our two principal tariff types and we're making it simpler for customers to help them  select the right tariff for them. We're also providing clearer information regarding the components of the bill,  including the cost of government environment policy. And we're also leading the industry in terms of health for  the vulnerable with the widest eligibility of any of the Big Six with the Warm Home Discount.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: However, with affordability now a key issue for households and the future cost of energy rising, it's important that  the whole industry, including government and the regulator, engages in a process to build understanding and  improve transparency. Any proposed redesign of the retail market needs to be proven to be transparent, simple,  and lower cost for the consumer as well as continuing to promote innovation, choice, and competition.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to the upstream, significant investment is required to deliver the country's energy needs for the next  generation. However, much remains to be resolved under the government's electricity market reform proposals  before investment decisions can be taken. As we set out in our Upstream Investor Day in December, we see the  most immediate investment opportunities in upstream gas and oil and in offshore wind with further options in  new nuclear, biomass, CCGTs, and gas storage; subject in each case to the returns being appropriate.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In gas and oil as you will have seen, we've made good progress towards achieving our target of 75 million barrels  equivalent production per annum. While in offshore wind, the priority is to bring the Lincs wind farm  maintaining a competitive post-tax energy hedge of around 50% to 60%, giving appropriate balance between the  upstream and downstream and the geographic diversity across the portfolio.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, we're making good progress towards our target of doubling the profitability of the business  with the potential to increase the scale of the business further for the right opportunities. Downstream, we  continue to seek growth in our core deregulated markets, Texas and the Northeast, increasing scale and delivering  cost efficiencies. We also now have a platform to expand our services offering, replicating the UK model with the  introduction of annual contracts and over time, cross-sell opportunities to our energy customer base. In upstream,  we continue to seek value-adding opportunities in both gas and power moving towards the 35% to 40% cover level  over time, but again only where attractive returns can be identified.

file: CNA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20February2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Of course, one such challenge is the political storm in which we find ourselves and which to an extent is  understandable. It's no surprise that energy prices are a hot topic and it's entirely reasonable that our politicians  should be exercised about cost of living issues. We are. And it's entirely reasonable that they should choose to  echo our customers' concerns about value, service and trust.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: But these same politicians have a choice to make as they draw up their electoral strategies for 2015. Do they or  do they not want a UK energy company of substance that is willing and able to invest on the international stage to  secure long-term gas for the nation and at home to help remedy the imminent shortfall in reserve generating  margins?

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In a rush to draw party lines, these politicians appear to have overlooked that Centrica's fortunes are inextricably  linked with our nation's, that we supply energy and energy services to almost half the homes in Britain and nearly  1 million businesses, that we support 175,000 jobs in our supply chain, procure around £10 billion worth of goods  from 6,000 UK companies, and are one of the country's largest tax payers and an important payer of dividends to  our 700,000 individual shareholders and numerous pension schemes.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: There's just too much at stake. The implication of broken markets and declaration of breakup intentions may  make for good politics, but the unintended consequences for our nation's energy future threaten to be significant  and irreversible for some considerable time.

texts.speaker: Rick Haythornthwaite
texts.profession: Non-Executive Chairman, Centrica Plc
texts.text: For the benefit of our customers and for the nation's energy security, we are going to fight to see reason prevail  over short-term politics. And we're going to fight to restore the nation's respect for the role we play and trust in us  earning the margins we do starting with the people that really matter, our customers. And above all, we are going  to fight to ensure that our performance maintains the progress that you've come to expect from Centrica.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Now much has changed since the first half results, particularly, of course, as Rick described, the political  environment and the unprecedented focus of the energy sector in the UK. We understand the very real concern  the customers have over energy bills. And as Rick has just outlined, there's a pressing need for investment to  secure the supplies of gas and power generation capacity that the country requires.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Alongside these actions, the key transactions that we completed in 2013, the Sabine Pass U.S. LNG export  agreement, the Suncor package of Canadian assets, and the Hess Energy Marketing acquisition, create platforms  for long-term growth beyond the short-term uncertainties. This is going to enable us to underpin our capacity  position through service and innovation to realize the potential of our enlarged North American business, to  develop our upstream portfolio, and to integrate our business along the gas value chain.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And finally, as Rick mentioned, we're talking to all political parties, firstly, to make them more aware of the  strategic and commercial role that we play in securing gas and electricity for our customers; and secondly, to help  them understand the makeup of the energy bill, something we pioneered together with our transparency of  reporting.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Sam. Good morning, everyone. As ever, I'll start with commodity prices and weather. As you all know,  gas prices were a fair bit higher in 2013, up nearly 15% year-on-year on the UK and by more than that in the U.S.  albeit from a lower base there, of course. In contrast, oil prices were down year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The forward curve shown here bottom left suggest oil prices will continue to fall. For UK gas, the curve has  flattened and recently fallen whereas U.S. prices have risen on the back of the cold weather. Moving bottom right,  outright power prices were higher in 2013 than 2012 tracking gas prices but spark spreads were close to zero for  the whole year with no signs of recovery in the forward market.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: On the weather in the UK, top right there, it was a year of two halves, very cold in the first half but close to normal  and, hence, a lot warmer than 2012 in the second. For the year as a whole, average consumption for British gas  residential came in unchanged.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Against that backdrop, the group produced a solid result albeit with no bottom line growth. Revenue increased,  the large component of the increase being the expansion of U.S. B2B energy supply including two months  contribution from the newly acquired Hess business. Adjusted operating profit was down slightly with pressure on  supply margins in the UK and the U.S. offsetting higher profits in the expanded upstream business.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: You see on the screen the breakdown of the operating result and you can see the lower profits from British Gas  and Direct Energy offset by the growth from Centrica Energy. Starting with British Gas, here, profits were down  6%. BGR came in at £571 million slightly below the year before, impacted by the warm December with the cold  weather earlier in the year due to the delay of the passing through of higher cost both commodity and non- commodity.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: BGS was up to £318 million benefiting from cost initiatives and that was despite responding to 200,000 more  breakdowns due to the cold weather in the first half of the year. The weak economy did impact contract numbers.  However, we saw a recovery in installation volumes which grew 10% in the second half. BGB saw continued  margin pressure in part due to our decision to end auto-rollovers. Profits dropped to £141 million as a result.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Looking into 2014, we continue to target similar margins across the business. The mild start to the year will make  it challenging for BGR, but there remain many variables that will impact the full year outturn, weather and  commodity prices in particular, of course.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, we saw pressure on margins in the residential energy supply market and even more so in the  B2B market. Direct Energy came in below our expectations as a result, down 11% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: With £77 million, DE business was somewhat disappointing. Market conditions in power supply were challenging  with highly competitive pricing across the sector. We did have the Hess Energy Marketing business for the last  two months, which is predominantly gas, of course, but its profit contribution was offset by deal and integration  costs. In contrast, the services continue to perform well with good growth and good protection plan volumes and  profits up to £36 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The start of 2014 has been difficult for Direct Energy. The polar vortex has caused extreme weather and turmoil in  wholesale markets, particularly in power where our balancing costs have been dramatically higher than normal.  All energy suppliers have been affected and we'll see how the competitive environment evolves as a result but the  short-term impact for us has been a hit of $70 million to $80 million, most of which falls in DE business.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Turning to the upstreams Centrica Energy, now including the Canadian gas assets, came in at £1.3 billion up 6%.  Gas production was up almost 20% and oil production by 7% both driven by acquisitions coupled with higher  realized prices of gas and a good mid-stream result that drove profits up by 23% to £1.15 billion.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In 2014, we will see lower oil production in Europe and DD&A rates will increase as new fields replace legacy low- cost older fields that will squeeze margins in Europe. In contrast, Canadian volumes and profits will benefit from  having a full year of the Suncor assets but won't be sufficient to cover the lower European pre-tax profit, leaving  total operating profit for upstream gas this year at around £1 billion. However, the lower tax rate does mean that  we can still target an after-tax result in line with 2013.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In UK power, overall profits fell by 45% to £171 million. Nuclear output was once again very strong and with the  business also benefiting from higher wholesale prices, nuclear profit increased further. In contrast, trading  conditions remained difficult for gas-fired generation with continued very low spark spreads and the fleet no longer  benefiting from free carbon allowances. As a result, our gas-fired fleet lost £133 million and we remain cautious  on the prospects for recovery in 2014.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Generation volumes from renewables increased as we brought Lincs on stream. However, unlike 2012, profits  from slowing down wind farm interest did not contribute to the overall result, but they were offset by a write-down  of our remaining development assets following the sale of the Race Bank project to DONG.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: On storage, operation in storage performed very well with record withdrawals in the cold weather during the first  quarter, followed by a record injection season over the summer. However, lower summer, winter spreads go with  a much lower SBU price causing operating profit to fall by almost 30%. Storage price do remain very low and the  business is only likely to be around breakeven in 2014.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The group did incur a number of exceptional charges in 2013. Low spark spreads in the Netherlands meant that  we have to take a further provision for the tolling agreement on the Rijnmond CCGT. In E&P, we have some good  reserve upsides in Norway that Sam will set out, but also have some resource downgrades and some cost  overruns on some of our projects in the UK Southern North Sea. Of course, for the accounts, we don't get to  recognize the increased value in Norway, but do have to take the downside impairments in the UK.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: At £1.5 billion, total organic CapEx was unchanged against 2012, but there was a shift from power to gas.  Upstream CapEx increased with significant spend at York, Statfjord, Cygnus, and Valemon. In contrast, power  CapEx fell with the final spend on the Lincs wind farm being the only significant item. There were two large  acquisitions in 2013, Hess Energy Marketing business going into DE business and the Canadian assets required  from Suncor in partnership with Qatar Petroleum.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In 2014, we expect CapEx to reduce. This reflects our decision to scale back E&P investment against the  backdrop of rising costs in the UK North Sea without rising gas prices to offset this. While we continue to invest in  selected projects such as Cygnus and Valemon, we will increasingly [indiscernible] (17:43) about new  investments and expect our E&P CapEx to average around £900 million per annum over the next three years.  With no major new products in the pipeline, our CapEx is expected to remain low.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: On the M&A front, everything we've announced to-date for this year has been on the disposal side, hence the  inflow you see there, consisting mainly of the proceeds from the sale of the Texas CCGT fleet. As you know, we  are part of the preferred bidding consortium for Bord Gáis in Ireland, albeit the part of the business we are  interested in would not involve M&A spend that would be material for Centrica.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In summary then, flat earnings in 2013 with higher operating profits helped by acquisitions, offset by margin  pressure in downstream energy supply, particularly in B2B on both sides of the Atlantic and by that also free  carbon allowances.

texts.speaker: Nicholas L. Luff
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Director-Finance, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Looking into 2014, with pressures across the group, at this stage, we expect overall earnings per share to be  below those in 2013 in line with recent analyst forecasts once adjusted for the impact of the polar vortex and FX  movements on Direct Energy.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Thank you very much, Nick. So, in February last year, we set out our strategic priorities in the context of an  increasingly international gas market. And just to recap, our priorities are to innovate, driving growth and service  excellence, to integrate along the gas value chain linked to our core markets, and to increase our return through  efficiency and capital discipline.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We've also made strong strategic progress during the year. Across the group, we invested £2.5 billion, both  organically and through acquisition, strengthening our businesses for the long term. And with over £60 billion of  long-term gas and power commitments in place, we play a vital role in securing energy for our customers.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, we have significantly enhanced the scale of our activities with the Hess Energy Marketing  acquisition transforming the size and capability of our B2B activities, while the Suncor transaction doubled the gas  reserves in Canada and materially increased our 2C resources.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In the UK, we'd simplified our residential energy offering and we made further improvements in the transparency  of our reporting. We also realized value through the disposals of selected E&P assets, some of our UK wind  assets, and our fleet of three CCGT power stations in Texas.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: However, with market conditions remaining challenging, we're taking positive actions across the group. We have  specific actions in place at each part of the business, improving customer service and developing innovative  propositions for growth on both sides of the Atlantic; cost efficiency programs in British Gas, Direct Energy, E&P  and gas storage, and more selective investments upstream and I'll return to these in more detail shortly.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As the UK's North Sea gas production continues to decline sharply, securing new sources of international gas is  vital for Britain. In 2013, we signed two further long-term gas supply contracts totaling £14 billion, including the  agreement with Cheniere to purchase LNG from the Sabine Pass liquefaction plant and an extension to our LNG  supply contract with Qatargas.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Both agreements underline the crucial role that Centrica is playing in accessing global LNG markets and to  secure supplies for the UK despite fierce demand from Asia and Latin America. And our acquisition of an interest  in the Bowland shale exploration license in the UK gives us a stake in a potentially important domestic source of  gas for the future.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We invested £1.5 billion in organic CapEx across the group, the majority of which being in upstream gas, as Nick  outlined. And here, we achieved first gas from three projects in the past 12 months. And in power generation, our  Lincs offshore wind development is now fully operational, capable of providing enough power for some 200,000  UK homes.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In North America, our $1 billion investment in gas assets from Suncor, in partnership with QPI, doubled our  upstream scale in Canada. The assets fit well with our existing production and processing hubs in the region. And  the acquisition further strengthens our relationship with our Qatari partners.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Initial production from the assets has been strong, ahead of our original expectations. And we now have over 1  million undeveloped acres, meaning significant potential for reserves and production upside leaving us well- placed to benefit from any improvement in North American gas prices.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Downstream in North America, the Hess Energy Marketing acquisition transforms our position in the B2B gas  market, making us the largest gas supplier in the U.S. northeast and the second largest supplier in power. With  advantaged position along the gas value chain, the long-term customer relationships, this transaction provides a  differentiated business model which is already delivering financial performance in excess of our investment case.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: This good strategic progress has come against the background of unprecedented political and media focus on the  UK energy sector. The prospects of political intervention with proposals of a price freeze and a resetting of the  market has created great uncertainty. On top of this, they're being called for the breakup of vertically integrated  suppliers further damaging confidence at the very time when substantial investment is required for the country's  long-term energy security.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: The UK now imports over half its gas requirements, and with worldwide competition for energy resources, the UK  must pay the going market rate. Financially strong companies are needed to secure long-term supplies for the  country. The same is true of power generation where although the government's Energy Act has now been  passed, many important details remain to be resolve and financially strong supply companies are needed to  underpin investment in new low carbon power generation capacity.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: There's been much debate about the efficacy of the retail gas market. And the competition assessment is  underway in which we are participating fully. We should, however, not lose sight of the fact that the UK energy  supply market continues to offer among the lowest cost prices in Europe while energy efficiency measures are  successfully reducing consumption.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As a result, when adjusted for weather, average energy builds have in fact increased by less than inflation over  the last five years. Indeed, average energy builds for our retail customers this year are expected to be around 8%  lower this winter than they were for the corresponding winter last year.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Nevertheless, public trust in energy suppliers has fallen to record low levels. While there's an improved  understanding of the true cost of supplying energy to the home, the proposal of a price freeze would offer a false  promise to customers, where the large majority of costs are external to the business. We've engaged with policy  makers to present proposals for more affordable ways to decarbonizes and reduce energy consumption, helping  more people at lower cost without compromising the long term decarbonization targets that we all support.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And we were the first supplier to reduce prices following the government's changes to the ECO program, passing  on savings in full to all our customers. We also recognize that the improving transparency is key to rebuilding trust  in the sector. We've simplified our product offering to four core tariffs.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We were the first major energy supplier to introduce a Tariff Check through our customers and show clearly the  margins we make in our upstream and downstream businesses and indeed from different forms of power  generation. And now for the first time in our accounts, we're publishing our audited Ofgem segmental statements  and we encourage other suppliers to follow suit.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Alongside trust, our continued focus on operational efficiency and service quality underpins our ability to earn a  margin in energy supply, making these the core areas of focus. And through delivery of these objectives, we  continue to see through cycle, post-tax margins of 4% to 5% as appropriate, given the risks and substantial  commitments inherent in this business.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Downstream, under the leadership of Chris Weston, we've completed strategic reviews in both British Gas and  Direct Energy, and new management structures are in place. And we've also set new targets to deliver better  service, lower costs and, where appropriate, drive customer account growth.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Upstream, under the leadership of Mark Hanafin as well as focusing on continued operational efficiency, will direct  our capital towards the projects offering the most attractive returns and the lowest political risk, primarily in gas  and oil, with limited near-term investment in power.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We have an award-winning digital platform and a leadership position in the smart metering and see the smart  connected home as core focus area transforming the customer experience and enabling the development of  attractive differentiated products. We expect to have installed 1.3 million smart meters for residential customers  by the end of this year, substantially more than any other supplier, helping customers to have real-time  information about their energy usage.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We've already seen a positive response from customers with smart meters, with lower consumption, none of the  hassle of meter reads, no more estimated bills, and this, in turn, leads to improve customer retention. And we've  sold over 50,000 smart thermostats to-date with weak weekly sales doubling since the successful launch of our  Hive proposition in September last year.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We also continue to drive growth in both residential and B2B energy services through targeted segmentation of  the customer base, expanded product choice and leveraging of our insurance-based platform.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In Direct Energy, market conditions remain challenging with margin pressures expected to persist in both  residential energy and electricity supply in B2B. Improving cost competitiveness is therefore a core priority and we  expect to deliver $100 million in cost savings from the underlying businesses over the coming year.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In Direct Energy residential, we're already benefiting from the creation of an integrated operation center in Tulsa  and a consolidated energy and services call center in Phoenix. We're also investing in a new residential energy  billing platform for the Alberta market with the potential to extend this to other parts of the business in the future.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Building a range of innovative product offerings is core to our future growth potential in DE. Our Power To Go and  Free Power Saturday products have both prove popular with residential energy customers.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: And in services, the initial rollout of protection plans is delivering promising results with over 80,000 products sold  to date. Over time, we see significant potential for bundling of energy and services propositions and we're already  starting to sell services propositions through our Bounce online platform.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: In DE business, the integration of the Hess Energy Marketing business is progressing very well having  transformed our capabilities in gas. Our priority is to retain key personnel and systems continue to deliver good  service and high levels of customer retention.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Looking forward, we see growth opportunities in – for Hess Energy Marketing to add supply positions for  Marcellus shale producers and also helping customers switch from oil to gas. As Nick mentioned, the very cold  weather of the polar vortex did impact the legacy part of the DEB power business through unusually high  additional network and balancing charges in the first two months of the year. However, given the stress this has  placed on the industry, we could expect to see some re-pricing of risk during the year.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Upstream, we've made good progress in developing our portfolio, lower future wholesale gas and oil prices do  present headwinds particularly in the North Sea given rising costs in reducing field sizes. However, we're  successfully delivering value through reserve additions particularly in Norway, underlining the quality of our  previous acquisitions. The business is also well placed to benefit from any upside in North American gas prices.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: Our 2C resources in Canada more than [ph] tripled (33:39) in 2013 with the impact of the Suncor acquisition being  supplemented by organic additions, providing us with the potential to accelerate our drilling program in Canada.  We expect to double the wells drilled in the first quarter of 2014 compared with the fourth quarter of 2013.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: This change in mix will, over time, reduce our cycle time, lower our capital intensity and tax rates. And recognizing  the increasingly international nature of gas markets, we will also continue to develop our LNG capabilities.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: As you can see on the chart, we expect the impact of these – with this reduction in capital expenditure, our near- term production to be limited, being in the range of 80 to 85 million barrels of oil equivalent per year or around  230,000 barrels a day of production. This will vary slightly as we continue to evaluate both acquisition and  divestment opportunities to enhance the value of the portfolio.

texts.speaker: William Samuel Hugh Laidlaw
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Centrica Plc
texts.text: We're engaging with all political stakeholders in the UK to help inform the debate at a time when a stable  investment climate is urgently required. Only solutions grounded on economic realities rather than political  rhetoric are likely to deliver the investment needed to secure the country's future energy needs.

file: CNA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19February2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We're going to take about 50 minutes for our presentation. Before Jeff goes through the results in detail, I'll talk  about the impact of oil and gas prices on the group, our response and the thinking behind the difficult decision to  rebase our dividend. I'm extremely aware how painful such a cut will be for our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: After Jeff's finished, I'll talk about my impressions of the business and our response to the current environment  and say more about the strategic review that we've announced today. Mark and Ian will then join us on the stage  to take your questions.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: These interactions have underscored the fact that Centrica occupies a vital role in the energy affairs of the UK, in  particular, and also in the U.S. and Ireland. We're a customer-facing company and our principal role is to deliver  excellence in the supply and reliability of energy and services to those customers.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Although we are facing some significant challenges at present, it's clear to me that Centrica has built a solid set of  positions from which we're going to be able to continue to play an important role in the developing energy  markets on both sides of the Atlantic.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The needs of our customers are changing and they're demanding secure, reliable, affordable energy and a  sustainable approach to its provision. Meeting those needs is a huge responsibility. I'm already impressed by the  quality of our people and their commitment to serving our customers competitively and with integrity, developing  new offers and services and providing secure and reliable energy supplies as we aim to deliver long -term  shareholder value. I'd like to thank Sam Laidlaw for his leadership and development of the company over the last  eight years.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As you all have seen from our announcement this morning, 2014 earnings were significantly down, impacted  particularly by the weather and falling oil and gas prices during the year. Group adjusted earnings in 20 14 were  £962 million, down 30% relative to 2013. Earnings per share were £0.192 relative to £0.266 in the prior year.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Before Jeff takes you through our 2014 results in detail, I'd first like to cover the impact of oil and gas prices on  the group, our response, and the thinking behind the board's decision to rebase the dividend. I'm extremely aware  of how painful such a cut will be for our shareholders, including all of our retail shareholders.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Let me start with oil and gas prices. Brent oil prices have lo st about half their value, falling from $110 a barrel in  July, to $80 a barrel at the time of our Interim Management Statement in November, to today's level of around  $60. Gas forward wholesale prices for 2015 have also continued to fall, from a forecast average level of £0.55 per  therm as recently as mid-December to £0.49 today.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The current environment will have a significant effect on 2015 earnings and cash flows, with the main impact  being on Centrica Energy.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In addition to the effect of oil and gas prices, the gas-fired power environment in the UK resulted in a decision not  to sell the UK CCGTs because final bids were materially below our whole value.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Since our IMS in November, the direct impact of commodity prices and power margins, the knock-on impacts  related to our ability to make asset disposals at the current time, and the impact to some systems implementation  delays in British Gas business will have an estimated impact on planned 2015 earnings of about £0.025 per share.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Oil and gas prices continue to be volatile and the forward curves suggest that such low prices could continue for  the next two years and upstream margins will remain depressed while the supply chain adjusts.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Let me now move to the subject of our credit rating, which Jeff will cover in more detail in a moment. Our primary  role as a group is to supply energy and services to our customers, and we provide security for that energy both by  owning gas and electricity production and also in the midstream by hedging procurement and optimization  activities, including securing long-term contracts for gas and electricity.

texts.speaker: Iain C. Conn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Given the combination of the factors I've described, and particularly the continuing lower levels of oil and gas  prices and the associated loss of cash flows, and despite the strong action we're taking to cut investment levels and  operating costs, we've therefore taken a very difficult decision to rebase the dividend by 30%, beginning with  the  final payment for 2014 which is due to be paid in June. This means that the total dividend for 2014 will be £0.135  per share.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Iain, and good morning, everyone. Let me start with weather and commodity prices, both of which had  a big impact on our performance in 2014. The weather first, and you can see average UK temperatures on the left- hand side of the slide, with the red areas representing warmer-than-normal temperatures and the blue area,  colder.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As you no doubt be aware, 2014 was very mild in the UK. In fact, by some measures, it was the warmest on record.  As a result, residential gas consumption per household in the UK was down 17%, which also lowered the average  British Gas dual fuel bill by about £100 compared to 2013.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In North America, it was a very different story, with extreme low temperatures caused by the polar vortex, as you  can see in the top-right. This increased demand for gas and power across North America but also resulted in  significantly higher commodity cost and additional service network charges.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: However, the big story in the second half of the year was the sharp fall in gas and oil prices. UK power prices also  followed gas prices down and spark spreads remained low. And although hedging protected 2014 earnings to a  degree, as you've already heard from Iain, the rapid falling prices has created a challenging environment in 2015.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The impact of the weather, decline in wholesale prices and difficult trading conditions in both the UK and in  North America significantly affected the group's performance. Revenue increased 11%, primarily driven by a full  year's contribution from the Hess Energy Marketing business and resulted in a 62% increase in Direct Energy  revenue compared to the prior year. This was partially offset by lower revenue in British Gas due  to lower energy  consumption and in Centrica Energy from the lower realized prices.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The decline in commodity prices also resulted in significant impairments in both our upstream E&P and power  generation businesses. In E&P, post-tax impairments of £712 million were recorded, primarily related to fields in  the UK North Sea and on our development assets in Trinidad and Tobago.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In power, the combination of lower forecast power prices and a lower-than-expected result from the first capacity  market auction in December led to a review of the carrying value of both the thermal and nuclear generation  fleets, resulting in an impairment of £673 million post-tax. These impairments were partially offset by profits on  disposal of the three Texas power stations and the Ontario home services business, which together ge nerated a  profit post-tax of £224 million.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In addition, with the rapid decline in wholesale gas and power prices on both sides of the Atlantic at the end of the  year, the mark-to-market re-measurement of our energy contract positions was a loss of £1.1 billion, or £771  million post-tax. These positions are held against forward sales and will, therefore, reverse as those future sales  realize.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So moving on to a breakdown of operating results, you can see each of the different business units and their  relative contribution to the lower profitability in 2014. In British Gas, profits were down 20% to £823 million.  Residential energy profit fell to £439 million, 23% down on 2013, primarily driven by lower customer  consumption. A drop of 2% in customer account and a falling average customer consumption of 17% on gas and  5% on electricity from warmer weather were the main contributing factors.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Post-tax margin reduced to 4.1% as the lower consumption and intensely competitive market meant profitability  was at the lower-end of what we would hope to achieve as a return, commensurate with the risk and the capital  employed the business incurs in procuring and supplying energy.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: British Gas business was also impacted by the warm weather, along with competitive margin pressures and higher  bad debt provisions following the transition to our new billing system. This resulted in a fall in profit to £114  million, 19% below 2013.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We are still integrating the new system, which has delayed the full realization of reduced operating cost and lower  bad debt. Looking forward, we would expect to see growth in British Gas residential energy and services in 2015,  driven by customer account growth and more seasonally normal weather, partially offset by a delay in the full  implementation of the new British Gas business commercial model.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Direct Energy, we reported a substantial decrease in profit, reflecting margin pressures due to competitive  market conditions in both residential and business energy supply and cost related to the polar vortex in the first  quarter of last year.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We see those trends continuing in the current year and largely negating the benefit of the more seasonal weather.  The business is focused on continued cost improvement and new customer propositions, linking our energy and  sales offerings to drive growth in the longer term.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Business energy was also down on underlying basis despite of good contributions from the newly acquired Hess  business, which is delivering ahead of its investment case. This reflected lower margins for business written in  prior periods. However, average unit margins written in the second half of 20 14 are significantly higher than in  the same period in 2013; 35% higher for gas and nearly 50% higher for power. When combined with the  expectation of more normal weather patterns and the roll off of amortization expense from the Hess acquisition,  this should result in a significant increase in profitability for business energy in 2015.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Turning to the upstream, Centrica Energy's operating profit was £737 million, 44% lower than last year, with gas  operating profit down 48% to £606 million. This reflected significantly lower European realized prices, do wn 17%  in gas to £0.539 per therm and 14% in oil to £54. This was only marginally offset by a slightly higher realized gas  price in Canada resulting in a price impact of over £500 million year-over-year.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Overall E&P production increased 3% to just under 80 million barrels of oil equivalent, with an increase in  Canadian production from a full year of the Suncor acquisition made in 2013 being partly offset by the natural  decline in our European fields. European production also suffered from higher unit lifting and other cash  production costs, which increased 6%, driven by a supply chain inflation and the continuing change in production  mix to newer higher-cost fields. This is an area of particular focus in the current commodity price environment.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: However, lower operating profit was largely mitigated on a post-tax basis as the benefits of hedging forward,  realized investment tax allowance on UK North Sea development spend, and a strong performance from the  midstream gas business resulted in post-tax operating profit only being down 7% at £302 million.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For 2015, the impact of lower gas and oil price environment and a more normalized midstream performance is  expected to result in a significant reduction in both the operating profit and post-tax earnings of the business.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In power, operating profit fell by 23% to £131 million. Gas-fired generation volumes increased by 12%, although  lower achieved spark spread meant the thermal fleet continue to lose money, albeit at a slightly reduced level. In  2015, we expect the thermal fleet to remain loss-making at current spark spreads.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Nuclear output was down, reflecting the temporary shutdown of four reactors resulting from a discovery of the  boiler spine issue at Heysham 1. As a result, our pro rata share of overall output from the nuclear fleet fell just over  7 % to 11.3 terawatt hours. The lower output and additional costs incurred related to the boiler spine were the  primary contributors to a decrease in operating profit to £210 million. All impacted reactors are now ba ck in  service although operating at reduced output until planned remediation effects are taken later in the year.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Wind profitability was also down, with the positive impact of a profit on disposal relating to the Barrow Offshore  wind farm sale more than offset by a £40 million charge recognized following our decision not to proceed with the  Round 3 Celtic Array offshore wind project.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And finally, the Storage. The rough asset performed well operationally, reaching its highest -ever reservoir volume  in October. However, seasonal gas spreads for winter 2014-2015 were down materially on the season before, and  operating profit fell to £29 million. Seasonal gas spreads for the upcoming storage season remain at similar levels  to the past year.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In a year where weather, prices and market competition meant gross margin were materially lower, the business  was focused on delivering cost savings initiatives to mitigate the underlying cost pressure.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Direct Energy, over $100 million of cost was removed with the integration of the Hess and Direct Energy  businesses, in line with our acquisition case. And while full realization has been delayed, British Gas Business  remains on track to take £100 million out of operating cost by 2016.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In terms of net investment, organic capital expenditure was broadly flat compared to the prior year. In E&P, we  spent just under £1.1 billion, slightly more than planned but reflecting good progress in the development of the  large-scale Cygnus and Valemon projects, the latter achieving first gas in early January.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: However, as you can see on the right-hand side we've taken action to reduce capital expenditure materially in  2015, where we are targeting a 25% reduction in E&P and further reductions in 2016 should commodity prices  remain low.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Overall, net investment fell from £2.6 billion in 2013 to just over £800 million in 2014 as disposals of non -core  assets replaced the significant acquisitions in 2013. This included the Hess Energy Marketing business and the  Suncor Upstream gas assets. Acquisition spend totaled around £150 million related primarily to the Bord Gáis  acquisition in Ireland and the Astrum Solar business in the U.S. This was more than offset by around £800  million of disposal proceeds from the sale of the Texas gas-fired power stations, the Ontario home services  business and our interest in the Barrow Offshore Wind farm. Further capital was released from the sale of a 40%  stake in our existing natural gas assets in Western Canada to our joint venture partners, QPI.

texts.speaker: Jeff Bell
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The group is a large user of collateral in both the UK and in North America, and a strong investment-grade credit  rating supports our procurement of the significant energy volumes needed to serve our downstream customers.
